assessmentNote: While this is a potentially useful project, it is not as innovative as other proposals in this challenge and the effects are not as far-reaching. Those funds would be better spent on other projects within this challenge.

The proposal claims that Cardano projects essentially will look the same. If that was the case, then maybe instead of JavaScript, this should be a Haskell project. This proposal, if implemented in presented manner, would do nothing for the Cardano ecosystem.
The proposal is simple and aims to provide a transparent government-approved exchange service, This has minimal risks, so the proposers will be able to implement the proposal.
proposalTitle: Cashout and Buy ADA in Ethiopia

assessmentNote: It includes stages that the project will go through in order to materialize, as well as a division explaining how the funding would be used, in percentage, for what purpose. We are also told the expectation of how the project would be impacting the lives of local residents (according to the data provided, 50K people would be using water transport in 6 months). Therefore, I believe that the project is well planned, very detailed in relation to an action plan and expectations to be achieved.

There is no technical documentation or WP included in this proposal and the timeline included says the dApp won't go live for 12 months, this is uncompetitive. This is also not DeFi if you need to rely on government utility depts/billing agencies that is CeFi.

There is no way to verify the experience of the proposer beyond the "relevant experience", no GH links, no demo app/website. The roadmap is also for 12 months out for go-live, given the requested budget 1 year out is way too long to have a production dApp.

The only gaps I can see to this proposal are minor and relate to the information provided. This proposal would have benefitted from further explanation of some of the more technical aspects especially in light of voter levels of understanding. Its really the only aspect that I found lacking.

The proposal is for development of mobile wallet with low data use and in local africal language/ no text wallet. The progress can be audited by monitoring the developmental. Success can also be accurately measured by seeing the number of downloads.
It is likely for this proposal to be implemented because Qbo is an existing company and the Qbo team has extensive experience in AI and ML robotics.

The project identifies an application that has the potential to drive adoption to the Cardano ecosystem in a substantial way. The superiority of having time-tracking data secure on the blockchain is easy to explain and visualise by people who are not crypto experts, thus if implemented it has the potential to drive adoption from within business circles that otherwise might not be exposed to the crypto technology.
This project provided a roadmap that highlight the overall project which is good. I recommend developing a more detailed roadmap with key milestones.
I am skeptical. For a running project, they have only 4 followers. Also, they are only two people, trying to achieve (as they admit in the comment) the same thing as catalyst.

I understood the metrics, yet I would rather see to have the number of  "unique" participants, and demand growth over time, to participate in such meetings. 
Suggesting to the proposer.

The primary proposer is a serving U.S diplomat as per his Linkedin reference and is planning for a part-time commitment from other members for 3000 U.S Dollars. The follow-up and onboarding of proposers by a person employed full-time by another organization may not be ideal.
The race on contract is a real risk for DeFi, sometimes even reported as a hack by the media. This proposal addressed the problem with a framework to avoid it.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote: There is no detailed development plan or KPIs included in the presented info. MuKn is the team behind Glow, a DSL, Plutus and the eUTXO model of Cardano is a general purpose, Turing-complete language, these are very different domains.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote: The proposer fails to recognize Cardano is 1. purpose built using the eUTXO model and 2. design patterns already exist to mitigate the single UTXO spend per block issue which is the focal point of the entire proposal. Rebuilding Ethereum accounting on top of Cardano is a poor idea.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote: How does this bring proposers to Porject Catalyst. This seems like the proposer wants 30,000 to enable themselves to make 500,000 personal profit.

The proposal appears to plan to have a group of community members begin using an alternative network as a key part of bringing adoption to the product. However based on the insulting remarks made by the proposer in the comments, there is possibility that a community will not form around the proposal and it risks destroying the outlook of the proposal.

I have no doubt that that Dan and Chris collectively possess the drive and necessary skills to complete this proposal. I would advise that they do go down the collaborative route and bring outside developers in – to increase their network and provide new opportunities for others.

The team appears to have the necessary skillset to set the proposal in motion but I found it difficult to ascertain whether the budget meets the deliverables from the plan presented. I would have liked to see a smaller proposal with suitably adjusted budget that had already established certain aspects such as team building and verification of interest.

This is a duplicate proposal and should be withdrawn.

it is important that more details are described about the problem, because in order for us to measure the impact of a proposal it is necessary to understand the size of the problem. Why would blockchains help reduce insurance costs? What is the potential for cost savings? The plan is still a draft and has few details.

*The team submitted 2 identical proposals, so I am submitting the same rationale.

Good on the Liqwid team to recognize the complexity in their lending dApp means a security audit of contracts before deploying to mainnet is a must.

Liqwid/MLabs Haskell engineers are using the deliverables in the proposal (code review and audit) to refactor their smart contracts/design pattern based on advisory/code review sessions with Well-Typed.
The security audit is the final stage every Cardano DeFi protocol must complete before launching and the Liqwid team is engaging with two of the top Haskell development firms to complete this work.
Liqwid Labs/MLabs team are working with a highly experienced set of Haskell development firms to fulfill the outlined deliverables.
The developers have selected highly experienced engineers to exhaustively audit/review the code in the Liqwid smart contracts. The plan presented is sufficient.
The plan presented is clear and focused plus the team has already begun delivering on their 1st deliverable.
The proposal, plan presented and team behind this are well defined and experienced which makes this proposal highly likely to be implemented successfully.

Liqwid protocol is a set of interconnected Plutus smart contracts that must be audited and exhaustively tested before reaching mainnet. This proposal provides sufficient information on the team's plans to complete this.
Liqwid/MLabs team proposal has sufficient detail in the plan presented and are working alongside top Haskell firms to implement.
The presented plan to test/audit the first interest rate protocol on Cardano is in line with the DeFi focused challenge and the info provided is sufficient to audit the project progress.

The Liqwid/Mlabs team is on the way to delivering the first lending solution on Plutus mainnet and security audit is a crucial step in that path. The plan presented is well defined, the proposer experience is made clear and the info included is sufficient to audit the proposal's progress.

It would be good to have more information on why the proposer is qualified to produce these metrics reliably. What is the basis for the models, are the parametric or non-paramtric? Where does the data come from (oracle) for the metric calculation and how is this verified for quality.

assessmentNote: This is a nice idea. However by design, it is focused on end users. Developers need machine readable names. Thus not clear how it addresses the challenge.

The proposal mentions prior experience of raffles but does not back up these claims with any evidence. Without that information, it is hard to consider the proposal credible, consider adding evidence for these claims.
The requested funding is 10.000 but the proposal fails to deliver a budget, time table, milestones and a cost breakdown. Without these components it is very hard to judge if the funding request is within reason or not. Due to the lack of basic information, this proposal has be be rated a (1) in terms of feasibility for the moment.

assessmentNote: The roadmap and milestones isn't very clear. They haven't explained well enough how the peer review and incentives payment will work, or how they will implement it.
Effective management of DOAs is critical to improving distributed decision-making. This proposal aims to provide a repository of resources to assist DOA leaders in sharing best practices.
The addition of metadata powered oracle in Yoroi's backend can open up a wide range of applications for developers to build out.
The implementation of the proposed  change to Yoroi backend would be able to be clearly verified. The proposers provide a clear timeframe of when the community can expect the work to be done.

The proposal is clear and has a proper overview for the whole project lifecycle. It is beneficial to have as many language adaptations. The cost noted are clear, one time cost for translation and 1 year maintenance.
The only question arises, what happens after the yearly maintenance passes?
Might be worth of dedicating some cost for a longer time maintenance.

This proposal is listed under "Developer ecosystem" but it seems like it would be better suited to address the challenge in "Dapps and Integrations".  However, it would still be helpful to Slovak developers.

Apart from targeting a new language, in a neighbouring jurisdiction, this proposal is effectively an identical proposal to https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Localize-Yoroi-for-Czech-market/352236-48088 , which in this case is not a bad thing, as it will further expand the Cardano ecosystem by the same rationale as that one. The proposal is not strictly related to the experience of the developers but would improve the experience of all users in a given region. Thus it could increase the number of developers actively building on top of Cardano.
As identified in the proposal it could also help with regulatory procedures in Slovakia, by helping Yoroi comfort to EU norms. This could also lead to an improved developer ecosystem.
With the assurance that  Emurgo has outsourced the efforts, it is always preferable to have multilanguage support in the primary mobile Cardano wallet.

The problem and solution description is reasonable and objective. Yoroi's location is an important implementation, but that implementation is more in line with the Dapps & Integrations challenge, so I recommend submitting the proposal there.

I am submitting the same assessment for two proposals, as they are similar, the only change is the language to be translated.
Experience is clear, maybe additionally some details about translation and its review/verification flow would be useful. The targeted goals can be reached in the given time.

The proposer gives a clear budget for about 17,000 words including upkeep and provides a firm timeline for completing the localization. They mention that they deal with localizations for some other projects. Yoroi wallet is a product developed by Emurgo; they are not mentioned in the proposal besides being customers. Does Emurgo contract out for localizations? It is not clear how this relationship works.

Given that this is practically the same proposal as https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Localize-Yoroi-for-Czech-market/352236-48088 , but for a different region the same arguments stand. Given the experience of the team and the fact that it's a very straight forward task I see no real obstacle that would prevent this proposal from being successfully implemented. The budget is also extremely sensible and an explanation is provided for the amount requested.

This proposal has great potential to combine two cutting edge fields (human genomics and blockchain). The implementation part of it is lacking as the next review sections explain. However, it certainly meets the criteria of DApps & Integration if you can pull it off. I am personally deciding about what sort of genetic testing I should have before having children. One aspect I haven't fully considered is who will be utilizing that data and who can be trusted. I would love to see a world where health sciences can benefit and the patient can maintain control over their genetic data.

The idea is good. It solves security issues that arise with potential sharing of personal DNA sequences to third parties without consent. A good example that is found in the proposal is that there is an option to share but a portion of a sequence instead of the entire sequence. 
It gives users the possibility of choosing in which research their data will be used. 
There is also the ability to scale to a global level explained in the slides. Yet it is unclear if this is realisable in a timeframe of 6 months.
The proposal  outlines a very interesting use case for Cardano. The financial incentives for sharing genome data could easily onboard many users to the Cardano ecosystem.
Great idea that could effectively address the challenge. The proposer has identified a suitable problem and has started to propose a viable solution.

Selective sharing of own Genome sequence with the facility to earn money looks like a revolutionary proposal. This has potential to encourage people to get their genome sequences which can earn passive income at the same time provide vital data to the scientific community. This will be a great use case for the blockchain as whole.

Your personal experience (life-sciences and tech executive) is impressive, but the NFT/blockchain parts are lacking. Also, there is no breakdown of how the $50,000 will be allocated on this proposal. I do see the 1-3 month($35,000), 3-8 month($155,000), and 8-12 month($1,325,000) breakdowns on the 24 slide download. I believe this request should be for $35,000 to more closely align with your presentation, but it should also be broken down directly on the proposal. I do not believe the NFT route will apply to secure medical data, but do think there is a blockchain use case here.

The proposer originates from a medical tech background. Judging from the slides, the plan is clearly laid out in detail, yet misses some factors to correctly determine the feasibility of the project. 
It seems that the project is already partially finished. Is this the case? 
It's not entirely clear who would perform the work to develop this. 
There is previous collaboration mentioned with engineers. Will they do this task or is the proposer looking for people from within the community? If so, using the seek-tags can improve trust and clarity.

The author appears to have the skillset to manage a project but will require a team that have not been identified as part of the proposal. This makes it difficult to gauge the likelihood of a successful implementation. The plan is lacking any sort of timeline, examples or budget breakdown.
The proposer is CEO of GenomSys and the company has verifiable core competence in this industry. The company should be able to manage the proposal in a professional manner.

The technology described in the slide download is impressive "Our mobile technology , powered by ISO/IEC
23092 (MPEG-G), allows individuals to share
their genomic information in one quick
transaction". The entire slide presentation is well designed and packed with useful information on your tech and the billion dollar genomic data industry. It is lacking a clear link to the Cardano blockchain. Slide 23 "Because you now control your personal health data, you can share and be paid for that information, through our secure and private health data market exchange" has a pic of Cardano logo, but does not even mention how you plan to integrate.

As the proposer mentioned, the roadmap is not worked out in detail yet. 
The requested funding in the slides does not correspond with the amount asked in the proposal. The origin of this seems to be the long term vision of the proposer. To improve this I'd suggest to break down the funding requests in clearly defined portions with a goal set for each fund requested and add in detail where the funding would go to. (Why 50k USD? What portion of that amount goes where?)
There is a potential risk not defined: DNA needs to get sequenced by an external party. Which assurance is there that this data does not leak before getting converted to an NFT?

As stated earlier this is a great idea but severely lacking in detail for a proposal. The author would do well to refine the finer points of who will be required for the Dapp development, and budget to at least MVP level. At present we are being asking to provide significant funds and trust that it will come to fruition. I'm not saying the proposer could not do this but need further information to assure me he can. Recommend further collaboration with the community, revision of funds requested and reapplication.
The proposal has been presented in a precise manner with clear goals in each step. The proposal is an open book and is easily auditable.

This proposal is a great idea. I would change a bit the argumentation. e.g. WHY: We want to give the power back to the creators. HOW: we create a cardano ecosystem What: we create a font management app

This proposal's idea is very good. It proposes a project that can cause a positive incentive in font development and create a lot of practical use cases in a timeframe of just 3 months. 
While reading it my mind was screaming 'NFT' as a means to distribute the rights of using fonts associated with the project. Could be a nice idea for a spinoff project in the future.

Effective implementation would bring new users to the ecosystem. Collaboration with Gimbalabs would strengthen that project and enhance future development onboarding. It appears that font monetization models could result in large numbers of transactions. Data from the current centralized market (for example number of users or transaction volume), if available, could help convince voters that the proposal will have  significant impact. It is encouraging that a similar project is under development for Ethereum.
Appears to be a well thought out design and solid team to address the problem of control in font foundry

I believe that this application has merit that may not be obvious at first glance. The proposal effectively addresses the challenge although it is difficult to gauge to what degree it would add value to the community. The proposal drew no comments from the community and that does concern me but perhaps that is because of the specific topic being tackled. I would like to see the team find ways of promoting the importance of fonts to design.

In my view the Team looks strongs. I think it is a cleaver move to integrate a strong technical partner. Phase 2 is a open point for me: How to attract Customers. Not only you need typeartist, you need customers who buy the font.

The proposers have 15+ years of professional experience in the font development business and provide proof of this by means of linking their portfolio website. The project is deemed very feasible as it is backed by Gimbalabs, which provides assurance that this will actually get done. Given the potential use cases, there is a demand for something like this.

Team claims good experience (linkedIn profiles would be useful) and plan is relatively detailed. It would be good to see details on how they plan to monitor font usage and get that information reliably into a smart contract.
Team and budget makes sense. The plan is well thought out. There appears to be enough developer support for the idea here.

The team have excellent credentials from the perspective of understanding the dynamics of the  font industry sector. They appear to have set about preparing a team to produce the technical aspects of the Dapp. The plan seems achievable given everything fits into place and the budget is not extreme. I do query the risk management aspect of the plan as this was handled somewhat superficially.

The proposer provides a step-by-step plan for the implementation with milestones and a defined time horizon. But I would go more into detail in the timeline for Phase 1 an 2. e.g. milestone designfreeze, start of testing, go to market. There are also several metrics that measure the success of this project. I recommend to split the KPI user in typeartist and customers and to define a kind of break-even point.

All the necessary information is present. In particular, the roadmap and funding breakdown are very clear and realistically set. The metrics seem too modest to me because there are marketing plans and I can imagine popularity within the font development community if this is executed well.
How will font usage be monitored in perpetuity? Does this require Bots scraping the web and sending data back?
Details about the team and roadmap are appreciated. Not seeing any clear issues on why this would hit any roadblocks in its development.

The information provided is sound and gives enough insight and clues to the potential of the project. Hints of further development angles are noted but are better left for further funding applications once this project is underway. The proposers would do well to include some sort of hook for voters as the topic is somewhat unimaginative which I feel may hide the true value of this project.

The proposal provides crypto holders to crowd-fund ideas and startups, bringing better returns to their capital. This is likely to provide better utilization and circulation of crypto and also attract new innovators to crypto.

First off, I really like this project. I gave you five stars all the way through because you have been very thorough IF YOU FIND all the attached documents and look through them... My only real criticism is that I am afraid there are going to be people that miss some of your documentation because it wasn't linked directly in the main proposal. I did notice the bold type that tells everyone to look at the attached documents but I (and I have been looking at a lot of proposals) did not know you could add extra docs at the end WITHOUT THEM SHOWING UP in a more pronounced way under the additional documents. 

Other then that, I think your proposal does directly address the challenge. You covered almost all the angles (I did not see a section for challenges but I am going to give you a pass for that based on your overall proposal). 

There is going to be a crowdfunding Cardano App. I have seen many proposals for this but yours stands out as the best I have seen so far. Great Work!
The proposing group has a sufficiently strong team to implement the proposal. A good mix of capable people with sufficient experience is present in the team.

Again, It is hard to find the experience of your developers but hopefully everyone critiquing your proposal finds it. 

The only issue I have with your experience is that it's not easily proven - you have a web site but in order to see more of the functionality, you need to sign up and get access... I did not get access but I gave you 5 stars, again, based on your overall proposal and some of the screenshots I saw in your documentation. 

In the future, you really should make it easier to check the technical abilities of the team.

The progress is auditable. A clear plan in the business proposal and the financing model for a long term with 2.5 percent fees seem reasonable and achievable. The success of the proposal is measurable based on the number of proposals listed and the number of proposals getting the fund.

This was an easy 5 stars. You provided almost all (no challenges) of the information we are looking for. You get five stars from me because, although you are missing challenges, you went above and beyond on the rest of the information.

You did a great job with this proposal itself, and with the project in general. I hope you do well in the voting
Catalyst already works as a lunchpad so why wouldn't  the graduates apply directly on catalyst? So maybe creating guides on how to apply directly in Catalyst would be better to scale propperly.

There is merit in the challenge and also on the solution presented. Finding employment is always a very difficult aspect after graduation and with Cardano's focus on Africa, particularly in Ethiopia, this is proposal if a good match.

The proposal fails to explain its exact purpose. African university graduates are going to get help kickstarting businesses and are getting some cardano related courses, okay. This could build up to something with potential, but so far it lacks any definition and concreteness. You should have a detailed concept of what is going to happen with the money before applying for such an amount of funds.

Yes, this proposal addresses the challenge, and the community can benefit from the launch of this proposal. Still, at this current stage, this proposal needs a more developmental description and a straightforward plan.

Draft proposal. The problem and the solution are within the scope of the challenge, but there are no plans, metrics or goals to indicate the impact of the proposal on this challenge.

A practical plan is needed indicating how the proposal will address the challenge

I don't know what this is... you problem is that African graduates have a hard time finding employment. I don't understand how a launchpad that is going to kickstart ideas will necessarily help with the graduation problem... You need explain how this is going to happen. You have no information on how the launchpad is going to work...
Unfortunately there is almost no information about the proposer, his experience and no budget as well.
There is no plan presented. The proposer says nothing about his qualifications. I was not able to find out what kind of organisation secure foothold is.

There is a massive potential for Cardano in Africa, but this proposal needs further development in terms of feasibility. This proposal lack details on proposer experience, team skills, and sensible details plan and budget implementation. I recommend reviewing your proposal by adding more detail on your experience, team skills, and how you plan to make this project a success.

Draft proposal. There is no plan, so there is no way to understand the relevance of the proposer's experience.

Anyway, I recommend that the proposal be detailed, as well as the profile of the proposer, citing experiences and qualifications that indicate the aptitude to execute the proposal successfully.

I don't understand how your experience, "I have experience of the African system and the difficulties faced by graduates who want to start a business in Africa" is going to enable you to build a business (or work?) launchpad. It's one thing to understand the problem but that doesn't mean you are able to fix it. You need expand on exactly how you are going to fix it and what QUALIFICATIONS you have to make this work...
This proposal is really short. It would help if we have more informations like a roadmap, a clear budget and maybe some introduction of the team behind the proposal.

There is not enough information in this proposal to consider. A challenge was stated, a solution was mentioned, however, the more difficult aspects of accomplishing the establishment of the launchpad Is severely lacking. This makes the requested $40000 very hard to tabulate in terms of project viability.

This proposal currently lacks milestones and KPI's.
Please develop a detailed roadmap of how you plan on implementing this project. Describe how you will manage the risk associated with your project. This proposal has potential if you add a lot of details to it.
Draft proposal. There are no metrics to audit the proposal. I recommend that the proposer follow the Catalyst documentation to prepare the proposal.

There is almost no information in this proposal except for a stated problem and a solution that does not completely address the problem as stated in the proposal. 

This proposal was also last updated almost a month ago... there should have been plenty of time to expand on how this solution was going to fix the problem but nothing has been done or expanded on. 

I suggest the author of this proposal re-think this idea and re-submit for the next available fund.

Reaching out to people in their native languages is a solid cause in the long term. Doing this by informing them about what the cardano blockchain has to offer will certainly create an opportunity for community influx with new insights and new ideas on Project Catalyst.

In my opinion it is good to adress people in their own language. The proposed topics will be usefull. I agree that the cryptoworld is Englisch minded. This might help people who probely already heard about crypto and blockchain from fellow countymen and got interested to pick it up and form an opinion based on what the hear in their own language.

The project aims to increase native language content for non English speaking Africans by funding language ambassadors.  I think native language content may become more important if Cardano can connect the unconnected bringing online media to new communities.  For this reason, I think the proposal addresses the challenge well.
This proposal addresses the need for accessibility to the crypto world for africans in their native languages. this increases the reach and depth of trust when individuals first learn about crypto.

It is likely for this proposal to be implemented because it includes a simple and straightforward strategy. This proposal is highly feasible. Plus, the proposer has experience speaking multiple languages, which is a plus to navigate and connect with various people from different parts of Africa and find ambassadors who will present the news in African native languages. The only question that I have is in which country or city will this project take place?
I'm missing the experience on making broadcasts. It would be nice if this was mentioned or if there isn't enough experience a way how to assure that it will be managed.
The experience and KPM driven plan show that the vision is extremely clear. proper planning prevents piss poor performance. the 6 P's of project management.

I believe that this proposal provides enough evidence that proves that they are able to implement the proposal in a realistic timeframe. The budget was explained well however, explaining the method in the way funds would get collected if a langambassador defaults on their loan would make it easier to understand the "safety" or rather backup plan in the case of default of this method

The proposal is very well planned: we have a list of subjects that are addressed in the translations, dates when the stages of the project will take place, details regarding the use of the money requested and an expectation in relation to the objectives to be achieved. Therefore, I believe that there are no gaps in relation to the information on the progress, planning and future execution of the project, everything being perfectly defined.

I like the idea and the first setup of topics. It might be usefull if there would haven been some information about the number of languages involved and the way to pick/choose the languages. As stated in reaction there are a lot languages.

The proposal has the potential to provide a source of revenge to photographers and videographers in general. Not only for drone imagery. The issue being addresses have a good market with a global reach and had potential to be catalysis in monitising other NFTs.

This proposal leverages the metadata-recording functionality of the Cardano blockchain, with a novel and niche set of data. Drone imagery, uses and business mechanics is not familiar to anyone but the proposer has presented a valid use case that could help expand Cardano reach in an unexpected industry. That said, the immutability of the metadata in Cardano could only be reliably trusted if there is a secure way of ensuring the cloud-stored (off-chain) file it's purportedly matched with, is itself immutable. The solution does not seem to address the fact that the data outside of Cardano would still be open to manipulation.

The proposal addresses the Fund 5 Metadata challenge very well. The problem is identified and described subjectively. The solution is well-identified but needs more description on scalability and how it will benefit the Cardano Community. Suggestion: This project can utilize the power of the Cardano Blockchain and can also integrate ADA pay for payment between buyer and seller of the drone imagery on the Paypixl marketplace

This is an interesting use case of metadata that fits well the challenge, namely as a way to prove of time/date of images and their authenticity. This would make the company stand-out by offering a unique authentication solutions to customers and a good use case-study of Cardano.

The proposal directly addresses the challenge's use case of proving that a specific document existed at a particular time. The approach blends the use of a centralized database for efficiency with the immutability of UTxO metadata. However, the approach only assures that the imagery, documents, and metadata weren't altered after their were registered on the blockchain: i.e., it doesn't prevent alteration of the drone data or metadata prior to ingestion in the paypixl system. (Such would only be possible if drone hardware components "signed" the imagery and metadata.)
Proposer already working on the marketplace and has experience in both the aerial photography and blockchain spaces

The proposal claims to be backed by Raven Spatial which has products involving Drone imagery. Details of the people in Raven is available on the internet. The credentials of the people can be established and are likely to be capable of implementing the proposal in right earnest.

The attached document lists all the technical elements that would make this model work. However, it lacks  details in terms of resources, timelines and costing to provide more confidence of how the project's life will proceed. The experience of the proposer is clear with the provision of the currently live paypixl site, but the type of work and how it will be approached is not included. This proposal will benefit greatly if an itemised dev path is presented.

There is a vast potential to grow metadata transactions by creating drone imagery and a service marketplace. This proposal has enormous potential but needs details on the team. Who will implement this proposal and the team's relevant experience? How do you plan to market this project once completed? How long will it take to build? Think of How do you plan to overcome the challenges of making this metadata application? Will you be working on it by yourself, or do you have a team? You can break down the final product into deliverable steps and include it in a roadmap.

At the very least a summary of the plan should have been presented here, having to open a scroll trough an attachment will likely deter some voters. Attachments should only be used as a supplement. Saying that the document explain well the  "why" and "how" paypixl intends to integrate Cardano into its service. It's difficult to determine what is the role of each of the proposers and what is their experience, specially in the area of Blockchain development. Just adding CV detailing past experience and what masters course the proposer is enrolled in would add to the proposal. The plan lacks a few details such as a budget breakdown, and a implementation timeline, that voters would expect to see.

The proposal team has demonstrated experience with both imagery and blockchain, and the proposal evidences detailed understanding of Cardano components. However, the proposal does not outline an actual plan (aside from justifying technology and design choices) and does not include a timeline roadmap: rather, it presents static design diagrams, lists of requirements, and the components of the software stack. Not presenting a viable, staged, sequence of activities and discussing risks makes it difficult to have full confidence in successful execution.

One question I have is regarding when the photography is getting linked to the blockchain. Ideally it would be directly from the drone with GPS location and date/time stamps. Thi sseem unlikely as I doubt the drone would be directly connected to the blockchain. If the images are only linked to the blockchain once downloaded from the drone, this allows for tampering with the location and timestamp data. Does the proposer have a solution for this?
The proposal is simple and aims to implement a straightforward application of metadata/NFT. It has sufficient details is included less a roadmap and deliverable timeframe.

The listing of the products that will interact with Cardano in order for the business model to work is clearly defined, however, timelines and targets for each product; SDK + API + CLI, etc is not provided and would make it a little difficult for this project to audit. It would be nice to see the timelines associated with the development of each item in order to enable validation of the requested funds and ensure traceability of the project going forward.

The proposal doesn't include any roadmap, milestones, or KPI's. Please make sure to include a roadmap and Key Performance Metrics. This way, the community will know what to expect out of the delivery of the project. Think of describing the major steps to complete this project fully. What is the project plan of this proposal? and include KPI's (Describe and factor in How many by when formula)

Given that there are no milestones, road-map or KPI's  presented it will be difficult, if not impossible for the community to audit the progress and success of the proposal. These are the main lacking features of this proposal

Because the proposal does not include a staged or time-based plan with intermediate milestones or deliverables, it would be difficult to measure progress beyond simply cataloging which parts of the proposal's block diagrams were nominally complete. Final success would be measurable against the requirements stated in the proposal. This might result in a situation were the proposal could only be semi-quantitatively audited near its final stage, and not in early stages.

Give credit where credit is due. As a CA I can't see the future of proposals in terms of implementation (I can just give my opinion based on presented information), but I know when I see a well prepared proposal. To be clear I mean a proposal that meets the requirements of the challenge and which has a clear pathway to attract new users to the platform. Furthermore, this proposal is heavily leveraging the advantages  of the Cardano ecosystem by proposing the usage of key Cardano advantages - easy NFT minting,  fractional ownership token minting contract (with Alonzo), a new decentralized protocol built on Cardano (Mosaic), etc.. I can see a new problem (full ownership of NFTs) that was identified and a clear and well-presented solution (fractional NFTs). Implementation of the solution - if successful - would attract new users to the platform, both investors and artists and ... fractional owners.
The proposal has been well thought through and addresses the challenge accordingly. I like that you are taking a novel approach to NFT ownership in a manner designed to make them accessible.
Its a very interesting Dapp application. I could see the concept of fractional NFTs becoming very popular. Cardano would benefit from this project.

The proposal is aiming to build a NFT minting site with a unique decentralized organization. The will be multiple tokens for representing NFTs and these tokens can be traded to discover the true price of NFT. This is currently possible with primary token ADA as the means of trading.  However, there is a requirement for these kind of alternate experiments to arrive at a successful model in NFTs.

The team has posted links verifying their collective experience in devops, as well as blockchain developer experience, although I wasn't able to find the Plutus Pioneer Program & Haskell experience listed (maybe I missed it). Although the proposers list their Tide stakepool, the stakepool has apparently never minted a block and has no active delegators as of early May and a 0ADA pool pledge.
The proosal has a clear timetable and deliverables with a detailed short-term, mid-term and longer-term plan. What is to be financed is clearly laid out. The proposal does provide a reasonable and well-thought out plan for implementation that shows how implementation will incrementally expand to include more features and possibilities, key for long-term success.

As the requested funding is relatively small, it is easy to correlate the entire sum to the sum of the proposed stages and development, so a more detailed breakdown for a funding proposal this small is not necessary (unlike for proposals that are requiring greater funding amounts).
Reasonably detailed plan. Proposer claims relevant experience. LinkedIn profile to back up would be useful.

The team appear to have the necessary skillset to get up and running and indeed this staged approach is clearly articulated. I do note that success is described by the team as being dependent on licencing. This is a concern although I would think other options may present themselves if current application is not granted.

The developers claim highly relevant experience and participation in Plutus pioneers. This means they are qualified and will have access to the testnet very soon.  The proposal is well organized with a detailed roadmap which will result in an efficient use of funds.  Even if the proposers run out of funds, value will have been extracted every step of the way.
The proposing team has presented sufficient verifiable credentials to show that they have the required qualifications to implement the proposal successfully.

I think that the provided information will allow a relatively straightforward possibility for assessing the progress and the success of the proposal. The proposers listed deliverables and metrics with deadlines, while also giving a good presentation of the issue that they intend to solve, how it relates to the challenge and how their proposed solution would work.

Very good information provided throughout that suggests the team is fully engaged in the proposal and not simply relying on PC funding. I would love to see further examples of NFT's that potentially be up for sale ( even if they did not eventuate) The example used on the website was a fine example but does not hurt to give more.

The authors hope to have a working product with minimal functionally at the end of a four week period.  I expect if they are successful they will seek addition funding through catalyst to extend the project. This is not a particularly easy project to audit, but being that the amount requested is small, the team are enthusiastic Plutus learners, and the project goals are well defined, I think this project would add value to the Cardano NFT space.
The proposal has a workable plan. There are clear phases to audit the progress. Sufficient information regarding methodology also has been enclosed.

This proposal is well within this challenge and it addresses popular and interesting topics within the crypto space as of today. Taking advantage of the current NFT and creative craze is a good way to bring in new users and contributors to the Cardano space. This proposal is well written and though out and addresses the challenge effectively. In terms of impact I give this proposal a (4). I would like the proposal to expand on how designers can use your tool in the future, the ease of use, and how you would market the tools you build. What is your plan to make the designer community well aware of your tools?
Bring in creatives to the ecosystem is a worthy goal. However how do they then sell these items? Does this need a marketplace?
The proposal seems well-reflected and has the potential to onboard a lot of value from artists and cater to art lovers on the Cardano network. It will provide a really usefull addition.

The proposal is providing a custom solution for minting NFTs for CAD designs and their incremental improvement in which the owner of the original design and the downstream contributor gets benefited. This a requirement that has the potential to bring a large number of designers to monetize their work.
Opening up more properties for use as NFTs and making it easier for creatives to use Cradano is a promising approach. The implementation with smart contracts seems to be a suitable approach.

The project intends to provide an NFT toolset for creatives. The tools in mind provide more evolved and nuanced NFT business models than what are widely utilized today. If the project is successfully implemented, I could see it drawing creatives into the Cardano ecosystem, and increasing the amount of NFT related transactions on the platform.

Onboarding artists and creatives early on to the Cardano blockchain could in time drive user-adoption to the ecosystem through the network effect that could be created. Exposure to the Cardano ecosystem and new users would come from the artist/creatives themselves, but more importantly from their fans and supporters that would be interested in interacting through their works. The volume of ADA involved in transaction could also greatly increase as the last few months have shown us that there's a strong appetite for NFTs.

The proposal provides a project plan with explanatory milestones and achievements. It also includes a budget that was revised from the comments and updated in order to make this proposal realistic to implement within the timeframe. Key metrics that strongly relates to the campaign are considered for the proposals success. The metrics are easily measured and evaluated in the future. All-in-all, this proposal gives off a very serious and solid impression. I think this proposal have a good chance of being implemented successfully if it were to be funded. I rate this proposal a (4) in terms of feasibility.

More details on how creatives will monetise their creations needs to be included. Without a market place why will individual buys get involved in these NFT's? Evidence to back up the experience of the proposers (linkedIn profile) would be useful.

The proposers are experienced in the relevant topics, so it seems. The github repository however is still empty, so a proof that they are up to cope with the work still is to be provided. The labor costs maybe are a bit high. assuming that three people work on the project and each of them works the days mentioned, that's a pay of 2500USD per person per month. Working on funds that also partially go into very charitable projects I'd maybe suggest you lower payment expectations a bit in order to enable more funds beeing spent on other items.

The proposers have claimed experiance as developers and pool operators. They will also be hiring developers for the development. The Git hub repository is almost blank and is not proving the capability of the team.

The level of detail of the proposal and the experience presented are convincing. The feedback to questions in the comments section also leaves no doubt about the professional suitability of the proposer.

The proposal lists two members with relevant expertise, but little verification is provided.  They do not list anyone with smart contract skills or propose how they will  achieve this important aspect of their development. On the positive side, the proposal is broken into many waypoints with clear goals, which should aid in the execution of the project.

The linked GitHub repository consists only of the proposed open-source license for now and no other reference material is provided to verify the credentials and experience of the team. The plan, metrics and budget are all well thought out but the chances of success for the project are very much in the hands of the developers and not enough information about their previous work is provided, particularly when it comes to artist management and curation. It's one thing to build the technical infrastructure but it's quite something else to onboard quality artists/creatives to it.

This proposal is loud and clear in terms of auditability when it comes to the roadmap and the time plan. It is easy to follow and understand your plan. You provide good key metrics that are easily compared. I believe this project would be implemented successfully if it were funded. My biggest concern about the proposal is how you will reach out to the creative community once you've built the tools. Great tools tend to spread by word-of-mouth but including a section about some kind of marketing plan or campaign would be a good addition to show that you have considered that subject.

A plan on what the creatives do with the minted NFTs. would be useful. THe plan seems to interchangably use smart contracts and NFT's. But what smart contracts? More detail on what the creatives would actually be making on the Cardano side.
A detailed schedule and success metrics were provided, this is exactly how you are supposed to plan a project. The plan overall has a quite professional appeal and presents an auditable project
The project has been clearly laid out with deliverables and measurable metrics. Detailed analysis is visible in the proposal. The progress is clearly measurable.

There are no metrics for measuring goal achievement. The metrics listed have no target value and no point in time at which this value must be achieved. There is a rough breakdown of costs, which should allow a small degree of auditing. The work packages listed are probably the most suitable for measuring the progress of the project.

The allocation of funds is broken down into a few categories but the largest, for actual development, is not further broken down.  The metrics of success provided rely on completion of the total project, which is supposed to take 10 months.  The attached google doc, however, does have "criteria for success" at each stage which should help with auditing the success of the program.

An overview breakdown of the budget is present, however I would suggest a more detailed explanation and a further breakdown to facilitate project auditability. As it stands almost the entirety of the budget is allocated to a single line, without further explanation given. There also seems to be an arithmetic error in the calculation of the total budget requested, as the sum of the broken down parts is 53000, yet 51000 is the requested sum. That represent less than 5% of the overall budget, so it shouldn't be a major issue.

good idea, through education and project advertisements, to increase the number of proposers. Definitely can work, but it feels like education is a primary goal, and increase the proposer's outreach is just a side effect, that is why I put 4.

Also:

"- Create informational content, exploring how Cardano can make the world more sustainable or help work towards completing current (SDGs).
- Create a network exploring and promoting current projects running on Cardano, that will help make strides towards a sustainable world.
- Encourage other members from outside the community to come in and implement their sustainable projects on or working with Cardano's blockchain technology."

it is only third goal of this project.

The proposal lists noble goals in the aims like " the focus of tracking and eliminating counterfeit goods in the retail system; help solve healthcare issues with fake medicine and a financial loss. These are just a few examples of direct changes Cardano is making." However, the role of the Cardano ecosystem in achieving these is not clear. Why there goals are selected to attract proposers to Catalyst is also not clear.

The proposal aims at promoting how Cardano could be used to develop sustainable systems, which is undoubtedly an central topic in our current time, and which can have a big impact on convincing people to use Cardano and/or make proposals.

The project has a lot of potential, because it seeks to tune into two areas that are very important and urgent for today's world. The economy is changing, and blockchain is a new way of doing it. Just as sustainability has always been, and now more than ever, an urgent agenda to be addressed. If the link between Cardano and Sustainability was formed, I believe it will be beneficial for everyone, and at the same time it can attract new entrepreneurs and members to our community (thus being in accordance with the objectives of this challenge) and benefiting the planet. I, in particular, do not have much theoretical basis on how Cardano can benefit sustainable projects, that is, it would be interesting to have this subject more studied and clarified for me too, as well as, I imagine, for many people.

hard to tell, whether he can pull it off, but the site works, and the budget is high enough to secure other people or tools to achieve the goal.

Still skeptical. 

Also, what is the final product? A website? If that is so, I believe he can pull it off.
To succeed it requires a plan for delivery of the materials to educators. It is not clear what this plan is or whether the proposer has the experience and connection to deliver on it.

The proposer is a university student. The goal set in the proposal is noble however connection to the requirement of "proposer outreach" is not clearly explained, leaving with the doubt regarding the capability to implement the project sucessfully.

The experience is relevant and on point, but the plan is a bit vague in some places, so it's not super easy to judge it. The proposal itself seems to have big goals, and the budget is not small, but the lack of a timeline and of work experience instills a little doubt whether all of this will actually be realized.

The author shows himself to be a well-qualified person to launch the project, since he has an academic background in Economics, and a specialization in sustainability. In this way, your theoretical knowledge is fully aligned with the project. It is also beneficial that there is a video attached to the proposal, where he introduces himself and talks about the project, the vision, the platform and so on. With that we can get to know him more particularly, and seeing him describing the idea generates a lot of confidence and credibility for the project. Besides the author, other people participated in the video, however, they do not talk about themselves, which would be interesting too, because apparently they are the rest of the people who compose and the team.
For this project to be feasible it needs to be successful in outreach. How this is going to be achieved should be detailed.
The proposal has a well-made presentation and a website. However, no clear plan emerges from the proposal which could be analyzed to evaluate the proposal.

The plan is quite detailed and the budget is partitioned. However, it lacks a timeline and success metrics are not defined, so judging its success, especially given the big goals, might not be an easy task

We have a very detailed division of how financial money would be used, which professionals would be hired, etc. We can also find out what actions would involve the project, in the Sustainable ADA Network part, in which it is explained which components would compose the future platform (which is a website, according to the attached video). In my view, there was only a lack of weather forecast in relation to the project, we could have an expectation of steps to be made according to the months, for example. I believe that only that part was absent, because otherwise everything is well explained, both in the text and in the attached video.

Seems a valid idea and may certainly contribute to developer ecosystem. I'm not convinced about the value for what they are saying they want to do. There are resources located within the PC community that already act as pathways for budding developers and this proposal appears to simply redirect those resources.

The proposed accelerator program addresses a challenge that could result in enriching and expanding the Cardano ecosystem as a whole. The initiative has merit, but I fail to see how it directly relates to the developer ecosystem challenge. It could be that some of the projects selected in the accelerator would address this challenge, but no direct mention of this is made in the proposal.

The description of the problem and solution makes sense, is reasonable and the proposal is aligned with the concept of this challenge in different ways through support structures, incentive models and the videos produced can be used as a knowledge base and reference for new teams / developers interested in use Lean Startup Principles to launch their ideas on Cardano.

In addition, the development of the MVPs would be recorded lessons available on our YouTube Channel to help others learn how to build on Cardano.

I recommend the inclusion of more objective metrics, deliverables and KPIs, as the only metric included is subjective for impact assessment. (6 Minimal Viable Products (MVPs) for the Idea Teams to use in their go-to-market strategy.)

The idea is interesting in the sense of supporting teams to develop their projects, as I understand it, according to the Lean Startup Principles. However, it doesn't come to me that the action is focused directly on the developers, which is the focus of this objective. Perhaps this proposal would be better suited to the challenge of reaching the proponent, because it is something that can attract and guide more diverse teams with their ideas. A website that talks more about the ADA Makerspace has been attached, and a 1-hour video on the space and some of its objectives is made available on the home page, which I consider to be a very excessive time to present the subject. This video would be suitable for people who are already interested in participating in the project, but it would be more interesting a short video that can introduce the subject in a cheaper and simpler way.

I believe the team certainly have the necessary experience but am not convinced that they are offering anything that could not already be sourced via CP platforms. The plan asks for significant funds which it states will be used to pay developers to produce MVP. I feel this aspect requires further attention to flesh the details.

The experience of the team and their involvement and commitment to the Catalyst project gives me confidence that accelerator program would be implemented successfully. The budget is concise and the fact that the proposers are not looking to this proposal as a means to compensate themselves should be noted. The eventual success of the projects participating in the accelerator program cannot be guaranteed, but at this point in the life of Project Catalyst I feel it's a risk well worth taking.

The team already actively participates in the Cardano community, with Boone being one of the first members of Catalyst (since Fund1). The team has already been financing for the first version of the ADA Makerspace (Fund3) and has demonstrated its capacity for the good performance presented.

I recommend including more information about the team (their jobs and qualifications / Linkedin) for the sake of transparency and easy access to the community.

There is a reasonable plan. There is information on the budget distribution and a reasonable timeline (16 weeks).

Unlike most proposals, here we already see the formation of a team, not a single person who has the idea and desire to execute it. It is said that the team in question has experience with incubators and are masters of Lean Startup Principles. However, it would be interesting to exemplify a little better about this experience and identify who the team members are. On the attached website we can see that the idea of the project is already under development, as in the video available on the home page, which is always positive, but I did not find any tab talking about the members of the team itself.

I feel that the proposal is a reasonable initiative but have concerns with the amount of information regarding budget and governance. It seems to ignore current resources freely available (albeit not entirely easy for anyone to access). This for me would be a reasonable point of difference and I would be more comfortable with this proposal being scaled back and being submitted to the onboarding challenge.

In a way this is an open ended proposal, the deliverables described in the proposal itself would be easy to audit, but the actual impact of the proposal itself on the Cardano ecosystem is dependant on the success or failure of the project selected to be a part of the accelerator program.

There is a 16-week timeline, but there are no milestones or KPIs. A single metric has been defined (6 Minimal Viable Products (MVPs) for the Idea Teams to use in their go-to-market strategy.) And it is subjective as it doesn't allow to audit the quality of what is being developed.

The team will provide videos of the cohorts and the development of the MVPs, which is an important element for auditability.

I recommend including more details about the team.

Pelo o que eu entendi, a execução do projeto se daria por meio de vídeos no youtube, mas fora isso não é dita mais nenhuma informação sobre como essa "consultoria" de fato seria feita. Temos também o tempo total de acompanhamento e uma divisão de $6000 por equipe, mas como esse dinheiro seria usado, exatamente? Acho que faltou detalhamento de uma maneira geral, tanto em questão da execução do projeto, inclusão de datas, quanto na parte de explicar como o financiamento de cada equipe seria feito. Uma sugestão que eu tenho, além de incluir esse detalhes, seria de investir em uma ou duas equipes primeiramente, medir e analisar os resultados para então dar continuidade ao projeto, pois me parece uma quantia muito alta para ser a inicial.

Great concept and really like the use case of this potential Dapp. Possible some issues may occur with the name RedToken - Redddit users? The concept will effectively address the challenge guidelines.

This proposal is very interesting and suits this campaigns brief and goals, as well as the "Grow Africa, Grow Cardano" campaign. In this regard, I think this proposal is very relevant for the Catalyst project overall. This proposal presents a quality dApp which have the potential to increase the utility and adoption of Cardano substantially if implemented well. The proposal ends with plans of scaling the platform into nearby related areas. This should not be too big of a challenge once it's implemented initially. In terms of impact, I agree that this proposal is strong. My vote will be a (5-), which will be rounded up to a 5.

Blood shortage is a big problem in the world today. A DApp that allows users to track their blood donations and inform what is being done with it provides with both a foundation of trust and a sense of wellbeing for doing something good like, for example, saving the life of someone who's had a motor accident. This alone is already a huge incentive out of a humanitarian perspective. Tokenising it for light utility bills just adds to the value and by doing this without pure cash payouts would avoid 'overfarming' of donors for financial benefit.
This is a great concept, with well-thought through use cases, impact analysis and incentive planning.  Clear vision for the application will lend itself well to development of a phased adoption plan.
The proposal team appears to have good diversity that should complement the project. It appears you will need to source further Dapp developers and this I could not establish from the plan.

The proposal presents a plethora of great areas of experience but there is nothing backing up these claims. To gain the trust of the community you should try to back up these claim, otherwise it is very easy to question the feasibility of this project. 
You ask for 35.000 dollars worth of funding which is 14% of this campaigns funds, yet there is not a single section that outlines the projects budget. I would like to have an elaborated and detailed budget in the proposal, this would give me confidence to support this proposal as a voter in the future. This proposal also lacks a timetable with milestones, as of now, it is hard to understand the scope of the project since no course of action is provided. 
How do you go about to make RedToken a utility token that can be used locally? Do you have any prior contacts or agreements to make this a reality or is this a problem that needs to be solved?
This proposal needs to be revisited with the above mentioned points in mind, for now, I will rate this proposal a (2) in terms of feasibility.

The team are planning to collaborate with established entities like WADA, ABCD, Gimbalabs and others, which creates confidence in their competence. Offering the possibility to expand services to other kinds of medical donations and insurance shows that there is still a future worth to explore for this project. However, I was unable to tell how it would be financed in the future. Where does the money come from to pay for the light utility bills?

More information on the legal status of paying for blood and the dynamics or who is actually paying for the blood etc. Are they planning to collect blood, or just work with existing blood collection centers? Do they have connections here? Proof of relevant experience would be good (Linkedin profile etc)
There is no information about how the funding will be allocated and what resources are needed for development.

The concept is sound and I like the direction of the proposal submitted but felt further work required on detailing your budget and how you would allocate it. Further detail also on timelines would have greatly enhanced this proposal.

This proposal introduces the RedToken-token which makes it easy to track the use and growth of the particular token. How will you use this data in the future to assess this project? 
The proposal discusses future plans about integrating closely related services to the RedToken but provides no roadmap or timetable. This makes it hard to know when the main part of this project is considered implemented. Would this future integration require more funding? Why(/why not)? As mentioned above, this proposal is inadequate which affects the auditability directly. I will rate it a (2) but I am comfortable giving it a 4 or 5 in the future if the mentioned points are addressed.

The proposal consists out of a lot of information, complemented by the slides to audit this quite easily. The DApp looks aesthetic and is simple by design, which would make it easy to use. Unfortunately there is no funding breakdown to explain the asked funding amount. A risk assessment would also be a nice addition to assure that everything has been thought of in terms of security and privacy of both the user and recipient.
There are numerous issues involved with physically collecting blood. How is this being handled? Risks to donors and to receivers. Who is responsible for this?

This is a well-thought through vision, but would benefit from a set of clear, measurable implementation milestones reflecting the phased development and adoption of the solution.  Currently there is no timeframe or approach to this described.

The proposal is an excellent concept that is likely to grow with further adoption of NFT's as an avenue for performers/artists to commodify their talents. A good deal of work evident but lacks supporting documents.

I found this idea very interesting, different from the approach of most of the proposals I saw here. In general, many proposals seek to improve situations and practices that already exist, inside and outside the Cardano community, but this search brings to the context of the community something that is not usually included. The less traditional art forms to be associated with tokens and NFT, such as music presentations, from what I understand. Therefore, I believe that this project can bring a differential to the community, add value and even attract new members, producers of this content.

It took me two reads - from end to end - to get a full grasp of the idea and the proposal's depth. I like idea it seems both simple and complex at the same time and it does seem novel. The proposed DubToken & digital marketplace that re linked to livestream content - effectively expands the NFT paradigma to include many more types of artists - or even wider - broadcasters in fact. The integration with YouTube and Twitch offers many possibilities.  It might have been good to envisage a partnership even with famous non-artist Youtubers from the Cardano ecosystem that would help to popularize the concept - but that doesn't detract from the value of the idea. If successfully realized, this proposal would generate value for the Cardano ecosystem, while it also carves out a unique and underserved space for NFTs.

Reserving a part of the requested funds for the proposal for artists is an unfortunate move. It weakens the proposal. Funding artists are  not a good fit for Dapps & Integration challenge. The idea itself is interesting and worth exploring. The scope of the proposal is quite big. I would be easier to evaluate smaller proposals for the stated solutions (3). apart from the concerns expressed, the implementation of a distributed and fair compensation for live streams is a suitable proposal for the Challenge.

This is one of many proposals for NFT integration with the music industry.  Successful implementation of such a system would certainly have a beneficial effect on the Cardano ecosystem in terms of transactions and adoption. However, the competition will be fierce and many projects will ultimately fail due to a lack of technical expertise, industry connections, and/or network effect.

The proposal aims to monetize streaming media using the DubToken media service relay. This offers a methodology for establishing ownership of the streams.  The use of centralized servers is unavoidable in the present-day streaming solutions however the proposal adds one more relay, which might degrade the lag and jitter performance.

The audience for live streaming has grown substantially in the past years, so has the number of creatives and content creators involved. The Cardano ecosystem would probably benefit greatly from capturing and driving adoption of the blockchain in that audience. The idea is promising, however I would suggest refining the points I mention in my assessments bellow and resubmitting the proposal in a future fund.
It would be good to have more information to back-up the proposers claim to experience and connections (linkedin profiles)

The plan appears well researched but does not provide any further evidence to help build the proposal. No links to supporting interfaces or even mock ups of portal. This makes it difficult to accurately assess whether implementation would follow. Experience too is somewhat barebones although the use of tech jargon (and the idea itself) suggests skills are likely evident. I would encourage further engagement with PC community to formalise such aspects.

Unfortunately, in this part, I found the explanation of the proposal to be very superficial. The author claims to have many years of experience with software development, and also that I work for notable companies like Amazon and Apple. However, it would be interesting to demonstrate the example of some of his works. In addition, it would be beneficial to better share who the project team members would be. In fact, it is not very clear whether the author intends to develop the system alone or in a group. But in any case, I always think it is essential to include a graphic designer to build an intuitive and ergonomic platform.

This proposal is written in a way that demonstrates technical knowledgeability and it is a shame that the proposer hasn't included other specific and publicly available evidence of relevant skills and experience needed to implement the proposal. 
The proposal states that the lead has "21yrs of building functional, distributed software" at Amazon, Apple, while partners are leaders in music and content design. It seems as if it would have been easy to validate this experience by providing flesh on the bones, alas the proposer has not done so. As it stands, this experience needs to be taken at face value, which is a minus for me.
25000 of funding is portioned to support 4 artists during alpha phase, however there is scarce detail about the selection of these artists - I would argue that this is an equally important element for a contract-driven livestream NFT - as demand and success will also be linked to the profile /desirability of the included artists. I do not see a rationale has been provided for allocating USD25,000 of funding to the 4 selected artists - instead of USD2,500 to 10 artists or USD50,000 to two artists (for example). 
The specific use of the requested USD 80000 is also not provided in detail, but for a project of this scope - a breakdown of the budget and costs is needed in my view. 
I would have liked to see more word about the challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation of this specific project - not just latency, but also from the point of view of users and artists. The end users are likely to be non-technical (users and artists alike) and their user experience could be a make-or-break element.
A general timetable is provided, which is a plus, as is the level of technical detail and thought that has been provided.

There are multiple aspects mentioned that need to be addressed to provide the proposed solution. This will be a very complex challenge with aspects that are outside of conventional development for blockchain applications. For example the real-time aspect. The complexity and only very basic information about the relevant experience cause mit to go with neutral.

The proposer touts functional development work at Amazon and Apple and has partnered with musicians. Unfortunately no links are provided to verify the qualifications. No mention is made of smart contract experience or connections to the music industry.  While the proposal does detail specific stages and goals, there is little discussion of how these would be achieved on a technical level. 4 musicians also seems a small number to bootstrap such a project to a state of relevance.

Proposer claims 21 years of experience in distributed software building in Amazon, and partners have experience in the music industry.  However, references to past work and verifiable credentials are not enclosed in the proposal.

The proposed project seems a lot more complex than many, so a lot more details could have been provided to allow for a better assessment of its chances of success. The description of the proposers experience is very promising, but no credentials or links to previous works are given to allow the community to verify and better judge for themselves. The items on the roadmap lack a justification of given times and without one, some of them seem unfeasible, for instance why would "backend prototype & load testing" only take 2-3 weeks. A clear description of the team that would work on the project is not given, would it be just the proposers?
Without proof the proposers have connections in the music industry it is hard to asses the feasibility of this proposal.

Again, whilst I think this idea is a really useful potential I found it was very difficult to assess accurately. Budget seems valid but perhaps if author(s) had requested initial start up fund (V1) with the completion of same leading to request for further funds. The proposal needs to provide greater clarity of roadmap and skillset information to meet criteria.

The author of the proposal provides an action plan, in which he specifies what will be done, in what order, and how long each stage will last. In addition, it establishes what are the expectations of expected results and how the requested fund would be divided. Regarding the last point, I was a little in doubt about how much of the money would be destined for the actual construction of this project (which I also didn't understand if it would be an app or a website). The author says that USD 25000 would be earmarked for supported artists... but what do you mean? It would be beneficial to explain how support would be used, for example. Apart from that, I believe that the project is well planned and structured.

As it stands now, the proposal seems to be auditable because the roadmap has identifiable  deliverables and they are time-related. The success metrics do not include parameters about the quality of the proposed solution and the user-friendliness of the entire experience. I think that those parameters are key to successful adoption of a project like this that has many integrations and moving pieces. So, the fullness of this proposal cannot be measured solely on technical merit - it aslo includes that issue of whether it has covered all the bases - meaning that it will lead to success when built. 
I have not been convinced that supporting four artists with 25000 of funding is the right way to proceed - although it is part of the offered solution. Maybe more possible paths to adoption could have been explored in the solution. The proposed metrics seem to be relatively underwhelming. 
Diversity of  artists by end of alpha period does not seem to be an important factor in my view, as it is not a true measure of success - when 4 artists are involved. The limited beta is anyway out of the scope of the F5 proposal. The weekly active platform-integrated users - demonstrating broad adoption - is a metric, but what will represent succcess is not clear from the proposal. Also the number of monthly private-stream events will be a number that can be clocked, but what is success? A trend? A finite number? The proposer hasn't quantified success, so almost anything might qualify as success in a sense. 
Essentially, I would have liked to see a much better and detailed consideration of success for this proposal that is not purely technical in nature. It involves an artistic element, an audience and interaction.
There is no budget breakdown in the proposal. Only that 25000 USD are used to support 4 artists during alpha phase. There is a basic roadmap and not KPIs provided.

25k of funding is allocated to support artists during the testing stages.  It will be difficult to audit the impact of these funds.  the direction of the other 55k towards the V1 roadmap is not discussed in any detail.  This is probably due to a lack of understanding of the technical requirements for the project.
