In other words, I believe that the people in question are well qualified (it would also be interesting to show some examples of their work), diversified and well oriented in the sense of seeking to complement and refine the team with audiovisual professionals.
WADA has been producing substantial content and has established a presence on the ground. Therefore with experience, it is highly likely that the proposal will get implemented.

Good quality proposal that would benefit from ongoing revision and collaboration. Its quite possible that this project could grow considerably. I thought of a longitudinal based concept re: interviews with storytelling focus. The budget detail is a little skinny and would benefit from further breakdown and priority.

The idea is very well unraveled. There is a division of phases, focusing on what will be done and in what order and also an explanation about the channel on Youtube (what would be the content and how it would be transmitted). Regarding the establishment of deadlines and metrics to be followed, a list is provided with weekly plans, that is, what would be done with what frequency. In addition, expectations for monthly content are also provided. Finally, it is explained how the financing money would be divided into parts, how much each thing would cost. In other words, in my view, the applicability of the project is perfectly planned and demonstrated.

The proposal is simple and straightforward. It is fairly comprehensive in its aim and methodology. Highlighting few specific instances or individual achievements that are proposed to be covered will bring out the theme of the proposal more clearly.
Few of the proposed tutorials are targeting or helping developers. It seems to me this proposal should be part of the ecosystem development instead.
The proposal is worded in a way that the educational material will only be distributed among the users of the project creators' clients.

The proposal can clearly help address the challenge as the availability of high-quality educational material can clearly support the expansion and improvement of the developer ecosystem. Nevertheless, I believe most people would have expected this challenge to focus on the technical development of the ecosystem, and not necessarily in its social dimension. Nonetheless, this proposal could have equally placed in any of the other five challenges: Distributed decision making, Proposer outreach, Catalyst value onboarding, Grow Africa or Scale UP!. The proposal is of clear value to Cardano and I believe the proponents have tried to leverage their expertise to maximize the returns (focus on more technical materials), which I find positive.

The proposal aims to make generalized information materials on wallets and other issues in Cardano. The materials will have limited use for the Cardano developers. There is a huge scope for improving documentation and program samples. The proposal is not addressing the core of the challenge.

The proposal appears to be a great way to attract new developers to the Cardano system, since it intends to create educational materials, which will be displayed in various media, about community projects. The proposal's authors claim that they will focus on specific materials for developers, that is, in addition to reaching the challenge objectives, this content could also attract other types of members to the community, such as idea creators, evaluators, etc.
The proposal doesn't look like it is related to this challenge, if it was then the information given in the proposal is inefficient

Everstake highly focusses on staking related information for several crypto currencies and to address the fund 5 challenge, the team would have to change their scope more to developer-focussed topics.
The experience given shows promotional videos for users, or introduction content which can easily be found on the blockchain websites themselves.
The team has a lot of blockchain experience, but not much experience in producing educational material.
From the evidence presented I believe the proponent has demonstrated the expertise to successfully implement the project.

The team that intends to execute this project already has a lot of experience, from what it looks like. Attached is a website where we can see some examples of his works, aimed at the Blockchain market in different ways. They are certainly qualified people to proceed with the project, because in addition to the website, a series of content previously developed by them is attached, which conveys security and solidity in their ability to materialize the idea.

Everstake is already providing some social media content and would therefore be able to build upon the existing accounts. However, the content is focussed mainly on staking and therefore targeted more at crypto holders than developers.
it is not clear how sending information to stakers in their pool will improve the developer ecosystem.

The proposal would need a careful and caring supervisor to agree with the proponent to an adequate set of indicators to monitor the success of the proposal, for example agreeing precisely, which material and for which platforms will be developed. Notwithstanding, given the experience demonstrated by the proponent, and the technical capacities within Cardano and its community, I believe fulfilling this requirement and auditing the progress and the success of the proposal is possible and very likely. Thank you very much to the proponent for their contribution.
The progress of the implementation can be clearly measured. However, its help for developers is the question. The material can help the general user in onboarding.

Some ways are said of how this educational content would be made: through blogs, videos on youtube, social media (and specifically which ones), in addition to others. We are also provided with what exactly this material created would consist of, the information is passed on by parties, and each party has an audience expectation that it can reach. In other words, the stages of completing the project are very well clarified. What I missed, however, was greater coverage of possible dates on which this content would be created. Despite this, the project seems to me to be well structured and thought out, needing only the inclusion of this information to be ideal.
Most of the information in the proposal talks about attracting OR helping delegators, not sure how this will help the developers.

It is not clear, what educational material will be provided, as the information given refer mostly to staking related material and there is no further information about which topics for developers the team would want to address. There might be a conflict of interest since the articles and tweets are also usually aimed to advertise the existing everstake website and their services. A roadmap is missing, the distribution of the funds are missing, it would be difficult to audit the proposal without these information.

This idea is interesting because it intends to use social networks already consolidated, and as a result, promote sports betting, and use Cardano to create a smart contract that will manage the bets. I don't understand anything about sports betting, so I can't say with certainty that I think it's a safe idea, but starting from the assumption that this practice is common and frequent, I don't see why the increment with a financial system in blockshain would not bring more security and advantages, both for gamblers and for the community.

The problem and solution description is reasonable and the proposal is within the scope of this challenge.

The betting market is huge and has a flow of billions of dollars of capital, today that market is dominated by centralized companies, which allows corruption and market manipulation, which harms gamblers.

The goals and metrics described are subjective and do not allow assessing the potential impact of the proposal on this challenge.

Launching an app / website and growing the number of users are extremely subjective metrics. Any app launched will have 0 users and will increase its user base over time, the question is how much it will increase and whether this growth is considered to be impactful for the challenge. For this reason, it is essential to establish objective metrics and KPIs.

The experience listed is relevant and the proposal is well organized, detailed, and reasonable. Development is already underway for this project, and there is a clearly defined timeline to set expectations and measure results against.

In this part, it is said that the project is launched for a while with members from various countries, with different functions, such as developers, marketers and so on. Despite being a very solid, diverse and knowledge-rich base, apparently, it would also be beneficial to exemplify some works already done by the accomplished ones. On the attached website, there is a tab that talks about the group, but also does not provide names. I believe that it is always safer to know who the people are, to make the team more palpable, say.

The proposer is a participative and relatively well-known member of the Cardano community. He elaborated a CIP to modify the pledge curve and participates in the Plutus Pioneer Program, but I recommend that more information be presented so that we can evaluate his qualifications in an easy and transparent way.


The solution presented doesn't solve the problem, as there is no indication of how the proposal can scale or be efficient.

A smart contract between two or 3 people is quite different from a model for decentralizing bookmakers, the potential for impact is much less relevant.

Betting sites like Betfair have models where the bets are p2p, there is no entity defining the odds, but an agreement between two users and a fee that is paid to Betfair. There is still centralization in some aspects, but a concept that allows a more decentralized and fair model of price discovery (odds)

Letting a person set their own odds is a poor design choice and not user friendly, as it does not allow liquidity. it's like placing a sales order on an order book exchange and waiting for someone to fill that order.

Sellers want to charge a value above the ideal and buyers want to pay for a value below the ideal, how to make the odds of the bets approach and make the proposal viable?

Bookmakers resemble market makers and in the context of supply and demand design they reduce spreads and make the service viable.

My recommendation is that the proposer better describe how this proposal will scale and how it will generate liquidity so that the bets are combined.

The proposal has a serious dependence on a centralized oracle and this makes room for corruption and liveliness.

There is not enough information to judge the feasibility of the budget, as the proposal does not describe enough details to understand the work required to develop the project.

The concept and experience appears valid but the proposal lacks sufficient information to really shine. Having said that I feel that the proposal will develop over time whether funded or not as the proposal team further their own understanding of what such a Dapp requires to be sucessful.

In the proposal itself it's unclear how the DApp will generate revenue for itself to continue operations, considering there are no fees to use it and there is no "house" (all betting is fair and the betters set their own odds). However, the proposer's reply to a comment has indicated potential methods to generate revenue for the DApp creators to sustain operations. Although it would be nice to see this outlined in more detail within the proposal. Hence 4 out of 5 stars for feasibility.

An action plan is drawn up, in relation to what would be done according to the time in months, as well as a division of costs. In general, we are provided with what we need to get a sense of how the project will go, however, I think that the part of the financial division could be more detailed. For example, in the $ 30,000 set aside for the development of the project, what would make up that development? As it is a large amount, it would be more interesting to clarify its use in more detail, in addition to dividing it into two large blocks.

There are not enough details on resource allocation. There are no metrics that indicate success and allow an efficient audit. There are no KPIs. Success goals are subjective and do not help with good auditability.

Although several relevant steps / implementations have been defined, there is no clear and understandable roadmap and this is essential to allow auditing.
No details are given as to how Cardano is actually going to be used. Smart contracts are mentioned, however they are not yet available on Cardano.
The proposal could be a lot more detailed. It is like a broad aproach at the moment. Maybe find a litte more concrete solution.

The idea is good because it intends to act on the problem of pollution, focusing on the use of plastic, and seeking to develop ecological housing for the marginalized people in this community. In addition to being beneficial to the locality, the project relates to the Cardano community through smart contracts, which would use blockshain technology, and the creation of tokens for various purposes.

The proposal is noble, unique, and has a good chance for positive impact in multiple ways for the society. The proposal also addresses the problem of poor urban planning in the large number of countries.

I think that the idea behind this proposal has enormous merit and promise. The proposed deployment of Ssocial housing campaigns using Plastic Waste-2-Brick technology sounds like an amazing approach for utilizing the advantages of Cardano - by tying in different actors involved in this space. 

We are not assessing the idea alone, however. 

The proposal itself still seems to be in the idea stage and that is a weakness to me - as it is still not sufficiently well defined to distinguish it from just an idea.

The proposer specifies that the Cardano smart contracts vehicle can be used to certify several components of the implementation, but the precise details of this remains sketchy at best and the smart contracts/Cardano integration seems to come as an afterthought. Still, the proposal's impact on Africa as presented could be important - not completely sure about its impact on Cardano - as it is not exactly clear to me how much traction would the Cardano blockchain have in this sense - as I do not see that the risks have been addressed sufficiently.

At first glance I couldn't find a connection between this proposal and the challenge. After reading the attachment, which is not mentioned in the proposal, that became more clear, yet I don't see the need for several for-profit organisations already operating in several countries around the globe applying for a fund in Project Catalyst, but rather getting in direct touch with the Cardano Foundation.
The link of the project to Cardano is very weak. The only connection would be, that the tasks could be paid in ADA.

I love the idea of a catalyst fund using proven plastic waste construction methods (bricks).  There are also proven small-scale methods to convert plastic waste into other useful objects.  Unfortunately the proposal offers very little information as to how the program would be implemented and the exact nature of the Cardano integration. Without more information it is difficult to understand the potential impact on the challenge criteria.

Although this proposal has merit in regard to African development it fails to address the implementation of the Cardano ecosystem into the project. Simply stating that 'smart contacts can be used' is not enough to explain how the proposal will help drive the adoption of Cardano in Africa. The idea of the Cardano Plastic Unit - the main connector is not fleshed enough to understand its actual implementation - the economics and workings of this concept would be needed to fully understand how this proposal can have an impact in Africa using Cardano.

The proposer has domain experience in the physical product, however no information is given on experience in connecting this to a blockchain. There are no real detail in the plan on what would actually be done.

If a proposal mentions partners it should provide a little more details about them. It would help as well if the team behind this proposal would introduce themself a litte more.

Then a clear budget which includes what is spent on what task is always beneficial. If you are serious about this project maybe re-do the proposal and propose again for the next fund with a more detailed proposal

It was not very clear  in the text who the authors of the project would be. In document attached we can see: It is the E&S group, which, according to what has been said, has a direct relationship with social and environmental programs, specifically dealing with the issue of plastic.  There is a short summary about the group and what it does. However, I felt that this information was still on a very theoretical plane. For example: It is not possible to understand who are the people involved in this group, what are their professional backgrounds, previous experiences. Also in the document, we can even see who the group's partnerships are, but no space is dedicated to getting to know their members better.
Es-communication and their partners have impressive credentials and have undertaken a substantial number of works in sustainable development. The project is likely to be implemented successfully.

I am not sure about the proposer's qualifications and ability to tackle a project of this scope and magnitude (it does not identify a microenvironment for implementation - rather it tackles Africa as a whole). The proposal does not include detailed information about skills, qualifications, prior experience, how will the smart contracts be developed, applied and tested, etc...
The proposed budget is not broken down into components, nor is a step-by-step timetable provided. The proposal seems still to be heavy on the idea part, but light on the implementation aspects and the nitty-gritty details. As the saying goes, the devil is in the detail and unfortunately this proposal suffers from a lack of detail - making it less convincing. 
If the proposer and his team (if there is a team) are well-skilled and knowlegable in the fields that are required, the proposal would have benefited from a detailed presentation of their qualifications, as well as how long have they been working together, plus the budget details and a clear timetable. 
Effectively, I find it impossible to determine whether the budget is reasonable to achieve the set goals and the challenges and risks have not been addressed sufficiently.

The team sounds impressive, and the plan is sound as well. However, key details on how the incentives will work are missing. What isn't clear is how $20,000 will help achieve the goals. Is there a market place where all of the infrastructure is already developed, but an incentivisation structure is all that is missing? then yes this sounds feasible. Does the production facility need to be built? if so what's the plan? There is significant risk of failure if the infrastructure for processing and moving materials is not yet built. Would love to see a business plan with numbers that are reasonable.

The information in the project description is not detailed. Additional facts can be found in the attachment, but that is not hinted at in the main text. Even so, after reading several pages, it hasn't gotten very clear what they are asking the money for. It's not a big amount, so is it more as a way to advertise themselves? There is definitely a good idea behind this and I would like to see it implemented on the African continent in the near future, however the proposal needs to be re-written for the Cardano community rigours.

The proposed solution is already successfully applied. The linked presentation is convincing. I deduct one star because it is not stated, what will be with the funds. I am sure, that everything related to the Waste-2-Brick solution could be done by the proposer, but providing a feasibility-score for tasks that are not really specified is hard.

The proposers appear to have experience and connections with the waste-2-brick technology. To make this proposal more feasible, I suggest they acquire some  partners 1) on the ground in Africa  2) experienced in business proposals and 3) experience in blockchain technology.  While some partnerships are mentioned, no relevant details are provided.  I don't see a feasible implementation with Cardano as realistic from the current proposal
The proposal lacks details on the team skillset, relevant experience, and Key performance indicators for the project implementation.

E&S Eurocentre appears to be a Brussels based co-working space - there is no mention of past experience in the deployment of social housing or details or links about the technical partners. There are details about connections to NGOs, governments in African countries. It is difficult to gather from the presented information if the proposer has the necessary experience or knowledge of what would be needed to implement successfully. Much greater detail is needed to be communicated about the team and partners.
There is not enough information on what is actually going to be done andhow this would involve Cardano.
The proposal is quite vague and it is hard to asses it. A well elaborated roadmap, budget and team-introduction would help a lot, maybe a risk-assessment as well.

Regarding the theoretical basis of the project, we have a lot of detailed information in the attached document. Even a graph, which visually demonstrates what this process involving plastic would look like. It is very interesting to build things like this, in a more direct and visual way, because it helps laypeople to better understand the functioning of a whole. However, I missed a more detailed planning regarding the act of making it happen. How this whole theory would be put into practice, set goals, worked on predetermined deadlines... In addition, they also did not include how the financing money would be used, which is a very important part to be analyzed.

The progress is easily auditable. The proposal aims to use the DEFI vehicle to ease transactions in the ecosystem generated by these plastic waste management programs. It will be possible to measure accurately the volume of micro-entrepreneur transactions that the proposed system will carry out.

Unfortunately, my impression is that the success of this proposal will be hard to audit as it does not include critically needed pieces of information that are required for any outside audit or auditing team. The timetable is simply not present as far as I can see.  The moving pieces of the project are not clearly presented and the budgetary allocation seems to be just a lump sum for everything - which will make it hard to assess whether the project is progressing according to plan. Furthermore, the cost of developers and smart contract development is unclear and the proposal would benefit from clarifying all these aspects. 
While the problem is presented in a manner that can be understood, the proposed solution is more akin to a framework for resolution, without a specific implementation plan that would inspire confidence in the success of the proposal. The inclusion of specific metrics and deliverables would have strengthened the proposal immensely.

the proposal doesn't include clear goals on what the  adoption rate is expected to be, and doesn't identify how the budget will help the team achieve their goals. What is presented is a framework but lacks detail.

The project is already running on other continents, so expanding to the African continent is a natural next step. They have a good idea behind it, yet strictly as a Catalyst project it's lacking too many informations to be able to clearly assess it. If they really need the funding to start organising the project in Africa, I would suggest re-writing it and applying for a future fund.
There are not milestone, KPIs or other aspects specified, that would allow to audit the projects. It is not known, what exactly would be funded with the requested amount of money.
no breakdown of fund allocation is provided. No metrics for success and relevant time frames are provided. I do not see this as an auditable proposal as presented.

The project lacks a roadmap that shows how this proposal can be implemented. 
Please develop a step-by-step plan of action.

There is no breakdown of the proposed budget of $20000, why this amount and how will it be spent? These two questions would need to be answered in order fulfill the question of Auditability of the funds provided. There is a section in the attached document "Volumes and financial forecasts" which does provide some details on the effect of the proposal on waste and possible economic outcome of the Cardano Plastic Units that could be used to audit the success of the proposal but it is not clear over how long the provide funds will cover or the period.

I do like the proposal and can see essentially the logic being submitted. A few points were not entirely clear (which is fine in these early stages). 1. the project is small scale (3 people team) that will work intensively until members evolve and then  are replaced? 2. The budget presented does not natch the requested funds? To be fair these are not crucial to success but led me to think the proposal will evolve with further work.

In the initial evolving stage of Cardano there is a need for self-motivated individuals with strong technical and professional skills. Writing proposal is relatively a simple tasks except if there is any language barrier. The requirement of motivational interviewing in this stage of Cardano is not a major challenge.
Not sure this will attract many developers. Developers need tools, forums, better documentation to build things on Cardano, 1on1 sessions, mentorship doesn't seem like developer things

I am confident that the energy and experience of the proposers will with time lead to a successful implementation. I like the diversity aspect being proposed and feel this may greatly appeal to some members of the Project catalyst community.
The proposer does not have developer experience. How will they successfully implement a plan to help developers?

The proposal involves interviewing, team building, and onboarding prospective proposers to enable a successful team. The experience claimed that the proposer and his organization are likely to achieve this.
Implementation of MVP, implementing a system to prepare videos, giving sessions seems bit difficult and in long term it may need more funding to sustain

Enough information was provided to suggest a feasible proposal (I think it will get better with time). Some minor queries with budgeting and perhaps the evolution process could be better laid out and detailed. I hope these proposers continue to pursue this concept with or without funding as I feel it will mature into a useful exercise for the community.
The proposal's objective is abstract, and identifying a tangible result is very difficult in an objective manner.
The timeline provided is nice and good, It's a long-term proposal that will require funding in the further rounds for success.
Availability of open-source Graph DB Sidechain will enable a host of services on cardano. The proposal address the challenge effectively.

I like this proposal, it does not seem like an afterthought - but a really well planned, well designed, meticulously thought-through concept that would bring value to the Cardano metadata space by standardizing metadata use and ensuring that the metadata is made available via sidechains in a transparent and open-source manner. The proposers are keen to ensure that there is some order introduced in the Cardano metadata universe and I applaud this effort. I also think it will be both short-term and long-term helpful if realized successfully. The open source component and the standardization of DApp data storage solutions would create new value in my opinion.

The proposal falls well within the scope of this challenge in its goal of highly usable, immutable off-chain data, and it does so by leveraging Cardano metadata capabilities, while respecting the 16kB limit on metadata.
Semantic web technologies seem a natural fit for the Cardano blockchain (since they are inherently distributable and benefit both from immutability and versioning), and this standards-based approach will accessibly open sidechain data to the large semantic-web development community, perhaps enticing that community to develop sophisticated blockchain applications.
It would have been helpful if it had discussed versioning in slighly more detail. For instance, it is not clear whether the project will use the reification capabilities of RDF or (on the contrary) if it will be developing its own non-standard solution to the versioning problem.
If successfully implemented this project would add incalculable value to Cardano as an NFT platform by storing extended metadata in a standardized, immutable, decentralized side chain.
The credentials of the proposal team are in the open domain and they have demonstrated capability in handling large software projects.

This looks like a quality team that will be able to work productively on this problem. I like that they are already committed to developing this, and are only looking for a relatively small amount for marketing. Each dollar of funding from Catalyst could generate a lot benefits for the whole community.

The relevant experience of the team is documented, the members are personally identifiable (not just job descriptions), the included Youtube video and links to the Fluree platform indicate that the team is competent and able to tackle a proposal of this depth and scope. There is a timetable that has been presented and the budget amounts to USD12,500. Although the budget is not broken down into identifiable items, the proposers have focused on a very detailed project roadmap with milestones - which makes it clear that the proposal has a very definite action plan. I do not take the lack of details on the budget as a minus in the case of this proposal as it is not an enormous chunk of the budget, the roadmap is very clear and  as they specify the team is "dedicated to start building it out regardless of funding or not". As such the budget is on the low side as the proposers state that requested funding will not be going towards engineering costs, but rather marketing and outreach, infrastructure and upkeep costs, and a bounty/reward system. So, there is a general overview of budgetary expenditure.

The proposers present a solid, realistic, and detailed plan for integrating a GraphDB sidechain with Cardano, and they have documented strong experience with closely related technologies and development processes. Notable strengths of the proposal are (1) its early engagement with use cases to drive requirements and development, (2) leveraging existing RDF standards and tools, and (3) gradually accelerating engagement with SPOs and the Dapp ecosystem over the course of the project. One weakness is that the proposal discusses implementing the security model in Phase 2, but it is not clear about the approach adopted for the security model or (alternatively) the Phase 1 activities involved in the design of the security model. Given the potentially complex and interacting uses cases for public/private and immutable/mutable sidechain data, the security model likely is one of the highest risk areas of the project.
The project has somewhat placed two other projects ("Indigenous Art Authenticity" and "NFT-DAO Boxcar") on its critical path, and the proposal acknowledges that public launch "will largely depend on resources we will be able to attract". Given the experience of the team and their awareness of these challenges, it is likely that the project can successfully handle these dependencies.

The plan is well organized and has a highly qualified team behind it. Partnerships with NFT DAO and other Catalyst projects and proposals further demonstrate the momentum and enthusiasm for the project. The project is much larger than the funding requested and expects to move forward with or without the Catalyst funds.
The proposal is detailed with a complete road map and the proposer hosts a firm with enough developer strength to implement the proposal.

Good roadmap and description of what they want to do. It explains well how it adresses the challenge and will positively impact the Cardano DApp community. I am not qualified to judge how feasible it is to achieve the milestones in the roadmap within the timeframe, but the team and vision seems very solid to me.

The proposed data-centric metadata sidechain that will be powered by W3C semantic web standards to me seems like a good idea, although I am not a developer myself. The explanation and rationale seem sound and I could and can see value in the proposed solution that would facilitate the linkage and sharing of metadata across DApps  as the proposers suggest. I also view the problem statement as pretty well defined (Off-chain DApp data storage options build silos that limit data's use across the ecosystem) - and the proposed solution to me is fully in the spirit of the Cardano ecosystem of building side chains, following the vision of the founding entity IOHK, relying on open-source solutions and teaming up with other stakeholders to build solutions that will serve not only one project - but the entire community. 

The roadmap is detailed enough for my taste to indicate that the project will be auditable and the fact that the projects under the MetaData challenge are permitted to liaise with IOHK developers and technical staff for a certain amount of time - will help to ensure success. The fact that the proposers are welcoming this interaction with the IOHK experts - speaks favourably about their intentions. 

I would have liked to see more information about the risks and challenges that could face a project of this ambition and caliber - and potential pitfalls and which elements could hinder adoption.  

I welcome the fact that the proposers have already tentatively partnered up with two specific projects to explore initial use cases: NFT-DAO boxcar and Indigenous Art Authenticity that will host their own Fluree metadata ledgers.

The statement of the project milestones and the time-windows for the three Phases is sufficiently detailed to measure progress and determine success. The three-level breakdown of Phases, milestones, and their details is particularly helpful in defining progress metrics, and the majority of the goals are straightforwardly measurable.

The 12.5K requested is small compared to the scope of the project,  and will be dedicated to infrastructure costs, marketing, and developer outreach. Auditing the success of the project will involve a level of trust and  entail assessing the growth and enthusiasm around the project as it moves through its proposed stages. As long as the project continues with its current momentum, I am confident the funds will add a lot of value to the metadata ecosystem of Cardano.

Blockchain provides means for the exchange of value without mutual trust or trust of third-party. Invoicing and payment is an important component in commerce that so far relies on shared databases or third-party services for exchange. The solution provides a method for the transfer of invoices using encrypted Metadata. There are more challenges in this process. However, as a first step, the proposal addresses the problem in an effective manner.

This is definitely a very good application of the technologies Cardano provides, and a very good use-case meeting the Metadata Challenge call [not sure about the 'without revealing the document or the event's data (because of privacy concerns)' part, as I am not versed enough in the security side, and may have missed mention of that aspect of the teams capabilities and take on security]. But the proposal addresses the Guiding Questions well.

The proposal is well aligned with the metadata challenge. In particular, the proposal's technical overview slides include a novel and potentially very powerful approach to compressing metadata within the 16kB transaction limit. However, it apparently does not plan to employ existing standards for interoperable business-to-business electronic data interchange, even though that would be accelerate development, and enhance acceptance/adoption.

The project is very interesting, because it aims to transform the old and flawed payment process between companies into something more modern and secure. This new modality of transactions is called E-invoice, and it is made through smart contracts, which dialogues directly with the objectives of the challenge: it will use Cardano to promote a metadata solution, in a way that keeps the target audience, on account of the advantages cited in the text, such as the acceleration and optimization of financial flows. I found the idea very promising and well organized, as I will talk about in the following topics.

A prototype software working on the Cardano testnet has been demonstrated by the proposers. However, no verifiable credentials regarding the proposal's past experiences have been included for assessment.

I really got it when watching the Demo!... Nice video to see the 'plan in action'.  I am encouraged by that for sure.  The target audience is clear, but, what I would like to see is a more detailed list of targeted clients/users, not only the generic list of CFO's, etc., but specific companies and potential clients. IF the team has worked in the business of writing smart contracts, servicing electronic invoicing solution, then give a list of existing clients, or likewise. 
Also, now having seen the ADAvoice 'pitch deck' of sorts, I feel that the team has good commication skills, and a sense of how to win over user/clients in this up and coming evolutionary new stage in the business of electronic invoicing!

The proposal only provides brief, generic information about the team's capabilities. It describes technological approaches, requirements, and goals, but does not organize these into a staged plan with intermediate milestones and a timeline. However, the video demonstration provides evidence of competence for successfully achieving the goals of the project.

In the text, we cannot find much information about the team that makes up the project. We know that they have experience with smart contracts and that they have already developed software for other companies. However, it is not clear who are the people who make up the team and their respective professional backgrounds, which would be interesting as well. I thought we could see this on the attached site, but from what I saw it has no content on it, I don't know if it was a team error or a bug on the site. However, with the attached video, and the slides that speak more deeply about the project, it is clear how the team involved knows what it does, has mastery of the idea and is able to clearly unravel it so that outsiders can understand it best. Therefore, I believe that the team is very qualified. The inclusion of some extra information could bring more proximity to those involved, but in terms of technical competence, it is safe that they have it.
A more detailed plan of what will be built and a timeline would enable feasibility to be better assessed.

A detailed technical presentation and a demo of the prototype have been provided in the proposal. The aim of the project is achievable and will provide an excellent method to exploit the metadata feature in the Cardano. Risk analysis in achieving the adoption of the proposed software is required to be carried out.

When it comes to auditability, I do not see information about judging the success of the proposal if implemented. First, What is the funding needed for specifically? Then, What are the milestones of the proposers development-roadmap?  What are the ways to see if funding leads to success in the coming months or year?
The proposal describes the end-goal of the project and that could be used to assess success, but it does not contain a roadmap that would contain details to audit progress towards the final goals.

In the attached slides, we can get to know the project in depth: what it is about, how it works, who would be the beneficiaries, its differential in relation to the current means of transacting expenses and so on. In addition, in the text, it is very clearly stated how this project would benefit the problem, and, in topics, how the user would be retained in the new system, what advantages it would also have. However, at no time did I see a more direct action plan, a line that detailed how this was going to happen in stages; it is not clear how the money would be divided, and a certain time estimate of how this project would develop. In other words, there was a lack of detail in relation to making it happen, in a more pragmatic way. Many proposals use almost all the space to defend the importance of their projects, and I believe that here we have one more example of this.

There is a need to have a blockchain verified storage mechanism for medical data. A multiprong approach to solve this problem will lead to development of at least one good solution. The proposal sets an achievable target and is likely to add value to the use of Metadata.

The proposal gives an interesting approach to the usage of metadata. The uploaded presentation of the app is nice and show's the importance of efficient medical documentation. However it is not fully disclosed how the data is planned to be utilized in addition to that, i.e. what the purpose of transferring it to blockchain is. You should reflect on that ahead of your proposal to present a good solution there. Keep in mind that you are asking 50000 Dollars of funds, it would be good to know what the exact purpose and potential of this could be other than "using it for further applications".

The problem and solution description is reasonable and directly related to the challenge.

The proposal describes how it will use metadata to store data about patients, but the lack of metrics, goals or KPIs makes it difficult to measure the impact on the challenge.

I recommend establishing these items so that we can assess the impact for Cardano's blockchain.

The proposal's intention to store medical information on-chain coincides with the challenge's immutable recording of event data such as transaction metadata. However, the proposal is not specific about how the solution will implement the privacy and confidentiality that are critical for medical data, especially in countries with rigorous privacy regulations. It is not clear what that project's goals are in distinction against the long-term aspirations presented in the proposal. The proposal also does not reference medical-data standards or clarify whether the project would develop its own standards.

Whilst the proposers have experience that would allow a project like this to be developed, with both domain and technical expertise, the plan is lacking in details on what will be produced. What interfaces will be produces for data entry and querying. How will patient consent be handled. Will they be enabling differential privacy on qureying?
The proposers claim adequate experience. A combination of medical practitioners and a developer is ideal for the settings.

While, after researching the proposers, it seems reasonable to say they are competent in their fields, the plan is not very detailed yet, which makes this seem rather an early stage project where some potential has been detected but proper goals and milestones have not been set yet. Considering you are asking the entire amount of funding for the challenge and other projects that are far more modest budget wise have much more concrete plans, this is not sufficient. By the way I would not call the budget you are asking for a "minimal salary". What you are asking for amounts to about the average salary in sweden, not a minimal salary. (I know it is a pretty low salary for your job segments, but just consider that the salaries in sweden and skandinavia in general are some of the highest in the world and yet it's possible to live on a lot less there). So considering the limited funding from Catalyst can go into a lot of very important projects where some of them have positive impacts on a lot of different fields, you should maybe consider accepting a lower salary if you are passionate about forwarding this project.

The team is already working on the development of systems to automate and standardize medical records through metadata, and has won awards for ideas and prototypes. No links or information have been described to attest to the qualifications and work cited in the proposal, which is essential for us to confirm the team's aptitude to develop the project.

There is no detailed implementation plan. The proposal describes that the team will spend most of the funds on salaries for 6 to 8 months, but this needs to be more detailed so that we can assess the feasibility of the proposal.

In addition to wages, what costs will there be? What are the project's deliverables? We need to understand what will be delivered in relation to the requested budget to judge the feasibility.

The project team has the right combination of medical and software experience to successfully pursue this work. The proposal presents a staged plan with vaguely defined intermediate milestones that are not tied to a timeline or a detailed list of constituent activities. In general, a lot more technical justification should be included for a proposal of this size.

The proposal requires a lot more detail. What exactly is being produces on both front and backend systems. How is this connecting to the real world (doctors, patients, researchers, regulators). How are they ensuring privacy and enabling changes in consent to view data etc.

The proposal is from a two-member team with a plan to acquire developers along the way. It is a feasible plan, there is a scope for improvement by developing a detailed plan with deliverables in phases.

Unfortunately, the information about the project is very vague. While it points out some potential that can be examined further, it clearly still NEEDS some more examining and more concrete ideas ahead of applying for funding.

The only information described to audit the proposal was a delivery period between 6 to 8 months and that part of the budget will be used for the team's salary during this period.

There is no reasonable roadmap, there are no details on budget allocation, there are no metrics, no KPIs, no deliverables.

This information is important so that we can judge the auditability of the proposal, so I recommend the inclusion of these items and that the team follow the Catalyst documentation as a reference to prepare the proposal.

The specific outcomes, timeline, and stages of the project are not defined in enough detail for confident auditing of intermediate progress on the project. The 6-8 month final goal is not defined concretely enough to quantify whether specific capabilities have been successfully achieved.

Not clear what simple GUI token generation ability actually provides. What is the use case? Without coding up something more complex (in which case you would not need this), why would someone mint a random token?

Whilst this is a challenge now, it can hardly be seen as a big one for the future. As the proposer himself admits, future Daedalus releases will deploy this very functionality in the official wallets (unsure of Yoroi but I assume there will be a light version too). Had this proposal been presented in Fund1 or Fund2, prior to Mary, its importance would have been higher and the need to address the challenge more immediate. Only a  middle rating was given this challenge because the date when wallet coin-minting functionality has not yet been confirmed and if it is in line with the release of Alonzo, then a 3/4 month wait is not that long. however, as it stands and if it can be delivered in the near future then there is a benefit...hence the middle rating.

The problem description and solution are reasonable. The proposal presented is within the scope of the challenge. Making the minting process for native assets more user friendly is an important step to increase adoption. A less technical minting model can increase the user base and this can generate a chain effect, as it is easier for mint assets, new projects will benefit.

The proposer is committed to developing relevant implementations.  Metrics were not included to measure the potential for impact.

In general, I see the proposal as promising, I recommend only a clearer definition of success through goals and metrics so that the potential for impact can be more evident.

The idea appears to be a valid use case of a Dapp that would add value for the community and as such addresses the challenge. The proposal has been initiated but needs further refinement which this funding would address.
The self-introduction is not enough to convey the skill required to implement most of the features nor does further investigation on GitHub.

The proposer has presented a test (MAC only) version of the functionality which interacts with the testnet and that provides a level of confidence that there is a chance for success. However, the admittance that an official minting functionality will be built in the official wallets almost forces the proposal to list more novel priorities. This proposal would benefit from a listing of the dev pathways for each of the items including a matrix of resources x costing, which breaks down the claimed 200 hours of work required. The timing of the release should also be prominent including what-if scenarios if there is a delay in the official releases or this proposed solution. Fund 5 funds are disbursed on the 26th of June so there should be clear statements about how the timeline of this dev matches with the IOHK minting functionality. When is the 200 hours of work starting? And if it starts after receiving the funds, how does its release align with the official version?  There is a possibility that this solution could be redundant by the time it's released.

The proposer described experience in software engineering, as a co-founder of a tech company and as a participant in the Plutus Pioneer Program. The proposal is already under development and an initial version of the application can now be used. The development can be checked on Github and there are technical details on how to use it.

The requested budget is for the payment of the proposer and is estimated at 200 hours of work, which is within the expectation for what is expected of a software developer / engineer.

The redundancy risk of the proposal was considered and this is due to the fact that IOG is also working on a similar type of implementation.

The plan needs to be better structured. There is no timeline / roadmap.

The proposer has the relevant experience to successfully implement the proposal and appears to be well along the track of development. The plan is a little light on for detail but I feel this may be more to do with proposer characteristics. I certainly feel the proposal will be improved with further iterations and increased community collaboration.

The proposal only includes an upper limit on work hours and a wish list of things that the proposer hopes to implement within that allotted time. Information of what can be realistically be completed within the funded period is missing.
Its not clear how this simple functionality would be useful. Could the proposer give some example use cases that would drive widespread repeated usage?

The proposal presents enough information to provide confidence regarding its feasibility. The proposer has already built a test version which any user can play with. Where the score is reflected is how it will effectively address the challenge, if it is still a valid challenge at all at this point of Cardano development. Had this been presented in Funds 1-3, there iwould have been a greater need for its development. That said and should this proposal proceed, the use of GitHub and reddit provides a level of transparency that will allow audit of the project. But better listing of each step of the process, assuming the priorities will not change, is required in order for the community to check progress stage by stage.

The project will be open source, which is a favorable point for auditability.

A budget breakdown has been described (although there is no clear definition, it is possible to identify that the budget will be used to pay the proposer for 200 hours of work).

Relevant goals / deliverables have been defined.

The project is already under development and there is a link to Github where it is possible to confirm that the work already exists.

I recommend the inclusion of metrics / KPIs and a roadmap to make auditability clearer.

The information provided is adequate without being as explicit as I would like for a non-technical audience. Having said that the proposer is open to questions and has a valid use case in mind. The Reddit community certainly engaged with the concept and the proposer adequately fielded the enquiries and with this approach I am confident good work may come with this proposal.
This is a proposal very aligned with the DeFi challenge from a proven GimbaLabs team.

The proposal carefully lays out the existing problems, short-comings and bottlenecks in the Cardano development space and does an even better job at carefully explaining the solutions to the problems, including proposals within the same funding round which compliments this dev. Not pretending I understand all technical aspects presented, however, the clear explanation of the missing pieces of solid infrastructure  and the boot-strapping required to get projects going is a very familiar narrative to the Cardano Community who have been exposed to SPO and NFT chatter in media channels where ADA is discussed. This solution is a critical part of Cardano's developmental success once Alonzo is released.

The problem described is reasonable and is in the scope of the challenge. DeFi dapps depend on API gateways and recently YOROI had problems due to excessive transaction load. Considering the fact that YOROI will be used in the interaction of users with different dapps on the blockchain, improving this infrastructure is an important step towards creating an efficient DeFi and blockchain ecosystem as a whole. Creating a market for APIs would allow better distribution of resources and network resilience to peak network usage, which would bring conditions for that DeFi dapps can run more smoothly on the blockchain.

The lack of clarity in deliverables makes it difficult to measure the impact.
the project vision for Cardano API's, 3 month roadmap and presented plan are all complete and in line with the outlined deliverables.

Being presented by an ex-Emurgo DevOps person gives this proposal credibility and familiarity with the technicalities required to see the problems and achieve the goals. The proposal carefully lays out the required resources, the breakdown of roles and responsibilities and the renumeration for the time period of the work, which without being mentioned, seems to be in line with the release of Alonzo. The proposer also elaborated on existing network relationships and the leveraging of outside participants and activities which would be critical to this development. this not only provides confidence in the implementation but provides an almost internal-audit mechanism from any boot-strapping partners. The fund requested seems reasonable for the time and amount of work that needs to be done

The proposer described relevant experiences for the execution of the proposal and the idea is to continue the development of the Dandelion APIs. Although the proposer is known in the Cardano community, I think it is important that he put more details about his bio and links so that the community has access to his portfolio. and qualifications (Linkedin or repos).

There are details on budget allocation.

Some goals have been defined in the roadmap, but the solutions and deliverables described are not clear. The reputation model is clearly an item to be developed in the proposal, but the rest are unclear. There is a dependency on the proposal in another proposal submitted in the Metadata challenge: https: //cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Blockchain-Authentication-Mechanism/352005-48088.

It is not clear whether a lack of funding in the above proposal could jeopardize development and this poses risks.

I recommend that you communicate more clearly what the purpose of each proposal is, the dependence between them and what the expectation of the project will be if only one of the proposals is funded.
The proposal directly addresses the challenge and is well positioned to become the API gateway for all Cardano dApps.

This proposal provides a clean budget which may be audited however it doesn't provide a metric on which we could judge real adoption, such as a number of new API gateways developed, number of calls, number of Dandelion 'seeds' in use etc.

The proposal has the credibility and the information to provide the confidence that the goals can be achieved. It was very tactical to include all the projects 'familiar' to the Cardano Community which they have already assisted over the last few months. This serves as a good foundation of the experience, the know-how and the effectiveness of the solution. Despite the 5-star rating given, the proposal can be further improved by stating how the service plans to make itself sustainable.

There is clarity on how the problem addresses the challenge.

There are details on budget allocation.

There is a roadmap with goals and the deadline for implementing the proposal is 3 months. There is no clarity in the deliverables, I recommend clarifying this aspect (This proposal is dependent on another proposal: https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Blockchain-Authentication-Mechanism/352005-48088 and the deliverables between them are not clear )

I recommend including more details about the proposer's experience so that the community can audit this easily and transparently.
The roadmap mentions milestones which can be reviewed. But there are no quantitative objectives on this proposal.
This doesn't seem to fit the challenge. This is not about the dev environment, but a new use case for ADA.

The proposal aims to build a prototype demonstrating the Capability of Cardano in developing a decentralized publishing platform.  There are many ways to attract developers and big business houses, however creating a prototype for a e-book store, decentralized publishing house with options for helping poor writers is a novel and possibly the ideal way.
The industry experience is significant, and so is the overall blockchain experience (just starting on development though).

The proposer has limited experience in development and will depend on developers to write the bulk of code. The proposal involves writing complex state of art software demanding top-class expertise. Therefore it is a risky proposition.
It is unclear how the funds are allocated and what the timeline of this proposal is. The video mentions explicitly that this will not pay for a developer that would actually implement the solution.
There are milestones that can be used to track the progress. There are no timetables about the progress of the porject.

The proposal list roadmaps and goal of the project quite clearly. However, the development schedule, the number of developers to be hired, and the time plan for the role out of the features are not clear from the proposal.

During the pandemic, phishing attacks rose significantly as users spent more time online. Working from home might remain part of the norm post-pandemic. It solves issues on mobility and is cheaper. There are market opportunities for a secure email service.

This proposal directly addresses the challenge's goal of assuring that a document has not been tampered with. However, it appears to rely on "your trusted list" for verifying trust, but it does not detail how that trust list is securely constructed from verified identities. Establishing trust for identities is a longstanding problem, but the proposal does not demonstrate awareness of risks in that area or of the relevant standards and best practices.
The proposer have interesting domain experience however they have not detailed whether they have the technical experience to program the product.
The proposal aims to build a complex decentralized security system. There will be a requirement for security-related manpower for enabling verifiable implementation.

The solution presented still relies on centralised domains. 
To counter this there should be made a completely new decentralised email domain service from scratch and then market that to compete with current centralised services. 
The system in the proposal brings about severe cost and security issues by storing users' metadata on a blockchain, where transactions are open for all to see. 
So I deem it not that feasible at this point until these issues have been addressed. 
You could consider a tokenised version of your plan so that token transactions carry a part of the metadata over. SPOs could provide a solution for the cost issues.

The proposers have relevant experience, including for blockchain technologies, but the proposal does not demonstrate experience with software engineering or with computer-security protocols. Given the nature of the proposal, one assumes that the "5 SMEs" would perform a software audit or security review—it would have been good for the plan to include more detail about testing and verification. The plan, however, has reasonable stages and intermediate goals.

A good business case is presented as are the details of what will be produced. It would be good to see more information on how the system will ensure identities and be hardened against attack as this system would surely be attacked if rolled out.
There is a requirement for more technical information regarding how the cryptographic constructs like "authentication" and "non-repudiation" of the email are implemented.

The metrics of success are realistically determined. I'm left with some thoughts on the amount of funding requested. There is an upper and lower limit set, but I would advise to make a more detailed calculation of this so that we won't end up with an 8k USD gap that could potentially fund an additional project, given this one passes the vote. 
For a security solution it lacks a risk assessment.
There is a breakdown of the budget and a timetable that can be used to track the project. All the milestones appear to be achievable.

The plan contains measurable intermediate goals, with details of the activities at those stages, and it provides a narrative defining success, althought that could have been framed more quantitatively. The lack of specificity regarding rigorous testing and critique of the design and implementation from a security perspective is a drawback.

The proposal is very interesting because it promises to simplify and make the act of generating tokens from NFT, digital arts, etc. more profitable. In other words, the authors aim to take practices that already exist and are growing in the community and make them more accessible to the general public. That is, the app they intend to create will bring a lot of value to the community.

This is a very useful and well-formulated proposal that will help to integrate NFTs into Cardano, supporting artists and other creators. It will provide a lot of positive impact with the new functions it adds to the ecosystem.

The proposal effectively addresses the challenge and appears to be a valid use case of community funds. The only issue I can see is that the idea has not been fully developed at time of submission re: commercial licencing and perhaps timeline is a little in need of refinement.

An advanced NFT minting, marketing, and promoting marketplace has been proposed in the project. There are a few proposals for the NFT market, however, in this space, it is always better for more than a few NFT markets place for the robustness of the echo system. The project also plans to provide easy-to-use fields for complex metadata.

Yes, this proposal addresses the challenge, and the community can benefit from the launch of this proposal. But still need more developmental description on How this solution will bring change and benefit the community.

This proposal is a great and complex implementation that improve dramatically the transactions volume on cardano blockchain,  because I think that NFT exchange attract enormous amounts of users and monetary value. The proposal clearly articulates how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and for the stakeholders (in deep detail for users that trade tokens, fungible and non-fungible assets, and  so on.. ). However the objective of the proposal not only related to Cardano but versus different community (eg. artists and so on…).
What is the competitive landscape? What would people choose this over other options? What is the marketing plan to stand out?

The team that intends to carry out this project is, apparently, already very solid. There are 3 people, from different areas of activity, with information provided and profiles on LinkedIn attached. I found it perfect in terms of transmitting safety in the team, showing examples of jobs and places where they worked before always increases credibility. However, one observation I make is that it would be interesting to also include an interface designer in the project, to improve the user experience when using an app.

THe plan is very detailed with realistic milestones and a detailed budget. The team has experience in software engineering and has already started to work on the topic, showing their engagement and making it credible that they will successfully deliver.

The team appear to be on the right track and seem well qualified and experienced to take the project forward. The plan seems straightforward but I am concerned with the budget request and whether this is realistic at this stage. I would like to see these aspects reviewed further with risks identified and timeline of plan to acknowledge these risks.

The profile of the proposers points to the fact that there have sufficient experience in IT and web development activity. The application proposed has few technical risks. However, with the experience of the proposers, they will be able to overcome them.

The proposal team is completed skilled and have a good trade off  between business and technical knowledge, so in my opinion will able to make surely a good production product. In relation to the possible success of the initiative, I think that exchange functionalities related to tokens, NFT,etc… are incredible evolving in the market during the last years, so there are a lot of possibilities for the adoption by the users. Further I think it's important to improve details about the process related to the issue related to the market or capital risk

More information on how they will make this the premier Cardano NFT market place. It is not clear the proposers have considered the competitors and how they would stand out. Are they communicating with NFT-DAO? Have they thought about persistence issues with IPFS?

The plan is detailed in a sequence of steps to be followed in 12 months, in which it is clarified which actions will be taken in a chronological manner. This way of demonstrating planning always seems to me to be very efficient, because it shows to outsiders exactly what will happen, tracing a logical trajectory. In addition, the authors also inform us about the expectation of reaching the public both in number and in the profile of future users. Also detailed how the requested money would be used, according to the passage of time. In other words, I believe that the applicability of this project is very well demonstrated and explained.

A solid proposal with plenty of merit. I like the collaborative nature of the team and feel that this will gain traction with further iteration. The budget and plan seem to be a step too far without anything concrete to show at this stage. Having said that I think the proposal will develop and looking at the minting tool I was certainly drawn to the potential. Would have liked to see a FAQ or guide attached to the minting tool site to give me greater insight about the teams capabilities.

The proposal is for building market place and proposers have laid out a plan for the progress. The plan is workable and the process can be audited. The metric for success as per the proposed plan looks ambitious and can be measured accurately.

The proposer provides a step-by-step plan for the technical implementation with clear milestones and a defined time horizon and uses cases for adoption. The only thing I miss in this area is that the proposer has not mentioned possible difficulties and how to deal with them.. The proposal offers a realistic timetable to complete the work. The proposer has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation

The proposal is very well prepared and it clearly describes the problem as well the vision how to solve it. From scalability point of view also addresses future possibilities for expansion and wide adaption.

The proposal aligns perfectly with the campaign brief with the team already delivering on it's goals. "At the end of this challenge, we will be asking ourselves: Did we manage to make it easier for developers to build on top of Cardano?" The team is creating open source tools, documentation, educational materials and now an onboarding process to help "traditional" developers transition into blockchain development on Cardano. Funding would go directly towards growing the number of active developers building on the Cardano blockchain, increase the quantity / quality of tooling repos, and help grow the collaborative development community.
From the propsal, it is not clear how the challenge will be specifically addressed. I would call it very vague and it is probably a better idea to ask for specific project for such a general funding.

Gimblelabs has been filling a void of providing startup tools to aspiring developers and API for accelerating development. These APIs have contributed immensely to rapid progress in the minting of native tokens and the proliferation of NFTs. The proposal is for repeating the same for smart contracts. This is likely to be a catalyst for further absorption of developers to Cardano.
The Challenge sounds clear. One Point is to find the people, or are they actually working for you? Perhaps there can be a kind of test to choiche the right people.

I'm convinced about the experience and that the job can be done by those persons. Also it is a big advantage that all found are dedicated to the developers. What is unclear for me is that for financing there is noted 25k / dev for 3 months, but the time plan is containing 12 months. Does it mean that once the tooling is setup they'll lead the team w/o any cost for 9 months? If the 100k contains complete lifecycle support, maintenance and all follow-up tasks might be ok.

The team is well ingrained in the Cardano community and has been delivering on it's Catalyst proposals since fund 2. They have the knowledge, experience and drive necessary to successfully implement this proposal; a solid plan that builds upon the firm foundation they've already put in place.
I'm little bit skeptical. The team is well know, but I'm still waiting to see what are they delivered, which is of low quality for now.

Gimblelabs has contributed quite actively in the developer's space in terms of developer workshops, API, and other handholding. Therefore it can be confidently said that the proposal will be successfully implemented.
In my view it can work quite well. Your plan is for 12 months and the people are only paid for 3 months. Are the people staying onboard? This is for me the highest risk.

Tools can be audited as well the project procedure. The team is clear, in case the open questions about financing / time plan and task coverage is answered this project has a very good potential and can the Cardano ecosystem can benefit from it on a long term.

The team has put in place metrics for measuring success at 3, 6, and 12 months. Given the open-source nature of the work and their community engagement, it will be possible to audit progress and success via GitHub, their weekly YouTube updates and activity on their discord server.

The success metrics are vague and not measurable. "engaging enough" is not something we will be able to define if it has failed and or not. For seasons proposers like this, I would expect more quality proposal.

The success of the project is subjective. The quality of the material created is also subjective. However, the project has a clear aim and will contribute to the developer ecosystem is easy to measure.

What i am missing is a concrete output and under which license. If Cardano invest 100k $ the results should be open for everyone. 3 months are not much and time flew by. Perhaps it is better to reduce it to 2 people for 6 months. There are some milestones and soft kpis, but  i am missing a detailed roadmap and some hard KPIs.

The challenge is clear to me. In my opinion it can be a little more specific. People with ideas do not automatically have the technical skills and vice versa. The challenge is to get from the prototype stage to the real world. You often need different skills. People who work in the Cardano ecosystem can use their experiences for new projects (lesson learned).

The problem statement can be improved, although it is possible to understand the problem it is implicit and this can make it difficult to understand the proposal.

This proposal is within the scope of the challenge, having a platform that can unite workers with entrepreneurs is something that is lacking and currently there is difficulty in connecting both parties. This proposal would allow better onboarding of proposers.

Despite the potential for significant impact on the challenge, there are no goals or metrics indicating the impact on the challenge, it is important to detail the proposal.
This is a good idea. It would bring members into funded proposals and from there they could also branch out in future to their own proposals.

The idea to organize the supply of workforce in the crypto space is interesting, but as mentioned there already are some platforms that do it, so it would be good to to something specific to ADA from the scratch, as mentioned. The Catalyst Discord server does this currently, but it's very limited. Also, the proposal mentions that tech people would be needed for new proposals, but it would be better if there were number from previous funds about this metric to sustain this idea.

This targets an area of great need and potential within the Cardano Catalyst community, perhaps with even greater potential across the Cardano developer and entrepreneur communities.

The problem statement is outlined well, but the targeted outcomes are unclear.  A website is the product of the work, but it's not clear what the website will offer to the community.

The proposal could be more effective if a more specific 6-month goal sets the foundation for next steps.  As an example, target could be engagement with Catalyst community to understand needs, then produce a detailed proposal to prototype a preferred solution.  Currently, there is no clear solution direction in the proposal, so some research to establish a direction would be a great first step.

To create a job & service platform is technical not a big thing, especially if you use existing ones. There are also lots of Open Source Software you can use. For me the key is the marketing and integration of the platform. I missing some details about this area. For me it is a communtiy of freelancers, companies and ethusiast. Who to attract these people to participate is the key. Somebody with experience what the needs are, what people & services are needed is good to start such a project.

There are no relevant details about the team's experience and qualifications. Considering that the proposal is about the development of a website, it is necessary to understand the team's expertise as developers.

The proposal was not detailed and this is made clear by the statement:

"Please let us know your opinion, suggestions and we'll provide the detailed plan soon."

The team completed the self-assessment checklist when the proposal was clearly not in accordance with the established items.

There is no budget breakdown either.

I recommend detailing the proposal and submitting it to the next Fund so that we can give appropriate feedback.

There is no plan on who the proposer will actually implement this and any fee structures involved etc. Presumably fees should be low. On a cost recovery basis to make the site self funded going forward.

The team has experience with marketing, but it doesn't say if they have experience with development or even if they plan to hire someone. The proposal should include a plan on how to implement this, some deadlines and a budget breakdown, which is very loose as it is. It also says that a detailed plan would be provided soon, so it looks like that the text was not finalized in time.
This proposal is feasible but needs more clarification on website management, scalability, and How the budget will be spent.

There appears to be no clear solution direction.  Several alternatives are described.  None of these are then related to the use of the funding (develop a website).

In order to increase confidence in the success of the implementation, more realistic and specific milestones should be outlined.  This could focus on early stages of developing the best solution direction (e.g. with research on needs & features).

The feasibility is clear to me and from my point of view it doesn't need a big budget. When it comes to effectiveness, I'm missing a few details. How come this to live? Various possibilities are described in this proposal. The project starts with research and brainstorming? The budget is not big and part of it should be used for marketing. So my suggestion: choose a way (quickly), realize it and improve it.

There is no detailed plan and information on auditability has not been included. I recommend the inclusion of roadmap, milestones, KPIs, success metrics, details about the team and budget, according to the Catalyst documentation.

it is important to say that the idea seems promising, there is only a lack of  a detailed plan.

It is not possible to audit the proposal as it is today. Information about a roadmap, milestones related to deadlines, KPIs and metrics should be included. For this proposal, some metrics like the number of jobs posted, people involved, people hired and other information like that could be very beneficial to the idea. Also, a budget breakdown would be needed to make the proposal auditable.
