There is currently no way to audit this proposal. The proposal doesn't include a roadmap or milestone. Please think of how long will it take to deliver this product. Who will build it? How will it work? and include KPI's for growth.

The authors cite some alternatives on how to execute the project, but it is clear that the option chosen is to build a platform from scratch. It is said that a more detailed plan will be attached later, because for now we do not have much information on how the idea will actually be made, what steps, possible dates for the project to progress, how the financial amount will be used, the people involved etc. However, we do not see any more information in the evaluation stage, unfortunately.

The use of the funds is clearly described, but are not directly linked to the purpose of the proposal or the community need that's outlined.

There is also no timeframe identified by which the website will be delivered.  

To be more auditable, it would help if the proposal included more details on how the funds would be spent, an overall timeframe for delivery, and some measure of success for this phase of solution design.

I believe this is a good idea, the proposal seeks to increase the media content related to the catalyst platform throughout the crypto ecosystem and it is considered that the amount of content in the ecosystem can be an important factor in increasing the success criteria of this challenge.  But there are many other factors not addressed in the proposal that enter at stake for meaningful participation from proponents, advisers and voters.

While I can see that some value might be had by onboarding the uninitiated I feel this proposal would have been better suited to proposer outreach. Having said that I recognise that new clients/consumers may be sourced with this initiative.

Assuming that the data in the stated problem is really an issue, i.e., that the intersection between the entrepreneurs which are doing business outside Cardano's world and inside is quite small, I still fail to grasp why it actually happens – which I imagine that if this entrepreneur works inside crypto world, I assume that he might have looked into Cardano, since it's in the top 10 in market cap coins nowadays. Therefore, I think the idea would have a great gain if the problem that should be tackled were more well defined.

I understand what you are proposing and I agree that more marketing couldn't hurt!  But I do think your problem / solution statement could do with some refinement.  To play devil's advocate:

Problem Statement:
- Does it really address the campaign brief, given that the campaign brief seems to be emphasize more participation from existing community members, rather than funneling in new ones?

 Campaign scope aside, do you think this is actually a problem right now?  I thought Catalyst is currently the largest decentralized innovation fund in the world-- so relatively speaking, it may not necessarily be the most urgent problem, but please clarify why you think this is a problem.
 
Solution Statement:

 - Will the platforms you suggest contain the sort of audience that will be valuable with respect to submitting proposals to Catalyst?  Will the participation be meaningful?  If so, why?

 - How will this increase 'efficiency', as you suggest?

 - It seems like cryptotexty is very Ukraine-centric, despite English translations being available.  I am not saying this is a bad thing, and I think it only helps to increase promotional efforts in all regions; but given Cardano's initial emphasis on Africa, and the limited funds available, why do you think it is valuable to concentrate promotional efforts in Ukraine (if my premise is correct)?

The problem description doesn't describe a problem, I recommend modifying it to clarify the purpose of the proposal.

The concept/plan is within the scope of the challenge, as it deals with the creation of articles related to Catalyst and the dissemination of material on different platforms. This has great potential to increase onboarding.

My recommendation is the setting of goals, so that we can measure the impact objectively.
Possible a good proposal for Cardano, however it does not address the challenge which is focused inwards on the community, not outwards.

I believe that the idea is good, the more content about Catalyst out there, the better. Although, the cost per article is a bit misleading in my opinion, it should not account for number of platforms, by only for different articles. Let's say the same article was published in 240 platforms. It would have the same cost per article per platform, but the amount of information out there would be the same. Most people might find this information from googling instead of looking at specific platforms. In this way, the cost per article is $375, which is quite high. The proposer mentions it could very well do 30 articles, which would bring the cost down to $200 per article, which is better. I believe this should be incorporated as a target goal, not only optional.

The proposal addresses part of the Fund 5 Metadata challenge. The problem is well described, including the solution. The only question is, how will this proposal attract entrepreneurs? It is good to post to get engagement and expand the Cardano brand awareness, but how will you make sure that your message appeals to entrepreneurs.

Although the proposal informs on the team's marketing experience and refers to a YouTube channel where domain interviews are conducted, there is not enough information on the proponent and the team members to allow a proper evaluation,  because no former content articles are available. To promote the Catalyst Platform brand, it is important to emphasize the generation of quality content and for this reason is recommended to include evidence of publication of past articles associated with the blockchain ecosystem in the proposal. Also, due to how the information is presented, it seems that the proponent allocates the same amount of budget for the creation of content and the replication of the same content on the different platforms.
I feel that the team certainly have the skillset to deliver on this proposal. My concern is the target audience is not entirely valid for the challenge.

It would be good see an actual evidence of the cited experience.
One thing that I am struggling to understand is that the price per article is stated as $25 per article per platform, resulting in 240 publications in total (16 articles in total). However the plain is to scale the idea and it's not clear how this growth would be financed, meaning that a better explanation in how it would monetize itself to allow the production of more articles would be of great relevance.

Are there any examples of articles that you would generate?  I understand that you interview crypto subject matter experts on your YouTube channel, but how does this translate in to articles?  I see on your website, https://cryptotexty.com/, that you post articles of those interviews, but they seem to be moreso direct transcriptions of the interviews, rather than a synthesis of the key learnings from the interview.

Are there any examples of of the articles that you would generate?  I think addressing this concern is critical to give voters a chance to understand the value you would bring with this effort.

Will all 16 articles be based on interviews you do, or sometimes just on other synthesized research that you've done on your own?

What if you don't line up an interviewee every week?  How will you generate an article for that week (if you wish to stick to your timetable of 1 article / week)?

The experience described by the team is related to what is necessary to execute the plan, but I recommend the inclusion of more information about the proposers and links to Linkedin or another reference source for your qualifications / work.

The budget described is reasonable and there are details on the budget allocation.

There is no clear definition of the content to be created, the suggested options are within the scope of the challenge, but I think it is important to describe in a more structured way what information about Catalyst will be prioritized.

When would the articles begin to be published? There is a definition of 1 article per week, for a period of 4 months, but the beginning of the timeline has not been described.
The proposer claims a reasonable amount of partially relevant experience, though no writing or production experience. It would be good to have some evidence of experience claimed (LinkedIn?)

The proposer seems to have some experiencein the area, although it is not easy to assess due to the lack of references. There is a youtube channel linked but with only a few videos, but no text directly referenced. It is not easy to assess the proposer capabilities in this way. It would be good to include more information to confirm the proposers capacity in delivering good quality articles.

It is likely for this targeted campaign to be implemented because it includes a straightforward campaign strategy. This proposal is feasible in the area of writing and posting articles across various mediums to promote Project Catalyst onboarding. The big question is in the visual content: How do you plan to deliver quality visual content to the segment of entrepreneurs. What is your visual content plan?

The proposal informs the content generation schedule, also informs that 16 articles will be generated and replicated on at least 15 platforms, it is not clear the number of hours that will be allocated, the proposal does not address whether it is necessary or not to assign a budget to pay a fee per publication on the aforementioned platforms. It is difficult to associate the content generation with the success criteria for this challenge, no key indicators are mentioned that allows to  evaluate the impact of the content generated.

Overall a valid proposal (albeit with some challenge misgivings). I remain neutral overall on the worth of this proposal as while I rate the commitment and energy of the team I'm torn on the outcome metrics being cost effective. Perhaps greater evidence of how each article will progress the message to the crypto community may have contributed to a improved submission.

A roadmap which explicit inform the dates and where the articles would be published would be a great information in this proposal. 
Besides that, a KPI to measure the success of the proposal would be of a great interest in order to validate the need of scale up the articles.

I think it's good that you have defined the number of articles, but after the submission of articles, are there any ways of measuring its impact?

Moreover, are there any metrics that you can provide for your current site with respect to traffic (ideally be region)?  Or even traffic that previous articles that you wrote that have generated high amounts of traffic / likes.  

I can tell that you're genuine in wanting to do this, since I saw in your channel that you were thinking about proposing this type of initiative way back in August.  I think this proposal would be stronger if you could proactively address many of the above questions / concerns, and it would definitely increase your chances of being funded.

There are details on the budget allocation. The plan describes the number of articles to be produced (at least 16) and the period of publication of the articles (1x week, for 4 months), which facilitates auditability.

There are no metrics or KPIs to assess proposal performance, which compromises the auditability.

I recommend the inclusion of this missing information, in addition to more details about the proposers, because despite being known in the Catalyst community, it is important that this be communicated in a transparent and clear way.
We can easily audit if the article are produced. What about metrics on quality, engagement etc? A plan to measure impact and meet the challenge goal would be useful.

Audit of this proposal would be easy, since the metrics are the amount of articles produced. Although, it would be good to have some metric about people who access Catalyst channels coming from the articles (links with tracked clicks for example). The goal in number of articles is there, but there is no information about the impact that would be expected, how many people would see that articles and other information like that.

This proposal needs a detailed roadmap and milestone. When do you plan to start posting the content? What day during the week will you be posting the articles? How many videos do you plan to publish? and by when?

The proposal completely addresses a specific use case for the storage of "documents" (NFTs) directly in transaction metadata, even supporting cases that exceed the 16kB transaction-size limit, and avoiding off-chain dependencies like IPFS or Arweave. Additionally, the proposal provides a well-thought-out emphasis on usability, relying on a light wallet that allows flexibility in the choice of trusted endpoints. The proposal acknowledges that full on-chain storage is not desirable for all use cases. The proposal is vague about privacy considerations and the details of how authentication "from artists' websites or business cards" would occur.

The proposed team has demonstrated skills and engagement with software development and Cardano. The detailed proposed solutions demonstrates solid planning and thorough understanding of the issues involved and the steps required to achieve full on-chain NFTs. Under "Blocking Problems . . .", it would have been useful if the proposal had discussed cryptographic issues and approaches related to the identity aspects of the proposal.

This proposal is a great implementation that mesh the cardano blockchain with the customer needs from any point of view. The proposal clearly articulates how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and for the stakeholders (in detail for insurer, investors and insurance company)

This is a complex business. The proposers don't specifically have insurance domain experience. 2 big questions. Normally insurance companies invest the float (premiums received) in risk assets. How will you compete when only holding capital in stable coins? As you are underwriting ratehr than directly writing insurance, how will you get to countries where insurance is not provided (as per the problem statement?)

The liquidity pool concept is innovative and has great promise, but the "payout" side of the insurance product is not well-described.  It is therefore difficult to assess the chances of overall success.  Blockchain technology offers great opportunity through network effects, so a lens on the consuming consumer community in the proposal would help reinforce the promise of the overall business model.

The proposal's listed three main goals address the challenge sufficiently. The estimated roadmap and budget allocation make this proposal appear feasible.

The information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

The proposal team is completed skilled and have a good tradeof of business and technical knowledge, so in my opinion will able to make surely a good pilot or MVP (I have 20 years experienced in information technology related to financial services industry). The proposal offers a realistic timetable to complete the work. 	The proposer has considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation

Auditability score = 2 because there are no KPIs listed in the proposal. There are a few targets in the time horizon so we could audit whether or not the team completed those tasks but extent of the success would not be possible to know. For example, they identify creating a partnership with 3MGAs or white label risk model providers from different sectors. So we could audit the number of partnerships they have created but I would not know how to assess the suitability of those partnerships.

Given that 6 months of funding is requested, it's assumed that the Q2 & Q3 milestones are most relevant.  These are clearly and reasonably laid out and form a good, measurable basis for the funding request.

It's suggested that proposed Q4 deliverables are not clear or achievable and that a Q4 "regroup" and learning / evolution phase would be valuable to set out the next phase of product evolution and deployment.

The proposal would drive greater confidence in success if the actual development milestones were outlined.  Proposal does a good job of outlining project outcomes, but project deliverables are not clear enough to support auditing and progress measurement.

There is already a test net block explorer by the Cardano foundation. However, it is missing features such as Cardanoscan has features to query tokens, policies, stake keys, stake key mapped addresses, pool updates, insights into all types of certificates, including the voting rewards.

Having a UI explorer for testnet likely reduces friction in developing on Cardano. Ease of use is beneficial in bringing more developers to the Cardano ecosystem. Thus, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
This tool would greatly add to the ability of developers to test their code before rolling out to the full production system.
cardanoscan is used quite extensively for development activities. There is a need for more than one blockchain explorer application to gain insight into the status and operations of transactions.
Every developer relies on testnet, this proposal may help developers in visualizing network data quickly which helps mainly for debugging purposes

As mentioned in the problem statement there are quiet a few information and insights that are not directly available in testnet from existing explorer and considering the provision of cardanoscan into testnet provides better insights and effectively reduce the grey areas
This proposal is self-explanatory in that essentially prior work be ported to the testnet. I have the upmost confidence that the proposer implements the proposal successfully.

The proposers are operating one of the most used blockchain explorers. They have demonstrated capability. The proposal is not offering major technical challenges and should be fairly simple to execute.
As far as I have seen cardanoscan provides data quick and mostly accurate data. High likely that they can build successful testnet version of cardanoscan.
Given the fact that the team of developers are running it on mainnet they are efficient eough to pull this off

The proposal is outlined with all the information that shows existing work and how it can be ported to the testnet - which is a request by many developers. The proposer further illustrates that the testnet explorer will actually require more maintenance as things are expected to break frequently.

The progress involves copying and migrating existing explorer to testnet. The proposal is for funding the initiative for six months, and the proposer aims to make it self-sustaining in six months. The progress is clearly measurable and can be monitored.
As we all have seen the effective implementation of cardanoscan, it would be easier to measure the implementation of testnet version of it.

They have clearly mentioned the details about the motivation behind choosing the problem statement and have explained about how they are planning to resolve it so the required information is out there

I feel that the proposal addresses the challenge as described in the Campaign Brief, and I think targeting university students and diaspora is a good way to target an appropriate demographic.  I would like to see this model or idea used in other international jurisdictions like South American countries, etc.
The problem and the solution are clear. The proposal is within the scope of the challenge. The goals set indicate a great potential for impact on the challenge.
Probably a worth proposal, however it is about bringing in new people, not encouraging meaningful participation from the community so it is not clearly addressing the challenge.

This proposal is well aligned with the challenge goals and it targets a very important group that can really contribute to the success of Catalyst. I believe that the expected number of people brought into Catalyst could be higher for such an effort. If 200 people get involved for 11k usd, the cost would be $55 for each one, which is quite high, but I don't see a problem with the budget itself, just believe that more people will get involved and the KPIs and metrics are conservative.
I thought Catalyst fund5 was the last funding round. Why do we need to include more people in Catalyst thereafter?

I would like to see a bit more detail on the marketing strategy (add venues like Telegram/Discord, etc.), and how 'onboarding' will occur, linking relevant past experiences to such activity.  Given this, I agree that this proposal can be successfully implemented.

The WADA team is very participative in Catalyst and in improving the Cardano ecosystem. WADA's expertise signals the ability to successfully execute the proposal. My only recommendation about the team is to include more information about the proposers or some link so that people who don't know WADA have access in an easy and transparent way. On the WADA website there are no details about the team members.

There is a clear and structured plan, I recommend the inclusion of more information on the subjects that will be addressed in the events, due to the fact that CAs and proposers need detailed information on documentation and guides for the onboarding to be more effective. We need to remember that the focus is on value onboarding, so new members need to understand the process and be able to bring not only numbers but quality to proposals and assessments (in the case of community advisors)

There are details on budget allocation as well.

Based on the team's experience, the proposal is feasible and I don't see any big risks in achieving the desired goals. The proposers are already committed to Cardano and Catalyst communities and have proven their capacity in previous rounds. Also, the plan is simple and well described.

As mentioned above, I would like more detail on expected feasibility (related to past experience, connection to BEN and how they operate for success, etc.) More on how the team has relevant experience to meet the challenge and succeed in their proposed solution.

There is clarity on how the proposal will address the challenge.

Reasonable KPIs and metrics have been described. There are details on budget allocation.

I recommend the inclusion of a roadmap, because the only information that allows us to understand the relationship of the proposal over time are the success metrics and they have long intervals of time (months).

Success criteria is very clear, KPIs and metrics are good for the proposal, and the risks as well covered in the mentioned Risk Framework. The only detail is to carefully keep track of everyone involved so the key metrics are accurate.

A highly localized community for sharing and nurturing ideas may not be suitable for a project aiming to span the world. There is a need for services scalable in reach with common minimum support to everyone in every part of the world.

There is no clarity in the problem, solution and in the proposal itself, the attached files do not contain details that assist in the understanding of the proposal. I did not find any information that clearly indicates the relationship of the proposal to this challenge. I recommend that the proposal clearly communicate its purpose and how it relates to this challenge.

The idea is good and there is some information to understand it, but I believe that more info could be added so it's clearer for someone who reads it for the first time. Also, some very nice information is present only in the attached images, but it would benefit a lot the proposal if it was in the text as well, since most voter will not open the attechments. This project would be a nice experiment for community self-governance in real life. I would like to see the sub-economy system better explained as well, I was excited when I read it in the 'describe your solution' section but its not clearly mentioned afterwards. A last point is that it doesn't seem that the proposalis very well aligned with the Challenge Setting, so it would be good to look for a better Challenge to place it.
This proposal does not seem to address the challenge of "How can we encourage more meaningful participation in Project Catalyst from community members in the next two funds?"
The proposers claim skill sets in "honing in on their skills and helping them find innovative solutions to life's toughest problems" however verifiable credentials are not enclosed in the proposal.

There is no plan, the proposal is very subjective, so there is no way to judge the competence of the team to execute the proposal. Several members are mentioned in the proposal's participation, but there are no details about the people who will participate. There is no budget breakdown.

I recommend communicating the intent of the proposal clearly and creating a clear, articulated and detailed plan, including the requirements present in the Catalyst documentation.

The proposer completed the self assessment checklist but clearly failed to include the required information on the proposal.

The idea is really good, but unfortunately it misses some important information about the plan, like how it would be implemented, how many people are expected to get involved with it, for example. It not clear what the money is for since there is no budget breakdown. I believe the proposer has all of this in her mind already, but it's not clear for the readers.
This project is not feasible as it lacks details on core team skills, experience, and details on how budget will be allocated.
The proposal is not clear in explaining the actual method for onboarding.  Mentoring and "new moon strategy" are unclear and open for interpretation.

There is no clarity about the problem, the solution and the proposal itself. There is no indication of how this proposal will address the challenge.

There is no clarity in the plan, no KPIs, no details about the people who will be involved in the development of the proposal, in the budget breakdown.

Some goals (3, 6 and 12 months) have been included but it is not possible to associate the relevance of these metrics since there is no reasonable plan.

I recommend that the proposal be communicated more clearly so that we can give appropriate feedback.

Since there is not much detail about the roadmap, milestones or how the project would be implemented, it is currently not possible to know how to audit the proposal. It would be good to break down the budget and set milestones related to each step. Also some KPIs relating the community's involvement with the project and some kind of feedback about how they are feeling during the experiment would be good metrics for this project, I believe.
This proposal doesn't include any roadmap. Please make sure to develop a step by step plan on how you plan to implement your proposal.

Flutter is a great development environment. As far as I know, there is currently no library to access Cardano chain, unlike web3dart for "web3 Ethereum".

Sharing a library would indeed ease the integration of Cardano in flutter apps.
Having another SDK für Cardano is a very good fit for the challenge. Flutter/Dart is a rising start and a good addition to the already existing/planned solutions.
I think it is good idea to built a library for flutter. To grow the cardano ecosystem you need tools to make things easier.
Targeting integrating into a popular web app/mobile app SDK, most definitely addresses the developer challenge.

Fluter is a google promoted next-generation framework for the cross-platform app generation. Availability of any form of API interface with Cardano in Dart will enhance app development in Cardano to a great extent.

Software Development kits (SDKs) constitute the corner stone of any dev ecosystem. This proposal aims to provide a Flutter SDK specifically for wallet operations.
Flutter is a new platform allowing developers to maintain only one code base for iOS and Android mobile devices, it also supports web and desktop deployment of the same base code... Flutter is still young (just a few years) as a platform but is backed by Google.
Making a Flutter SDK is very important as it will make Cardano an option for literally tens of thousands of developers on just all the existing consumer platforms.
Flutters will streamline mobile development for every mobile devices on the planet lowering the maintenance cost. Although the proposal depicted is a long term project and only sets the bases it is a very important one.

Without SDK, each developer needs to reinvent the wheel in order to solve common problems instead of focusing on their real project.

A quality SDK ensures reliability for all the application depending on it and rapid development. The availability of an SDK is many times what will make the difference when choosing a platform to develop on. Since there are many other blockchain projects competing with Cardano, the more SDKs there are the better.

The stated experience is very convincing and I am very happy that Blockfrost is mentioned in the proposal. If an api-gateway is used, the proposer can fully concentrate on the development of the flutter/dart components.

It looks like Richard has enough experience to realize the project. 100 paid hours should also give him some buffer to finish the project. An open point is how this library will be updated. This a key for future usage.
Detailed enough plan, and relevant experience presented. The technical details are well explained and consistent.
The proposer has claimed substantial experience in a large number of software technologies. His Github page has code from 2014 and has around 13 repositories.

The proposer's experience is important and totally fits the scope of his project. We just regret the lack of a direct link to his LinkedIn profile but it can be found easily: www.linkedin.com/in/richardeasterling/ . There are also links to his GitHub profile where we can see that he does have experience and has already started working on the project.
There is only one person behind this proposal but major part of the code will be open source and given the low budget there is not much risk and the benefit will be huge if the proposal is successful.
Work has already been started and a demo app is already available. So it's clear that the proposer is committed to this project.
Moreover the detailed plan shows that challenges and risks have been considered and that the project is well under way even before funding (some of the comments also confirm this).

The proposal of making a library & a demo wallet totally makes sense to me.

I think making sure the app also works on Android and iOS would better answer the overall challenge.
Possible KPIs were mentioned but sometimes no concrete figures were provided. The finalization after 2 months is pretty good. Not much auditing will be needed.
I would break down the roadmap. In 2 months i am finished is not enough. Also it would help to define KPI goals e.g 1000 Downloads after 1 year.
The plan and break down of the technical challenges to be resolved are well explained and consistent.

The progress can be audited by monitoring Github for updates and achieving the features provided in the proposal. The steps and the features expected out of the API are covered clearly in the proposal.

The progress of this project will be visible both through the demo app (closed source) and the open source SDK (Apache 2.0 license) on GitHub. The closed source demo app development is not part of the budget, although we may regret this, it is not a problem because the best way to make sure an SDK is actually useful is to create it to support a real use case, the demo app will thus ensures that the SDK is focused on what is truly necessary and actually works in real usage conditions. So it seems that all the conditions are here for this proposal to go as planned.

while this proposal identifies a great opportunity, it fails to identify a problem which fits within the challenge of scaling up DeFi within the Cardano ecosystem. There is a great pool of talent available, but it isn't clear how this proposal would boost DeFi. The proposal is aimed at generating teams which may or may not produce rather than delivering results which are directly tied to DeFi.

While the vision is to grow organic collaboration within the development ecosystem, the proposer does not provide specific details as to how this would be achieved.  A more detailed proposal with a clear structure would be required to avoid being redundant with Catalyst itself.

The focus of the proposal is not DeFi, but on onboarding and discussing mechanisms for team building. KPIS described are not KPIs but metrics, these metrics are not related to the metrics established in the challenge brief, which indicates a lack of alignment with the challenge. Although I do not see the alignment of this proposal with this challenge, I think it can be included in an appropriate challenge, such as the Value Onboarding Challenge.
While the proposal would likely be successful in connecting people in various ways, it isn't clear how this would boost DeFi.
Would have liked a little more relevant experience information, and more details on how the solutions will be staged.

The proposer has relevant experiences for the described proposal, is a participative member of Catalyst and one of the facilitators / organizers of the Catalyst Retros.

There is no structured plan, the proposal needs to be better detailed. There is no budget breakdown. I recommend including this information so that it is possible to judge the feasibility of the plan and the proposal.
No plan on how to actually achieve the stated goals. What formats are you going to use (voice [clubhouse?]chat, video, text, etc?). How are you going to pull people together?

No experience given about creating communities.
Unclear how the plan improves the current tools in place.
The proposal doesn't identify how generation of teams will create more DeFi users within the cardano ecosystem.

The metrics described are good indicators for this proposal, they would allow a successful understanding of the proposal, however the absence of KPIs (The items called KPIs are not KPIs, as they do not establish indicators or tangible numbers) makes it difficult to measure impact and compromises auditability.

There are no roadmap and budget breakdown, wich makes auditability difficult.

There is relevant information about the proposer's experience.

No clear plan on how to achieve goal, thus not possible to audit progress. This proposal is more a statement of something that needs to be done that a proposal on how to do it. No clear budget for the use of funds.

This is an ambitious project to eventually fund the building of housing in Africa through the issue of NTF's which earn returns based on rent generated by those houses. However the current proposal is purely to build one house, with further development requiring smart contracts on the Cardano blockchain. Perhaps this proposal should wait for a later round?

This proposal addresses the need to allow affordable housing to the community in Africa, by leveraging smart contracts in Cardano ecosystem to provide the financing aspect for them through investors using tokenomics approach.

The Empowa team consists of four members, with expertises in different area that are close to how the community works in Africa, as well as their plan partnership with Casa Real as well as WADA will definitely improve their chance of success. A more detailed plan can be found in their whitepaper => https://drive.google.com/file/d/1a6jfh2srNLXvNp0GSLyFAc-51DGBY6Br/view

The information in the roadmap and milestones is sufficient and can be audit against the project progress. The only question is: Does the Empowa project already started? I am asking this question because the roadmap state that the project began in Q1 January 2021 and that token pre-sale has occurred. Is this correct? Otherwise, the proposed project provides clear KPI's and milestones.

The team defined a concept called Empowerment scores that will be incorporated in the NFT cards to include a history around the property and empowerment it represents, such
as stories, images and video, the completion of the property's construction, tenant stories, community projects.
It is not clear how exactly this proposal it going to benefit cardano or the people in the african countrys.
Draft proposal. The description of the problem and solution are reasonable, but the absence of a plan and goals makes impact assessment impossible.

This proposal is aligned with the challenge, and the idea seems good. Although, the proposal lacks information about how this would be implemented, what mechanics it would use, a roadmap, dates, therefore more information in general. As it is its just an idea, should be worked into a proper proposal.

The proposal is very relevant, because it intends to work with, in my view, the biggest problem present in the African continent: hunger. If it were possible to improve this situation, and at the same time use token technology, promoting the activities of the Cardano community, how much the continent and our community would benefit, and the objectives of the challenge would be supported.

While the problem statement and solution do provide some glimpse into the idea of the proposal and  have the potential to result in an interesting plan, that could benefit both the African people and the Cardano ecosystem, the fact that the project description is missing entirely lead me to suggest a re-submission for a future fund.
The proposal consists of two sentences and a request for USD100,000. There is no plan. It is not likely to succeed
Given there are only 2 sentences in this proposal it is not likely it is going to be a succes. And for 100k funding there should be more information here.
Draft proposal. There is no plan in the description. I recommend including a detailed plan as per the Catalyst documentation so that we can give you appropriate feedback.

The proposal lacks information about its implementation and how the idea will become a product or platform. There alleged experience also is good but not sufficient to implement the idea since it would be needed some other different background such as blockchain devs and legal. More information should be included in order to properly assess the proposal's feasibility.

The author claims to have more than 15 years of experience as a professor in the financial industry, which is positive, given that the Cardano system is mostly a project of economics and technology. However, we do not know if the author is already familiar with Africa or even with blockchain systems. We also do not have a more detailed explanation regarding your professional journey. It would be beneficial to include some content in this regard, for example, a profile on linkedin. In addition, there is no apparent intention to form a team here, as this project would certainly need professionals from various fields. That is, the information about who would carry out the idea is, unfortunately, superficial.

The self describing 15+ years of experience in financial industries are not backed-up by any external, verifiable links. The project description field is missing entirely, therefore there are no details (budget, plan etc) that could be assessed.
There is not detail on how tokenisation of uncultivated land would occur. There is no plan given thus it is not a feasible project.
Like mentioned above it is not possible to properly asses this proposal. Please add more information and re-submit this for the next fund.

There is no information in this proposal to make it auditable. Important points are missing, such as: roadmap, milestones, budget breakdown, KPIs, key metrics, and delivery dates. As it is, it's not possible to evaluate its auditability.

In theory, this project is great. However, in practice, we have no information on how it would materialize. There is no action plan included, neither an explanation of how the financing money would be used, nor a forecast of the results to be achieved according to the measurement of time. The project is much, much more comprehensive. There are 50% of the unexplored areas. It is a lot of ground to be worked on. It is not said how these tokens would be generated, by what platform this project would be guided ... In summary, we have no content to be analyzed in this part, unfortunately.

As mentioned above, the detailed plan field is missing entirely, meaning that this proposal does not have any detailed, budget, any relevant experience links, any metrics and so on. An interesting proposition, I suggest re-submission for a future fund with all the required information added.

The proposal very effectively addresses the goal of bringing users and value to the network by creating a market for and onboarding users.

Job search is a stressful and tedious affair where personal information is often spread around multiple insecure websites, including SSN and critical PII. 

Integrating Cardano identity solutions and blockchain into the process would have a strong effect and bring a great deal of value to Cardano.

The proposal address one of the core area identified for blockchain application. Distributed trust setup. The proposal if successful can introduce blockchain to a large section of the job market. Verification of candidates and authentic mutual verification are major selling points for this proposal.

This dApps is a very good example of use case of the blockchain technology. And the idea itself is also very relevant and could bring a lot of attention to Cardano in a positive way. It also has a huge potential of impact, as it could be one of the largest platforms for online recruitment. All the benefits listed there are excellent and very well described and discussed. I work in a company that is nationally recognized as one of the most diverse in my country, my I still see many problems in this regard. I hope this kind of tool will help to address this in the near future.

The team has a very strong background with over 50 combined years of experience in the fields necessary to give this project a strong chance of coming to market.

The plan presented addresses the multiple areas of focus over a 5 year period giving clear milestones for each, targeting early revenue sources to maximize chances of success.

The proposers have verified credentials and established a track record in the recruitment roles, including roles in the Blockchain industry. The primary proposer has worked in IOHK. The proposal will likely be getting the best attention.

The IT and HR experience of the team is very much aligned to the proposal. Although, it does not mentioned if any of the proposers has experience in developing blockchain applications, and does not mention recruiting someone to do that. It might be a part of the plan that is not included in the proposal as well. But since the proposers are heavily involved in the whole blockchain ecosystem, I believe that it won't be a problem. Some cost breakdown would also benefit the proposal (besides listing what would be done, but also how much each part would cost, to give a better understanding of the rationale behind 55k).

The team has a clear plan to provide audibility, including biweekly progress reports. 

The plan includes clear and achievable goals broken up into 5 annual phases of progress with specific milestones for measuring and auditing progress.

The proposal has included an exhaustive document outlining all the steps. There are many unassessed technical risks particularly in identity management and in credentials management including selective protection of sensitive personal information to recruiters to avoid bias. However, the proposal fit for carrying out a bold experiment.

There is a list of goals related to the so called Phase 1 of the development of this application, besides the overall roadmap looking at the next 5 years. The Phase 1 roadmap could have some deadlines included to improve the proposal's auditability. Some key metrics and KPIs could be included in order to evaluate the performance of the platform during Phase 1, even though it's going to be used only at CF. Also, the plan should be included in the proposal prior to the voting phase. It says that the plan would be shared later, but this compromises both the assessment of the proposal's feasibility and also it's auditability.

This type of certification does work and there is demand (see IOHK's work in Georgia, Ethiopia); we are beyond the proof of concept phase as a community.

It is unclear what training organizations would be targeted. How would this DApp interconnect with existing solutions? Interoperability for this type of proposal is crucial to make it truly valuable.

The problem and solution presented make sense and can add to the challenge, but this proposal does not seek to deliver a working product/dapp in line with the challenge, but rather a proof of concept. A proof of concept doesn't meet the items / metrics set out in the Challenge brief and would have no relevant impact on Cardano's ecosystem and this challenge.

This proposal's problem statement doesn't identify a trust need that only blockchain can solve. The proposal also doesn't show what aspects of the idea would be else of funding which puts the delivery at high risk.

The characteristics of the information (certifications) that needs to be stored for a dapp to manage certifications does fit very good to blockchain technology. Therefore a very good fit for the challenge.
Certifications' secure management on blockchain technology has valid applications and is worth implementing. However, this proposal does not include enough information beyond this first draft.
This is a clear use case for Cardano DApps. There will be a lot of competition in this space and many projects will fail.

The proposal appears to effectively address the challenge. It seems to be somewhat aligned to similar proposals and even larger projects being touted for Africa. I was unable to ascertain what makes this proposal unique to those proposals.

It is not clear if  the proposal will be within the challenge goal, because the information's needed are not clear exposed, especially the role of the Cardano blockchain in the manage certification process. I think that it's need to clear explain HOW and WHAT, through use cases related to user's operations.

The proposal aims to create a subset of the solution which IOG is building for the Ethiopian Ministry of Education. Based on the team size of IOG it can be inferred that this proposal grossly underestimates the work involved in building such a system.

The proposer can not build this prototype alone. Approaching the web developer community as the final step in the plan (if technically feasible) conveys little thought and research on the technological side as well.

The plan is very brief. It appears the proposer has domain but not blockchain experience. More information on where the documents will be stored (IPFS, centralised data base etc), and how these will be accessed would be required for a successful delivery.

The experience described by the proposer is subjective and vague, I recommend including tangible information, such as experiences and related work, as well as a link to Linkedin or any means so that the community can verify this information easily and transparently.

The plan needs further refinement, there is no budget breakdown, no roadmap. I believe that some items of the proposal could be defined before the proof of concept.

The proposer has proposed a something which aims to discover the issues surrounding the idea rather than providing a solution. This means that it is highly unlikely that the proposal would yield results that the Dapp Challenge is looking for. In addition, the proposal should identify if these certificates will be used with self sovereign identity concepts, or simply stored on the block chain unencrypted forever for everyone to see. If the privacy aspects were thought out the proposal would get a better rating.  Sadly, anyone in the world is is still too broad of a reach to set feasible goals for since many individuals don't have access to internet.

The stated experience lack references and detail. What projects were done? Is there any public information available of them? What kind of knowledge did you aquire during the exection and how does it map to the proposed project.

The proposer has not provided enough information regarding his past experience, and when asked about it in a comment he has not provided any clarification. The proposal contains a good idea, but at this stage it looks more like a draft.

The proposal is basically for research/proof of concept. Future proposals would fund development.  In this sense, I think the project is feasible, but the proposer lacks the experience to make it truly attractive from a risk/reward standpoint. The proposal is very brief as well which does not give confidence.

The author describes himself as having a track record of successful projects in this specific domain but then fails to provide links or evidence of these. This simple addition would have made a vast difference to our ability to see the potential this project may have. As such I find it difficult to determine the likelihood of success for this proposal.

It's not simple to define if the proposer team states has the necessary experience, because it's clear the experience in vertical market (product owner and certification world), but I don't discover team member with experience in blockchain. The given metrics measure what the proposer wants to do, but the success of his actions is not defined. As mentioned above, the description of the solution is not well explained (e.g. what is the reason of technology mvp…), so the progress of this proposal is not simple to assess

The proposer claims experience in centralized data storage; he does not claim experience in Blockchain tech. He also does not specify the team that will be building this. There is a lack of clarity on the capability of the proposers.

It appears that the proposer is still trying to figure out how feasible a solution might be - and requesting $12,000 for something we know is already possible.

The information provided is insufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.
There is no information to allow audit of the proposal. I recommend that the proposer rewrite the proposal based on the Catalyst documentation and include information relevant to auditability.
the proposal identifies milestones but does not detail how the budget will be used to achieve them.

The proposal is about the creation of a proof of concept. Therefore it has a limited project scope and no detailed auditing will be needed. The objectives for the first phase (this proposal) are stated very well and this a good basis to audit a project with this scope.

As mentioned in the above assessments, the proposal does not provide sufficient information. There is no detailed plan, no budget description, no metrics. I'd suggest re-applying for a future fund in a more complex shape, as the idea behind it is interesting.

12k of funds are allocated for the proposer to produce research/proof of concept and possibly a prototype or acquiring developers to build one. No time frame is given. It will be highly difficult to assess the success of the project without a time frame or more specific goals.

The proposal is lacking sufficient information to audit the progress and likelihood of success. The use case seems a valid and indeed topical area of need. The proposer would do well to investigate areas of this proposal that could set it apart either through further collaboration or with information that highlights the differences.

Roadmap and milestones (incl. time horizon) are not described. The budget provided is very general and therefore I cannot say whether it is appropriate or not. There aren't more details how the budget is going to be spent, also I'm trying to discover attachment to deep dive the solution. Furthermore there aren't a lot of information about the proposer...

The proposal is not clear on the scope and scale of implementation. There is likely a requirement for an identity solution which has not been referenced. The project is not clear and it is difficult to audit.
Microinsurance protocols in the Cardano blockchain are a important usecase.

The availability of insurance products on blockchain will be a proof of concept for major adaptation. There is a large scope to leverage the blockchain for insurance processing. However, there are a large number of uncertainties, risks, and regulatory compliance requirements.

The proposal addresses the Fund 5: Grow Africa, Grow Cardano challenge. It addresses How Cardano can reach more people in Africa by offering insurance products to Nigerians. This project, if implemented well, will bring more users to the Cardano ecosystem and Atala Prism identity when onboarding new insurance clients.
The proposers have relevant experience, however this is not a small project, thus it is hard to agree two people can implement it successfully.
There is a lack of senior members with blockchain development experience.

The teams experience seams sufficient to the task. The budget seams reasonable. But the overall plan seams off to me. The challenges seam to me not really thought out. The challenge of building an insurance on top of the blockchain is very big. So the team might be up to it but that is not clear.

The proposal has set an enormous scope, from regulatory approvals, development of risk models, and overcoming of technical challenges. The proposer claims eighteen years of experience. However, there will be a requirement for a large team to handle the complete process.

More information is required on the feasibility of this project. It would also be good to understand how they will address the cost issue involved in claims validation which is inherently a high touch business to avoid fraud. No mention is made of how the entity will invest premiums and how this risk will be managed which is a large part of a successful insurance business.
The challenges of building an insurance on top of the Cardano blockchain and how they are going to be met is not really clear.

Progress can be audited, but it is difficult to measure the chance of sucess with the available date. The status of regulatory clearance and the policy of the Nigerian government toward crypto-based insurance will be a major hurdle. However, there is a reason to try this experiment, at least for trailblazing purposes.

This proposal have identified a very interesting problem that seems to suit the DeFi ecosystem well. The scope of the proposal is a bit hard to grasp, given the brief presentation. This proposal gives the impression of an loose idea rather then a 
well thought out plan. 
I will rate this proposition a (3), in order for me to stand by this proposal in the future, I would like a more elaborated plan on how you would go about implementing your idea. The idea is very interesting and I encourage you to refine the proposal for upcoming funds!
while the proposal includes a fantastic idea, a mechanism or solution for DeFi to solve it isn't shared.
Draft proposal, there is no clarity in the relationship of the proposal to the challenge. There are no plans / goals that indicate the relationship between the proposal and the challenge.

Whether such a project would benefit the Cardano ecosystem and the challenge remains to be determined. The proposal takes no effort in explaining such benefits or even explaining the subject proposed in detail, so this can not be considered adressing the challenge.
No details. Is this DeFi? What is medical credentialing. Please explain the problem and how this is a solution.

The proposer mentions that he have 18 years of experience within insurance. This kind of experience is very valuable to the Catalyst community, however, some kind of proof would increase the credibility.
No plan of actions are provided which makes this proposal hard to assess, there are also no arguments for the amount of requested funding. I would like a detailed plan and time table with concrete milestones and a budget. If you introduce the above mentioned information to your proposal, I could see this project as a very interesting candidate in the future. For now, it lacks too much fundamental information and I will give it a rating of (1).

While the proposal has the relevant experience needed for the credentialing/insurance side of trust generation, the proposal has high risk of failure since no developer or plan to obtain help from a developer is presented.
Draft proposal. There is no plan, because of this it is not possible to understand the relevance of the proposer's experience.

Taking a closer look at the proposer, it becomes clear that they proposed a lot of different things in different areas, some of the proposals are really brief and lack important information. This proposal however really does not explain anything at all and can not be considered a serious commitment without any kind of plan and any verifiable credentials of the proposer. Maybe consider proposing just one proposal in the future that is well structured and formulated and in a field where your competencies would predictably contribute to solve the challenge and already team up with people ahead of proposing it so you have realistic expectations of solving it.
No plan provided, thus unlikely to be successfully implemented. Proposer has domain but not technical expertise.

This proposal fails to provide information how feasible this project is to implement. This could be addressed if a roadmap with milestones and a time table were provided. This should be complemented with key metrics that can be measured in order to evaluate the projects success in the future if it were to be implemented. This project addresses a very interesting problem but it is too brief at the moment to be considered feasible. I rate this proposal a (1) in terms of feasibility but encourage you to update the proposal with the suggested information and submit your proposal in upcoming funds!
The proposal identifies an intuitive opportunity however it lacks detail surrounding that opportunity which would allow for the scope scale and timeline to be generated.

The proposal lacks any structure and fails to fulfill formal requirements. The purpose is barely comprehensible, especially as it lacks any details about the implementation. I advise you to take a look at other proposals for reference and closely read the guides for future proposals.
There is no plan. Please provide detailed plan with milestones covering technical, operational and marketing strategies and KPI's to measure success.
There is virtually no information that would allow 3rd parties the possibility to track the progress of the project.

I feel this team ought to come back in Phase 03 of their project named - Supernovae starting Q2 2021  to conduct "Smart Contract on Plutus Platform exploration" and collaborate with someone in the community on a specific piece of work for which they require specific support that can be named less abstractly.

Unfortunately, apart from the statements about the proposers' experience, there are no clear external references to their experience or work already done.
The costs are indicated only in a generic way, and even if several cost items are indicated, it would be really useful to have a cost breakdown, in order to evaluate better the amount requested. In the proposal is clearly indicated that the fund requested will not be used for the development of the platform and therefore the technical aspects are not mandatory requirements: at the same time it would have been very useful to have some technical specification of the technology/languages involved for the development of website / apps / smart contracts and the architecture in general that will be used for generating tokens, buying, selling and bidding.
All these technical aspects, even if external to the funding, would help to have a much clearer idea of ​​the project in general and its feasibility.
To be a successful card game needs work not just on the programming, but also the game dynamics. The proposal currently does not show much though on these, thus it is unlikely to be feasible.
It is unclear how tackling the perceived problem of lack of coverage for dental procedures would benefit the Cardano ecosystem and drive adoption.

It is not clear if  the proposal will be within the challenge goal, because the informations needed are not clear exposed, especially the role of the cardano blockchain in the "insurance" process. 
At the same time the statement of how problem is to be solved (e.g. "…provide high-value dental plans at a fraction of the cost…", "…easy for employees to manage and use their dental benefits…") is not deep specified and remain vague. I suggest to better introduce and explain HOW and WHAT, through use cases related to user's operations.

The proposal does not clearly identify the solution to the problem they propose and why it is relevant to blockchain technology. Is the proposal for an insurance company, a group funding platform, or an employee benefits company. Please clearly identify the company and who are the consumers (companies or individuals).

I understand the problem statement but it's not explained how a DApp would help solve this problem. It also doesn't introduce Promptous and it's current business model and how it would benefit from Blockchain technology. Given the lack of details of this proposal it is not possible to assess if it addresses the challenge or if it would increase the adoption of Cardano.

Draft proposal. It is not clear what the purpose of a dapp is to solve the problem described. There is no plan to assess the impact of the proposal and how it addresses the challenge. It is important to include more details and provide a rationale explaining whats the value proposition to use a blockchain to solve the problem described.

The linked website puts faces to the team, but does not speak to the required competencies to build a DApp or integration into the centralized apps provided by the team. A cleanup of the most obvious gotchas on the team and a more professional company section is expected for an incorporated business that has been around for some years.

The proposer team states that it has the necessary experience in vertical market (insurtech and dental), but I don't discover team member with experience in blockchain. The given metrics measure what the proposer wants to do, but the success of his actions is not defined. As mentioned above, the description of the solution is not well explained (e.g. how the funds will be spent, how the employees manage their benefits …), so the progress of this proposal is not simple to assess.
This proposal is lacking on details. Please provide who is on the team and how their background is relevant to this initiative as well as a schedule for what you aim to achieve.
without even a simple plan provided this is just an idea, not a proposal. Unlikely to succeed in current form.

The Promptous website is well designed, but besides that it's not clear what experience the team has to develop a functioning DApp. There's a very brief explanation on what's the intended purpose of the DApp, but no details on how this will be achieved. There is no plan presented, no technical details and no budget breakdown. As it stands this is not a executable proposal, just as idea.

Draft proposal. There is no plan. There is no information about the team's experience in developing smart contracts. Considering that the proposal is for the development of a dapp it is essential that there is a qualified person for the development of smart contracts.

This proposal lacks details, such as what exactly is going to be built and how the funds would be allocated. Since it is unclear what the end goal should look like, success and progress cannot be sufficiently audited.

Roadmap and milestones (incl. time horizon) are not described. The budget provided is very general and therefore I cannot say whether it is appropriate or not. There aren't more details how the budget is going to be spent, also I'm trying to discover attachment to deep dive the solution. Futhermore there are a lot of information about Promptous platform (that seems to be just realized), but there aren't information about the connection with blockchain application or benefit for Cardano community...

Please describe what the goals are for this project as well as 1)how many users are desirable to be profitable 2) how funding is possible as an insurance company at the start 3) how users will find this company 4) why users will use this company and 5)what kind of interface is being proposed (web, mobile etc).
No detail on what is actually being done thus feasibility cannot be assessed nor whether it addresses the challenge.

The proposal lacks all details that are required to measure it's progress and impact. There are no milestones presented, no KPI's or criteria of success. It would not be possible to audit the progress of this proposal.
Draft proposal. There is no information related to auditability. I recommend including details according to the Catalyst documentation.

Yoga teaching and prescriptions are not standardized even in India leading to a large number of self-claimed Yogies.  There is an urgent need for a decentralized and verifiable certification in the emerging field. The solution proposed is ideal to solve this specific issue.

In addition to using transaction metadata to store certificates and contracts, the proposal provides the novel use case of recording yoga sequences/prescriptions there. It also incorporates innovate use of Wolfram Language Entities. However, it is not clear whether Atala PRISM will be publicly available during the Q3-Q4 timeframe of this project, so that might put the identity-related aspects of the project at risk.

The attachments to the proposal outline a sufficiently detailed plan, but it appears that the team will rely significantly on consulting with IOHK to mitigate execution risks. Also, it may not be realistic to put use of Atala PRISM on the critical path to success, given that PRISM's public release date has not been announced.

The project proposal and checklist are detailed. The developer support will be available after the smart contract feature is rolled out. The proposers aim to recruit pioneers to write the smart contract. No inherent developer capability is claimed. I feel this will not hinder the project.
More information should be provided on the goals. Why is the blockchain required to manage metadata of distributed creations. Is goal 3 planning to use ADA for payments or rewards in their system?

The proposal does not outline a staged development process, so it would be difficult to gauge progress towards the final goal. The final goals, however, are defined in the proposal, though they could have been specified in concrete technical detail, rather than briefly and abstractly.
More information could be provided on why Panama is an ideal place to start this and how much impact this will have.

Incentivizing entrepreneurs through raffle draws and providing guidance, space, and advertisement for start-ups is a novel idea. There is a good chance the scheme will be able to attract capable people.
Based on the Linked-in profile enclosed, the proposers have substantial experience in organisanising and managing projects of this size.

The team appear to have suitable experience to entertain such a project although I am unable to ascertain if they have worked on similar projects previously. Would do well to provide further details in experience. Great to see that they have started the project, shows initiative and commitment. The plan does need further revision, need to tell us how this campaign will work.

From my understanding the project has two goals and both of them need to be addressed in detail and separated from each other in order for the proposal to be better understood: 1. the staffed centres for online/offline meetings, and 2. the raffle events. As it stands now, it's not very clear how both these undertakings will be completed and how successful they would prove to be. The metrics, budget and other specific information would be easier understood if they would be separated per objective.

The proposal is not very clear in the write-up regarding the revenue generated from the sale of the raffle(?) and how the raffle will be sold. The gift of stake pool equipment as the price is also not clear if the equipment for a gift is sourced from the sale of the raffle, then why the amount is included in the budget for the proposal is not clear.

The milestones are clear, although some more information in this regard could be added, but there is enough for an overview. Goals and ROO are good indicator of success, and it would be good also to include in the auditability of this proposal some more time of self-funded rounds, which is the goals, to be sure the money spent with all preparation is not used only for one single round. Key metrics, or key performance indicators as mentioned in the text, could be improved to include more metrics regarding new proposers outside from Catalyst, which is the main objective of this challenge, as well as community engagement, and possibly Catalyst winners that have participated in this incubation center.
There is no real detail as to what this proposal has to do with metadata on the blockchain. Whilst it may be an interesting use case, the details of the proposal need to be fleshed out.

The proposal is aiming to develop a costing model based on using industry and company-specific metadata. The details of the type and manner in which the data is currently existing will help in the assessment of the effectiveness. How will this model be released for community befit is also not clear from the proposal.

the problem statement doesn't have enough detail to grasp how large the problem is, who it is a problem for, or why it matters. In addition, it isn't clear why this needs to be in Metadata of a transaction. Why Couldn't this data be shared through an open API instead?

This proposal is really short and except for the website there is not much content. It is hard to tell if this is acually an issue because of a missing detailed description of an actuall proplem. It kinda reminds me of Dentacoin which is considered a failed project. The proposal doesn't really show how a blockchain is going to solve this and how it is goning to benefit our community.

The proposal does not mention using Cardano transaction metadata, but that is the core requirement for the Metadata Challenge. (Its mention of "company-specific metadata" is not related/connected to Cardano transaction metadata.)

Draft proposal. The description of the problem and solution are within the scope of the challenge, patient records are data that can be recorded with the help of metadata, but the absence of a detailed rationale and plan makes it impossible to assess the potential impact on this challenge.

Whilst the proposer may have the experience to produce the project, there are not detail on what it is actually going to produce and thus it is hard to determine if it would be likely to be successfully implemented
The proposer is involved in a dental insurance space therefore there is a very good chance that they will be capable of completing the project.

While there is plenty of experience in the insurance field an unknown amount of blockchain experience is presented. It is also unclear how the proposer would convince carriers to share this data, or how the data would be provided to the chain in a trustless manner.

In my opinion ''Blockchain''-Experience doesn't really show the voter what kind of experience the Team has. The team didn't introduce themselves. The proposal doesn't ask for a lot of funds. But it is not clear for what the funds are used for. If it was a serious Insurance-Protocoll the requested funds should be higher to succeed.

The proposal does not describe a plan to utilize the metadata capabilities of the UTxO model--"development of a actuarial model" does not constitute such a plan--, nor does it state that the proposers have Cardano-specific experience.

Draft proposal. There is no information about the plan and this prevents assessing whether the team is able to implement the proposal. The team has experience in the dental insurance market, but there is no information about technical experience for the development of an application/software.

I recommend that the team submit a proposal with details so that we can give appropriate feedback and assess the feasibility.

The proposal needs to bring out the type and current source for data to be put on the blockchain. However, the proposal is to develop the model to estimate the cost based on "off-chain " metadata. Therefore the effectiveness of the proposal in exploiting the Metadata feature of Cardano is not clear.
Given that the proposal fails to share what metrics support the problem statement, it is extremely difficult to judge success of the proposal.

The proposal is too short to properly assess it. There is unfortunately no roadmap and no Clear understandable description of problem and solution. I would recommend to re-write your proposal so the community sees clearly what you're trying to achieve and then re-submit for the next fund.
The proposal does not include a timeline, measurable/quantifiable metrics, or any specific deliverables.

Draft proposal. There is no information on auditability.

I recommend that the team follow the Catalyst documentation to detail the proposal.

The description of the problem and solution are reasonable and within the scope of the challenge, but the goals set out in this proposal do not indicate that the proposal will have a relevant impact on the key metrics set out in the Challenge Brief. 

The timeline and deliverables indicate that in 6 months a closed alpha will be delivered. There is no forecast for the launch of dapp described in the timeline. This indicates that the proposal will not have a relevant impact on the challenge, as there will be no use of the protocol by users and there is no expected date for the launch of a functional version.

The past experience of the developer on Github doesn't show any concrete implementation.

The plan presented partially addresses how the solvability risk is handled.

The proposal is a draft and there is mention in the description that details will be added. The problem statement is reasonable, but it is not clear how the decentralization relationship of Catalyst can address the challenge, there is no indication of a relationship with distributed decision making. I recommend that the proposer make the idea clearer so that we can understand the proposal and give appropriate feedback.

This idea would address the challenge, but as it stands, it is only a idea, not an executable proposal. Lacking many details as i'll mention in my assessment notes below. Perhaps the proposer could join the NTF-DAO community that is working on a more concrete proposal to solve the same problem.

A decentraliced Project Catalyst sounds beneficial to our community. The thing ist that most of the blockchain projects are a little centralized, but as long as the voting happens on the blockchain the most important part is decentralized.
Further decentralisation is a valid concept although the author needs to expand their idea so that it can be judged on its merits.

Discussing the current state for Catalyst should always be open, even if it is a still being developed. The community could always extract beneficial information and decision making ideas from such a topic. Yet the problem is not additionally described and no plan offered.

There is no relevant information about the proposer's experience or details about the proposal concept and its details. The proposal is just a draft and needs to be further worked on and clarified so that we can give appropriate feedback.

The detailed plan section describes the thoughts of the proposer, but a plan is not presented. No description of how each of the loosely mentioned steps will or could be achieved, no timelines are and no budget breakdown are presented. It's not clear what experience the proposer has to implement this, besides his/hers enthusiasm.

The proposal sounds more like a thought process that an actual idea which can be implemented successfully. There is no information about the proposer or the team behind it. Also there is no budgetplan on how the 20k are used.

Experience and plan are very minimal at this stage so difficult to gauge what the project is about and what it can deliver. There is no way to actually review experience of the author and the plan has not been laid out or budgeted accordingly. If the author were to further engage with the community and perhaps collaborate around details the proposal may be suitable for a future fund.

The self-described experience is very poetic, yet obviously it doesn't offer any relevant information. The proposer needs to add links to his previous experience and a detailed plan, metrics and budget description.

There is not enough information to judge the feasibility and allow the auditability of the proposal (there is no roadmap, metrics, plan and any other relevant details to allow a concrete evaluation). It is not clear how the proposal will improve decision-making. The proposal needs to be worked on so that we can give appropriate feedback.
The proposal lacks most expected details such as milestones and metrics of success that are required to measure progress and effectiveness

The proposal is really short, has no roadmap or clear definition of success. I would recommend to re-do the proposal when it evolves from the idea that it is now to a proposal thats ready to be funded. Good luck!

The proposal is simply lacking in assessable content and this makes it difficult to review. The author has a valid concept but has not really teased out any details that give insight into what is planned. I would recommend scaling down the budget and focussing on delivering something that might add to the knowledge base of decentralisation. Such as a literature review or small scale community views survey.

As stated in the above assessments, the project lacks a detailed description, budget, metrics, expected launch date - all included in the self-assessment checklist. Suggest re-submission to a future fund with the missing information added.
A good insurence programm on a blockchain could bring a lot of benefits. But you can't tell from this proposal how exactly they think they will manage to do this.
Insurance is a dirty business and I am not sure this is the best method for scaling up DeFi. I do not see where this fits into blockchain tech.
The problem identified is easily understood but it  What isn't clear is how this will interact with the community in a decentralized finance manner on a public blockchain.
