Achieving decentralisation of claim validation could be awesome. No detail as to how this would actually work. There are large governance and fairness issues here. How do you deal with disagreements on rejected claims?

Draft proposal. The solution statement is not clear, I recommend greater clarity in the communication.

There are no plans or goals to assess whether the proposal is in line with this challenge.

I miss an explanation of what kind of blockchain experience the team has.
There's no real introduction of the team
Theres no clear roadmap.

The collective experience of the team is impressive. I think this idea can be a successful business model that can help keep peoples mouths healthy. The link between healthy gums and lower heart dieses should be mentioned and could be another sales point.
There is no detail in this plan. Please provide detail on technical, operational and regulatory issues.
Draft proposal. There is no plan that can indicate the relevance of the team to the proposal and the feasibility.

There is almost no information on the proposal. This makes it really hard to asses. An insurance on Cardano must be really complicated so a risk assessment would be beneficial. Also a roadmap would be really nice. Then to asses a proposal a link to a website unforunately isn't enough.

This proposal is very bare bones with limited information provided. How much ADA will someone receive for a perfect score on the examination? What about if you need multiple cavities filled, no ADA for you? How long does it take to establish loyalty and where is the funding coming from once the requested funds run out.

This proposal identifies a real issue where there is an expensive cost to trust which could be helped by blockchain. However it doesn't include any metrics on just how large that problem is. How many 'certifications' 'documents' and 'expert opinions' exist in the current insurance space and which could be eliminated by use of blockchain? how much time do adjustors / claim processors spend on generating trust?
No plan provided. Please detail operational, marketing and technical milestones to allow progress to be audited.
While the proposal itself is very scarce, the provided links in the comment section aid in understanding the value.
The proposal seems a little lite on content to convince me that it effectively addresses the challenge. Further revision and collaboration with the community to grow the idea is required.

The problem statement is very vague; It doesn't explain what problem bringing NFTs to the DEFI market would solve. The proposer provides links to several other NFT related projects, but they all seem very disparate. The link to nftfi.com (NFT collateralized loans) sounds the most like what the author is describing in their detailed plan, but this is not clear. What are the other DEFI platforms that users are investing in? Would also recommend to check spelling of acronyms to improve clarity of proposal.

While the proposal generally seems to be a useful idea to utilize NFTs and connect them to decentralized finance, NFTs are (despite currently beeing hyped) so far still a niche thing that is not understood or utilized by a lot of users, hence this project will most likely only have limited effect on the challenge of successfully providing benefit to as many users as possible. Even more so given the fact that a very vague plan without any information about how it is going to be implemented is presented, which makes this more a pitch than a proposal and unlikely that it was well planned.

wNTFs are being discussed and used in other DeFi ecosystems, and it's important to develop something like this in the Cardano ecosystem as well. Although, the proposer only describes the wNFTs and how the system work, but does not give enough detail about its implementation and how it would connect to the ecosystem. More information is needed in this regard.

The one sentence paragraph of the description doesn't make it clear what the proposal is about, yet the links provided have given some insight into what the proposer might have wanted to suggest. Highly recommend revisions to the proposal and reapplying with a re-written one in the next fund.

Draft proposal. There is no clarity as to which problem this proposal seeks to solve. The problem statement doesn't describe a problem. The absence of a plan, goals or metrics makes it impossible to identify how the proposal addresses the challenge. I recommend that the proposer detail the proposal so that we can give appropriate feedback.
The listed experience is not enough to warrant a high confidence in a successful implementation. No budget has been listed either.

I was unable to verify the experience of the proposer although I am inclined to think they understand NFT's and the potential marketplace. The plan lacks any real detail about how this proposal will proceed. Links to work already completed or pending would have been good to see.

The proposer does not give much information as to how the 20000 ADA requested would be used. The proposer does not clearly explain what their role would be in implementing this project. The proposer has relevant experience as a software engineer which might be useful in implementing smart contracts for example, but doesn't state if they have any experience with implementing a smart contract. It would be useful to specify the specific skills required to meet that target goals. They also do not state any experience with decentralized finance beyond being an entrepreneur.

While, at least according to their linked in profile, the proposer has experience in software development, the plan presented does not indicate that the proposal has been planned in depth or that the cost assessment has a solid foundation. The current plan makes it seem unlikely that the proposal will be implemented with success.

The information about if it's a team or a single person committed to the project or not should be included. It seems to be a task for a group of developers, so if a single person is committed so far, a plan for hiring should be included. Also, the budget should be broken down to better explain the required amount, and related to a roadmap.

The proposer describes vaguely his past experience, but provides no proof of it. The single phrase plan does not convey a a clear idea, has some spelling errors, giving the impression that it was written in a hurry.

Draft proposal. There is no clarity as to what this proposal seeks to develop, there is no plan, just a draft idea for wrapping NFTs. Without a solid implementation plan, there is no way to judge the aptitude of the proposer in relation to the experiences described.
While a overview of the functionality has been provided, there is no information on how to implement this. Success/progress is not defined.

Like the idea and recognise that the proposal has merit but cannot assess feasibility without further information. I would recommend proposer establish further collaboration within the PC community to further this idea.

There are no clear goals or milestones so it is difficult to assess the target for success. If the proposal is to "create a platform to provide NFT collateralized loans on Cardano", then it can be assumed that it effectively addresses the challenge as it would provide additional utility, but it is unclear if this is the actual intent of the proposal.

While the proposal provides some examples about the concept in action, it does not present any roadmap or milestones on how the plan is going to be implemented. In this form it can mot be considered very audible

The plan to develop a platform to negotiate wNFTs is not included. The proposal should include information about roadmap, KPIs, milestones an other information to make it auditable. Definition of success is not clear as well, and risks are not mapped. It is not possible to assess its auditability as it is.
detailed plan required to assess feasibility. More information required on exactly what is intended to be done to see how it addresses the challenge.
The proposal would be better re-submitted in a future fund with a revised project description, that would also contain a roadmap, a detailed budget, metrics  etc.
Draft proposal. There is no information to audit this proposal. I recommend that the proposer elaborate the proposal based on the Catalyst documentation.
While the need for blockchain is openly questioned (and rightfully so), it is an important step into the direction of incorporating real world assets into Cardano.

Due to the type of proposal, I think it might actually be difficult to categorize this between NFT/Integration. The proposal starts by talking about NFTs, but then moves onto the integration of a real life use-case and website. I found it hard to assign this rating as there's nothing wrong with the proposal in that regard, just hard to stick it in a single category.

Original idea to explore the NFT market applied to living things. 
This doesn't really solve a problem yet, but it would be interesting to see where it leads to. the community might even expand a little bit by interested people that really, really want one of these bunnies.

The proposal gives an interesting usecase for applying NFTs to living things. While it is rather experimental than providing a very big use to a wide user range, it still explores an interesting usecase at low cost. It would be expected that the proposer provides detailed documentation of the process and the implementation if funded in order to aid other developers with similar use cases. The project could have a more defined relation to blockchain.

I found this proposal very different, I have never heard of an "adoption" of animals in this way. From what I understand, it is a kind of sponsorship, in which the user would pay to interact with a real animal through transactions in cryptocurrency, on a specific website for that. The idea is good when it comes to innovation and to focus on the use of technology that Cardano develops, and it is certainly a new way of looking at this relationship between people and pets. However, I am not sure if the public will find the proposal interesting and will be open to doing this, I think it is a matter of trying and observing the results. In my view, the proposal has a chance of working very well or being just an attempt that did not get much return, because it is very different from the other activities in this medium. A very important point to be considered is how these animals will be treated. An animal is not a toy, it should not be seen as a source of profit. If, for example, 4 users wish to play with the same rabbit on the same afternoon, that animal will be exhausted. I think it is essential to plan and supervise the treatment and welfare of rabbits very well, so that the project does not become just a source of profit that exploits animals.

The combination of experience listed, the mentioning of wordpress, a potentially problematic implementation of the centralized value for token-holders, the mix of taking plutus classes while outsourcing some work to another developer (for little money) is unlikely to succeed exactly as planned.

It can be imagined how relatively easy this proposal can be implemented; however, the surrounding factors are not in favor of success.

A project like this is bound to draw some attention in an online community. To my knowledge, nothing like this has been done yet. 
Once you start upscaling, are you sure there is enough space and manpower to facilitate all these animals?

While an actionable plan is presented, no information can be found on the proposer so the credentials cannot be verified. All that could be found is a pictureof a couple of bunnies and another cryptocurrency project that the proposer is apparently working on that is still in early development stage and seems to be rather a joke project about verfying a cat chasing mice.

I understood that the proposal was launched by a group that already owns the animals and is already developing the project (for example, they already have a logo, a brand concept, etc.). They have also had experience in raising animals. They also clarify in the proposal what kind of professionals they will hire if they are financed and what they will do. So I think that this issue of preparation in relation to the project is well defined.

The work that needs to be done, while not outlined explicitly, can be imagined. While it is generally feasible, the budget may not suffice, especially if an outside developer has to be consulted.

The missing/pulled IG page and lack of engagement on Reddit is problematic as those are mentioned as strong points.
This doesn't serve an innate need, thus needs to become desired. A social media marketing plan would be a good addition.

The project is clearly still in early stages. 
I've indentified a passionate and experienced proposer, but it needs more clarity. 
A roadmap is present and the asked budget is correctly set, but it needs a risk assesment: What happens if a bunny dies? If a bunny spawns more bunnies through breeding. Will the offspring be property of the holder of the mother bunny or mother and father bunny holders or will the baby bunnies get forfeited to the io? Those are all questions that I couldn't find a clear answer to in the proposal.

Is Instagram account working? I wasn't able to visit see it when following the URL to visit the site.

Side note: What happens when a rabbit dies? What happens for the NFT owner, what happens to the NFT? Is there something done to indicate the NFT represents a deceased rabbit?
The roadmap and the budget are defined clearly, while some details about the implementation and the relation to blockchain remein undefined.

The group that made the proposal has a plan that measures actions in relation to time, on a scale of 3 months, 6 months and 1 year. They clarify well what objectives they intend to achieve according to the project time, and as mentioned in the item above, they already have a predetermined team structure, with the respective values that each part of a whole will need. They attached a link that talks more about the progress of the project, in other words, I believe they were very precise when it came to planning. In my view, the most problematic point of this project is the question of acceptance and how they will take care of the animals. It is also a little open to question whether the project will need more funding beyond the initial amount that was requested to be able to continue. But as the team determined that the money will be used to build the site, buy food for the animals, etc., I believe that from that initial investment the project would become self-sufficient.
Creating a game/tool for children to learn to develop can help foster creative solutions from young minds. An interesting approach to the challenge.

According to Mckinsey research, Africa pharmaceutical industry jumped to $20.8 billion in 2013 while Goldstein Research predict the market will be worth USD 56 billion to USD 70 billion by 2030.

According to Mckinsey research, Africa pharmaceutical industry jumped to $20.8 billion in 2013 while Goldstein Research predict the market will be worth USD 56 billion to USD 70 billion by 2030.

Two key challenges are infrastructure and funding. Africa have many world class talents and researcher but lacking in the support by the government and local funding. Objective is to solve funding and centralised repository issue and these have been highlighted in the proposal.

Neglected diseases are a huge problem in many african countries and this idea is sure to give good impulses and funds to mitigating that problem, so it will sure help to grow the cardano ecosystem and make it more popular within those countries that would benefit from such a project. In addition to this, the knowledge of this blockchain will also increase within medical research and open-source research communities, which males the proposal even exceed the challenge of just growing cardano in Africa. The additional benefits fore society outside of the scope of the challenge are obvious from the proposal and have the potential to be quite massive.

The proposal aims to implement the "Flemingo Protocol," which provides a mechanism for open-source medical research funding. The proposal is revolutionary and can be a prestigious experiment. There are many unassessed challenges and technical risks; however, this proposal is worth taking risks.
The proposers have a good range of experience. The plan is highly ambitious. It is hard to know if the proposal will succeed, but the gains if it does make it a worthy proposition.

There are three names suggested in the proposal. These names are the subject matter expert in their field. 

I am suggesting to add more names with better credential to cover the whole ecosystem including finance and marketing. Highlighting project teams focusing only on subject matter expert will Will cause investors to be disinterested. 

Investor's level of confident is not high if looking from the angel of key personnel and the experience.

The experience and connections of the team make it quite obvious that they know what they are doing. The connections also show that they are in dialogue with affected actors, which is an important aspect of successfully implementing such a project. The plan itself seems thought through and detailed and likely to be implemented, especially as it builds up onto existing concepts.
The proposer has expertise in the related field and has presented an exhaustive cited paper. The team in Flamino is likely to of sufficient strength to undertake this process.
The proposal clearly meets the challenge. It is a complex subject an the are many difficult problems to resolve, thus feasibility is hard to asses. This is a high risk, high reward proposal.

Proposal provides complete information and addresses the methodology thoroughly in a simple language. It is not too technical and easy to understand.

Effectiveness to achieve the objective will be based on the methodology presented in the proposal and whitepaper. The high level roadmap (timeline) looks reasonable to achieve.

The proposal is very well written. It provides detailed information about the problem and the employed solution, a profile of the proposers that makes them credible and indicates that they are up to the challenge and also connected with affected people. The whitepaper is very detailed and shows that the idea is well planned, all of which makes it possible to assess this project to be highly likely to be feasible.

The white paper lays out clear plan objectives and likely contingencies. There is a requirement for substantial research for successful implementation. However, the proposal has a symbiotic relation for Cardano, and success can be mutually beneficial.

The proposal is taking a unique approach to quality onboarding rather than quantity. It may well grow substantially over time. I see this as a valid pathway to onboard people whom are shy about plunging headfirst into Project Catalyst.
It would have been great to proof that the problem statement is accurate. If the takeaway that more participation is desirable for Cardano to grow, the answer is yes.

I agree with the statement "there will never be "one right way" to onboard people to Catalyst". There proposed personalized workshops in addition to the townhalls can help many proposers and other stakeholders. These workshops when hosted on youtube can become a record for future rounds.

The proposal works with the human nature of 'fear of getting judged', of thinking that our idea might not be as good as we think, and sometimes it freezes us, causing a bad impact in the Catalyst community. That said, creating a non-judging, free speech environment could add value to the community, and it clearly could 'encourage more meaningful participation', as the challenge asks.
However, I do think that if someone is too scared to participate in some way in the Catalyst project, I might assume as well that they will be scared to participate in these workshops too. In order to avoid this problem, maybe some workshop that people can enter as anonymously would help.

The problem and solution are clear and reasonable. The proposal is related to the challenge and can play an important role in value onboarding. The workshops can identify painpoints in the onboarding process of new Catalyst members, through the concept of first principles approach.

The workshops are focused on identifying the painpoints of the onboarding process and the results would be used to create proposals to solve these problems.

Although the idea is promising, there is no indication of a significant increase in participation / onboarding in the following 2 Funds (which is established in the metrics of the Challenge Brief), since the proposal is about the identification of problems.

This could be interesting. It assumes the proposer can find the new commers to bring in. Is town hall advertising enough? Is $10,000 for 12 catalyst skeptics submitting a proposal a good return on investment?

The idea is very good, we need to find ways to lower the entry barriers for new comers. The goal is to aim for Funds 7 and 8, as mentioned, and to bring 12 people in each one. This means that the cost per 'Catalyst Skeptic' would be $$416, which would be a bit high. I would like this to aim for bigger numbers so the impact would be higher. Since it would be a weekly meeting, $500 per week seems to be too much for preparation and running the workshop. I believe that the word 'skeptic' also is not a good fit here, because I'm not sure that skeptic people would be reached andwould like to participate. Also, some other onboarding initiatives are going on and I believe that some partnerships could be done.

I thought the idea was very important. In fact, the Catalyst project may seem like a very vast universe and one that requires a very high level of improvement of knowledge and techniques to participate. Thus, an action aimed at clarifying the doubts of possible new members and better detailing how things work in the community can solve a large part of these prejudices. This idea dialogs directly with the objectives of the challenge, because it will be a factor that will help the growth of the community and will also promote more integration among the members, it seems.

The proposer has the correct experience to ensure the proposal is implemented successfully. I like that they have previously engaged in earlier Funds and have insight into some of the barriers that newcomers to Project Catalyst are likely to encounter. I particularly like the line" some people will discover they have an exciting proposal to write".

Gimblelabs has been delivering training materials on Cardano-related technology. The highly successfully NFT project SpaceBudz had attributed its success to the availability of free API support by Gimblelabs. Therefore the proposal has enough credentials and experience to implement the project.

Although the proposer seems to be a long time active in the Catalyst community and the website provided guide to some good sources of information, the proposal itself does not provide KPI, does not explain how the budged should be spent and, which is a critical situation for me, it seems that it is not scalable – it seems that just one person wants to build the workshop and work together/mentor lots of people (if it scales up). Thus, accounting the feasibility I think that the whole process should be better explained (which platform would use, how it would actually work, how many people would mentor, credentials, etc).

The proposer is a member of Gimbalabs, one of the winning proposals at Fund2, which has been promoting improvements for the Cardano community. The proposer has relevant experiences for the proposal.

Although the proposal describes an excellent rationale to justify the idea, there is little information about the workshops and considering that there will be 8 weeks in each Fund, I think the more detailed definition of topics for the workshops is important.

There is a description of the budget breakdown, but as there are no details on the duration of the workshops, this makes it difficult to understand the feasibility of the budget.

There is a clear and objective timeline, but the Fundind rounds have been modified, and from Fund5 they will last for 8 weeks and not 6 as was foreseen in the proposal (this modification was recently decided, so there would be no way for the proposer to know) and this may require a modification to the plan.

I believe that the proposer had a very good experience and based on his participation in Gimbalabs, he's very well prepared to run such workshops. The plan is clear, and budget is well described, even though it seems to be a bit high for the proposal.

In my opinion, the team that will develop the project is still a little abstract in the text. Initially I did not understand if it is a single author, who already makes the idea happen (as you can see on the attached website, which talks more about the concept of the project and has links with some videos for youtube), or if there are several people. However, this is clarified when we look at this site, which has a tab that shows who is involved. The author of the text claims to be a veteran of the Catalyst project, but has not specified since when he participated, which would be beneficial to validate this information. He also says he is very involved in the issue of training people, which is evidenced by the fact that the project is already underway, which always brings a lot of credibility to the request for financing.

I felt the proposer has provided enough information to assess feasibility. They have included personal experience to highlight the hesitation that newcomers will feel towards PC and offer a pathway to onboarding these people. They may be inundated with applicants. I would like to have seen a little more on 'working with skeptics' as the crowd may require some careful handling for efficacy sake.
It is unclear how decentralization helps lowering the bar for entry. In my assessment it would complicate matters even more at this point in time.

The proposal is based on a theory that a personalized workshop for onboarding can help. There is a large number of unknown variables in the proposed methodology. However, it is an experiment worth trying.

Although it has a clear and understandable problem addressed, it has only a clear idea of what is the solution. There was not provided an actual project of development or explanation of how it all is going to work. Besides that, I do miss the tool to actually measure if the workshop is converting the `lurkers` into committed participants.

There is clarity the problem and solution description.

In the definition of success, reasonable KPIs and metrics were described.

There is a budget breakdown, but there are no details on the complexity and duration of the workshops, which makes it difficult to audit.

The timeline is clear and objective.

There are details about the proposer and a link to his project (Gimbalabs).
A reasonably simple proposal, thus easy to audit. I would like a more detailed plan on marketing to bring new people in.

The roadmap is clear, definition of success is also clear. Some metrics besides 12 'Catalyst Skeptics' should be included in order to better understand the impact of this project. Same challenges and risks should be assessed, like not having enough 'Skeptics' joining the workshops and keep attending to them.

The author determines a metric of success, according to the months, in which we can know the expectation of the results to be achieved according to the time. Also, it divides exactly how the financial amount would be divided, in parts. In addition, he sets out the answer to some possible questions from readers, something that I have not seen in anyone's proposal so far. In other words, the plan is very detailed, the information is cohesive and we can understand how the project would work in chronological order, making its applicability very palpable.
Whilst this seems like an interesting project, it does not seem to fit this challenge. It is not aim at the developer community. Perhaps it should be in the Grow Africa, Grow Cardano challenge.

The proposal is an excellent way to connect developers within and outside indigenous community, progress no-code application to Cardano and create a usecase for the implementation of intellectual property to Cardano. Not to mention the very good cause to work against the economic and social disenfranchisement of indigenous communities

The idea of storing intellectual property rights on a blockchain is intriguing. What is being proposed is basically a decentralised patent service. By making these patents available through leasing, there can be set a legal base. 
There are 3 things not entirely clear in the proposal; 
Is the focus for this solely on Africa or is it meant to apply in other regions for the world as well? 
What is defined as an 'indigenous community'? 
Some doubts that it is filed under the right challenge.
The proposers don't have a clear plan for how they will deliver the project, relying on developers to figure it out for them.

Directly affected people work in the proposal team and cooperate with other actors that are ver credible and competent, the plan is detailed and actionable and the budget is diversified into comprehensible positions. Good job with the proposal, it seems like you really thought this through and have a realistic plan and expectations.

The colaboration with WADA and the opportunity to integrate IOHK's Atala PRISM technology makes the proposal feasible in terms of implementation. However, this will not solve any of the problems that occur in the centralised sphere. It will still come down to the same base question and that is 'How do you prove an idea is really yours? '

WADA if I remember correctly, is part of Catalyst since round 2 funding, solid team, together with Indigenous Source, strong support and commitment from local communities and their chiefs, local developers witch are active and already involved, building on Atala Prism group identity and ownership ecosystem. Plan to start in Q3 this year, looking activities planned, they going to eat this elephant, little piece by piece and will get all the help, support and advice if needed from the cardano community
Information given in proposal seems like they have good experience, but the there are various things mentioned in the proposal whiich looks like very broad to acheive the goal.
As mentioned in the feasibility note, the plan is very well formulated and realistic and the project is really well-defined, which makes this proposal very actionable and auditable.

All elements are present in the proposal to properly verify the proposal. Except for definition of success metrics. (How many people are you trying to reach and how many would you consider a success?)

Available space provided, cramped with all the detail needed, seem to comply with self assessment checklist. References needed there, timeframe of 3 months seem tight but can be sorted with midnight oil. I wish you strength and good fortune and will follow your progress.

Even though I personally find the demo duller than some NFTs the proposer is bashing, I see potential if implemented right. While it's a stretch to call this a game, it may help in adoption and set a bar for true games on Cardano in the future.

Valid application that addresses the challenge and certainly sure to generate plenty  of interest. The proposal seems a little chaotic at present and it may need further refinement and attention to priority to progress further.
Emotionally reactive NFTs have a niche market and can become a source of innovation. The proposal also has constructs that can cater to the gaming NFT market with slight adaptation.

This project is somewhat similar to an Ethereum-based game, called "Axie Infinity" that seems to be popular at the moment and has a big base of players. This project seems to be going in a similar direction, though their NFTs will not have as many playable functions. If it proves successful, it could lead to a growing community of players and of Cardano developers.

Traditional web development has little overlap when it comes to blockchain development. The plan only addresses the UI. The proposers' listed strengths vary tremendously among their multiple ideas. I deem the anonymous nature troubling in combination with a high ask. The scarce GitLab history gives further reason to not have confidence in a successful implementation.

Where does React gets its data from? What will the mentioned server look like? How does it transact wit the Cardano blockchain?
More details on how the proposer intend to market this project once built to get it to go viral would be good.

Difficult to assess higher due to anonymity wish of proposers which I understand but then cannot really assess experience. I do feel its highly likely that they may have excellent experience but then how would I know? The plan while detailed is somewhat chaotic and while this speaks of great enthusiasm I would like to see a more measured approach that promises to deliver an achievable proposal.

The proposal is made by anonymous proposers. The innovative idea is good however there is limited information to verify the capability and experience. The viff.club sire referenced in the proposal is not sufficient for judging the capability of the team.

As one of the comments on the proposal has also brought to the attention, the team refuses to provide identity and credentials, stating that "pseudonymity and concentration on the proof of work and delivery builds much stronger trust than just showing faces and credentials". This statement might be valid in some contexts, however in the case of Project Catalyst, the team's experience is a requirement, based on the fact that everything is open, community-based and can provide some form of trust that the team is capable of finishing the project.
In combination with open source repositories, the progress could be compared with the outlined timeline. Self-specified success can be audited with the deployed DApp.

I actually feel this proposal has great potential and hope the proposers consider a stepped application that starts the process without asking the PC community to trust us we know what we are doing. Lots of potential and I highly recommend building relationships within the PC community and aligned enterprises (such as singularityNet).

The proposal is comprehensive and is addressing all the technical components of the project. The success of the project is very difficult to predict. However, based on the current NFT trend and market there is a very good chance the project is successful.

The budget is not detailed and they recognise that they only have approximate numbers based on their experience, but since they refuse to reveal their experience, then the approximations cannot have a valuable meaning. These two areas, team experience and budget, are very important in assessing a project. I suggest the team tries to find a way in which they can present themselves to dissipate any kind of worry, in the process making their budget look well grounded and re-submit their proposal to a future fund.

Accessibility will be a major hurdle toward blockchain adoption. I feel a project like this, which aims to focus upon accessibility as a central issue will contribute greatly to the Cardano ecosystem and also serve as a working example and instigator for future projects.

The proposal proposes a novel solution for the ecosystem (No-code) which would potentially onboard people who are not inherently coders by trade. It is an interesting idea, and as a non-developer I would be first interested to use the possible use case - borrow-lending platform (such as Kiva-heavily desired by Charles Hoskinson).
Enough data was provided to verify the No-code claim and movement and it would for sure be beneficial to have something similar on Cardano to add on the Plutus/Marlowe foundation.

The proposal has the potential to unlock massive potential, as a lot of great ideas currently are prone to fail because of the lack of software developing knowledge many people have (especially considering that people that have quite good skills in other fields that would be beneficial to the cardano ecosystem often don't have the developing skills required to put them into action). To summarize, the project would oerfectly adress the challenge.

The proposal to have a drag and drop site for creating front-end applications for Cardano smart contract is unique and is a highly desirable feature. This is likely to reduce the technical threshold for entry into app development in the Cardano ecosystem leading to a cascading effort in the number and quality of apps/daps.
Definitely a lot more people could start developing of Cardano If we elliminate the coding experience barrier completely

Building dApps without having to spend years of learning code is a dream for many people involved in other domains, from Arts to Finance and so on. This project could lead to a real growth of apps being developed on Cardano, if the knowledge barrier can be replaced.
I think the proposed budget is very modest and I am excited to see what the team can produce in the given timeline.  I do feel like both budget and timeline might be overly optimistic.

The proposal is nicely structured, showing the estimated budget (hourly rates), work, milestones and deliverables. The needed resources are shown and the delivery schedule is clear in particular.
What might be emphasized a bit more are the people behind the project. The proposal mentions `we`, but the rest of the proposal reads more like one person. The experience is noted, but there is no evidence or verifiable source to check. The Github link showed very limited commits, and that for one person.
The webpage is a landing page only, with no further data or work done. It might be hidden under beta registration, but it was not clear if there is any substance at the moment.
The risks are not considered, and it would be beneficial to have some notes on potential delays or lack of certain resources and ways to mitigate them. For example, the failure to deliver the flycode platform as desired.
To conclude and based on currently available insight, although the plan and idea are very sound, there might be a lack of expertise.

The proposers are experienced in developing and also in the specific skills required. At least the about the mentioned person, credible information exists that indicates that this person will indeed have the skills to fulfill the task. The costs are assessed in a transparent and credible way which shows that the proposer has indeed properly reflected about the project. All in all it is highly likely that the project will be implemented successfully.

The prosal is not very explicit about the development team and the experience of the team. The Github repository referenced is also not showing much activity. However, the claim regarding the readiness of the parts is encouraging and it is likely that the proposer will be able to implement the tasks.

The idea and plan are well presented, the fact that the Cardano no code devs will be able to benefit from the other modules of the presented platform is a huge plus and also gives more confidence on the team's ability to implement this. Most certainly the implementation of this idea will also help flycode as integrating with blockchain is a nice buzzword for any product these days so the team also has an incentive to build it.

The team is not only knowledgeable, but they are already building a platform for people without coding skills to use in building their desired apps on blockchain. From the presented plan, the project gives no reason to doubt its implementation, the team is skilful, the plan is not only detailed but written in such a way, that anyone can understand it.
The proposal is focused in its scope on what it plans to address and in doing so make me feel like it is feasible to complete.

The proposal has nicely structured plan, with milestone and deliverables.
The metrics and goals are mentioned, as well as overall expectations after the implementation.
The stated problem was a coding barrier, and with this proposal there will be ways t o eliminate or reduce a number of coding requirements. This could speed up the adoption and implementation which is crucial for Cardano to catch up to competitors.
It is an overall quality made proposal with potentially nice impact.

The proposal is very clear and structured and provides additional information about the technology used, demonstrating its importance and feasibility and the impact it might have in the future. This also indicates a good use case for the Cardano ecosystem.

The proposal has clearly articulated the features to be build and their interaction. The project is likely to be open source. The project's progress can be easily monitored and audited based on the roadmap and the feature set expected.
The plan looks well thought and needed information is presented. Given that almost anyone could play with the presented features, it will be easy to follow the progress by non-devs too

The proposal contains all the requested information, a detailed description, a broken-down budget, an estimated launch date, definition of success, use cases and more. All the information presented is clearly written and sufficient in helping to audit the proposal.
Improve Scaling for the already established API Gateway Blockfrost is a very good fit to the challenge.  It will make an already existing solution better and well prepared for future requirements.

Availability of WebSocket will provide an option to app developers to write responsive applications. BlockForest APIs have contributed substantially in these nascent stages of NFT and native tokens. Therefore an availability of alternate protocol in very reasonable effort is likely to contribute to the system further.
Blockfrost is already established as a trusted partner in the Cardano ecosystem. Several successful products use Blockfrost. The provided information make an successful implementation very likely.

Blockforest API is currently the leading Cardano blockchain API providers. The services are being used by quite a few develers. With this as the experience it is very likely that the proposers will be able to implement that process in timely manner.
There are specific and details milestones defined for 3, 6 and 12 months in the proposal. The Project itself should not be to complicated to audit, as not many parties are needed to implement is.
The HTTP service will be free and the proposer is expected to release the code in opensource. The progress is highly objective and monitoring it is feasible and auditable.

Its not clear who the client for this product is. 
Is it an existing social media platform? Why would they use this? Is it users? 
How would they use it without a platform on which to use it?
Without a use case to drive take up, how does it help the Cardano Platform?

The proposed idea is an interesting take on the metadata challenge, utilising two levels of NFT's to uphold the Main profile and app specific transactions respectively. Also the incentives for SPO's and dApp users would be key for encouraging adoption. As this proposal is looking at the idea of taking throughput off the main chain, a look at the Hydra scalability solution for certain aspects of the data transaction could be useful more for metric based elements (ie. likes/voting polls etc). The impact could be great as it potentially brings many people into the Cardano ecosystem. Does this approach take into account that a social media platform could potentially run it's own stake pools, which could be a barrier to decentralisation?

While the proposal gives an interesting usecase for metadata and deals with the question of social media data storage, it does not adress the full scope of the issue that is also represented in some of the metrics of the challenge, specifically traceability: While it clearly describes intended mechanisms that are supposed to allow users and SPOs to opt-in or not in the use of their data and to monetize it (which might bring some users that want to monetize their data onto cardano). However regarding traceability, the proposal does not imply giving the data subjects any transparency about how or at least by whom their data is used. Since the proposer has worked a lot in Big Data he should be well aware that this transparency is very important considering recent big data scandals (e.G. Cambridge Analytica, where big data was used to manipulate whole countries politically). I would advice the proposer to adress the aspect of data usage and transparency more detailed in future proposals.

It seems emphasizing a bifurcation of user generated content to an SPO side chain node, opens up the door to some data being securitized in time, (that associated with the blockchain), and other data being left vulnerable (that associated with the SPO Social Media storage), and open to many outside forces associated with the the specific Social Media operations which could vary greatly.
the proposal provides an interesting idea, that if successful could change the way social media is used forever. Where does Digital ID show up in this proposal?

This proposal meets the Metadata Challenge criteria by developing a proof-of-concept standardization of social-media data using a novel combination of on-chain metadata for slowing changing information, coordinated with a side chain for high-frequency data. The proposal acknowledges that moving from a proof-of-concept to widespread adoption would require incentivizing SPOs to host the decentralized side chain, and it properly frames the work as a foundational R&D effort.

The idea is sound and innovative, and the experience shown is solid. The idea itself works well in theory and could be very successful and bring in many users. Details on some KPI's are there, in the form of monthly milestones. But the auditability is hard to define, as is the exact nature of the POC (is it a working app, a dashboard prototype etc). Is this to be solely developed by the proposer with the input from IOHK, or is this going to be a team formed to tackle this proposal. There isn't really a breakdown for budget allocation either.

The proposer obviously is quite experienced in the Big Data topic and has worked for several employers utilizing it. Since the plan is very open-ended it is likely that it will be implemented to some degree, but it is hard to determine the quality to which it will be implemented. The experience of the proposer in blockchain development remains unclear.

While the proposer is well versed in tech, there are some concerns about blockchain experience. This is mitigated with plutus pioneer course and advice from IOHK but it may not be enough in this research based proposal.

Although even the POC effort is ambitious, the proposer appears to have adequate experience for pursuing the project. It would have been helpful if the proposal provided more detail in the roadmap, which is somewhat generic and not directly tied to elements of the technical description of the solution. The project plan would benefit from the use of agile methodology or design thinking in order to continuously engage prospective users as the POC R&D proceeds.

Subsequently moving from the successful POC to widespread adoption would be a high-risk, high-reward effort, but there is a reasonably high likelihood that the POC would result in a sufficiently concrete product to propose next steps.
It is not clear without a usage case that would drive take up how this proposal would help the Cardano ecosystem.

As mentioned in the previous assessment note, there could be more information given on the KPI's and Roadmap and what to expect from the POC although I agree that the function and some KPI's of said POC are indeed outlined, it's more the form that it would take. As well, some kind of budget allocation would help.

The milestones are a bit vague and open-ended and the budget does not have a rationale. More concrete milestones and success criteria would be in order and the propoal should adress some more of the specific criteria of the challenge.

Some clarifications in writing may be helpful for those reviewers who may not be familiar with the discipline-specific language. For instance, when you use an acronym for the first time in a proposal, write the full phrase, and then in parentheses the acronym:
supply path optimisation (SPO) 

Also in this example, avoid definitions like "certain", but instead give an example:

included in certain Cardano main chain transactions initiating the minting of NFTs representing slowly changing entities such as user accounts.
Note: "explain certain" give example of certain...such as...
Does certain mean "user accounts"?

Lastly, it may be best not to compromise user's data persistence on the blockchain for ease of usability... maybe there is a way to educate users about this issue. As some users may opt for this solution out of ease of use, without knowing what they are risking...? 
Referring to thus phrase:

"Furthermore, giving application users full control of the storage and marketability of their metadata may involve expenses and responsibilities that most users would find unpalatable, or even intimidating."
the proposer gave milestones that could be used for gauging progress. However, this alone won't result in realized changes in the number of metadata users.

The proposal's roadmap and solution contains the barely sufficient basic information needed to gauge progress, but it would have benefited from a more quantifiable roadmap and a listing of delivables or artifacts such as a design document, a precise definition of the form of the POC (and its delivery), and the type of testing.

Strong team and understanding of the problem is obvious.  Complex problems require complex solutions and this verification system should help developers build on this platform and trust the correctness of their code.

The success of DApps in Cardano depends on their ability to produce verifiable applications. Glow is being seen as a multi-blockchain language with support for Cardano. There is a need to have a toolkit for formal verification of dAPPs utilizing smart contracts. This will be a certifiable daapps if this proposal becomes successful.

$60,000 in the first 3 months for a proof of concept seems steep. I would prefer to see that initial amount last longer before additional funding is required. If it is fast and cheap it can't be good (Iron Triangle). Maybe a solution that has a longer development window would give this a better chance of successful implementation.
The proposers have the skills. It is possible it still fails though as they have to solve this problem on the Cardano blockchain.
The proposers are authors of a full-fledged multi-blockchain language. It is almost certain that they will produce a prototype within the time period they had set.
Very well documented and researched proposal. I am very impressed with the presentation and team compiled. Answers all questions from a development perspective.
This is a detailed plan to expand a product the proposers already have onto DApps on the Cardano blockchain. This could make DApps safer and more likely to be produced.
The project is open source and the community will have access to the progress. The progress has clear benchmarks and it is montitorable.
Cardano offers a basic REST endpoint, which makes means clients have to develop the service stub. A SDK would help developers.
Making the cardano api accessible in an easy way does address the challenge very well. Blockfrost is already well established and an c# SDK will improve the situatio further.
C# is a very popular language so lots of devs could benefit from this

The team already operates nodes and exposes endpoints. The documentation is very good https://docs.blockfrost.io/
Hence I completely trust them to implement a SDK.
Blockfrost is already well established in the Cardano ecosystem. Five Binaries is well known for their good connections to the community. The estimations are reasonable.

The proposer clearly stipulates a timeframe and set of deliverables and outlines exactly how the proposed budget will be used. The proposer has been successful in previous campaigns so they have some experience in this regard. As an experienced developer myself, there is nothing here that suggests that what is described here can not be accomplished
The team has implemented other APIs in their platform so it's very likely they already have a good and fast process for new APIs

Regarding auditibility: Definion of success is stated and quite reasonable KPIs. I think 5 downloads in the first month is a pretty low KPI, but the guys of Five Binaries have more experience than me. It will definitly increase over time.

As mentioned above, the target deliverables, timeframe and budget are all laid out in a very clear way. The proposer identifies some key performance metrics to gauge their success. Also, by making this open-source, they are contributing to the Cardano community
There is a general timetable. But it lacks more detailed milestones to follow the progress of the project.

Clear metrics for audibility are provided in the project. The implementation roadmap is described and would be easy to follow by the community. The fact that the SDK that is the scope of this proposal is going to be open source further improves the audibility of this project.
They know how to ask for funding. All questions were answered, and this proposal is in complete alignment with the aim of this fund.

The team of proposers already actively participates in the Cardano community. The NFT DAO was one of the proposals voted and approved by the community at Fund3. There are details about the experience of the proposers and their skills, signaling the qualification and aptitude of the team to execute the proposal.

There is a reasonable plan for the development of the proposal, there is a good definition of the timeline, there is information on the distribution of the budget during stages, but there are no details on the allocation of resources. I think it is important to detail how the resources will be used, even if it is entirely spent only on members' hours of work and research.

They already delivered the previous proposal to the end line, expanding the team. Yet transparent and promising team. 

 I could not join the discord. Idk why.

The proposal is very detailed and provides concrete objectives which gives confidence that the objectives can be achieved. More information is needed regarding what will drive the value of the proposed NFT-DAO tokens. Exactly what utility will users be provided based on ownership of the tokens? If this is primarily the authority to vote, is that enough to establish value and under what circumstances.

The proposal addresses the challenge in a relevant way and has great potential. There is a roadmap, with milestones, reasonable metrics, details about the proposers, their qualifications and experiences. I think it is important that the budget allocation is more detailed. There are no tangible KPIs.
provided in a detail. Overall, this proposal is one of the top tiers, which I assessed, both by "structure" and the "final product".
The proposal is very thorough. The existing Github repository has substantial content. The leadership team is well described. And there is an active community contributing to the project.

Although it is possible to glimpse the proposer's idea, the problem statement doesn't describe a problem and the description of the solution is not clear. This information is essential for the proposal to be able to clearly communicate its intention to the community and increase the chances of success in the vote. The plan described is a draft, it needs to be better detailed. Improving the communication of important events is an important aspect, but it is not clear how it will have a relevant impact on the challenge.

It is essential that the proposal communicates more clearly what the objective is and how that objective is related to the challenge.

While incentivizing participation is a good idea, a model like this might most likely attract many people just grinding for the rewards that are not really interested in the projects. The amount of work and costs for programming a new app and cryptocurrency does not justify compared to the small amount allocated to the rewards and the effect they will have. I encourage the proposer to refine the idea for the next funding round.

The reward mechanism for participation in Catalysts is already present. The catalyst voting app can be also be configured to send notifications. A separate app for reminding stakeholders is likely to a unsustainable solution.

The idea of reminders to increase the participation in Catalyst is great, but I believe that the proposal budget is somewhat unbalanced. 90% of it would go the developer and 10% only for rewards distribution. This amount would also give very low incentives to all participants, and would probably have a low impact. I believe 50/50 would be a fairer split and could increase the proposals impact. Some more information about the kinds of interactions that would be rewarded should be included in the text as well to support a better understanding of it.
It could be an interesting way incentivise participation. More thought needs to go into the tokenomics, fees involved and ongoing funding model

The proposal has good intentions but doesn't relate it to Catalyst in a clear way. more details are needed. How would the proposed tokens be valuable (DANO?)?
Where would the ADA come from? Also, a centralized server based app which tracks user activity would be a hard sell in the community.

The proposer did not describe experiences relevant to the proposal. For the development of an app, a developer (who would be hired) would be needed.

There is no reasonable plan and there is no clarity in the purpose of the proposal. Some ideas are mentioned, like the distribution of funds for people to read proposals and comment on them, but how will this be accomplished? Creating financial incentives for comments and reading inserts vulnerabilities where people can exploit the system through fake accounts or bots. There is no mention of this problem or how to mitigate it. There is also mention of a voting app, but voting for what? Proposals? We already have a voting app for Catalyst proposals and soon this will be done by official portfolios, so what is the purpose of a voting app? There is mention of allowing video conferences in the app, but how does this relate to the challenge?

I recommend clarifying the points mentioned above and that the proposer follow the Catalyst documentation to write the proposal, addressing the points.

Finally, the proposer completed the self assessment checklist, but clearly the proposal lacks details.
The assessed budget is not at all enough to develop an app and a new crypto token. No rationale is provided for that extremely optimistic cost calculation.

The proposer needs to hire a developer for making app and the does not claim prior experience in software development or management. There estimate for cost for secure online chat app is very optimistic.

The proposer relevant experience is the knowledge of similar applications in other areas that served as inspiration for this idea. Although, there is no dev in the team yet, and the dev would be hired only 3 months after the fund is released, which seems a long time for this step only. It also aims to increase involvement in 10 times, but it seems unfeasible with the amount of rewards that would be distributed.
Proposer is not technical thus needs to hire someone to do it. Without a solid plan unlikely it will be implemented successfully on budget

The proposer doesn't have any relevant experience with the technology stack required to accurately scope the work needed to achieve the goals presented. the problem statement doesn't identify a problem, it could be clarified with some more data which shows low involvement / participation.

The proposal is a draft and lacks many details to allow auditability. There is no clarity on how the proposal will address the challenge, there is no concrete plan / roadmap / milestones / metrics / KPIs. There are no details on the budget allocation (a budget of 9000USD was defined to hire a developer, what were the references for setting the budget? Is there a rationale or number of hours of work to justify this amount?).

Which references were used to define the established goals?

I recommend that the proposal be detailed and follow the Catalyst documentation so that we can provide appropriate feedback.

While the general idea to incentivize participation is good, many questions on the exact development plan and the specific mechanisms and role of the crypto token are left unanswered. Simple reminders would not need something as complex as an app. If re-proposed. this project needs more detailed schematics in order to be deemed feasible
The development of the proposed app is likely to be feasible however the app with chat and notification along with the reward for participation may not be addressing the value onboarding issue.

An overview of a plan was stated, and the KPI proposed is a single one based on the increase of involvement of the community, which is not clear about how it would be measured. Some challenges regarding how to assess each one's participation and calculate it's rewards was not discussed and this would be very important for the proposal's accountability and transparency.

There is not actual plan for the technical build. This is an idea that needs more detail. Where will future funding come from. If this involves thousands of micro payments how will the transaction fees on those be paid?

The proposal provides a small amount of unclear milestones, which don't relate to achieving the stated goal in a measurable and auditable way. simply publishing an app isn't sufficient. A 1000% increase in involvement doesn't show an absolute change in participation, what was the baseline?

The problem and the solution are clear and objective. The proposal is within the scope of the challenge and can assist in the administration of the Catalyst server on Discord. This proposal has a considerable impact in relation to her budget, which I see as a great cost-benefit ratio, as Catalyst's Discord is being the most engaged tool in the community and needs to be improved in order to maintain the onboarding capacity. It is a priority for our community.

The idea of removing the responsibility of creating channels from admins and sharing it with the community is good and aligned to community-governance ideal. Although, I'm not sure that this alone would increase the number of proposal related channels. I guess that most proposers wouldn't know about this feature upfront, and will have to ask someone, just how they ping admins today to ask for a channel. There are also possibilities of spamming with multiple channels, and this could be critical because the Discord server already has many different channels.

Pinning IPFS files is indeed a way to keep the IPFS resource available. 

I don't judge whether keeping these resources for one more year is wanted, or if pruning is the expected behaviour. 

I'm however noting that this is a medium term solution.
The proposal is one of value to the dev community and future Cardano users. It also bolsters the IPFS ecosystem.
Feasibility is already demonstrated from past experience. The evaluation of costs lacks details, but doesn't sound irrelevant.

The proposal is forthright enough about opening up its book-keeping to the community that auditing does not seem to be an arduous exercise. The team has provided enough information on background, plans and pricing to build confidence that it would address the challenge and would be of great benefit to the community, especially given how CNFTs have grown. However, it didn't receive a 5-star rating as the proposal does not provide insight on what happens after six months when the funds requested is obviously spent. How does this tie in with Cardano releases and what if there are delays in the Mainnet releases? It might be beneficial if 'what-if' scenarios are added to the proposal seeing as though this is a short-term solution. Points given for presenting server solutions spread across the globe however, the pricing presented is from a single source (currently the provider being used by the proposers themselves). There may be benefits to Catalyst if the lowest possible price is presented and/or costing from other providers for comparison with pros and cons. This would be in case an extension past six months is required by the team and any additional cost to further provide the service past six months is required. Overall, good proposal.

The project is feasible. More information should be provided on how this project meets the challenge. It seems this is targeted at the whole Cardano ecosystem, as opposed to developers. Though I can see how Dev's might not want to use IPFS on Cardano without something like this.

Verifying if the proposal achieved its deliverables would be an extremely easy thing since the scope of this proposal is the deployment of servers. My only concern with this proposal is that the company behind it already offers the service described in the proposal as a paid service for Cardano developers, with the option of a limited free plan that seems to be subsidised by the paid subscription. However no attempt is made in the proposal to clarify why and how the result of them being funded through Catalyst would differ from the free service they are already provided. Maybe it will, but the info is not in the proposal. I would suggest clarifying this aspect in the future.
A defi lending plattform can help to scale-up carano's DEFI ecosystem. The community would benefit as there are more people using cardano.

The proposal does not clearly communicate the goal of the challenge. The entry to DeFi on Ethereum is primarily due to the high fees. People with high student loans are more likely to be able to enter DeFi than the unbanked - which is one important aspect of the challenge.

this proposal doesn't have a clear problem that it addresses, nor a clear plan on how loans and staking will bring additional users into Cardano's DeFi space. it would be helpful to know what the loan structure and staking structure is for a more complete evaluation. The proposal also plans on using a central server.

There is no description of a problem in the problem statement. The creation of a dapp that allows loans is within the scope of the challenge, but the goals are not reasonable and do not indicate how the proposal will address the challenge in the next 6 months.
The plan doesn't explain how real-life assets or credit rating can enter in the smart contract.

A physician that works in cancer imaging and therapy has probably a lot of work to do. This sounds like a full time job. I'm not quite sure why it is important that the proposer has a mortage, education loans and staked ada. 

There are already other lending proposals that already started biulding. It is gonna be difficult to catch up if you have to search and hire devs first.

30k for marketing is in my opinion not necessairy as good projects in crypto don't need marketing and our community has a lot of proposals regarding marketing.

Having a want to solve the challenge for oneself does not automatically mean one is capable of implementing a vague idea successfully. The proposal does not indicate a good understanding of the developer market, infrastructure cost, nor does it communicate if relationships to lenders exist.

Given the plan and the proposer's skill set there is a large risk that the proposal will not be able to deliver a working product. The budget for a programmer is extremely low, and the skill's that the hired programmer should have isn't identified which adds to the risk that the hired person may not be the right person for the job.

There is no reasonable plan, the creation of a loan protocol requires details about the financial and technical model so that it is possible to assess the viability. The experience described by the proposer is not related to the requirements for the execution of the proposal.

The information and requirements for the team are insufficient, the development of a dapp of this type requires developers with skills in several different areas, such as the development of smart contracts, front ent, financial model, web devlopment, among others and there is no mention of which will be technical requirements for the team. What is the purpose of a $ 30,000 marketing budget when there is no development plan yet? The budget is unreasonable and does not reflect the costs required to pay the staff required for this kind of project for one year.

No detailed plan on how to actually implement. How are you managing the loans. Interest rates? collateral levels? Essentially this is just taking a leveraged position in ADA. To secure the loans this would have to be marked to market. Given ADA traded in a range of .92 - 1.55 just last month this could be a very risky porposition.

The past experience is irrelevant for this project.
The plan is imprecise, and doesn't explain the economy of the project.
There is a plan on what the proposal would like to achieve. Unfortunately there is not that much information on how they would achieve it. A more detailed roadmap and a risk assessment would be good.
The proposal appears to be roughly oversimplified while providing numbers that seem unrealistic.
There is a general outline of the idea. But the proposal originates in a personal experience, and not in an understanding of the DeFi market, or need for the product.
while the proposal identifies some basic goals, the proposal fails to show that they are directly related to the problem statement.

It is necessary to refine the proposal in general, to include technical details and the financial model of the protocol. The development of a loan dapp requires a staff with different skills and this is not specified in the proposal. The budget breakdown is not reasonable, the costs have been underestimated. The established goals are questionable, as they are extremely subjective and do not help to indicate success in the challenge. There is no roadmap, no milestones, no KPIs.

I recommend including this information and, if necessary, the proposer can ask for help to assemble it.
Please provide both technical implementation plans and operational/risk management plans.
The project description is about resources ; not what needs to be done or how to achieve the goal.

The team is already involved in the Catalyst community and participates in projects to improve Catalyst, such as participation by Swarm Sessions, Landing Page and documentation. The team has already developed a good part of the work and there is a lot of information and details on the Miro board, so the team's ability to execute the proposal is clear. I recommend only including more details of the team in the proposal, so that the community that does not know them has access to this.

There is no description of budget breakdown in the proposal and I also did not find it on the Miro board, there is also no description of the workload so that it is possible to understand the feasibility. From what I checked on the Miro board and the intention I think the requested budget is reasonable, but including details is essential.
There are already loads of youtubers and dedicated News pages. Most of the youtuber don't need funding from catalyst but they are building a community from scratch...
While this YouTube channel may bring some awareness to Cardano, it is unclear how it is directing viewers to submit high impact proposals.

I like the idea itself. The proposal itself might be a bit too raw, pure PR forcing. In my eyes if I would like to target enterpremeurs and developers to join Cardano a transparent overview about full capabilities, advantages and disadvantages, ecosystem high level overview and a short training materials would the first steps. Technical facts could be much stronger convincing factor for devs. Main language with subs would be sufficient, majority of people targeted with this knows some level of English, the subtitles could do the rest. Purpose of bots might be out of scope, personally I think it is a bit offensive, I would rather tackle it with some way of feedback survey.

Such a channel is generally a good idea. What makes it a bit difficult is the fact that there already us quite a lot of social media coverage of Cardano and it would really need a new interesting angle and high quality videos to be seen through the noise. If that can be done, it will sure attract some new people to Cardano, especially if it puts in the effort to subtitle the news in many languages.

Currently a large number of Youtube videos with substantial viewership exits. The effectiveness of those videos has enabled Catalyst to have exponential growth in the last six months or so. Therefore the incremental benefits of additional information videos on Youtube are not certain.

The proposal posits a very important challenge, I.e. how to get entrepreneurs to build on Cardano, however, the proposed solution seems off-key or rather unfocussed as it steered more towards a news channel offered in multiple languages. The proposal does not articulate well how the offering of the YouTube channel in multiple languages can directly reach 'entrepreneurs' who are looking for protocols to build on. It does sound more like a general information channel. The solution is further confused by the mention of 'incentives' to attract builders. The mechanism of this incentivization is not mentioned again in the document.
This proposal acknowledges the challenge by addressing a position that individuals outside of catalyst and the community could interface with aspects of it.

The problem statement doesn't describe a problem, it just rephrased the challenge question. There is no clarity in the solution statement. I recommend modifying these descriptions so that they communicate the idea of the proposal more easily.

The idea is to create a marketing campaign through videos on Youtube, but there is no plan for how this will attract entrepreneurs. The proposal is still a draft and needs to be better structured

The metrics described are not solid and do not indicate potential impact on the challenge.

The goal established at 12 months is unrealistic, reaching 1,000,000 subscribers is a difficult goal and there is no plan information that demonstrates how this goal will be achieved, in addition, a large number of subscribers is a KPI that alone cannot measure the success of the proposal for this challenge.

The proposal meets the challenge's objectives well, as it promises to clarify the Cardano project and its positive points for people outside the community, through a channel on youtube, specifically aimed at attracting more members. In other words, I believe that the possible results relate very well to what is intended, making the proposal very interesting and relevant.
This would certainly increase attraction towards cardano, and create a good outreach

This proposal is somehow aligned with the challenge but not completely. The creation of a/some YouTube channel(s) to give information about Cardano in general does not directly increases the number of proposers in Catalyst. It might have some increase due to this initiative, but such channels would aim into public in general. This challenge is intended to focus mainly on the proposers, so content should be specific to this audience somehow. I believe that the proposal could be remodeled for the next Fund with proposers in mind.

The proposer says in the comments that he doesn't have much time because of sports. But he has another proposal next to this (Fund the masses). I like the effort and motivation but I think maybe it is a little to much work. There is no mention about a team or people that help out so far.
For anyone claiming to have more than 1 million subscribers per channel, I would expect to see a link to an existing YouTube channel that is at least in the hundreds of thousands of subscribers.

Seems that the proposer has enough experience, even tough the headcount overview isn't transparent. The budget broke down is given, as well time plan, it could be realized. The question is the quality of the content, maybe that is even more important to measure the content quality rather than amount of subscribers.

While it will be quite difficult to get a million subscribers in such a timeframe and to produce several regular videos in 6 languages at a constant rate, with some söight modifications (e.G. subtitles in the required languages instead of actual video duplicates in those languages) the project might have a good outreach, maybe not as high as set but still good.
No evidence is given on how the proposer can make a channel in 6 languages or build up an audience of 1 million followers.

The proposers have limited experience in content creation or they have not referenced materials created by them. Without verifying established capability it is difficult to assess that the proposal will be implemented successfully.

The proposer lists background and experience pertinent to the project. This proposal would benefit greatly if links to authored/produced education materials or videos is provided in order to validate the claims. The breakdown of the cost for each activity is provided but lacks details that would help paint a better picture of the activities, e.g. what social media channels will be utilised, how will the marketing seek the entrepreneurs who are looking to build, and what content will be produced. This proposal will benefit from explaining how a multi-language YouTube channel will run, whether as a subtitled/dubbed single video or multiple videos done in the different languages. Marks were given for success metrics however a target of 1million subscribers per language channel seems quite high. Charles himself only has a little more than 150k subscribers so an information channel targeted to those unfamiliar with Cardano may only get 10% of his numbers. I do hope I am wrong.
This proposal is a working roadmap. However, it is very lite on substance.

The team declared experience in creating videos, but did not provide any link or information to support this claim, there are no details about the team members and their qualifications. I recommend including more information that demonstrates the aptitude to create a marketing campaign and the experience in creating / editing videos.

There is no solid plan (there are no details on how to implement the proposal, there is no clear roadmap). There is a budget breakdown, but the absence of a solid plan makes it difficult to understand the feasibility of the requested budget.

The author of the proposal claims to be Stake Holder, professor and creator of audiovisual content, that is, he has the basic knowledge to carry out the project.
