However, I believe that this idea needs a larger and plural team, people who work directly in marketing, in social media, to help give visibility to the channel ... Some members from within the community to explain better about Cardano's work, it would be interesting also some designers for the creation of digital arts that would help in interacting with the public (this is a suggestion, actually!). Therefore, I believe that the author is competent for the action, but requires the formation of a team.

The proposer seems to have experience in teaching and it is relevant for the creation of a YT channel and better explain Cardano's principals, goals and news. Although, it doesn't mention how many people are involved with this project so far. If channels will be created in all languages, at least 5 more people are needed, and also it mentions the creation of a AI bot to answer audience questions, but this alone could be a single proposal in another area, depending on the level of details, and it would need people with very specific skills which the proposal don't mention if there someone already onboard or if they will start looking for someone. Also, the budget for AI creating doesn't seem to be enough for the desired development, it should be increase of the limitations of this AI should be mentioned.

The proposal is really short which makes it again hard to assess. The roadmap and the milestones are only one sentence. I'd love to see a risk assessment from the proposer maybe for the next fund. 1 million subscriber on youtube are quite hard to reach within one year.

1 million subscribers per channel (or even combined) seems out of reach with this team within one year.

IOHK's YouTube channel has less than 70k subscribers. No (english-speaking) established crypto YouTube channel comes even close to 1 million at this point.

Big news YouTube channels like Los Angeles Times (~450k), Boston Globe (~50k), or even Democracy Now! (<890k) has that subscriber base. And they've been around a lot longer, have a bigger budget, and know what they are doing.

As written above, it isn't clear how effectively it addresses the challenge. Another aspect is that from community point of view how many people share, retweet and gets convinced by the content, joins the movement and spreads the words afterwards is the key measurement parameter.

The proposal lacks information of what the content if those videos should actually be, which makes it difficult to assess how effective it will be towards the challenge, as it would need a certain uniqueness to attract many new people.
More information is required on why is is feasible to expect the proposer to create a you tube channel with 1 million subscribers across 6 langauges,
The proposal is clear and brings out a clear scheme for implementation. However, the effectiveness of information videos on attracting new proposers can not be established clearly.

Given time (12 months) and $10000 a YouTube channel can be produced quite easily. The difficult part of this project is to attain the level of success aimed for. There is enough in the proposal to suggest some measure of success can be achieved (even 1k subscribers is already a huge win if they are legitimately entrepreneurs) so the main question is, which of the metrics will be used to indicate the $10000 is well spent? One can say that 10k is a lot to create a YouTube channel while another can claim that the same amount is not enough to build a news network. To sway the proposal from one view to another, greater detail needs to be added in order to provide a=better clarity of what is being funded.

I believe that more particulars would be needed before true success could be assessed.
example:
- What are the values that will link these videos, youtubers, teachers? How do we attract the right entrepreneur for the needs of the communities we serve?
- What is the minimum production value we must attain? Who is vetting people?

This proposal strikes me as requiring more work.

There is a budget breakdown and goals, but the goals are not good indicators for evaluating performance. There are no details about the team, there is no clear roadmap, there are no milestones, there are no KPIs.

The information described does not indicate elements to allow an efficient audit. I recommend that this information be included in accordance with the Catalyst documentation.

Included are the specific costs of each part of the project, such as expenses with advertising campaigns and the creation of artificial intelligence to interact on youtube. Goals are also set according to time periods (measured in months), which makes community monitoring much more possible. In other words, the project seems well planned, structured, and conveys certainty as to the steps that will compose the whole, even including the expectations of probable results.

The proposal has goals for 3, 6 and 12 months, but more information about milestones, roadmap and KPIs should be included. The frequency of videos created, their release dates, for how long this work will be done, etc. Also, KPIs about how many people would be reached (not only 1M viewers after 1 year per channel), where it would be advertised, etc. These are all very important information to include here to make it possible to audit the proposal after it's funded.

Selecting a stake pool for deligation is a very easy process through official wallets.  The use of third-party applications and authentication using a single sign-on will add layers leading to stringent security control and might prove counterproductive.

The proposal is within the challenge goal. At the same time the statement of how problem is to be solved (simplify operation for delegating to a stake pool) is not deep specified and remain vague. I suggest to better introduce and explain HOW and WHAT, through use cases related to user's operations.

In my limited understanding of SPO management & operation, the algorithm takes care of the reward distribution to the SP and to delegators. This proposal could be improved by explaining the complexity of the distribution mechanism so the challenge will appear blatant and the solution proposed is a good one. A secondary challenge is also presented in terms of newbie on-boarding and while this is a valid issue, the proposal may well benefit greatly if this was instead presented as an added advantage of the product rather than a prominent problem its aiming to solve. There are numerous staking tutorials produced by the community in graphic and video forms and both Yoroi and Daedalus have been improved to be user-friendly that a   2nd-grader can actually already follow instructions as is. This secondary challenge seems to be moot and distracts from the main challenge of charity-specific allocation of rewards.

The proposal doesn't look very effective now as the delegation process is becoming more user-friendly in wallets like Yoroi. And the process involved in using the smart contract may also introduce the same level of complexity.

The proposal is vague on the handling of Staked ADA. Will it remain in the user wallet and what is the security of their party SSO. These issues are serious and require developer effort with dedicated security training.

The proposer team states that it has the necessary experience. The given metrics measure what the proposer wants to do, but the success of his actions is not defined. As mentioned above, the description of the solution is not well explained (e.g. how the funds will be spent, how the delegators improve their customer experience, and so on…), so the progress of this proposal is not simple to assess.
More information of the proposer would be good to enable estimation of success likelihood.

The proposer is an SPO and this gives credibility to the challenge/solution pair. However, a more detailed presentation of how the solution is going to be developed is required. There's a fair bit of information on high-level functions with no breakdown on the technical development required to produce each aspect, and also in terms of resources and costing that would display how the 50k being requested has been calculated. The fact this proposal is asking for a very sizeable chunk of the funds allocated to Fund5, a much more sophisticated and informative proposal is required in order for the milestones and dev pathways to be scrutinised and this proposal to gain a higher rating and greater confidence. Almost anything can be achieved with $50000 but that amount will require the kind of proposal that matches its value.

The proposal implementation might happen when smart contracts are launched on the main-net, but the wallets might be updating themselves in terms of multi-delegation and so.., So it may be better to wait for such things before implementing smart contracts.

The challenge being addressed by dApp is to simplify the process of stacking. However, the staking process in Cardano is so easy in the official wallets. Therefore it is not clear why such a complicated dApp is required to address this.

Roadmap and milestones (incl. time horizon) are weakly described. The budget provided is very general and therefore I cannot say whether it is appropriate or not. There aren't more details how the budget is going to be spent, also I'm trying to discover attachment to deep dive the solution. Furthermore there aren't a lot of information about how smart contracts will be developed and usable for the different touchpoints.
Whilst the proposal is likely feasible, more information should be given on how this is a better solution than staking through Daedelus or Yoroi.

This proposal lacks the IT and development breakdown that makes it an auditable project in terms of milestones, timelines, costs and expenditures. It could be improved by firstly stating the difficulties experienced by SPOs in extracting the portion of the rewards to be donated to charities and organisations. Perhaps by stating this is such a laborious exercise, etc. and then clearly stating how each of the functions  of the smartstakepool resolved each of the mini issues , it can better demonstrate how its addressing the challenges.
Smart stake pool seems cool, the success of this proposal can be measured after smart contracts are live and this proposal is deployed

The problems or "obstacles" mentioned are not not described in the appropriate fields (e.g.  in "Describe the solution to your problem"), but became clear in the plan. This proposal addresses the challenge, but i don't see it as a crucial step. I would have liked to see a proposal to offers a continuous way to improve IdeaScale platform based on feedback rather then this "one" time fix that is proposed.

While reviewing this proposal, I was hoping for an indicator of how many times this proposal has been reviewed by my peers. While I have never submitted a proposal myself, I fully support markdown and agree that this would improve the experience of creating/editing proposals.

The problem and the solution described are reasonable and are within the scope of the challenge, but the proposed improvements are extremely simple (tool for text editing and minor adjustments to the website UI), which doesn't show great chances of impact and improvement in decision making. It is important to note that the Catalyst community for several weeks discussed several ideas for improvements to the IdeaScale, a poll was realized between members of the community and a list of suggestions was defined and forwarded to the IdeaScale team. Only part of these suggestions were included in the proposal, which reduces the potential for positive impact of the proposal.

Although this project is essential to improve the platform itself, I do not think that it will improve the decision making. It will make the editing and browsing easier, but this don't necessarily improve the quality of reviews and decision making.
Other than that, it's impressive that you are charging $10K of a client to make some easy changes in the platform which will benefit not only Cardano, but every client.

This proposal is a little confusing to assess, despite the validity of the challenge presented. As a CA, I can clearly see the benefits of the solutions being proposed in terms of Ideascale reconfiguration to assist my peers and proposers, however, I am of the understanding that ideascale is just a product utilised by more than just IOHK's Project Catalyst hence any enhancements to its functionality is a cost that should be carried by ideascale themselves or by all its customers, not by the treasury of IOHK.

This proposal does address the challenge with the regard to actually improving the ideascale website. However, this proposal does not grow the community, but instead locks us with one specific vendor.

If IdeaScale shall remain being THE ideation-tool for the CATALYST Community, a quick reaction to community feedback and quick Improvement-cycles are crucial. Therefore it is great to see IdeaScale starting to participate in the CATALYST proposal process themselves! What keeps me from rating this with a (5) is the static list of improvements in this proposal (which I understand out of pragmatic reasons). I would prefer to keep a community-experts-prioritized, more dynamic  improvements-backlog and tackling always the highest priority items in such proposal (of course the content of the proposal must be sufficiently described also in this approach). Maybe this is already existing, but then the proposers missed to provide a link to such a transparent backlog.

This proposal would help out in the immediate to help make IdeaScale a much more manageable approach to handling the proposals and subsequent assessments for all users.  Enhancing the browser and community advisor tools will make it much easier to navigate and assess.

It wasn't clear to me at first that this proposal came from the IdeaScale team. The 3 proposed changes are well described and i'm confident that the team can implement this, but it would still be nice to see what resources are required for this (e.g. hours of work) and a budget breakdown to understand what the requested funds are being used for.

The proposers are responsible for the IdeaScale platform (website) and are known to the Cardano community, they have the capacity to execute the proposal, but have failed to describe details of their experiences in the proposal, which is an important factor and must be required for all proposals, to guarantee equality of conditions in the dispute and transparency, even if the proposers are well-known figures of the community.

Three improvements have been proposed that can improve decision-making. Despite the simplicity of the changes proposed for IdeaScale, there is no detailed execution plan, and in addition the lack of a detailed budget is a negative point. A criticism was made in the comments of the proposal in relation to the requested budget to be high for the proposed modifications and this criticism was not answered by the team.

There is no timeline.

I recommend that the team reassess the needs that have been presented by members of the Catalyst community and incorporate them into the proposal. In addition, it is important that the plan is better detailed, because despite the simplicity of the proposed changes, it is necessary to provide information on the timeline for these implementations and budget details.

I also noticed the team's lack of participation in the comments, which is a negative point.

There is no doubt given this is an ideascale-drafted proposal that the itemised enhancements proposed could be successfully implemented after all they are responsible for the entire platform. This assessment and the rating granted is moot simply because it is ideascale who presented the enhancements and should be responsible for making the user-requested changes within their own budget.

From the experience presented, it is not clear how successful will the implementation be.  From how the ideascale looks like, it is far from professional. Also, this proposal makes it clear that the proposer themselves are not capable of fixing something a lot of people would call a must have feature in the first place. IdeaScale is stuck in the past.

This proposal seems feasible coming from the Ideascale community since this is their platform and they want to help improve it with funding.  Additional guidance may be needed to ensure that the changes are in the best interest of the community and maximize the potential of the proposed changes.  The funding amount seems reasonable since the cost would be to make slight changes with the UI/UX and no major redesigns appear to be needed.

A roadmap with milestones is not presented, so it will be difficult to follow the progress of this proposal. There are also no metrics of success, these could be based on feedback provided by users as changes are implemented.

The proposal addresses the challenge, but lacks some information to indicate its auditability, such as details on budget allocation, timeline, metrics / KPIs and details on the experience and skills of the proposers.

Although the IdeaScale team has a great reputation, we need tangible aspects to audit the performance of the proposal, otherwise the evaluation is based only on trust.
This is not the point of the Catalyst distributed decision making round, Ideascale is already under contract with IOHK, the community should not need to pay for basic platform improvements.

Anyone who logs in and uses ideascale's Project Catalyst community would be able to essentially perform an audit of the works as they are deployed. We afterall live in this space in the performance of our roles and duties. And I would reiterate the fact that there is no doubt ideascale can deploy the enhancements presented. The neutral rating given to this proposal can be attributed to my initial confusion in terms of dipping into IOHK's treasury to fund enhancements to a platform that it merely uses. I would go so far as to say, IOHK should find another platform to conduct its Project Catalyst activities if ideascale cannot enhance its own product and paying for it themselves.
It is not clear from the proposal how the funds are going to be used and what the licenses of the changes funded by the community will be.
Roadmap and timeline of deliverables would be a nice thing to have to ensure that there is a project plan in place to implement the changes.  The ability to make this visi
This "market" is not a positive way of scaling up DeFi. I do not like the idea of profiting from someone's loss.

Insurance is an indispensable part of a financial system. The proposal aims at building an insurance protocol for real life events. If successful, it should expand Cardano's DeFi ecosystem significantly.

The proposal focuses on bringing an innovative decentralized way to provide coverage in case a damaging event occurs. This proposal does not identify how this method of providing insurance will gain traction  and convert buyers from the current insurance providers. it also doesn't provide an estimate on the efficiency gains that this deployment might provide over traditional insurance providers beyond immediate payouts. will this result in less expensive insurance for the buyers?
COukld be an interesting idea. Not sure this directly meets the challenge. This is a specific DeFi proposal, not one to help scale up the DeFi ecosystem

There is no clarity in the purpose of the proposal. There is no detailed plan. The articles described are vague and do not explain in detail how the protocol works. The goals set are subjective and do not indicate how they will address the challenge.
The amount of experience on the team and presentation is very impressive. They clearly know the insurance world well and have experience with other blockchains.
the team has sufficient insurance experience and is working on an ETH deployment while also waiting for smart contracts on cardano.

Very light outline of a plan. It would be good to have mor einformation on the oracles and how you are going to validate the data. Data quality is integral to this working. It would also be good to have some evidence to back up the claimed experience of the proposer (LinkedIn profile?). Go to market strategy is stated as a strength, but not actually detailed.

The team stated that it will deliver a mvp to Ethereum in June, but in the articles and links described there is not enough information to assess the development of the project. In addition, there is no reasonable roadmap.

The proposal describes that it has a team with Cardano developers, but there is no information about the team's experience in Plutus.

The budget is divided into 3 parts (marketing, LP and team) but the proposal plan doesn't describe details about the project's development that indicates the feasibility of that budget.

I am still not clear why the person who's property suffers a loss does not have insurance. Is the MVP used instead of going through insurance? Is the property then used as collateral? Insurance is a dirty business, but maybe blockchain technology can help correct that. I am left with too many questions.

The proposal lacks technical details for assessment of its potential. For example, it is unclear under which mathematical construct the ACM will operate. Terms like MVP and UVP are left unexplained. And there are multiple typos, like "cryppto", "BUyers".
A more detailed plan with milestones should be provided to allow progress auditing and layered release of funds. Details on methods to ensure data integrity of the oracles is essential.

There is no clarity as to the objective of the proposal and how it will address the challenge.

The indicators described in the timeline are subjective. There are no metrics/ KPIs. I recommend including a detailed plan and base the budget on that plan. The inclusion of this information is important for the auditability of the proposal.

There is no information about the team's knowledge in developing SCs in Plutus or Marlowe.
Compared to traditional means, running lottery as a DApp increases transparency and reduces friction. It also sparks synergy with fiat on-ramp and off-ramp systems currently being built.

Lotteries and games of chance by their nature attract users to them. When paired with social good they have the ability to transform society from building critical infrastructure to supporting great charities. This proposal offers a novel approach to building a blockchain based charity that can have a global reach. Developing a native governance token and rewarding holders for participating in the vetting of charities is a fantastic Idea!

Creating a better lottery system is a great idea. A huge part of the reason that I don't partake in regular lotteries is that you don't really know how it works behind the scenes, the people and the picks are not transparent. This will hopefully address the concerns and be a level playing field.

The lottery has a market, and if combined with the tag of Good cause, it is likely to produce an excellent use case for Cardano smart contract and blockchain. There is a scope for the growth of adaptation.
The plan is well laid-out with clear goal posts at each stage. The team has relevant experience in the industry.

A detailed and lengthy roadmap to success is presented in the proposal. Limited information is presented on the leadership and implementation team which makes it somewhat difficult to gauge the ability to succeed. I've requested further information about the team in the comments.
More info on the proposers capabilities would be useful to enable assessment of their ability to deliver.

There is a very detailed plan here (in the google doc), great job!
I especially like the clear address of the problem, the proposed solution, fund allocation and extra detail on things like experience and roadmap.

The proposal provides high-level information about the planed project. Some technical details are left out that may affect the project's feasibility, e.g., the source of randomness, and the lottery mechanism.

A great timeline breakdown and success based KPIs. If proposer is not successful this fund I'd suggest looking for funding of early stages to develop credibility and apply for funding in later rounds. A detailed team breakdown would also bring this proposal up a level.
The project has described its roadmap with the information about needed developers, but they doubt, that requested funds are enough for the project success.

There is sufficient information here for me to believe that the team is solid enough to complete this project. It is good to know there is also a plan for stages of development and how they will accomplish.
The roadmap and metrics are well defined, although the over-all plan still needs some fine tuning which in turn could change everything else.

Decentralized finance has shown to be in high demand for those adopting cryptocurrency.  I think it is important that Cardano develops DApps in this space so that it can function in interoperability with other blockchains.

I give a 5 for impact because the proposal aims to bring an enormous, possibly incalculable, amount of value to users. This proposal is a platform for advanced trading of cryptocurrencies, including exchanges, index investments, derivatives, and mirrored investments. Not only would this application bring value to users of this application, it would bring value to the entire cryptocurrency community. The most important objective, for me when reading the proposal, is the one to increase market efficiencies by allowing traders to short a currency. This is based on accurate financial principals and is critical to lessen volatility in crypto markets. This helps the currencies themselves and anyone who holds or seeks to hold the currency. This will help bring cryptos into more common use because there won't be huge price swings.
they sure have a lot written out in the proposal, yes they seem to cover how they will address the proposed challenge.
There is a need for a DEX to enable Defi services in the Cardano blockchain. This is likely to improve liquidity and encourage market participants to utilise Cardano.

The broad vision and clearly articulated elements of the solution are impressive.  This could bring great value and many users to the Cardano ecosystem.

Including a specific focus on education and communication will be a great source of value.

The anonymous nature of the proposal has limited this ranking, as trust is important for an exchange and the value it can generate.

The proposal could be improved with more clarity around the operational aspects of the exchange (fees, tokenomics).

I appreciate the honesty from the proposer(s) that this is something hard to gauge in terms of scope, budget and also the security concerns.  I believe this shows they are aware of the complexity and not being naive. I think this will need to be a integration that will need various rounds of funding to fully mature, but that what has been proposed is possible considering a few working examples already exist. I think Cardano could solve some of the existing shortcomings and would help drive adoption and attract further innovation.

I give a 4 for feasibility because it is a large scale, complex application. The proposers demonstrate their knowledge of both finance and coding within the proposal. The budget is reasonable and they provide specific time bound measures of success over the next year. The item that prevents me from giving a 5 in feasibility is concern about how the DEX will handle short trades. What country's regulations will you use - if any - for margin requirements? When will a margin call happen? There are many complexities to this type of trade so I am concerned about its implementation.

The proposers are citing reasons for the lack of a legal regulatory mechanism for remaining anonymous to safeguard their own interest. This gives no option to evaluate the proposer's capability. The requirement of escrow services to verify the identity and capability is not suitable for the catalyst proposal.
The team is anonymous, but the depth of detail in the proposal shows a deep understanding of the crypto world.

The information provided does not give any indication whether the $50k would be enough to implement the challenge to the point that this project is self-sustaining and will already have a significant amount of users. The scope is quite large and the realization of all of this seems with the given self-imposed constraints and presented information is unrealistic as per my assessment.

The scope of this proposal is large to say the least.  I feel like enough detail is provided, but that the upfront funding is justified to help develop a first Iteration that then could be evolved through consensus.
I give a 4 for KPIs because they list the metrics but not their targets for each metric. The time horizon is clear and reasonable. The solution to the problem they outline is clear.

It is a detailed proposal. It is not clear how it addresses the challenge. More detail on exatly how if differs (and improves upon) other centralised and decentralised options out there would be useful. Ie why is this needed.?

The proposal claims that the output can be considered to assessing the team's capability during an audit, even for open source code that operates on implicit trust. There is a need to audit the code before the community accepts it. Software backdoors and other related threats are detrimental to the Cardano ecosystem.
There is a thorough breakdown of the budget and timetables that would allow for the tracking of the progress.

I get the idea of creating videos, but according to the example, a large part of it is entertainment, and then education. I doubt it will attract a large number of proposers, and I doubt even more that these proposers will be qualified. The target group of these videos would be very young people (IMO) thus, I do not believe in this idea. Also, the budget feels overextended -  40k USD.

The official IOG marketing campaigns present the Cardano/Catalyst ecosystem as a serious, peer-reviewed one, that wishes to attract talented entrepreneurs. A series of video content would certainly achieve that, yet that type of content should have a similar direction with the official campaigns, otherwise the attracted people might not be the one it aims for. The proposal doesn't make it clear what the content will be, there is no general script, not even a general topic of the videos that would help the community determine if they would vote for it.

Video is an engaging format for marketing. For finding potential proposers, there may be more targeted ways of distribution than blasting through all platforms (it is not 100% like advertising for a consumer product).

The use of comedy videos for attracting proposers to Catalyst is not ideal. The audio visuals of IOHK and Catalyst town halls get substantial coverage and will get the required result once Smart contracts are in place.

Catchy videos are good for a broader audience! I think this will have a positive impact for proposers outreach for 2 reasons:
* Spreads the word about cardano, thus more people may get involved directly in Catalyst
* More people will learn about Cardano and this will help proposals in other challenges since target audience for such proposals will already be familiar with the Cardano ecosystem.

This proposal can make the IdeaScale project more popular among crypto community, as the submitters look like real professionals, but that appears to be a pure marketing campaign, without any technological aspect and as I can see now, IdeaScale becomes more popular from day to day by itself

I think they would be able to deliver the product - video - but their outreach (85k followers on tiktok) - it is not much imo. So I do not think that the outcome would be that large, as they expect, but they would be able to deliver such videos.

The team behind the proposal seem to have experience in creating a certain type of video content that has the potential to become viral. Yet the proposal describes the production of 5-10 videos, which is quite a big difference. Will there be 5 videos, or double, 10? It is hard to estimate it the allocated time and budget are appropriate if the number of videos they wish to produce is not known.
The experience seems in line with the proposal made, and previous works seems of quality. The plan is detailed enough with milestones and timelines

The proposers have demonstrated the capability to produce videos that get the required traction in social media. With this talent and dedication, the team is likely to produce quality content as claimed.
team is experienced with good portfolio and the plan of implementation is described, but also it could be good to have ane demos on each stage, which is not mentioned.

I could not find metrics on how to measure it. Maybe the increase of followers? A number of likes?  Still, it would provide no value and we could not confirm the relation between the number of ideas and this project.

The team presents itself as being talented, however the proposal doesn't provide enough detailed information regarding the content of the videos, only a promise that they will be funny and viral. There is also no detailed budget, not even a mention on how much will be spent on ads and how much on content creation.

The provided plan is very detailed and realistic. The team should be able to catch the attention of many eyes. The conversion rate may be not as high as usual consumer goods due to the nature that we are looking for proposers.
I would like to see a partitioned budget, but otherwise the plan seems solid, the amount of work defined and the objective clear.

Reaching out to proposers by information videos is a novel idea. There is a substantial reach for funny/comedy videos. However, the effectiveness in attracting serious proposers outside the blockchain industry with capability by this kind of video may not be great.
The proposal effectively addresses the challenge but it is lacking documentation. Please create an actual WP.

This proposal is a great and complex implementation that improve dramatically the transactions volume on Cardano blockchain, because DeFi (liquidity providing and farming) applications attract enormous amounts of users and monetary value. The proposal clearly articulates how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and for the stakeholders (in deep detail for users, traders and so on.. ). However the objective of the proposal not only related to Cardano but versus other PoS Blockchain.

Case not clearly made on how this benefits end users. These types of strategies would definitely benefit the traders who are followed. It is basically a system that automatically enables those traders to front-run their followers. They will always buy and sell before their followers. The bigger this gets the more unstable it will make the ecosystem enable pump and dump by the traders who are followed.
This proposal took the challenge and applied a real world lens to it. As well gave proof of concept with examples.

Congratulations. For me it is one of the plans being described perfectly.  It will have to compete with a number of other systems of the same kind, bt this proposal fits in the idea of Cardano, well thought and careful design
The problem was stated clearly and the solution of using automated trading was explained thoroughly. There is even a whitepaper posted.

The proposal team is completed skilled and have a good trade-off  between business and technical knowledge, so in my opinion will able to make surely a good pilot or MVP (I have 20 years experienced in information technology related to financial services industry). In relation to the possible success of the initiative, I think that trading functionalities are incredible evolving in the market during the last years, so there are a lot of possibilities for the adoption by the traders and by financial institutions. Further I think it's important to improve details about the process related to the issue related to the market or capital risk.
It appears the proposers have not yet figured out how they are going to implement this so it is hard to guarantee they will be successful in implementation.
The plan as presented demonstrates high quality work with an emphasis on proving itself as viable. This proof is cited.

Documentation is excellent and descibes all phases correctly and proportional. It will take a year before fully operational and the funds requested are in line or even below what I think will be needed to create the project. I have a feeling that testing the system will require more time (and money).
I think that the roadmap is a good map for success but there needs to be more contingency planning and risk analysis done.

The proposer provides a step-by-step plan for the implementation with clear milestones and a defined time horizon. The only thing I miss in this area is that the proposer has not mentioned possible difficulties and how to deal with them.. The proposal offers a realistic timetable to complete the work. The proposer has considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation

More detail on exactly how the algorithms will be implemented, and how they will choose the followers should be detailed. THe proposer should also make more of a case as to why this type of fund is beneficial to users and highlight some of the risk entailed in following this type of strategy and how they could minimise them (ie front running and pump and dump issues).
This proposal as presented makes sense and seems very viable. I am just looking for more information on the team..

This is indeed an important challenge that should be implented sometimes soon in the future, especially since it will potentially make access to ADA easier. The amount of set budget however is very high and there is no rationale why it needs to be that high, even, after it was asked for in the comments.

DeFi/CeFi has been booming in the blockchain sector in 2020, creating some seasoned developers, fin-tech professionals who could lead the pack within Cardano community. With the successful Goguen release and proved track record, these individuals will be looking to apply their knowledge on a proven platform. Currently, Catalyst development community is spread thin over various challenges and proposals, but has high enthusiasm and spirit to take on new projects. It is still early on to expect any major developments in this area from the community, but nonetheless possible to achieve results.

I believe that the Catalyst community would be able to submit good proposals to this challenge since it has a similar technical side as the DeFi challenge, and this one has great proposals already. Although, there are probably taxation problems that might make it unfeasible to create such a seamless, almost zero taxes international transaction system.
The criteria and metrics are sufficient and measurable. However they might be a bit biased, as the proposer indicates he already has a solution for the challenge.

Cardano is in the early stages of becoming a platform where individuals will manage their identities, ownership, assets and more. The proposed challenge setting would allow the community to explore possible use cases utilizing Atala Prism that are outside of IOG's scope at the moment. This would accelerate outreach and mass adoption throughout industries and drive brand recognition.

I see this challenge as a very promising one, specially due to the mentioned aspects that make Cardano a great choice to use DIDs. It would be an excellent use case to bring awareness of Cardano technology. It also makes sense in this case to aim using a specific tool since it's being developed by IOHK to serve as a basis for the Cardano ecosystem.

It is worthwhile to examine DID use cases. The future of self sovereignty depends on robust and actually decentralised DID and Cardano is uniquely positioned to provide it. A challenge in this area could be a good way of eliciting useful new use cases and project teams to pursue them.

This challenge would be very technical and specific, and I am not sure if the Catalyst community today would have enough people involved to create 5 high quality proposals in this area. Although, this could bring new people to the experiment. I believe that the budget could be a bit lower since it's the first time that such a Challenge would should up and since this is a technical and specific field, I think it would be better to have like 150k or 200k maximum to fund only high quality proposals.

What I like about this proposal is that it addresses the challenge. It's a very good idea explanation and bringing Atala PRISM mass-scale adoption will be extremely important to Cardano.
The outcome and idea proposal would have been much stronger and bolder if they were sustained by additional information and data collected from solid sources in the proposed area, thereby creating a sort of triangulation in your data to be in a better position to draw such conclusions and recommendations ... making them much more credible and authentic.
Different types of use case for DID are within the capability of the community to come up with and some will be more able than others to implement.

The proposer has a great understanding of what is required to measure performance and success of the project, and has identified areas to track data for assessment. Following these KPIs should provide with sufficient understanding of the progress.

As I see, the main key metric in this Challenge would be how many places Cardano reaches out to due to the proposals submitted in this challenge, and also how many daily users, as already mentioned in the possible campaign brief. Other specific metrics should be included based on specific use cases for DIDs, but the ones mentioned are a very good start point.

The success criteria are clear, however a bit narrow as they are very focused on one aspect. The metrics could be more diversed and consider more aspects of the topic to enable more diverse proposals. Overall, they are executable, bit still there would be more potential.
The peer-reviewed process is obviously a big factor for Cardano development, however it is certainly not equally available or accessible to all.

It is difficult to ascertain the proposed challenge setting will support Cardano's mission directly. One can envision the proposed challenge setting would attract more researchers and solidify Cardano's established image as a research driven blockchain project. Presently, researchers need to find a profit oriented solution to study in order to secure financing from interested parties. This presents a great opportunity for Cardano to expand its mission statement and support the academic community which presently makes up the core of IOG.

This challenge is very relevant in the context of decentralized knowledge development. It's a way to Cardano itself improve over time, and I see this as a seed to what would substitute IOHK's current role as development budget provider. I believe also that other topics besides the ones mentioned in the text could be covered by this challenge.
Proper research of related topics will be very beneficial to the Cardano Ecosystem, especially if it is independent. This challenge has the potential to be very valuable to the ADA community

Great idea. Needs more funds. No point making a challenge that can only fund 4 researchers for 2500 ea. Its also important to make sure this challenge if accepted gets promoted at universities and research institutions around the world (to be honest I think this is also the case for all project catalyst funds in general).

Cardano is a blockchain differentiated by its approach of first principles approach to academic research, academic research and this challenge is fully aligned with this concept.

With the full launch of Goguen, we will have hundreds of projects under development and we need to continue pushing for the construction of a solid foundation and much of that goes through studies and research.

One of the points raised in relation to the reason for importance was to create research on important topics without reinventing wheels. But I believe that in many fields related to blockchain, innovation is necessary and reinventing the wheel or creating a new wheel can be valid options, since several problems that blockchains are helping to solve are new implementations and many never seen before, so I think that we must keep the field of possibilities wide.

This might be useful to think about once the roadmap is implemented and we are looking to renew and or augment research and implementation that IOHK have been conducting, but for now there may be more immediate things to address through challenges.
The Catalyst community includes highly educated people that went through the peer-reviewing process already. I'm certain that more papers can be published by the community.

Cardano has already attracted attention of the academic community being the first research based cryptocurrency. Giving them support to develop within their own field without having to learn anything about blockchain would embed good brand recognition that can be carried forward into the future.

I am not completely sure about how many science people are already involved in the Catalyst community, but this challenge could bring a lot of new people to it. Anyway, at least 4 papers will be funded and this is probably not too much and could be fulfilled by the existing members.
Despite only a minor portion of the community having the ability to research on the topic, the small initial fund should not make it a problem to get at least some good proposals in this challenge.

I see no difficulty that this challenge can be addressed. There are already some proposals in Catalyst aimed at developing proof of concepts and research and the Cardano community is one of the most accustomed to this concept. We can count on the expertise of several researchers from the community,  from IOG and Emurgo.
Ahead of implementation of the roadmap it is hard for the community to set out or assess scope of work in terms of proposals, although the time for this may come.

The author has given good thought to their challenge setting initiative and believes this can serve as a breeding ground for further research into blockchain focused products. It is possible to expand this challenge setting to cover more than just one academic field of research and provide support to wider community. Low cap amount is sustainable and puts less pressure on the community. Suggested KPIs are sufficient to provide feedback about the ongoing success of this challenge and its proposals.

The verification of such a challenge would be more tricky then the other ones. The peer-to-peer review would already be the audit of such proposals. Also, I believe a deadline for paper release should be clear, like 3 or 6 months, since these areas evolve so fast that if it takes too long, there is a risk it would not be relevant when it's released. Besides that, the suggested key metrics are great.
Lets also add metrics on research being picked up in mainstream media and leading to application in Cardano (be it technical, governance etc).
Relevant metrics were defined in order to verify the success of the challenge, but no time was set for the verification of the metrics.

These are perhaps criteria for the proposals to be assessed by rafter the event rather than by which the challenge for them is set. Capability and credentials might be good metrics to try to elicit so that the community could choose between proposals.

Cardano's mission might have to expand in order to include the ever-expanding and changing blockchain use case. NFTs give the ability to securely verify ownership of any asset, which might become beneficial to future onboarders of the technology is developing nations. Having another NFT challenge setting will give current running/funded projects a chance to compete for more capital in order to secure more Human Resources. It is difficult, however, to state that NFT is high on a priority for Cardano's growth at the moment.

Establishing Cardano as the top platform for NFTs would almost certainly drive a significant adoption of the blockchain and thus assist in furthering Cardano's agenda as a whole and in time in all aspects of it. However I have some reservations about how this project is formulated, see the reasoning for the other scores for clarification.

This proposal is well aligned with Cardano's goals. Indeed NFT are very much in the spotlight right now and Cardano is probably the best blockchain for its developments. There are some NFT related proposals being submitted in other challenges, specially in the Dapps challenge, but it would be very good to have one challenge specifically for this and aiming in more variety of utility as well.

Since there already are some proposals being submitted in other challenges, I believe that Catalyst community is very capable of submitting very good proposals here as well. It might be good if the most of them highlights the benefits of having NFTs in Cardano, as mentioned in the text, and this should be clearly stated in the challenge if this proposal wins.

Certainly. When observing the large number of proposals related to NFT in Catalyst and this is self-evident. Today we already have dozens of proposals in the area of NFTs and a wide variety of niches among them.

it is important to note that there are currently many quality proposals related to NFTs in Catalyst and creating a specific challenge is just listening to natural demand.
The criteria on how many NFTs are traded via the cardano blockchain can indeed be measured on the blockchain and could be quantified, as well as their frequency.

Interesting metrics have been defined, but I believe there is room for many others. I believe that metrics that indicate the volume of transactions and number of users are good examples of what can be included.

The definition of success defined for the challenge is reasonable.

I think it is important to include a window of time for the success of the challenge to be verified.

There are plenty people that know how to set up a stake pools and can teach it to others or execute it for them. A lot of people that might not have done it before might even put in some efforts if an incentive like that is provided and they are less scared of failure costing them substantial amounts of money
I don't know if it will help onboard new users to Cardano. But potentially create a lot of value for the users/institutions already on the blockchain.

It would be a challenge setting in July/August, which corresponds with Alonzo mainnet launch and SingularityNET's (partial) migration to Cardano. 
Dedicating a challenge to this entry would strengthen the bond between our and their community and thus make our ecosystem stronger.

I'm not convinced that this challenge is critical to achieve Cardano's mission but its an excellent idea and I feel is a worthy submission. I note some discussion regarding what the focus should be but I believe it's the sort of challenge better left open to see just how creative people can get with their proposals.

Entrenching the connections that already exist between Cardano and SingularityNet would result in a higher likelihood that if Cardano's near to medium term goals are achieved they would survive in a future dominated by AI. Especially if that AI would be centralised in nature.

AI's and decentralised ledgers are made for each other. I would question whether this challenge shoudl apper to be favouring singularityNet over any other AI groups/protocols. The Challenge should focus in bringing in the AI community at large, not favour one given community.

Ben Goertzel has addressed future and present collaboration with Cardano and how beneficial it will be for both ecosystems to work together. Singularity Net's goals and aspirations can prove to be beneficial to Carano's mission, but it is difficult to ascertain this partnership as critical at this point in time.

I believe this is a very good challenge and since SingularityNET will be a strong player inside Cardano's ecosystem, I think that this is very appropriate. I also don't any problem in suggesting partnership with SNET because this is much more related to SNET community than to the platform itself. Budget is quite high, but I think it's fair and I believe that the outcome of such a challenge would be very good.

I think so. SingularityNet could be an incredibly powerful technology. But we need to find out ways to use it, to solve real world problems. I'm sure there are many people on Project Catalyst with creative ideas on how the technology can be used effectively, in combinations with other products being built on the blockchain.

This is a great way to onboard the AGI community to Cardano and Project Catalyst. 
A partnership like that is beneficial for both. 
Both communities are highly motivated, so there is little doubt about the Catalyst community's capacity to address the proposed challenge. 
As there has been great anticipation for this event in both communities, it is likely that it would be accepted with enthusiasm.

Strongly feel that once the community started to wrap their heads around this challenge that some really innovative and left of centre concepts might start being generated which is partly what PC is all about.

If the aim of this challenge setting would be to build bridges between the Catalyst community and the SingularityNet community then I'm certain that in time the Catalyst community would be able to do so. But if the scope of the challenge would be to actually build AI applications on SingularityNet, originating from the Catalyst community, then I think that's something outside the current incarnation of Catalyst. The objectives of the challenge should be more clearly expressed if resubmitted in a future round.

Ben Goertzel has voiced his vision for Singularity Net launching their own project Catalyst alongside Cardano's in order to cast wider net over the AI tech sector and attract talent. It is challenging to assess how current Catalyst community can provide benefit to AI research, however they can explore areas of potential collaboration.

Since this challenge would be a bridge between Cardano and SingularityNET, I believe that both communities would be capable of, together, submitting very good proposals in this challenge. The budget can also be sufficient to accommodate very good and well structured proposals. I believe that SNET community might have very good proposals waiting for funding, and now they could benefit from Catalyst as well.

This is a very deep area which IOHK and Singularity are thinking about and it may be worthwhile saving the engagement of the community, and Treasury funding, until there are some more concrete tasks we can help with in a. challenge.
Seems alright. Ideally we want the proposers to be very familiar with SingularityNet and possibly have created or started building AIs for it already.

The metrics and criteria set in the proposal are correct and emphasise the scale of the potential market. The guiding questions provide clarity towards possible proposers and encourages them to think how AI can come to the benefit of the blockchain by combining forces. Great reasoning behind the budget decision. Thank you for including this as it makes clear how careful it was considered.

I feel success criteria are valid and author has certainly put some thought into this submission. It is the sort of challenge that I feel would benefit from a slightly different approach re: budget allocation where many smaller projects are encouraged to be submitted with the rationale that they seek further funds as they progress ( I realise that system informally operates at present).  Call it a flash fund...no idea is too small.

The proposer has identified several KPIs to track performance and progress of the participants in this challenge setting. Should this proposal go forward, this list will need to be expanded upon to gain more accurate understanding of the collaboration between the two platforms and how its benefiting their ecosystems.

Success criteria is clear and well defined. Key metrics for the challenge are good as well, but I would like to see some suggestions of KPIs and key metrics for the proposals submitted in this challenge. I believe that the majority of KPIs in this sense would be proposal specific, but some guidelines in this regard would be good.

I think the metrics would need to be thought about carefully to dovetail well with particular objectives we might have for a challenge leading to Treasury funding of particular development ideas for AI, but these are some interesting metrics and criteria to add into that when the time is right.

It is absolutely critical to the success of the Cardano ecosystem to constantly iterate monetary policies. This will help increase it's benefits for as many people as possible and increase resilience of the system against manipulations, bad actors and errors.
I like this idea, I think it is in very compliance of Cardano is aiming to achieve, and thus, further exploration of the whole monetary policy would be useful.

This is an exciting and novel area that is under developed in the Cardano ecosystem. A robust monetary policy that is developed after exploring an array of potential options will be invaluable. 
The challenge question, importance indicator, and success indicators are clear and transparent. I appreciate that this challenge is directed at a broader audience of participants within Cardano. While the current focus on devs and dApp development is necessary, incorporating more economists, social scientists, and financial experts will only strengthen the ecosystem's applicability and adoption.

While it is not absolutely crucial to explore alternative objectives for Cardano, it will be beneficial in the long term. The financial system as we know it is testing its limits, and should it reach the end of its possibilities, the world will turn its eye towards something more robust. Cardano should research ways to position itself into an advantage point prior to this occurring.

Taking a proactive step towards researching and exploring the vital topic of monetary policy will enable Cardano to grow and expand more easily in the future by enabling foresight into the matter and by identifying potential risk and dead ends.

Cardano monetary policy is important if ADA is to achieve its goal. A decentralised currency should have a decentralised organisation in charge of its monetary policy. But what should this be and how do we govern it?

For Cardano to be a global financial system, we need to have more and more great minds being part of the journey, and this funding could help in a very good way.
Research must be done to explore this whole new world, as the greatest human's collective intelligence experiment is moving forward.

This challenge is aligned with the goal of bringing more people and visibility to Cardano, as well as improving the long term adoption. If the monetary policy if robust and science based, it will attract the attention of lots of people and it would make it easier for ADA to be the leading currency in the world.

Fungibility, Durability, Divisibility, Portability and Acceptance are characteristics that define what good money is. When Bitcoin came into being it wasn't considered a store of value, but its properties and the immutability of these properties over time made Bitcoin a store of value.

ADA can also be a store of value, but the biggest challenge for this is monetary policy, so this is a topic that is totally relevant for a blockchain that intends to become widely accepted and fulfill the ideal for which cryptocurrencies were designed, give power back to the individual.


One of the aspects that guarantees the security of a PoS blockchain is the cost to cause a 51% attack, so in theory the greater the ADA's market value, the greater the relative security. Because of this, it is important that monetary policy is designed to preserve the value of the currency and create incentive mechanisms (annualized income subsidized by inflation + treasury). In the future the idea is that the fees replace the subsidy and the incentives to use feedback to the security of the protocol.

Studies on monetary policy are essential for the community to understand the impact of changes in the blockchain's base parameters. Over the past few months we have noticed a considerable increase in the transaction fees of the blockchain as the tx fee doesn't take into account the price appreciation of the ADA asset. This type of tx fee will be defined by governance and for the community to make this type of decision it is essential that there are people studying the impact of these changes. Today the IOG is in charge of this work, but creating this challenge will allow the community to begin to assume an important role for the decentralization of Cardano.

I am not sure that this is the most urgent matter for which we should set a challenge at the moment, although it is good to be showing interest in it and to be thinking about ways that the community can contribute to ideas about monetary policy. In particular it is important that transaction fees should be sustainable, which is both about making sure they remain affordable but also that they remain in demand , which is a complex matter, especially with the addition of layers like Hydra coming on top of Cardano which may provide opportunities in that regard. It may be worth waiting until IOHK's research and proposals in this regard are clearer. What arguably should never be questioned is the need for ADA as the key to EUTXO in the base layer, and the value of its being scarce and highly functional. Systems which enable it efficiently to be lent and borrowed will emerge over the next year that will give a much better idea of how this can work practically to manage use parameters that may be important.

This challenge might be difficult to adress to a notable portion of the Cardano community, however due to the nature of the challenge being on monetary policy connected to crypto and the fact that some people in crypto came there via the route of the interest in monetary policies, there might be a sufficient number of savants in the community to at least present a small number of valid proposals.

I am quite skeptical here because I just think that there is more of a developer or IT-educated people, rather than economics, but once this section gets approved, definitely we can find some proposers.

This catalyst community certainly has the capacity to address this challenge. Not only will existing members likely have ideas on how to achieve this challenge, the opportunity to increase community outreach and involvement is necessary. Through many discussions on discord, and elsewhere, it is often noted that the community requires a diverse background of expertise and monetary policy spans many professions that would help Cardano but are not necessarily involved at this time. 

It is also very encouraging that any monetary policy be developed by and for the community. Allowing for an iterative development process that provides community members opportunities to participate in its development truly speaks to the nature of what we are trying to achieve through catalyst. In particular, as the funds continue to grow in available rounds, having a principled and reasoned approach to monetary policy can help overcome both known and unknown challenges.

Cardano is known amongst some academic demographic, but it is difficult to say if it attracted the attention of the financial world. With time, this could be the right challenge for the ecosystem, if the right audience exists to take on the challenge.

Varying degrees of interest into the topic of monetary policy is naturally coupled with an interest and desire to participate in crypto in general. So I feel the Catalyst/Cardano community would more than be up to this challenge if presented. High quality research, papers and articles are bound to be produced by the community if this challenge is set.
This challenge could also attract talented and capable economists from outside of the Cardano/Project Catalyst ecosystem by incentivising research into the field and thought development.

The more is see, listen and talk with people in the community, the more i trust it, deeply.
One of the goal of our community is to work in harmony with the scientific world or scholars. 
I can't see any reason for this challenge to fail.

I believe that the current Catalyst community itself may have some limitations to create proposals in this specific area, since it is very technical and would need very specific knowledge. Nonetheless, some people might have this kind of knowledge, and just didn't have yet the opportunity to show it. Also, this could attract people outside from Catalyst or even Cardano, as mentioned in the proposal itself, and it could help to bring more visibility for the whole Cardano ecosystem.

There are no major technical challenges that involve creating proposals in this challenge, only people with knowledge in economics, game theory, incentive models and knowledge in blockchain. The Cardano community has people with knowledge in these areas and as the budget set is relatively low, the risk of funding this challenge is small.

This is a very technical area that is waiting for input from IOHK fro the community to be able to be properly engaged, but it is good that this challenge has been proposed so that people in the community can start to think deeply about what is important about monetary policy and how it works.

The criteria and metrics are diverse and well-defined in order for them to ensure the auditability of the potential proposals and also allow a number of diverse proposals exploring different aspects of the issue.

The proposer has clearly thought out an extensive list of measurement indicators to prove whether the challenge will be a success. The indicators allow for a wide range of activities to be undertaken in the challenge so that innovation can continue to be pursued. 
I would have appreciated a bit more details on the budget and how $50,000 was decided as the right number? Is this reasonable for this type of work?

The proposer has demonstrated a deep understanding of what a successful monetary policy challenge looks like. They have presented an extensive list of KPIs and performance metrics to follow. Potential expansion of this challenge could include students majoring in Business who could apply for a Cardano grant with a proposal "case study" etc.
The definition of success is clearly outlined and would be easy to understand to future applicants. The metrics are appropriate and would be a easy to quantify and measure.

I think even more important than the metric stated are that proposals emerge which can challenge and improve the way Cardano Monetary policy is currently conducted. Maybe we end up with an elected board of governors in a Cardano Central Bank DAO. what are the governance procedures for it?

There are probably no real metrics that could be used to measure progress of the challenge at the begining.
The only metric i can measure right now, is the budget, and it seems to be a little bit too low as the challenge is to keep creating a new global financial system, almost from scratch, while boarding some of the greatest minds out there, at least, those who have not heard about cardano and catalyst project yet.

The success criteria is clear, and proposed matric are very good. They will lead the goals of proposals under this challenge and they are very broad and embracing. It would be good to have some quality check in regards of verifiability in this case instead of only numbers, since some metrics could be easily achievable if quality is not taken care of.

The definition of success is relevant to indicate the performance of the challenge and the metrics described present a good range of indicators to assess the performance of the challenge. The only point that needs to be improved is the definition of a time interval to assess the success of the challenge.

The metrics are all interesting and not un-useful if we get to the point of needing to examine closely whether policy should change and why, but I do not personally think we are at that point and it is worth seeing how Goguen and Hydra are implemented and how adoption evolves over the next year before assessing that we should have such an introspective process running. It may be that more practical metrics as to what might be achieved by such introspection should be used should we come to needing it. For the time being though lets focus on finishing the implementation of the roadmap and boosting adoption by. communicating the excellent base monetary policy and hopefully the high quality research based implementation of it through eg Babel Fees and Hydra for microfinance. In that sense encouraging clear communication materials around these matters is worthwhile, but maybe that should be IOHK/Cardano Foundation responsibility rather than Catalyst.

While this challenge could indirectly contribute to cardanos success by possibly advertising project catalyst, it is not directly focused on the cardano network. In it's current formulation it rather sounds like an individual proposal than a funding challenge, which could in a best case scenario add some value and popularity to Cardano but is in fact not critical to it. I encourage the proposer to propose a similar, fine-tuned proposal in a NFT ore generating popularity/value related funding challenge though.

This is a fantastic idea! The "Jodorowski Dune" of Cardano as a short film NFT.
In terms of impact and alignment, this proposal have the potential to establish very valuable assets :
-Assembly line for creating future audio/video assets 
-Artists Collectives within the Cardano Network (Audio/Visual/Design/etc...)
The video examples the proposer have listed are great to convey the idea, but a clear and precise composition/tone/style is missing.

Keeping the Cardano style of showcasing Mathematicians, the proposer's use of Fibonacci sequence for pricing the NFT is very well positioned. A consideration is to the accessibility for a regular ADA holder to participate after the 40th bid?

The idea has merit but seems to have adopted a massive project that does not necessarily meet the criteria for the challenge. The author acknowledges that the budget is extreme. I would suggest a smaller proposal based on similar principles might be workable with attention to Fund challenge being noted.

It is difficult to extract what exactly the proposer is suggesting here, however, one can assume they aim to promote Project Catalyst and therefore Cardano with an NFT marketing campaign. It is also unclear why this has to be an NFT project and can't simply be a filmography-oriented challenge. Overall, it does not appear to be critical to achieving Cardano's mission.
This would be one of many possible marketing formats for Cardano. Its not clear this one is critical to Cardano's misison.

There is a real need to attract attention to Cardano's NFTs since it's probably the best blockchain for this application. The proposal is very good, and there is also another challenge setting with similar idea. In this case specifically, as mentioned in the comments section in IdeaScale, the challenge should not suggest the use a specific platform, as it does and it is also mentioned the use of NFT-DAO in the key metrics of the challenge. I believe that the challenge setting is great, but because of that I can only give it a rating of 3 for alignment.

The description of the challenge question and the description of the importance are subjective.

In general, NFTs are an important topic and deserve a challenge, but this challenge does not present a clear idea of what proposals can originate.

The challenge description is full of jargon, technical terms, references and catchphrases that do not aid in the description. My recommendation is that the description of the challenge should be concise because several people will need to rely on this description to make proposals. If there is no objectivity and clarity in the purpose, confusion occurs and this reduces the efficiency and productivity of the participants.

The description mixes the concepts of the creator's personal proposal with the concept of the challenge and ends up generating confusion.

There is no way to indicate the alignment of this challenge with Cardano's mission as there is no clarity as to what it is about.

I think it is great to think about ways that Catalyst could be used as art itself, but that this might deter be structured as a proposal for something specific rather than a challenge. This is because at this stage we are trying to encourage functionality, development and adoption of the Cardano network in an increasingly competitive environment and so our challenges should be directed more towards areas dealing with those aspects.

The tasks neccessary to conclude such a challenge (e.G. creation of art/animation, it's marketing and creating an NFT for it might be tangible for a part of the catalyst community. Still the description makes it hard to grasp the exact requirements and skills for fulfilling the task envisioned. Thise could have been formulated more concrete.
While the community has the capacity to create NFT art and marketplaces, this proposal is not really a challenge, but a bucketed proposal in itself.

Difficult to gauge as too many variables and hence why this proposal needs to begin in a scaled back version. Collaborating and plan building as it progresses. Again the author acknowledges the risk but has not taken necessary steps to show how we can mitigate that risk.

There has been an explosive interest from outside of the blockchain audiences towards crypto because of NFTs. This has attracted many to project Catalyst and since the last fund, there have been projects in the running to get funded with relation to NFT space. Taking this into account, as well as increasing amount of onboarders every day, it can be assumed that the Catalyst community will have the capacity to address whatever this challenge is in Fund7.

Some NFT proposals have already been submitted in other challenges in the past Funds and I don't see any difficulties on the Catalyst community coming up with new proposals for this specific challenge. Although, I don't agree much with the calculating done to set the challenge budget. It seems to be too much, as it's asking for the whole Fund or even more, if available. NFTs project really are very important, but the budget could be set to be smaller and, later on, if successful, it could increase for new Funds. Such a big Fund specific for NFTs could even create space for funding low quality proposals.

The Catalyst community is fully capable of developing NFT-related proposals, but the challenge description is extremely confusing and this does not allow us to identify which proposals can be created. In addition, the description mixes ideas from a proposal with the concept of the challenge and there is no clarity of what the proposal is and what the challenge is.

The challenge is requesting the entire available budget and I think it is not feasible, even though there are dozens of proposals related to NFTs in Catalyst, creating an exclusive challenge for this niche will expand the budget above what I see as reasonable. If this challenge is approved, we will have an exclusive challenge to create proposals related to NFTs and in addition several other challenges also allow the creation of proposals on NFTs, because NFTs are a broad theme and fit into different niches.

I hope there will be many artistic people in the Catalyst community who might be interested in proposals like these, or challenges in respect of them, but maybe this should be pursued as a subgroup of Catalyst for that type of purpose. That could perhaps form part of a proposal.
Participation in creation of NFT art is one suitable metric, but the other metrics are not quantified or measure other things that are not directly related to the challenge.

This is potentially a great idea that needs to slow down a little, engage with the community and find a level of risk that is reasonable. If the author sets about making the connections within the CP community I believe they may progress this idea and develop metrics that are achievable.

The proposer suggested several KPIs which could serve as accountability metrics for the suggested challenge. This list can be expanded upon given the complexity of the challenge and the vision behind it. The proposer could also benefit in the future from applying common language and breaking down their vision into simpler terms. The success of one's endeavor depends on how clearly one is able to communicate it to others. We may all be able to read/write English, yet we all learn it in a different way and live in different areas, therefore simpler does more.

Success criteria is clear and well defined. Although, key metrics should be better worked out, because some of them are not metric but goals (e.g. "Exponential participation…", "Viability of NFT…", "Rewards for completing…", etc.). It should state key metrics related to proposals as well, for example, number of active users, number of NFTs and single digital assets created, trade volume in a specific period, etc. More information about how to check if the proposals have achieve their goals should be included in the proposal.

The metrics described are not objective indicators, in addition, one of the metrics is endorsing a particular proposal, which goes against the objective of the challenges. Remembering that the creator of the challenge filled out the self assessment checklist stating that there is no endorsement of a particular proposal, but mentioned the NFT DAO a few times and although he wrote that it was just an example, most of the description ended up being of the proposal and the concepts were mixed.

There are no reasonable elements to verify the success of this challenge.

For challenges we need criteria and metrics that can elicit high quality and specific proposals to address it and I think those appended would need more work to be worked into specific deliverables that could form part of a challenge int he future, or challenge within a subgroup of Catalyst proposal as referred to above.
I think that supporting and encouraging ideas that are completely experimental, unorthodox, or new in some way is very important to develop. It applies to everything if a development is a goal.

This is indeed an interesting proposal for a challenge. It indeed needs to be assured that new approaches are not shunned right away and get, as long as they are within legal framework. While I don't have the impression that new opinions get shunned or don't have the change to prevail if they are really well made, some kind of open discussion and sandbox environments could still be very beneficial to the Cardano ecosystem.

Maintaining a path toward distributive, novel, ideas is vital for the success of Cardano's mission in all the fields it's currently engaged with. Actively encouraging disruption would represent a unique approach.
