I believe this outside the box thinking is critical for enabling Catalyst to continue to thrive. The proposer mentions the echo chamber of today's society and the need to fight against the norm. Echo chamber defined - "an environment in which a person encounters only beliefs or opinions that coincide with their own, so that their existing views are reinforced and alternative ideas are not considered." This proposals ask a lot of the right questions, but also admits they do not necessarily have the answers. It is a refreshing view to admit the need for help and cultivate an open discussion.

It is important for an experimental community not to get locked in a tunnel visioned mentality. Therefore it might be interesting to provide an opportunity to explore what else might float in community members' minds that is not worked on yet because of mainstream thought processes dominating the platform. 
As stated, planting the seeds for this early on might grow in some hefty fruit-bearing trees later on and come to the benefit of all of us.

Whilst I may not feel that this challenge proposal is critical to achieve cardano's mission the author has certainly hit upon a useful concept. How to encourage those that swim against the tide. I feel the community will recognise the net worth of encouraging and welcoming all views even if they do not necessarily agree with them. This proposal is in line with the theme from references such as 'unleashing the masses'
Interesting idea. I am not sure how we manage to fund minority views in a challenge that is voted on in a majority way. This would need some new kind of voting and ranking mechanics

I believe that the idea to stimulate disruptive and innovative ideas should be something in the core of Cardano, and this proposal addresses that. This can improve Cardano in the long term, and even though it's not 'at first' linked to some goals related to challenge setting, it indirectly contributes in that direction. With a small budget like the one suggested, I believe that this is a very valid experiment.

One of the proofs of the relevance of this challenge is the very existence of Cardano. If it weren't for the minority and contrary view of Satoshi Nakamoto, we probably wouldn't be here today. If it were not for the opposite view of Charles Hoskinson on the direction of Ethereum we would not be here today.

I think it is important that the minority's opinion is not drowned out by the crowd. The debate must be guided by reason and common sense and not by popularity, as the majority did not always take society on the most promising path.

Regarding the legality of the ideas presented, I think it is important to indicate that legality is a complicated concept, ethics and legality are different things. Slavery was legal not too long ago.
The use of cryptocurrencies is legally banned in several jurisdictions with empty and misleading arguments (money laundering and terrorism are two puppets used by governments to gain popular support and mask real interests)

My point is that we shouldn't exclude ideas simply for legal compliance.´

To conclude, I think this challenge is important and is fully aligned with the mission of Cardano and Catalyst.

I would agree that "red team" self assessment is very worthwhile but I on't think it should be set as a challenge. The Catalyst process itself is designed (and evolving) to incorporate self assessment and challenge. It is good to remind ourselves of that and for all to participate in a constructive but challenging manner.
definitely creating a special fund for "groundbreaking" ideas would work, but how do we know which idea is more or less groundbreaking? But it can be done for sure.
While programming sandbox-like testnet environments might be a bit of a challenge, many other participation tools could probably be easily adressed by the community.

The proposal seems very promising in essence and theory, but in practice there might be a problem. How is a would be proposer to this category recognise his proposal as radical or disruptive accurately. How is the community to correctly identify an actually disruptive proposal without mistaking it for an outlandish and foolish view - being in the misunderstood minority often results in that. I see the small budget of this proposed challenge as both a blessing and a curse, you certainly don't want to experiment with a lot from the start on bold new ideas, but on the other hand truly disruptive concepts may require much more. Still, something well worth trying by the community.

From my experience in Catalyst the Cardano community will embrace "Contrarian, radical and bold ideas." Still, I do see a need to continue to reinforce this growth so we do not revert to just another mediocre cryptocurrency project. I believe creating the type of sandbox environment mentioned in the proposal is possible, but I would have liked more details about how this differs from the test net. Also, if funding is received what are the first steps to develop and deploy this proposal? Please continue to connect with community members to build a team.

The feasibility of this challenge proposal would depend heavily on the needs of the voterbase. If there are a lot of community members that would like to appease their curiosity at a relatively low strain on the fund budget, it is very likely that this proposal might pass.

The PC community is showing great resilience to date at remaining inclusive and open minded in the face of alternative views. The community welcomes challenging ideas and to date (in my experience) handles contrary view with respect and commitment. This type of challenge is likely to strengthen the community further.
I am sure the community can generate thses idea. The current governance of catalyst projects is based on majority voting however so I am not sure how we can implement it with the current framework.

Being part of Catalyst for 3 Funds so far, I've seen lots of people that have non-usual ideas that are not well accepted by the majority, but if we bring them all together and let the community vote, the outcome might be surprising. Since the budget it not large, I believe that the community will be very capable of writing good proposals in this challenge.

This challenge presents no technical barriers and this increase the reach of proposers. The defined budget is relatively low and was set to test the potential of the concept, which makes the resulting proposals have greater competition and with that the chances of a good quality proposal being funded increases.

This challenge primarily requires free thinkers and good ideas and the Catalyst community is full of people with these characteristics.

well, no metrics are stated in this project, but I do not need to see them at all. Having a given budget, and new ideas posted - and their realization will serve as an indicator, how good a decision it was.

What I think can be done is - having a fund for "experimental ideas" or ideas that "did not fit in" to any other section. Ideas posted in this fund would be an indicator.

Some of the criteria are quite possible to measure, while others might be difficult to quantify, especially given the fact that "non-traditional and contrarian views" can be defined quite differently for different people, given the fact that everyone has their own subjective views on what is contratrian and radical.

The aim of the challenge for now, in what I imagine would represent a first step, is the creation of networks, communication channels and sandboxes for the nurturing of fringe, potentially disruptive ideas. I would recommend clarifying and detailing this point and also expanding on the vision of how these networks, communication channels and sandboxes would then lead to the generation of disruptive, revolutionising ideas and practices.

The proposal attempts to set metrics to measure success, but they are still vague. There are 6 possible metrics listed and none of them have a fixed amount associated. It is challenging to define "non-traditional" or "contrarian" so it will be difficult to set static goals. Who gets to be the judge of visionaries, orthodoxy, or "a general sense of a widening" of community views? The nature of the problem the proposer is attempting to solve makes judging success difficult. My advice would be to start with a baseline of how many creative proposals you see per fund then set clear quantitative metrics for which Ouroboros can measure success.

The proposed challenge fund is set modestly, but correctly as it is meant to explore the community to reveal any hidden potential. The proposal is very broad for interpretation, which seems to be the point of the proposal.

Author has had a valid attempt at suggesting metrics suitable for the challenge. Funding budget may be a little low but can be revised. Some metrics will be difficult (but not impossible) to assess for example "a general sense of a widening, not narrowing, of the community's views, discussions, ideas, projects, focus". Overall however, the premise is sound and the proposal has merit.

More thought needs to go into how we enable and measure success here. In reality we want high failure rate, but big impact from a small number of successes. Funding for any individual project should be capped at a small percentage of total fund. There should be staged funding such that we cull quickly and early, but then provide follow on funding to the small number of successful projects.  Perhaps the goal is just to provide enough funding to get a project to an MVP where it can then go through another challenge and scale up to production? But is that different to many projects already?

The success criteria and metrics related to this challenge are well stablished from a general perspective. Although, it might be needed to create specific criteria for each project related to its specificities. The subjective impact of this challenge, however, might be more difficult to measure, but the community could be invited to give their opinion about the funded proposal(s).

The metrics described for success assessment are relevant and allow the community to check success in a tangible way.

The definition of success is reasonable.

I recommend including a time frame so that the success assessment can be more objective.
The metrics would need more work so as to suggest criteria by which self assessment in Catalyst for example could work better.

Securing the network and giving people (incl. but not limited to SPO or personnel from the three big orgs) incentives to test, educate themselves and others allows for more input into the secure development of Cardano.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: As stated in the proposal, assuring the security and robustness of the blockchain is integral to its success, and decentralized efforts would sure help to make it more secure if many different devs and SPOs etc. could inspect the security mechanisms and work on them transparently.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: Ecosystem security is about as mission critical as it gets. Devoting a challenge setting to it is certainly justified and I would urge the entire community to consider potential risks if we do not address the security aspect early on to maximise impact.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote:
Proper risk assessment and preparedness is key to every well laid plan. Setting up a mechanism for ensuring the backbone of the whole Cardano ecosystem can efficiently recover from an disaster situation would be a very smart thing to do.
The name of the challenge could be rewrote to better describe the actual challenge and make it more appealing to interested parties to participate.
Note: It would probably take a series a disasters to actually cause damage to the network, as the decentralised nature itself protects from a single disaster, but still.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: As pointed out by the proposer, establishing system support from within is crucial to maintain stability and security. Having SPOs be involved in the development of some of the upgrades, building out the architecture of a more robust network, having them communicate in an organized environment will set them up with tools necessary to ensure decentralization of the Cardano ecosystem. This challenge setting is a proactive action that will act supplementary to the main Cardano mission.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: This challenge is well aligned with some of the guiding questions of the challenge. A more secure network will make it easier to increase adoption, might attract the attention of lots of ADA stakeholders, specially SPOs, and the outcome would benefit the whole community. Some initiatives by IOG have been going on related to the security of the network, but I've not seen one specific for stakeholder operability. I am not sure if it already the time to focus on this points, but as mentioned, it would be good to have some tests doing on during testnet.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote:
There are several intrinsic risks to a blockchain and this challenge is a good way to study those risks and propose solutions to increase the blockchain's resilience in the event of attacks.

IOG has done a great job in research to design the blockchain security consensus mechanisms, but in the end it is all about incentives. Every blockchain has a cost to be attacked. The development of Ouroboros Omega was recently announced and the development of a self-healing concept was mentioned. This challenge is a step in the same direction that IOG itself is going, but with the added benefit of engaging the community and decentralizing the blockchain security process among members of the community.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote:
For me this challenge setting is adressing a super-important topic. In established companies there is typically a dedicated risk-assessment and risk-management team. I highly support such a proactive and systematic approach also for CARDANO. The following ideas could be investigated and incorporated into this challenge setting:

1) This could contain an even wider screening of potential risks, such as CyberSecurity, political and regulatory risks, internet-related risks etc.

2) Investigate to what extent IOG and/or CARDANO Foundation are already working on this. We need to make sure that this challenge setting is utilizing all potential synergies.

3) Make this to an integral part of Cardano branding strategy. Proactive risk assessment & management by the community would be another great argument and 'USP' for CARDANO.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: I think a challenge is not needed for this matter at this time, as much thought already goes into Cardano in respect of its resilience one way or another. It does make sense though to highlight the need for SPOs to have their own resilience plans, and bare metal facilities with backup and a good range of relay partners if at all possible.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: Social engineering, impersonations, as well as political, regulatory, and business risks are topics that the greater community can and should contribute to.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: It takes a lot of knowledge and education to audit systems for their security, especially such complex systems, that even a notable portion of devs might not have. This might make it difficult, but probably not impossible to find a sufficient number of people involved in the process. Expecting several proposals however seems quite utopic. I think this would better serve as a concretized proposal than as a challenge.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: The community's SPOs have the experience to handle this challenge. They know best where possible pain points are and are best positioned to tackle these issues. So in terms of capacity to handle this, the infrastructure is already there.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: A lot of SPOs are part of the Catalyst community. What better source of drawing up tests and plans for recovery than the collective intelligence of the ones that have the most skin in the game.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: The Cardano ecosystem has plethora of highly motivated and variously talented SPOs who are involved in the process. This will give them yet another chance to share information and resources as well as provide incentives for doing so. Another benefit is this will give them a chance to stand out as the active and involved community members vs the idle stake pools that only provide delegation slots.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: The Catalyst community has some active SPOs that would probably submit proposals in the challenge, and also this would bring the attention of other stake holders. The amount asked for in the challenge is said to be used, for e.g., to reimburse some of the SPOs losses during stress testing, but for big SPOs I am not sure that this amount would be enough, depending on the duration of these tests. But in any way, I believe that if this is clearly communicated to individual stakers, mentioning that it would be a test to the improve the system itself, I don't see it as a big problem.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: This challenge has a different concept than the others and will require a more academic and theoretical approach. The Cardano community has hundreds of SPOs who can help to come up with proposals for this challenge.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: Yes, I think that the community is able to do this. Especially the SPO community can make major contributions to this. Together with an emerging team of community-elected experts, this can not only become an important activity, but also another source of income for SPO and experts.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: I am sure the community would have lots of knowledgeable people able to contribute to ideas in this regard but not all members would be interested, and there are better fora such as the Discord/Telegram/Reddit groups for advice on these matters.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: Most of the key metrics that have been set could be adressed by concrete projects and their success measured. However, there are far to broad for the small group of capable people that will be adressed by this challenge.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: A lot of potential risks are already listed in the proposal. Additional, possibly unknown ones are TBD through stresstesting.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: The proposed challenge offers metrics that should cover almost every conceivable type of threat that could be posed to stake pools. It addresses the need for incentivization models to be planned for to get SPOs on board. The definition of success is clear, understandable and would be easy to track.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: The proposer has given a thorough review of what is required in order to see this challenge setting become beneficial to the overall mission and long-term success of Cardano. Their suggested list of KPIs and performance metrics is a great way to track the progress of the perfoming SPOs.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: Well set out proposal. I think its also important to publish metrics on SPO's in terms of location, operating system, hardware diversity. This should be included in the SPO ranking analysis in Daedalus to encourage this.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: Success criteria and suggested metrics are good and clear. My only comment is related to the 'dedicated team' metric. If the team goal is work in building the plans related to disaster events only, it would be ok, but it should be noticed that a dedicated team for the network, if created, should be as decentralized as possible. Maybe people from different SPOs, countries, continents, etc.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote:
The definition of success is clear and well articulated, but I recommend defining a time interval so that the performance evaluation of the challenge is more objective.

The suggested metrics are good quantitative and qualitative indicators of the proposals resulting from this challenge.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: Even though the input to verifiability is not (yet) fully elaborated in detail here, future proposals could be based on very tangible KPI. There is lots of experience available in established industry segments, where best-practice-examples can be found.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: Including women and non-male identifying people is critical to build solutions for a better world.

Cardano thrives to be inclusive and representative. For this to be truly the case for Cardano it is essential to discuss measures to onboard more people identifying as women in the traditionally male dominated crypto space.

The proposal has a very strong argument: "If we do not widen the net, we won't capture talent. Women are 50% of the world's population and a major source of available talent." The fact that women are underrepresented in technology-oriented companies and projects for a variety of reasons deserves an additional effort by the Cardano community.

The (relative) poor engagement of women in Blockchain and Crypto represents a good opportunity for Cardano to distinguish itself from other projects and increase it's user base. The proposer has done a good job in supporting his argument in the challenge brief with external literature and also by making it clear that the challenge is about promotion rather the exclusive or sexist proposals.

Absolutely! I fully agree with the importance of raising the participation of women in the Cardano space, and would say the opposite of 'It may seem non-essential now', that it is essential now, and has been since the name ADA was chosen.  Move aside boys and tech-men, the stronger sex is on the rise!  More female leadership, less men in the mix (percentage wise!), and Cardano will thrive all the more.

I am a woman and can speak from experience when saying that initiatives designed to "attract women" or "specifically for women" are more often than not, a means to mask the preservation of the male dominated status quo. The initiatives that are actually sincere in their intentions, very rarely produce meaningful results.

It is widely known that the economic expansion in developed countries during the 20th century was in large due to Women entering prominent roles in every industry en mass. Creating a welcoming and tuned-for-success environment will aid in the attraction of the 50% of the population and hopefully finally break the "men only" tech sector stereotype.
Obviously we Cardano cannot become a significant part of the world economy without significant contributions from women.

I believe this challenged is very much aligned with Cardano's missing to be an open, inclusive and strong community, and this cannot be achieve without the participation of women. The challenge is very clear to address that it is not in any way promoting unfair treatment, but trying to leverage women participation in ways not yet foreseen, it's open for community ideas. I also believe, and that's my personal view, that incentives to create role models, or even quotas, are beneficial in some aspects, but not needing to appeal to that would be even better.

While it is hugely important that people of all genders are welcome in our community and given the tools to participate and achieve their dreams, I do believe that the community and protocol do this well and it is brilliant to see so many awesome women involved. Long may that continue. Women are by and large bigger adopters of crypto as it is and that should definitely be encouraged as decentralised identity and financial capability are critical in the modern world to everyone being able to achieve their goals. I don't believe though that this is a good topic for a challenge as challenges should be aimed at delivering functionality, development and adoption for everyone. It is always open fro proposals that target the female population for engagement on those particular aspects within challenges to be submitted so that we make sure any gender specific ideas that might help are drawn out.

Comments by personnel of the three big organizations drive the culture of the ecosystem. Unfortunately, these have often underlined the heteronormative view and reinforce contemporary conservative gender roles of the West. The Catalyst community should strive for improved equity among women, however, I evaluate this needs to come from the centrally organized organizations that currently drive most of the actual development and adoption of Cardano.

The diversity of the community is a big strength in this challenge, as the many different cultural and social contexts we come from can gelpt to adress many intersectional aspects of onboarding more women.

Of course, the Cardano community has the skills to meet this challenge. However, it will not be a quick win and there is no model solution either, it is about the willingness to face this question and to fight for change together.

The challenge is very open ended and could be addressed in many different ways. The creativity of the community would be able to address this. On the negative side, some community members could be skeptical of this challenge.

Again, Absolutely!  There are many active members, both women and men, who are working around these issues, and the numbers are growing every day.  This challenge would super-charge the growth of female participation in our Cardano ecosystem.

As an accomplished woman I know that talented and capable women are often put off by the fact that they're viewed as needing special assistance. 
How is it that it's ok to lump 50% of the population together and view them as a single block simply because of their gender? A lot of men would be (rightfully so) horrified by being equated to every other man simply because they share a gender.
I would also add that Cardano/Catalyst is an open, decentralised and democratic system, everybody's voice has a chance to be heard, everybody can participate. This is really not the space to be worried about anti-woman discrimination. There are definitely failings of society at large that reduce the participation of women in technical environments, those certainly need to be addressed, but apart from that it would be like forcing young girls to play with boys toys and calling ourselves progressive.
*I don't feel that the Cardano 360 example given is representative of the Catalyst community.

Currently, Cardano is proud to present several examples of Women being showcased at the front line of the ecosystem. They can act as examples and benchmarks for what is possible. This can be expanded upon by initiating the challenge to see what other ideas the community is able to come up with.
I don't know if the community has the resources. Do we have gender stats at the moment? Its easier to drive non-male focused outcomes from non-males.

The Catalyst community today has a small representation of women, there are some strong and very participative examples so far but they still are minority. Even though, I believe that the community could come up with several proposals regarding this topic, and it could even put lights on Cardano to bring more women to participate, and in this way the whole ecosystem would benefit from it.

While female role models are certainly important, they are not the metric to be measured for real progress. Not accounting for people's wishes for anonymity, self-identification of gender in combination of an increased presence in the ecosystem is a suitable metric - which is of course also used in other industries.

The metrics and success criteria set are well suited to measure the implementation of the challenge. The blockchain has the potential to even record many of those metrics and record their change over time if the future data and anonymity policies will allow it.

The success criteria suggested are all relevant but might be hard to measure e.g. "increased female presence in the Cardano ecosystem" how to you measure that ? or increase of female participation in Project Catalyst ?. A more simple metric could be external recognition of Cardano having higher female presence e.g. number external articles of social posts  mentioning Cardano and female engagement

Maybe I miss something, but, I do not see any such metrics... There is justification for the chosen budget, but to be honest, I am not sure what such metrics for evaluating success criteria, etc. would be. 
I do think that this challenge should and will achieve a high number of voters, and will provide springboards for adoption of Cardano.  May it become a challenge in Fund 7!
The proposer presented a sufficient list of KPIs and performance metrics to measure in order to track the progress of the challenge and its participants.
The success criteria and metrics suggested needs more focus. If we don't use quotas how do we drive it?

The verifiability if this could be a challenge since the idea is not to 'tick boxes' about this topic. The key metrics are good ideas and represent what should result from the proposals in this challenge, but it might be difficult to put a number on it. Even though the idea is not to 'tick boxes', some metrics like number of women in Catalyst, Discord, proposals, CAs an other places could be tracked for reference, but not as a goal. Maybe a subjective feedback should be assessed from those participating in Catalyst, or something similar to that.

Some good metrics there for measuring the challenge if it were to go ahead, but it might be good to focus on the degree to which women have been able to achieve their goals, in addition to the degree to which they are represented in different aspects of community and protocol participation.

While digital inclusion is certainly important (the Africa special had many good examples), giving people access to the internet and computers will not necessarily grow the Cardano ecosystem without specific purpose. Do you expect people who were presumably technology illiterate to have an interest in the Cardano community and making meaningful contributions? I do not see the connection.

As the target group is people that are excluded from society, you can not access these in schools (this is were funds could actually go to and have a program on Internet/Blockchain use).

The idea is good, but to jump from learning about computer and internet into the blockchain world might be very challenging. I believe a better challenge setting would be to enhance the digital inclusion in places where technology has not reached yet, for example, and link use this to make publicity for Cardano as an sponsor of digital inclusion. It would be worth it to check what is happening in Cardano Africa initiatives.

In general, this could be, if implemented correctly, an important measure to increase social digital inclusion in general and to some amount the interest and inclusion in Cardano. It needs to be minded that the measures are properly integrated and adapted to the people need and actuall access to devices and internet is considered.
Blockchain needs people connected to technology/computers/internet yes but the execution plan is lacking and requires many more details on how to accomplish.

The challenge presented is undoubtedly a very big issue for a large part of the global population. How could we expect the disenfranchised and the unbanked to participate in the revolution and the coming new age when they do not yet have the basic knowledge of computers and electronic tools and how they work. There is merit in pursuing solutions in this particular challenge. They would primarily need to be hands-on, face-to-face programs which would also be localised in different geographical areas around the world.

Increasing digital inclusion is a great mission, that aligns perfectly with the Cardano mission of empowering people in developing countries. 
Unfortunately the proposal for a challenge itself is not very well framed and might deter voters, it has a very brief explanation on why this is important and seems to focus on Brazil

While it is unfortunate that people all over the world have none or limited access to online content, Cardano's mission is to bank the unbanked, primary demographic target being within the African continent. This proposed challenge setting appears to be outside of those parameters and therefore not critical to achieve the current mission.

There is no challenge question. A statement was included in place of the challenge question, I recommend the modification for clarity of purpose.

Digital inclusion is a relevant aspect of Cardano's mission, but the rationale for this challenge needs further refinement to make it clearer what kind of proposals can arise from it.

Digital inclusion is a brilliant objective and Cardano's initiatives in Africa show how serious the community is about that. I think the idea here may be better suited to a specific proposal rather than a category of challenge however, as there are many agencies trying to encourage digital inclusion and we need to focus on things that will develop Cardano and its use across existing networks so that it can be adopted widely, including in areas lacking in digital inclusion.

The challenge would need most hardware than software to be executed. To bring people that are not already connected to the internet into the blockchain world would be very challenging. Regarding the digital inclusion side only, it would be more feasible.
Assuming there is a sufficient amount of Portugese speaking people within the community and some locals, it should have the potential to adress this challenge

Anyone can help each other in learning about computers, I think the community does that anyway because they are interested in what can be done with blockchain and want to share that with the world. Its not clear what this proposal is needing exactly.

The Cardano Community is spread globally. And inherent in our belief in Cardano is the spirit of adventure, of sharing and of entrepreneurship. Why else would we invest in a project which started on a whiteboard and for many years had no functional product? Because of this, the challenge presented here will be taken up by quite a number of ADA believers, including those who may not have been planning on putting through Catalyst proposals under the challenges we've focussed on so far. Most of us are too far removed from the African continent and could only help from afar by donations, etc. This challenge provides a number of us to assist locally and at the same time propagate Cardano to the uninitiated. I am very sure even those of us who live in the western world are aware of segments of our local populations who have not been lucky enough to have access to 21st century tools. I say bring it on!

We have already seen proposals in previous funds that would align with this challenge and the catalyst community is spread across a wide geographical area with many opportunities for impactfull proposals to be generated

At the moment Cardano is still very early in its grand scheme and we are yet to see its effect on the poverty levels of developing countries. Perhaps with more time and data, it will be possible to determine if certain success can be replicated in other regions of the world.

it is difficult to understand what kind of proposals can arise from this challenge, in addition, restricting the successful of this challenge to the Brazilian community greatly limits the possibilities of proposals that can arise.

Digital inclusion is a much bigger problem in Africa than in Brazil, why limit this challenge to one region?

In Brazil 74% of the population has access to the internet (https://valor.globo.com/empresas/noticia/2020/05/26/acesso-a-internet-cresce-no-brasil-mas-28percent-dos-domicilios -noo-are-connected.ghtml)

Looking at data from Africa, the numbers appear to be worse (https://www.pewresearch.org/global/2018/10/09/internet-use-is-growing-across-much-of-sub-saharan-africa- but-most-are-still-offline /)

Development goals such as digital inclusion can be encouraged by Cardano and enabled by specific projects such as seen championed by IOHK in Africa, and their plan is to roll them out around the world. I am not sure that a further challenge to the Catalyst community in this regard is the best way forward at this time.

The challenge setting mentions some project metrics that could be used to evaluate the challenge's success, but metric for the proposals themselves are missing. KPIs such as number of people involved and local communities reached are examples of good metrics for this challenge.
The metrics set are a bit unclear and difficult to determine. Especially in the respect of how they will be quantified. In general the metrics could be more detailed and diversified.

Metrics would be nice. How many teaching hours would the budget cover? Where would be the targeted audience? How much does it cost to teach per hour? How many people would learn? There are so many questions here, it would be beneficial to narrow the scope of this proposal by a significant amount. Start with a clear understanding of who will learn from this and when/how that will occur. An itinerary of the material would be great.

The metrics provided by this succinct proposal is not as expansive as other metrics presented. However it contains the gist of what and who this challenge will help and can easily be expanded upon by the community as a whole. That said, if additional time is available to the proposer, it is recommended that a more in depth response is provided so that voters get a sense of confidence and push this challenge forward.

Success criteria and metric to measure are not well set and seem to focus on Brazil. Relevant metrics could be, 1) number of people that gained access to a computer or internet, 2) number of people trained in some IT skill

The proposer provided limited amount of KPIs and performance metrics necessary to track the performance of this challenge setting. They are encouraged to expand upon their idea and align it better with the current Cardano's roadmap.

Only two success metrics have been included, both are subjective and would not be good indicators for verifying progress. The definition of success is subjective and restricts the challenge to proposals that address only the Brazilian community.

Sustainability and  social impact of particular solutions would definitely need to be assessed as criteria for any projects in this area. More detailed metrics as to what would encourage theses aspects, and other details as to background of proponents, their capability, commitment, contacts and ability to achieve goals would I think also need to be requested and meaasured.
I agree wholeheartedly with this proposal. Elrond's explorer is another good example of some easily digestable data visualization that drives confidence in the system.

The challenge goal is good. It's not clear for the community if some kind of etherscan for Cardano is under development or not, but I think it is and will be launched together with smart contracts in August. Although, if it's similar to etherscan, it will not be as user friendly as mentioned in the challenge. I believe the idea is very good, but the understanding of available data and platforms when smart contracts are released would be good.
To enable governance of the blockchain to stay doable and comprehensible for everyone in a constantly growing ecosystem, having a good overview over it is indeed important.

Data is what will enable decentralised anything (DeFi, governance, DAO's etc). We need more projects enabling easy use and visualisation of data on the blockchain. If we want to widen participation we need to make it easy for everyone to get information.

Public, decentralised statistical data to aid in governance decisions of the Cardano network will definitely help improve the Cardano ecosystem as a whole. My only reservation is whether or not this should be a top priority for now or perhaps we should focus on solving more immediate challenges first.

It appears the proposed challenge setting would supplement the development and utility of the protocol with further adoption, but will not directly impact Cardano's mission. This opinion is given from a limited technical background.
Effective, public tools for accurate data analysis is critical for the credibility of the Cardano network's operation.

The challenge question is not clear. I understand that data analysis and the presentation of this data in different formats is something important for blockchains, but what is the relationship of this data with the governance layer?

Limiting the challenge for analyzing data related to governance can limit the proposals resulting from this challenge and cause confusion. What is governance-related data? I do not see clearly defined borders and this can make it difficult to evaluate the proposals resulting from this challenge.

The statement as to why the challenge is important brought more doubts and did not clarify the importance of analytics in governance. I see potential for positive impact, but I think that needs to be more explicit.

I recommend that the challenge establishes more clearly whether it is restricted to proposals related to data on governance or whether proposals can be created in other niches.

This proposal fro a challenge is both broad in scope and specific at the same time and it might be worth trying to keep it broad in order for it to be developed as a challenge rather than a proposal. For example if it were a broad challenge to elicit proposals for information systems that can navigate the Cardano ecosystem it might be more useful. II am not sure how useful this would be until the Cardano ecosystem is more extensively developed however, and there are other industry commentators and information providers who are already seeking to help people navigate the crypto asset world more generally. It may be that a holistic view of the whole digital asset world ends up being more useful to people in the end. For example Google is a type agnostic search engine and universality is the direction such navigation systems tend to head in.   It feels to me that perhaps a single or multiple proposals as part of a dApp challenge could be a more appropriate place for this idea to sit.

Catalyst community would be capable in developing such applications, and also this could bring more tech people onboard. Although, I believe it's crucial to know what Cardano's official developing team is preparing as a basis tool like etherscan, or to know if that's being developed or not at all.

While the collective knowlege of the community over the different projects and ways to quantify those is likely sufficient to perform such a project, it will be difficult (yet likely doable) to amass the knowledge into concrete projects and pare it with the skills to present the data apropriatly

Although this is a challenge that definitely needs to be tackled by the Cardano ecosystem as a whole I believe the proper implementation of data visualiser and analysers would require a more substantial investment than the current, relatively limited budget of Catalyst would be able to cover. And the uncertainty that could come from relying on future rounds of Catalyst funding that may not come. Both in terms of building such tools but more importantly in terms of maintenance. Could very likely work in a future Catalyst fund with a substantially higher budget, possibly next year.

There are many involved developers seeking to improve tools and documents to promote the development of the ecosystem. This challenge would resonate with this audience. Furthermore, there are already ongoing developments seeking to implement improvements to dev's toolbox.
Cardano is a technically sophisticated community. The community is sure to rise to this challenge and provide the best-in-class data services for cryptocurrency analysis.

I believe that the budget set for this challenge is greater than it should be. Why? I do not see such a huge demand for data and data analysis at this time and in general there is not a relevant number of proposals created on this topic. As this challenge overlaps with the Distributed Decision Making challenge, there would be a total estimated budget of $ 300,000 in similar fields and this could cause the approval of low score proposals.

In addition, by limiting the challenge to data related to governance, it is expected that a smaller number of proposals will be created.

I recommend that this challenge better define the scope, perhaps opening the topic to data in other niches, such as data about the blockchain itself (data about delegation and pools).

Mapping, search and navigation system development skills could be available within the Catalyst community and it is good that you have reached out with the idea that people should start thinking about this. They might be able to give better input once the ecosystem has developed more and there is more value on chain to navigate the way through.
Number of projects/proposals as a metric is easy, but the metrics do not measure the claim for Cardano's supposed competitive advantage if a proposal under this challenge would be implemented.

The key metrics included in the proposal are good to evaluate the challenge's success, but it would also be good to include metric to evaluate the proposals submitted to this challenge. In this specific case, for example, it could be included statistics like number of accesses and requests for each platform, its coverage and similar information.

Many important metrics on what would be needed for execution of the challenge are given on a top level, yet the details on what data should be analyzed could encompass mor aspects and a rationale for the budget is lacking. Yet a good proposal.
I think its also important to measure the usage of the data. How many member of the community are using the data. Are the analytics reaching outside the community etc.

The proposed metrics are for measuring the success of the challenge itself and not for measuring the success of the proposals that would be entered in this challenge if it were to be voted by the community. I suggest rewriting them to reflect the desired outcomes of the projects generated by the challenge and not as a means of measuring the challenge itself.
The proposer has provided a sufficient list of suggested KPIs and performance metrics in order to gauge participation and productivity of the challenge setting.
Proposal lays out both a clear set of metrics and several potential examples which would address the challenge and its metrics.

The suggested metrics are based on the number of proposals, but this does not allow to evaluate the quality of the proposals being developed, only the number of them.

I recommend the inclusion of metrics to identify the quality / ROI of the proposals.

The definition of success does not clearly demonstrate the impact of the challenge.

I like the idea which `I think you are getting towards of an index of participants and their particular skills and interests, as Catalyst might usefully developed further as a P2P collaborative tool. I think overall the metrics would need to be clarified for a challenge in this area, and related directly to how they elicit proposals that directly enhance the experience of users in their specific fields of interest.

Fulfilling the sustainable development goals is critical to humankinds survival and a better future for everyone. While the destruction of the planet and unsustainable economy only benefits few, tending the SDGs benefits everyone and hence is in the interest of most, which makes it align perfectly with Cardanos grassroot oriented decentralised decision making process. Fulfilling the SDGs is, for the abovementioned reasons, indeed very critical to cardanos mission.

There is certainly a lot of overlap between the Sustainable Development Goals with Cardano's mission, but this can be said of all projects that aim to have a mid- to longterm life. As much as I want this to be critical, I do not see the strong connection in this proposal by restating what the UN said should be accomplished.

This challenge is a great example of alignment with Cardano's goals. It is much needed and necessary for everyone. It also has the potential the bring more positive media coverage to Cardano and it's projects. There is enough information here to inspire people to engage and tackle relevant challenges to create a better future.

altough it is a noble idea, I do not believe that this should be the next fund section. I think, that currently, many other organizations are supporting it, and this has less to do with Cardano itself. 

Of course, if we have a planet in a better condition, it can accelerate the whole world thus adaptation of blockchain tech.  etc. Definitely, there are good outcomes of such an endeavor. I just do not think that it is something new, groundbreaking, or overlooked. 

There are definitely larger subjects than Cardano, which are promoting such endeavor, and this would be just a waste. With all the respect.

Whilst this proposal is so expansive that it could be an umbrella challenge for quite a number of things, e.g. an all female team from the Pacific Islands developing a DApp but under this challenge, this falls well and truly under the Cardano vision. We think long-term. That's the game and this challenge is the summary of everything we do, outside of building the future global operating system. Because of its encompassing goals, relevant proposals which may fall under a different category could decide instead to submit it under this challenge if there is a belief that it can have better chances of being approved (much like the example above).
Great idea. This could help bring in many more entities to the Cardano ecosystem and drive wider adoption whilst working to wards a better future for us all.

While environmental concerns are urgent and important to us all, it is not clear how this will help achieve Cardano's mission. It is perhaps too early for Cardano to start changing the way people live and behave. During these early stages of growth, it is important to continue developing strong foundations for the community, before its ready to embark on larger global issues.

This is an outstanding proposal which is well-written, well-thoughtout, and well-aligned with Cardano's mission. While it may not be the most critical challenge for the Cardano network, the criticality of sustainable development makes it a showcase project to demonstrate how the Cardano Network can be leveraged to achieve local/global goals.

Projects that enable greater energy and environmental efficiency, social advancement and better governance are definitely to be encouraged. Use cases such as commodity provenance, ESG and supply chain tracking, direct and auditable finance into local NGOs, energy efficiency and trading coupled with digital inclusion in association with development agencies are all exciting areas where Cardano and its partners could have particular abilities and appetite. These, and the protocol participants' commitment in these areas to date, are all reasons the world should look at implementing Cardano solutions to solve pressing development and ecological problems and some well though out, engaging proposals would be a great way of enthusing the public and governments about the utility, importance and engageability of Cardano in these tasks.

The catalyst community is indeed very diverse and compromised of people and visionaries from a variety of fields, so they have a lot of potential to use their joint capacities to adress issues as multifaceted as the SDGs. I indeed see this community as a multidisciplinary think tank

At a local level, some of the SDGs are currently addressed through funded proposals and IOHK/IOG's (and their partners) work - in Ethiopia for example.

"Life below water" is one SDG that I don't see the community tackle at this point at all.

Some proposals in Catalyst are already aligned with sustainability goals, but to have an exclusive challenge for that would be great. The mentioned proposals are examples that Catalyst community is capable of presenting proposals in this area, and this could also bring more people onboard and leverage Catalyst's visibility in very relevant knowledge circles.

I think this would attract rather new people, than current community, which would definitely be good, but as I stated above, such goals are already propagated by other subjects (organizations, states) and I do not think we would create a large attraction of newcomers.

This is a resounding yes. The Cardano Community consists of like-minded people who have envisioned a future world that is equitable, safe, healthy and progressive. Besides the different kinds of proposals that could arise, all aligned to the fulfilment of SDG goal, teams themselves could be representational of those ambitions. We don't need to wait for 2030 to see where we are at. We already have resources now, if pooled correctly to begin representing how we want to be in 10 years' time. Kudos for proposing this challenge because I can't wait to see how well the community will respond.

Cardano community is growing by the day, attracting an array of talent around the globe. Each individual comes with unique worldviews and positions. Prior to exploring ways this talent pool can be directed to tackle global humanitarian issues, perhaps it's best to exhaust all options aimed at improving the ecosystem.

Several Catalyst proposals are already considering issues of equability and sustainability, so a focused effort on these objectives is feasibility. The focus this challenge would provide, and in particular its wise statement of a maximum of 20% of funds to one project, will motivate higher quality proposals in this area.

Cardano's community is more engaged in thinking about solutions for these issues than any other blockchain protocol's, but it is worth thinking about how to garner outreach and contacts in government and other agencies that can partner with particular projects, and who in the Cradno community can help expand them.
The SDGs are publicly available for everyone to read, so there should not be any big problems in measuring how well a particular project adresses one or multiple of them.

About half of the proposed metrics are incredibly difficult to measure.

Number of developers this community-focused challenge brought into the Cardano ecosystem, number of new Cardano users (overall users does not measure progress of this challenge), and even just tracking impact on any of the SDGs is incredibly difficult to measure and impractical.

Key metric are very well aligned with the challenge goals and represent a good starting point for the proposal and for the challenge itself. Success criteria is also clear. Linked information is relevant. The challenge setting has all information needed to be successful.

There's a lot of details added into this proposal. It's very well considered that all manner of metrics have been added and all are valid in terms of how we should be measuring Catalyst projects. As mentioned in my previous responses, even team-constitution itself could be representational of the aspirations of the SDG2030. That said and idealism aside, proposals under this challenge will also need to be measured by the SDG ambitions which means the proposers themselves will need to bring additional and unique metrics which align with and stand up to the 2030 goals. The true measure of the progress and success of this challenge is the number of proposals that it generates, and I'm pretty sure no-one of us would be surprised. We'll have to on-board more CAs :)

Detailed set of metrics. I expecially like the 20% cap to any single project. Caps should be added to all challenges. There were a number of proposals asking for large portions or all of challenge funds across the challenges this time. We need to encourage many projects.

The proposing team has given put forward a detailed plan for their vision and set a sufficient amount of KPIs and performance metrics. Should this challenge go forward, this will enable to determine the success of the participants and their projects' progress.
The proposal describes eight detailed metrics including for instance number of partnerships, proposals, projects, and hubs regarding the 2030 SDG.

A good set of criteria and metrics. It would be good also to seek proposals that make best use of the specific technologies and functions within the Cardano blockchain itself that differentiate Cardano projects from what could be achieved in other ways.

Grasroot funding many different projects encompasses that one or the other might have financial difficulties for various reasons. Yet projects that are in the great interest of the cardano community should not straight away be abandoned if they have a good explanation for financial issues. However not just any project that runs out of money should be funded to a fixed set of rules but the reasons need to be examined individually. also, the funds assigned to an individual project should not be fixed at 1500 but variable, as different types of projects can have different magnitudes of costs.
Allowing projects to keep on going until they reach maturity is certainly a good thing but it may allow for too many suboptimal proposals to be funded.

I see this challenge as a way to lower the risk of new projects to commit some time and money before being successful funded, besides the continuation of already funded proposals. Although, I believe that the timing could limit the applicability of this challenge, since a proposal that didn't get funded and than wants to ask for operational budget in this challenge may have to wait for some months until receiving the operational costs funding, which would be ok for some but not for all. It is worth thinking about a side-treasury for that purpose, as has been suggested in the DDM Challenge, for example.

The concept is notable. But the budget is too low to have meaningful impact. If a project is going to fail for $1500 at one point, it will fail for another and another $1500 at the next step. Difficult to set an allowance that accomplishes anything impactful. Like treating a skin infection with a steroid ointment. The real issue is inaccurate initial funding levels. The system as is force a race to the bottom, just to get funded. Wrong approach.

Helping smaller projects get started with the bare minimum or helping larger projects stay afloat between several rounds of funding could greatly improve the results and ROI of project Catalyst which in turn would reflect positively on the whole Cardano ecosystem.

This proposal is very interesting and innovative, because it allows giving a "second chance", it can be said, to proposals that were not chosen for financing, or that are unable to maintain their operating costs to achieve their objectives. I believe that with this type of support, proposals that have potential, but that for various reasons were not selected at the time requested, can bring real results and increase the number of those responsible (even attracting new voters) to give a new direction to the same situation.

Proposals fallen outside of the winning list are free to reapply at their own pace for either initial or additional funding. They have great community feedback to utilize to their advantage in recurring funds. If a certain project falls short by a small margin of votes, that should be a token of confidence needed to continue trying. This challenge setting will thin out the current CA pool, which will negatively affect the rest of the process during a fund. However, it could be convenient for both proposing and voting group to have a separate challenge setting where only ongoing projects are allowed to apply for additional funding, especially if they were clear about their budgetary needs from the very beginning (their initial proposal).

This challenge is aimed at creating alternative financing models, which I think is important for Catalyst. The current proposal funding model is laborious for small proposals and I think it is important that there is a faster funding model, but the idea described is confusing in some points. Operating costs are subjective and can be interpreted in different ways.

The established rules are confusing, for example:

"Proposals can not include budget for work to be done or any rewards for the proposers (can be done in other challenge)"

How to differentiate operational costs of work to be done?

I believe that this challenge is important but needs to be better designed.
Good ideas and feedback to the Catalyst process but not I think a challenge proposal. The challenge might be "Ways to improve Catalyst / Governance" or something else more general.

As there will be a lot of CAs that are there for a longer time and know projects from older funding rounds, it will be a doable amount of work to reassess the projects and the reasons for their failure

The idea is very straight forward and completely feasible. The challenge would probably have tens of proposals submitted and might be very successful. Also, total budget and maximum per proposal is reasonable to allow the funding for the best proposals.
Yes they do have the capacity, but as mentioned in IMPACT, the award of $1500 will not solve the bankrupted project from failure.
Yes it could be done. However there are issues in balancing reducing governance workloads and avoiding wasting money. Its not clear how this balance will be achieved.

From what I understood, this new "analysis" and support to the proposals would be made by the community as a whole, in a similar way to what is already happening today. Would it be better to clarify this, if for example: would it be suggested to create a new group, specifically designed to review whether the groups you propose have possible conditions of accomplishment without an aid? If this doubt were resolved, the understanding of who would do this new activity would be more possible.

Giving this opportunity to "fallen" projects will encourage everyone to reapply for a small grant as suggested, which will require some oversight by a CA group. At the moment, the CA pool is still limited and fresh, therefore this will inhibit the overall process of the fund.
This challenge does not bring technical barriers, which indicates that the community will have easy access to create proposals.

It does but I think the challenge needs to be broadened as to governance and then it may be that not all community members are as interested in the governance side as they may be, and will be waiting for guidance within the main Catalyst framework dn IOHK research programme in respect of governance to usefully engage.

The rules for re-funding in this proposal are so far set relatively vaguely and the CA rating rules are not yet defined. This part would need some more refining in order for the proposal to pass in my opinion. Regarding fixed rating rules, I am not sure it should be done like that. The community can set up some guidlines  on how to evaluate such proposals, but fixed rules would basically get rid of the grassroots aspects here.

Key metrics for the success of the challenge are clear. Also, idea for the auditability of the funded proposals should be included. For example, the proof of operational costs if essential for this challenge, and might be also the only metric needed in this case.

What will determine the successful use of the $1500? How to identify the Proposal that really be saved by the injection of $1500, and the proposal that has debts to pay off? Not easy to design a mechanism. I think the challenge should be reconfigured, reconsidered.

Some of the metrics suggested have nothing to do with the funding request for the challenge (ie  Proposals made in later rounds by funded proposals, First time proposers who get funded here but not in their full proposal). Perhaps this should just be a proposal in itself (there was one similar in this funding round).

Would have liked to see more clearly defined metrics and a clearer explanation on what types of expenses could be considered eligible for this challenge. Other than that, the metrics seem appropriate for correctly assessing the results of this challenge. Unsure about the proposed CA changes, fear of overload are probably justified, solution might not result in the best outcome though.

I missed explaining exactly how the idea would happen. Would it be a new stage among the others? Or an activity that would take place after the close of a cycle, and that would select projects to be supported and launched in the next round? But it was interesting that the author limited a financial amount for each proposal that would be revised, because it gives the idea that the goal is to work with small proposals in fact, to give voice to those who may have little or no resources. Note: 3.

Should this challenge setting go forward, more detail and thought needs to be allocated in order to expand the KPI list. Currently suggested KPIs are limited and will not be enough to give a sufficient overview of the ROI from this challenge.

Some interesting metrics have been described to assess the number of proposals involved in the challenge, but there are no relevant metrics to identify the performance of the proposals. How to identify if the proposal is successful? Some parameter needs to be established to identify whether the operating cost fund is being used well.

The definition of success is not an objective indicator to measure success, I think it is important that something more tangible is established.

The challenge goal needs more explanation. The main idea is clear, but some suggestion about how to do it would increase the challenge clarity. Also, the proposal would also benefit from some metrics about the current and expected size of the ecosystem, and number regarding number of tech people needed, some estimations, to give it more weight. Also, although the topic is very important, budget seems to high. It would be better to create a first challenge with smaller budget and than increase it if successful.
The bar to entering the Cardano ecosystem is still quite high. Education and bringing awareness to resources is crucial in bringing more people to Catalyst and the greater Cardano community.

Reasonable concept and valid endpoints described but proposal is very limited in its design. The author needs to provide a good deal more to this proposal to ensure that it meets the minimum requirements.
As a challenge, soliciting proposals and encouraging initiatives to train is an essential element of growing the use of Cardano protocols. An excellent use of community funds.

Developers and others are set to gain once they learn how to develop in Cardano. Once the technology becomes apparent there will be third-party efforts to support training. However, the is a need for handholding since the language (Plutus and Haskell) has comparatively low penetration among developers. A strong developer community is a major asset to any cryptocurrency.

Cardano's ecosystem is self-sustaining as can be seen by SPOs collaboration in order to strengthen the network by building tools and upgrades for their nodes. This can act as an inspiration for someone to create a hub/library of open source information for everyone to use. Eventually, an online course would be beneficial in order to encompass all of the material needed to be successful within the ecosystem. This, however, is not critical to achieve Cardano's mission in the foreseeable future.

Promoting developer education is an important aspect of Cardano's success, but the challenge is focused on DLTs and Cardano is a blockchain and not a DLT, so I see no sense in defining the challenge in DLTs. I recommend removing the term as it causes unnecessary confusion and takes away the purpose of the challenge.

Skills development related to Cardano tech stack is undoubtedly important, although I think this challenge proposal is perhaps too broad and IOHK and the Foundation are already working on programmes which it might be better to see evolve before the community in Catalyst looks at how to fill in gaps or enhance.

The Catalyst community as it is today is capable of creating courses to train new people into the blockchain and Cardano ecosystems. Also, this challenge could bring new people from educational world into the Catalyst and Cardano ecosystems, and even universities: for example, the University of Zurich, that has just launched a summer course about blockchains, including Cardano, could apply for funding to create a course specifically for Cardano.

In my assessment, the current plutus pioneer program has several community members that could tackle this challenge with their specific proposals.
To come up with a industry specific and globally accepted standard will be a lot more challenging.
The proposal really lacks substance at this stage of its evolution and I cannot fully assess the feasibility without further contribution from the author.

As the Cardano Africa 360 revealed, building cardano devs at all levels will be an essential element of growth. The community already assembled has shown serious interest in marketing, education and training. I  believe this challenge would be highly subscribed with proposals.
There should be a sufficient number of people within the Ada community to be able to adress such a challenge and building projects aiming towards it.

The community has conducted much self-initiated training and another onboarding initiative. Therefore, it can come up with an innovative methodology to come up with the new ideas to provide the Cardano with enough trained workforce.

The Catalyst community is fully capable of creating educational material to train more developers, but Cardano is a blockchain and not a DLT and there is no point in establishing this restriction on the challenge theme.

The success criteria is good, to have more tech people trained in Cardano's blockchain, but the suggested key metrics are good for the long run only. It is needed to have metric for the projects development as well, for example the development of a platform, students enrolled, that can be measured within 1 year or less.

The lack of data and planning provided means that at this stage the proposal is simply an idea and as such cannot be accurately assessed in term of the success criteria and metrics to address the challenge.
As all challenges, the verifiability of success will be the number and quality of proposals (metrics) submitted in the challenge. Not too much more to be said.
The metrics are good al in all, however they could be more detailed and diverse in order to be able to distinguish different projects and approaches within the same challenge

There is a need to improve the metrics as suggested in the proposal. Few suggestions are the (a) Formalisation of levels of the curriculum. (b) Numbers of partners for the issue of certification. (c) Evolving a methodology for funding the training. ((d) Level of diversity achieved in attracting people around the world (no of languages in which curriculum is developed etc).

The challenge needs more clear goals on how to do this. Where ar ewe aiming. Worldwide? Universities? Schools? Startup accelerators? Colleges? Build an online education course on Coursera. I realsie some of these may be the solution to the challenge, but without setting some goals of where the results should come from and what we want how do we know where to focus resources?

Given the scope and role of this challenge setting, the suggested KPI list needs to be expanded upon. The proposer is encouraged to build onto their current idea in order to present it more clearly yet with added detail.

Establishing success in 2030 precludes a reasonable measure of success. The metrics defined are subjective. When would the metrics be checked? 2030?

It is not clear what it means: "project items developed for the graduation", what would project items be?

The metric related to DLT does not make sense, as Cardano is a blockchain and not a DLT.
I think a challenge proposal would need more detailed metrics and criteria for proposers and their projects to meet and submit, but those suggested are definitely a start.

The proposed topic is very relevant and is makes a lot of sense to create this bridge across science backed blockchains, in the same way that it occurs in science in general: there are no 'parallel' sciences going on, everybody talks to everybody. It blockchain wants to benefit from science, this bridge between science backed blockchains must happen.

Interoperability with peer blockchains, preserving value across blockchains, and cross-pollination of technologies, on the whole, will be ideal for the development of the cryptocurrency industry as a whole. A challenge to identify how bridges could be found between projects either technical or structural can be a major catalyst for future growth.

Cooperation with crypto projects built on similar foundations and with similar goals as Cardano could certainly help make those goals a reality much faster and much more efficiently. However sometimes cooperation without synchronisation can have the opposite effect, and the risk is not appropriately identified. Would the efforts required to achieve that synchronisation be worth it? But it would be a potentially great loss, not to attempt the route of cooperation.
I would suggest a different name for the challenge.
Collaboration is always good. Its not clear this is critical to Cardano's mission however. The exact goal needs to be specified.

This challenge setting has the potential to attract talent from other chains who want to collaborate or need more resources in order to accelerate their development. If they present favourably to Catalyst community, this can lead to interoperability in governance at the least, which would expand our existing talent pool. As a result, more quality developments and partnerships will take place because of Catalyst. Projects with similair long term goal for blockchain technology as Cardano have an incentive to partner up and take charge together.

One of the biggest obstacles we face today is the lack of communication between blockchains. Interoperability is a complex challenge due to the great technical difficulty to create such solutions. Promoting a challenge that seeks to address this problem is essential for any blockchain that wants to be used by hundreds of millions of people, such as Cardano.

The open source nature of our space is one of the properties that guarantees the constant evolution of blockchains and prevents the technology from being contained by governments interested in maintaining financial control of the global economy.

The open source nature exposes weaknesses and this exposure stresses protocols and makes them stronger. Increasing collaboration between blockchains focused on solid foundations of research, science and collaboration is a way to pressure Cardano to face the best of each blockchain and this is a positive game for the ecosystem as a whole.

Dissemination of knowledge about what constitutes well founded blockchain and DLT and what is not would definitely be useful, as would thinking about modes of cooperation, and it is fair to say the Cardano blockchain's community is more willing than most to pursue such goals. I am not sure we need a challenge to look into this and question whether it would be the best use of Treasury rather than focusing on development and adoption, which are at the end of the day what will make or break any project.

I see this as a very high level interaction between blockchains at first, if the developers of each one are going to talk about all the possible interoperability. But, as well as is happens in Cardano, the communities of other science backed blockchains might be very active and this bridge could start from less technical community members. I see the budget as being reasonable for this kind of interaction at first, instead of connecting the 'core' of blockchain at first.

The most innovative community in blockchain industry is with Cardano. There are substantial technical challenges in achieving interoperability however enough technical expertise exists In the Cardano Catalyst community to come up with good ideas.

Given that the proposal is for an initial, exploratory challenge that would later set the ground for seeking of actual technical solutions, I feel the Catalyst community is more than equipped to address it. My only concern is that the proposed budget for the challenge might be too low, as some high value individuals and organisations would need to be engaged.
THere are plenty of communit members with links to other coins. However it is not totally clear what the goal of the challenge is. This makes it hard to asses if we can address it.

At the present, there have not been many cross-chain partnerships outside of the existing IOG ecosystem. Project Catalyst has yet to create an environment where this can be facilitated. Creating such a challenge setting will put the Catalyst community to a test, and it should be ready to produce results given this will take place in Fund7.

There is already a public interest in creating interoperability between Cardano and other blockchains, such as Litecoin, Iota and Cosmos. The interest in creating a model of interoperability between Litecoin by Nipopows is public and is already in the early stages of development by IOG and Litecoin. A few months ago there was a mutual interest in integrating IOTA and Cardano and this was made public by Charles Hoskinson's conversation with Dominic Schiener. In addition, interest in the community arose to create a bridge with Cosmos blockchains. We have a very strong research partnership with ERGO and there are already projects in joint development. Other blockchains like Algorand and Tezos have synergies in their interest in research and similar technologies.

This all indicates a great potential for collaboration that is already public knowledge and has already led to the creation of some proposals in Catalyst itself. Just look at the recent proposals to integrate with blockchains like Cosmos, Ergo and Incognito.

The criteria are for the most part clear and measurable, expect for example the stratification of cryptocurrencies. This will be hard to measure and quantify as their are many multi-purpose coins and those that can not be clearly defined and also the crypto space is expanding faster than it can be analyzed and measured.
