Since the proposals in this challenge would lead to connection between people at first, and that seems to be the objective, specially with the proposed budget (a technical bridge between blockchains would need a much higher budget), I believe the metrics proposed are appropriate and embracing.
The proposal has listed nine criteria, and all of them are clear and easily measurable. Many are even achievable with moderate effort and can bring up the value of the complete ecosystem.

The metrics are clearly defined and appropriately set for what is intended to be an initial exploratory challenge. There would however, probably be some difficulties in measuring results and success given the community nature of the challenge.
The goal of this challenge is not clear and no metrics have been suggested for success. What does success look like? Are we trying to collaborate with other blockchains, or is the aim to merge?

The proposer has identified multiple KPIs to track the performance and success of the participants and their projects during this challenge setting. Should this challenge setting take place, it will be sufficient to measure progress.

The key metrics describe various topics relevant to assessing the performance of the challenge and the definition of success is clear and objective. My only recommendation is to define a time window for assessing the performance of the challenge and to increase the objectivity of the resulting proposals.
I think more criteria and metrics for dissemination of rational material to educate people would balance the metrics of the challenge better.

Project Catalyst has attracted many early adopters who have adopted the responsible, independent approach required for a decentralized project to exist. Many are eager to improve the system in order to set up future adopters for success. It is without a doubt we will see great ideas come forward should this challenge be put in place.

Based on my assessment in the first section, I do not have any confidence that this is an aspect of the project that we can entrust to the Community, i.e. to present proposals on how it can qualitatively audit a project. Quantifying a thing can only be translated to a level of 'quality' to a certain extent. One can seat that the number of developers on-boarded into a project does not translate to a higher quality project or the fact that the number of commits into GitHub means the code is elegant and perfectly programmed.
Across the community there is the ability to address this and we should also always be looking to expand.

In Fund4 a very similar challenge has been launched (Local Community Centers). This challenge could be a continuation based on the results from Fund4 challenge. It is very important to bring non-english speakers into Catalyst and the proposal is very relevant. Some hubs already exist, so maybe this continuation should be considered in the budget rationale as well as the creation of new hubs.
It is essential to the Cardano mission to educate many people on blockchain technology and ADA in a decentralised manner in order to enable inclusive and diverse participation.

I am very happy to review a proposal that I find well thought out and presented. Yes, the proposal aligns very well with Cardano's mission, vision, community, and values, and its technical capabilities and potentialities. In my view, the proposal aligns with the necessity and the goal to reach people generously with a life-transforming technology in their own terms and empowering them to steward the technology and their communities. Thank you for presenting this.

This challenge is fully aligned with Cardano's mission. At Fund4 the Cardano Foundation had funded a similar challenge as a pilot and the community created promising proposals where it was possible to see the potential of this concept. It is extremely important that Cardano's regional hubs exist in different locations around the world for Cardano to be disseminated in different cultures and languages and thereby achieve greater adoption, which is one of Cardano's greatest objectives.

I like this idea and think it is suited to a challenge that can elicit many varied proposals. Real world adoption means and requires real world engagement presenting people with solutions to their real world problems. This can enable cross fertilisation of ideas as well as the dissemination of use cases and growth of different elements of the ecosystem.
Catalyst community is capable of developing such hubs, and some of them already exist. The challenge is completely feasible and will probably have many proposals submitted.

While the cardano community consists of many people in different countries with a good collective knowledge doeaking many different languages, it will be quite a big challenge to manage these skills in a way that all hubs can benefit from them in a sufficient manner, especially at the low budget allocated. In general, the budget allocated will nit be enough to create 10+ community hubs being equipped to performing all those tasks.
A similar challenge was created on Fund4 and there was a relevant demand, ideas for different types of local Hubs were created and the proposals created demonstrate the feasibility of the concept.

The general metrics provided are good to evaluate the proposals, although each proposal might as well include more metrics and KPIs. Key metrics of the challenge itself could also measure the delopment of already existing community centers/hubs. Communication between different hubs and the creation of a hub network should be incentivized as well.

Reach and new (average) "users" are somewhat difficult to define and track. But the overall sentiment is clear enough. It would be up to the hosts or participants of the community hubs to (self) report; the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

Creating a system of feedback and auditability is important if we are to give fair votes to competing projects. The suggested KPI and metrics are a good starting point if this challenge setting is to go forward.
The challenge establishes a reasonable time interval, the key metrics described are relevant and good indicators for evaluating performance and the definition of success is clear and objective.

The idea is good and this is the expected path for Catalyst, in order to become fully decentralized. Some discussion with IOG have already been going on in this regard, and it seems that they think it's too soon to turn the process completely decentralized. There will probably be a overlap when part of Catalyst will be decentralized and another part would be the way it is today. The expectations should be aligned with IOG development plan. Also, not only the treasury should became decentralized, but the process platform as well (a alternative to IdeaScale) and other topics as well. It would be good to discuss this in the challenge as well.

A decentralised treasury can indeed be a good addition to a grassroots oriented system such as project catalyst. It does not seem like an absolute critical item though. Especially the very brief form in which this challenge setting is presented does not gieve any good rationale for why it is important.

It appears the proposer is unfamiliar with the current funding process as well as the voting mechanics of project Catalyst. It is not necessary to decentralize the proposing platform itself in order to achieve a decentralized and fair selection process.

The proposal aligns well with Cardano's mission. Nevertheless, the challenge statement is too underdeveloped to use to guide the community.  From what I can see Catalyst is fairly decentralized, even though, it is, so far, very limited to the English 'speaking' population. This is not centralization, it is not an insurmountable difficulty for many,  but it definitively restricts the reach of Cardano. It is necessary that the proponent elaborate better (more clearly, more descriptively, providing verifiable examples) what is the problem that they see, for others to be able to propose effective solutions to those problems. Cheers.

The challenge presented in this proposal seems to be arriving too early. If my calculations are correct, this should be presented as a challenge from Fund 10 onwards when Voltaire is on the table. At this stage of Catalyst, we are yet at a stage where we can say the DAO experience has been bedded down and the experiment a success. I believe there's a long way before we get there. All one needs to do is look at the healthy discussions in Discord. I recommend this proposal is revisited at a later fund when we have a better understanding of the processes and our directions. This should serve to articulate this challenge much better.
eventually this would be great, however this is part of decentralising governance. Any errors here would lead to someone somewhere attempting to game the system and empty the treasury.

I think it is essential to decentralize Catalyst and that goal is a consensus among the community, but what does it mean to make Catalyst's "treasury" decentralized? Decentralize what exactly? Resource management? The idea described needs further refinement, as there is no clarity as to what the objective is.

Well, I think that this is way too general. The entire VOLTAIRE/CATALYST activity is aiming for this. Before being able to 'decentralize Catalyst' completely, we as the community need to learn and establish at least the basic skills, expert-groups, processes and tool-sets. In my view, this is already ongoing in existing challenges. No need for such a 'general' new challenge.

The challenge proposal could do with more work to elucidate how this might work. Catalyst is already decentralised and incentivized, but it is good to highlight that these are things the community should value and think about. It may be that a particular proposal f=might be more appropriate for this idea, within a challenge such as "how to improve Catalyst".
Information is too sparse to accurately assess whether the community has the capacity to address the challenge during Fund7.

The community is probably capable of developing solution in this regard, but the decentralization of Catalyst itself must be aligned with IOG expectations and roadmap. Even though this is the future of Catalyst, the timing should be evaluated.
Only a small portion of the Catalyst community (devs experienced in this area) will be able to adress the challenge

Voltaire era is still ways away, and IOG has ample time to work things out in order to streamline the process in order to set up Catalyst for success. At the moment, the community is working with developers of both Ideascale and IOG to improve the process.

Unfortunately, the project's criteria are not very well defined. For example, "The launch of varied custom catalyst experiences". How do we define what constitutes one experience and what makes it different from another? From a personal point of view every experience may be perceived as unique, at the same time if we are generous, we might say that 'all human life experiences' in the end are the same. The goal of the project seems laudable, nevertheless, for it to be feasible and verifiable, it is necessary that it is less ambiguous and open to interpretation, so that we can agree, what needs to be done? and when we have achieved it. Other examples of this lack of precision would be: "measure number of custom catalyst experiences", and "quality of engagement" (what does it mean that the experience is customed? and how do we measure in a standardized way "quality of engagement"? With respect and appreciation for the effort and the intention of the proponent, I believe that the prevalence of this lack of definition demonstrates the underdevelopment of the proposal and sufficiently questions its feasibility. Cheer up, the need is real, you have a good question, and a good idea, there is much work to do! And you are being part of it! Thank you for being a part of it.

There is a very good possibility that the community can rise to the challenge and address this. We have no choice. We must in order to grow and fulfil the aspect of our industry that drew most of us here...decentralisation. If enough lessons are learnt from past, current and future funding rounds, then we can better address this challenge with greater chances for success.

Assuming that the idea is to decentralize treasury management, I don't think this challenge is feasible at the moment. The treasury contains more than half a billion dollars in ADA and we have to be cautious about managing these funds, sharing the management with the community so early can bring considerable risks.

Yes, the Catalyst community has the capacity to address the challenge - AND IT ALREADY DOES. This very generally formulated challenge setting would in my opinion just open a parallel world to the already existing Catalyst activities. I see no need for doing this. I would be afraid that we would just confuse the community and loose focus with this.
Quality of engagement is not specified and also not a particularly good metric for decentralization - it measures different things. "Custom catalyst experience" is not define and cannot be measured.

Metrics are not clear enough, more detail about the challenge in general should be provided in orther to proper evaluate its verifiability. If other topics for decentralization are included besides treasury, it would be good to include metrics for them as well.

The key metrics are not detailed and the success criteria are formulated very briefly and difficult to quantify in this form. There is no rationale provided for the amount of funds demanded to be allocated for this challenge. While this project idea seems like a really valuable addition to the cardano ecosystem it should be published in more detail, either as a challenge or as a concrete funding proposal with a plan on how to achieve this goal.

The proposer needs to expand their list of suggested KPIs. It is also recommended they dive deeper into the current works and mechanics of Catalyst in order to be able to provide further improvement suggestions.

The metrics presented here are the metrics we actually need to measure now and present to the participants of Catalyst. I try to keep my eyes and ears out for news and I am yet to see a summarised view of survey results to get a glimpse of how we are actually doing. Surprisingly, we are still moving forward with a 'sense' that things are going well. However, we have not yet been presented with metrics of past funding rounds that could reveal where our experiment is succeeding or are failing. There is a big disconnect between the 'experimental' aspect of the DAO and the 'professionalism' that is expected of the proposers, proposals, CAs and VCAs. We are yet to learn how we are doing now that to decentralise Catalyst earlier than Fund 10, we may end up taking backward steps and somehow harm what we have already started. I understand I can be penalised by stating an opinion but how can I not express it to explain my rating when the proposed challenge itself is about us and what we are doing.

I believe I have already illustrated that the proposal is not sufficient to adequately formulate a challenge. In this section I will try to signal how the proposal may be improved, focusing on the information provided specifically for the item on Verifiability. The proposal reads: "measure number of custom catalyst experiences, quality of engagement during proposal iteration and during voting, etc" 1. In this item etc. is not adequate. It is necessary to list specifically, the items the proponent believes need to be verified. The proponent could be right or wrong. There could be more items and people could identify more and better items, but it is necessary that the proponent does and shows their effort. It is necessary that the proponent reports their best work, for it to be improved by the community. Without their work, there is not much to build on. 2) It is important to define what a "custom experience" is in a manner that can be shared and therefore verified by many. There does not need to be a unique perfect definition but there needs to be a minimal definition that we can discuss and agree around. Furthermore, it is necessary that we can identify specific qualities of that definition that we can verify. This is the goal of this criteria. For example, you could say there will be experiences in the seven major world languages (or Cardano languages, English, Vietnamese, etc...), and you could say this would be measured by the number of catalysts web pages translated into those languages. From there you could go into as much detail as you believe is necessary. 3) Lastly, it is necessary to provide an idea of how to measure "quality of engagement". This is not easy and there probably is a lot of disagreement. But, if this is going to determine the verifiability of the project it is necessary to provide a definition and characteristics that we can agree on and verify. Furthermore, notice that this is required for different stages of the Catalysts process and therefore, I believe it could be expected that the definition and characteristics to verify "quality of engagement" across these different stages will need to be defined for each of those Catalyst stages. There is a start and there is a lot of work to do, hopefully, we are all animated to contribute to it.
More work needs to be done on how we measure success here. How do we measure if the funds have been well spent? Do we know what timeframe we want to spend the funds over?
The suggested metrics and definition of success are extremely subjective. I recommend the inclusion of tangible items.

Due to being formulated so vaguely, and due to therefore leading to huge complexity, I see no simple success criteria for this. Let's remain on the VOLTAIRE/CATALYST main road with all its already existing challenges. These are more specific and allow better measuring and success-tracking.
The metrics could do with further elucidation and detail and contain all of the criteria and metrics for the challenge proposed, as that way the most value can be derived from the challenge.
Lowering the bar to entry for people to start making meaningful contributions to Cardano is a very much in line with Cardano's mission.

The suggested challenge setting would allow early on-boarders to go through a low-pressure Catalyst proposal experience in order to gain better understanding of the inner works of the system and establish connections with the developed teams. This would not have an immediate impact on Cardano's mission achievement, and potential result depends on the implementation of such Hackathon.

Excellent idea, budget is well fit and I think this would be a great experience. Since this would be an 'irregular' challenge, voters should be aware that they would be voting for a already developed project. The idea of rating only 5 or 1 also seems a good way to leave all decisions to the voters in this specific case. If successful, each Fund could have a different topic for this hackathon.

While it is a really creative and open concept that has the potential to unlock more resources, it is not essential to cardanos mission; It will basically not introduce new projects that could not be realized via other funding challenges. A lot of them are already formulated in an open manner enabling many different ideas to be integrated. It is still a great idea for people to self-organize themselves ahead of proposal phase of a funding round in order to brainstorm and plan ideas

This is great to encourage first timers.  It seems essential to involving more people into the community. Consider strengthening the rules to include new proposed, like increased scoring or requirement to have a new proposer.  All other sections seem to encourage it, but missing action from rules to acquire this group.

Creating alternative funding models is promising and can benefit people willing to work first and get paid for the quality of their work, which helps to bring about a dispute for productivity and innovation.

My only recommendation is to rewrite the challenge in order to communicate the concept more clearly, because the name of the challenge, the question statement of the challenge and the statement of why it is important did not effectively communicate the idea presented.

This might be better suited as a proposal within a wider challenge as to "how should we improve Catalyst", although the idea that ways of linking community members to each other to develop proposals and practical ways of delivering on them is very valid for consideration.

The idea of having a lower-barrier to entry Catalyst experience might prove beneficial as Voltaire era nears completion and full rollout. New to Catalyst individuals will have to compete with seasoned and established teams and might find it challenging and discouraging. Providing a level playing field for this group has the potential to spur collaboration and create new connection and networks. As we continue with project Catalyst, more and more people could benefit from this implementation.

I believe many people would be able to participate in this challenge and I can see this experiment being very successful. Catalyst community is very active and lots of people will probably participate. I believe this challenge is completely feasible.

This challenge will of course be within the community's capacity and potential, as it plans to utilize exactly those resources and even has the potential to mobilize more of those resources by the openness of the procesd.

I think that the concept of this challenge stimulates the development of good proposals and can stimulate a healthy dispute where those who produced more have more visibility and more confidence in the community. BUT, how do we judge the proposals by the result they delivered without Catalyst having a functional audit model? Before this turns into a viable challenge, it's necessary to establish how to evaluate these proposals in a fair and efficient way.

My recommendation is that the challenge describes how these proposals will be evaluated fairly so that the model is not gamified.

There may be community members who could set up incubation hubs as part of community hubs, including virtual connection and collaboration, who might be interested in pursuing this, and it would be worthwhile.
The metrics will not necessarily measure the impact of the challenge, but potentially the overall increase of people's awareness and the improved capabilities of the Cardano ecosystem.

The proposer has laid out good foundation for their proposed challenge setting and is encouraged to build onto it by adding more depth and detail. Overall, great suggestion and good start with KPIs as mentioned.

Since the project needs to be ready in time for voting, it would be easy to verify which ones have met their goals. Also, in the unlikely case that not enough projects are delivered in time for voting, a backup plan for what to do with the Fund money could be developed.

The success criteria and metrics suggested are useful, however the demand of changing the voting system is not reasonable, considering there are already several mechanisms built into the challenge proposal (budget, team requirements etc.) that would limit proposal numbers.

Metrics set out well. Its not clear however that enough funds have been requested. 25,000 would only cover 5 projects at the cap. Either set the limit lower or raise the funding request. Perhaps have a lower initial payment then prizes at the end of additional funds for the best completed projects?

Overall if the focus is 1st timers, add data for new proposers in addition to the full population.
- number of projects that manage to deliver before the deadline 

- number of mergers before finalization 
- number of proposers that continue on in other challenges (consider having a metric of all participants that continue & 1st timers separate as well).  


- People that continue to work together after this challenge (consider having a metric of all participants that continue & 1st timers separate as well).  

- first time proposers (good easy metric to acquire)

The metrics and definition of success described are reasonable. 

The problem I see with auditability is before the vote stage, because today there is no audit model done by the community, will we depend on the IOG staff? Do they have the capacity and time to do this?

The metrics appended are more for assessment of whether a proposal has worked than of how particular solutions to your proposed challenge might be assessed by the community. They are though the sorts of things that should be thought about within iterative feedback to proposals that have been funded by Treasury and can therefore improve Catalyst.
Fundamental to decentralization. A central storage or even one that is controlled by a select set of datacenters defeats the decentralization purpose.

As outlined by the proposer, the challenge is critical to achieve Cardano's mission. To reliably and securely implement things like NFT marketplaces, this challenge is needed (potentially, as indicated, over multiple rounds).

Part of managing one's identity is to be in control of one's online presence. At the moment, majority of users do not control or posses the data they produce online. This data is being harnessed to be used against users in order to exploit their behavior patterns. Creating a decentralized data storage solution would greatly compliment Cardano's mission to bring financial identity to the under-banked and bring another level of control to the individual on-chain.

The topic is very clear and very relevant to the ecosystem and a solution like that is really needed inside Cardano. Even though several solutions should exist and compete amongst them, I believe the proposed budget is too high for such a specific topic. I would set it to be 150k at most.

It is an interesting proposal for a challenge that would make a nice addition to the cardano ecosystem that goes beyond monetary blockchain aspects which is part of cardanos mission. However it does, while beeing a great addition, not make it absolutely critical to the mission.
Good solution for saving files is needed, but it could easily be another platform/solution linked to Cardano and does not need to be built on top of Cardano.

This function is something IOHK and its development of Hydra on the metadata and ADA/native token base layer might be best placed to contemplate, rather than it being a specific challenge. Perhaps it might best be part of a proposal in response to a wider challenge of "how to improve Cardano from a technical perspective" once the initial roadmap is complete and the operation and possibilities of Hydra and Goguen are fully understood by the community.

Fund5 proposals already include NFT marketplaces and Filecoin integrations that seem feasible. This is a more focused continuation of that work that brings more value to the Catalyst community and Cardano at large.

It is difficult to assess the capability of the Catalyst community at the moment. It is rapidly expanding and growing, yet this challenge setting is of a massive magnitude as can be seen by other projects outside of Cardano who have been tirelessly working for some number of years to bring a ready product to market. One advantage that such a project would have building on Cardano is CF's support and market penetration on African continent.

I can see some proposals being submitted in this challenge, and I believe that Catalyst community has enough knowledge to develop such solutions. Current solutions in other blockchain could also inspire the creation of some solutions inside Cardano.
Only a very small portion - specialized developers - of the Catalyst community will be able to adress the challenge.

I have no doubt the community can rise to this challenge, but as mentioned, the only limitation I can see is the amount of funding that would be reserved under it. We could end up either funding a small number of niche solutions or one big one that would serve the entire Cardano community, i.e. a filecoin-type of decentralised solution. I have no inkling as to which way things would go but if this challenge goes ahead, I look forward to the novel ways our brilliant community members will present ways to address it.

The community in general might not have the technical skills to engage with this issue ahead of the Hydra implementation so as to understand Cardano's full feature set and what might be possible in second layer development.

Success Criteria needs to be a bit more descriptive. I would also add efficiency as a metric. One of the key trade off for decentralized storage is the efficiency and speed. Cardano should offer improvements in both areas.
The metrics properly measure the challenge progress and to some extend overall adoption of Cardano among blockchain developers with storage needs.

The proposer outlined several KPIs to measure success of the project who would participate in the challenge, but this list can be expended upon further. It is encouraged that the author continues to add more detailed explanation to the structure of the challenge and how the suggested budget amount would be distributed.

In my opinion, key metrics are very good and would be a great start for proposals. Although, as mentioned that proposals might need to participate in more than one Fund to get everything done, it's preferable to set expectations of each round. The solution should accomplish measurable goals in all Funds.
The success criteria and key metrics are defined well. As no rationale for the funds allocated is given while this is a concrete challenge that could be quantified, only 4 stars.

I think its also important to measure privacy, reliability, latency, and longevity. It may also be useful to consider geographical location of storage. It may be desired to have locally for latency or regulatory reasons, or distributed for backup. Success metrics should also look at the amount of data stored relative to competitors and relative cost of storage and access.

These might be metrics better used to assess a proposal specifically for a storage solution, or whether a proposal for such has been adequately delivered. If this were to be submitted as a challenge still I think it would be best to assess what proponents' capabilities and resources were to be able to work with IOHK to complete its integration, as well as its realistic ability to deliver features, and they would need to explain to the lay community member how this might be achievable technically.

At the present, IOG is working on creating robust DID system utilizing Atala Prism. In a way, that is already an example of a use case for NFT. Setting a fund challenge to explore more options early on will benefit the ecosystem in the long term.

NFTs really are very important and could be as big or even bigger than DeFi. A Challenge specific to NFTs could bring more attention to this topic, even though some other challenges, like DAPPs, already have some proposals in this regard. As per my current knowledge, the use of Cardano to leverage NFTs is as good as it is for fungible tokens, i.e., Cardano was not specially built for NFTs but for every kind of token. Anyway, I believe this would be a great challenge.

Encouraging NFT proposals other than art related will open up the creative resources of and opportunities for a much broader range of use-case proponents and developers. The examples provided are an excellent starter group of ideas.

NFTs are a critical issue in the field of blockchain adoption. However, it still takes a lot of work to develop convincing use cases. Here Cardano could become a lighthouse. In particular, there is a chance that the superiority of the Cardano tokens will be clearly noticeable.

This challenge is of high importance not because of the boom of digital art NFTs but in educating everyone, including Cardano Community members of the other types of things that can be recorded as a unique record in the blockchain. The proposal is very well written and hopefully leaves no doubt that NFTs can be used for more than just artistic objects.

Challenge is seeking to increase adoption of ADA through real-world use cases involving non-art NFTs.  There is a lot in the news about NFTs and blockchain.  Certainly, this is critical to achieve Cardano's mission

This challenge will encourage utilisation of the metadata functionality as well as native tokens which Cardano is leading the industry in providing in a secure and cost efficient manner. When it comes to high value items, and concepts for their securitisation, the predictability, security and functionality Cardano can provide are real advantages. Security and provenance for particular items can be proven within metadata itself, rather than relying on smart contracts, which is different from other blockchains particularly at the scale and distribution capacity of Cardano's network. It is important that transaction fees, which are in the long term the lifeblood and security of the system as well as underpinning of value in the token which keeps users engaged are secured for the network by having a dynamic ecosystem to support NFT uses in scale and over the long term, therefore it is important for this use of Cardano to be supported with Treasury funds. It is important also to demonstrate the willingness of developers to code these functions on Cardano in as broad as possible a range of use cases, in addition to deep functionality in each use case that differentiates Cardano as a solution.

Some proposals are already being done in other challenges regarding NFTs, and the community is already developing some projects related to this. So, I believe lots of proposals would be expected from such a challenge.

I am giving 5 stars because the implementation requires few, if any, special tactics or techniques to be realised. Our community is already a collection of broad interests. NFT's are being heavily promoted and discussed, so there is strong awareness within the general cryptocurrency space, .

The Cardano community is already very familiar with CNFT art due to successful pre-Alonzo minting projects and I have no doubt that ever since IOHK announced the Ethiopian government's use of ATALA Prism to on-board 5 million students, most were further educated of Cardano's flexible utility that re-imaging NFTs as more than just artworks is already happening. I actually cannot wait to see the kinds of proposals that would be presented if this challenge goes ahead. And what's even better is that since minting an NFT is a 'native' (excuse the pun) functionality of the Cardano blockchain, developments would not need huge amounts of funding to bring projects into fruition.
There are many talented individuals within the Catalyst Community, including developers, programmers, entrepreneurs and marketers with the capacity to address the challenge

It does, but this could be improved with outreach to different industries that can benefit from distributed asset or access management of one kind or another.Warehouse receipts for commodities could easily run in this manner on Cardano but outreach to bodies such as the London Metal Exchange for example could be fruitful in making them aware of the simplicity and predictability of function that is possible with Cardano. With community members involved in finance these contacts should be possible, but community development to identify particular reach into different industries to find creative thinkers and problem solvers would be a useful output of thew or of this challenge, in addition to particular use case ideas.

The success will speak for itself. Bringing more real life utility via blockchain will turn heads and benefit the ecosystem, in turn drawing more talent. The proposer has a great vision for this challenge setting and has set a lower limit for budget, making this attractive as a probe challenge in order to gather data for future planning with regards to NFTs' use cases.

The success of the challenge will be simply the number of proposals that are attracted. The metric that was proposed of 4 x $50k proposals allows for a situation of few proposals, but, based on the level of interest in NFT proposals in  f3, f4 and f5 experience more likely there willl be 20-30 realistic proposals. An indication of success of the challenge
The assessment criteria need further sharpening. Which aspects are relevant for the quality of the use cases?

The proposal does very well in not simply listing key metrics for the Challenge itself but of the key metrics that would validate effectiveness of submitted proposals themselves. This provides CAs like myself a good reference point on what to look out for, as additional guidance. Whilst we're at the height of CNFTs and the ATALA announcement, this challenge cannot come at a better time when proposers (hopefully) are already thinking about valuable projects that would address this challenge.

Charles is a motivator for many people, so having him understood by a non-English speaking population could prove beneficial for the Cardano community. As another member of Catalyst community asked in one of the comments, I'm not sure how much more effective dubbing is over having subtitles.

The proposer has created a demo for about 2 minutes of one of Charles' videos. I cannot say how well it was translated, but on the quality side, I think for a demo it was quite good. Splitting his proposal over several funding rounds is a good idea, having a smaller objective of translating only 25 hours at first, shows that he's quite serious about the proposal getting done.

The roadmap is simple and clear, and the audience related KPI is also good. It would be even better to track the amount of people who goes into Catalyst based on these videos, since this is the main goal of the challenge. It would also be very simple to audit the proposals since the objective is clear, to dub all CH videos within 3 months.

The idea is good, but it is not new. Similar products already exist. According to the author of the proposal, this idea would help to spread ADA in Africa, which is related to the objectives of the challenge. The author also says that part of the transaction carried out there would remain as a fee for the store, but it is not known who owns it: an African in fact, or it could be a multinational franchise, for example. "The customer would go into the store and have heard about ADA somewhere," which is a problem, given that it is known that this subject still has little scope on the continent. The ideal would be to ensure that stores that have a possible local machine, and that there is, at the same time, a process of disseminating information on the subject. As I understand it, the only African explicitly in the project would be the shopkeeper himself, which the project specifies as someone who understands the technology of cryptocurrencies. And this would need training, which would be another benefit for the community, after all one of its members encompassing the universe of finance and technologies. However, proposals must seek to be plural, to reach the maximum number of people possible. The beneficiaries here before, bulletin, the store that owns the machine, the shopkeeper and the team involved in the manufacture of the technology. It is necessary to expand this network.
proposalTitle: Paper wallet terminal for in a shop

assessmentNote: This project addresses variations of user conditions and integrates physical objects and unique interface considerations relevant to the community. The interface also addresses needs when power grids are interrupted. It opens many doors which could be expanded for more resilient physical forms or materials for interface. These could include materials which the community is familiar with, in terms of history and tactile familiarity. It is important to consider, especially at this early stage, how we connect the human body with diverse locations and histories, to the blockchain.
proposalTitle: Paper wallet terminal for in a shop

assessmentNote: I give a 5 for impact because the concept is simple, spelled out, and definitely addresses the question of expanding Cardano in Africa. The proposal tells us that there is a lack of technological access in Africa but that should not stop people from acquiring ADA as an asset. The machine this proposer seeks to build will allow for Africans to access the ADA currency without having a computer or cell phone. There are metrics for the project and it can clearly scale beyond the prototyping and initial build outlined here.
proposalTitle: Paper wallet terminal for in a shop

assessmentNote: I give a 5 for feasability because the proposer provides a clear and managable timeline along with images and flowcharts for the project. They know exactly what needs to be done and how much time it will take them. They explain the technology and resources needed for the project. Budget is provided.
proposalTitle: Paper wallet terminal for in a shop

assessmentNote: Here is a step by step of how the project would happen, making it very clear how this process takes place, as well as some production costs and possible release dates for the prototypes. It is possible to know the total amount of investment requested, of course, but it is not whether the project would need more money to keep going. Many technical details about the wallet machine are provided, including a video of 13 explaining the mechanisms of its operation, which serves to increase the credibility of the product. There is also attached a website in Dutch explaining some technology projects, but few people speak Dutch, this website confuses readers and fails to be informative.
proposalTitle: Paper wallet terminal for in a shop

assessmentNote: I believe in the idea because I think it's gives more options to people and even without using it in the start (it will actually, depending on the software have many options of use) by the customer it will help to get used with the idea. It will also gives some practical solutions and opportunities for people to get a wallet.
proposalTitle: Paper wallet terminal for in a shop

assessmentNote: The KPIs are simple but completely match with the project as needed. The roadmap and milestones are clear and they target the problem. This machine itself could be audited for success.
proposalTitle: Paper wallet terminal for in a shop

assessmentNote: I think that the idea itself is good, but the approach chosen to do it is not the best one. The idea of breaking down the project into 8 phases creates a high risk of not receiving the desired fund or a big part of it. Also, referencing full books in order to explain why the idea is good is a bad approach, because most people don't have the time to read them, or even research about what they say. It is also not clear that in the context of Catalyst, this kind of interaction would make a huge improvement in quality of proposals in comparison to what they are today.

There are no details on the proposer's qualification / experience, just a vague mention that he works for a company related to the Japanese government.

The plan needs to be more detailed, there is no clarity in the purpose of the proposal or how it is related to the challenge, there is no timeline in the roadmap. There is no budget breakdown.

I recommend including this information so that we can understand the concept of the proposal and give more appropriate feedback.

How will you measure diversity? How will you reward it? How will you bring on the stakepool operators you want to fund this? This proposal has no clear goal on how to achieve its object thus is unlikely to succeed in its current form.

The proposal doesn't have enough information about the person or team behind the idea, and there is no clear roadmap for Phase 2, about what would be executed. The Phases 1 and 2 seem to have some overlap and it's also not clear when one finishes and the other starts. The budget should be broken down to better understand how the money would be spent.

The information provided to assess this is too lean. 
To clarify: the plan is way too vague to determine what is actually being proposed. 
There are no metrics set. What would success look like? 
There is no funding breakdown to justify the 50k USD asked for.

There is not enough information to audit the proposal efficiently.

First of all, it is important to define the relationship between the proposal and the challenge, if there is such a relationship it is important to define details for the proposal plan, such as timeline / roadmap, milestones, KPIs, details about the budget and about the team / proposers.

I recommend that the proposer ask the community or a mentor for help and follow the Catalyst documentation to write the proposal.

In regard of Phase 2, the proposal lacks a plan, roadmap, milestone, KPIs and metrics. More information should be included regarding all the topics mentioned above in order to make the proposal auditable. Also, risks of not receiving funds for any of the phases should be better evaluated, since now it just says that this could happened and the project should be flexible and adapt.

As said before, I do believe that you could explore the volunteering feeling that is a natural state of this community and, by doing it, you could reduce the $3k of salary. Other than that, thinking about other approach method than emailing would be of a great help, since it would reduce cost and, in my point of view, more appealing. I really think that explore the people in lots of locations across the world and providing them with a platform to share experiences of presentation in the universities would be a great thing.

Another question that arises is that your proposal is only feasible if you get funded every time (until a point that is self-sustainable), however, lets imagine that you get fund now and in the next one not – will the project over?

Furthermore, it is not clear the intention of deploying a website – what it will be for? What are you aiming with this?

The proposal contains the basic information that would be required to to measure success, but it lacks the intermediate timeline that would be needed to measure progress towards the final goal. The project would need a roadmap if progress were to be audited efficiently.

The Catalyst Common Idea Funnel is interesting and fits within the challenge, however, more information should be added to increase the score. Specifically, additional efforts could be made to link this proposal with the key metrics to measure within the challenge brief. The proposal could be expanded to explain how it can reduce the overwhelming burden that people face in order to get more external interest in Cardano. New proposers would still be faced with a deluge of information and without ongoing oversight, how would the system adapt or grow based on the level of interest/participation? The reliance on community is one potential way but it may also create further challenges since it's all volunteer leading to individual experiences being very different and inconsistent.

I see that you have not provided a plan of how this website would be constructed or how you would roll out your vision. I am unsure whether your experience is entirely relevant to the task you outline. I think that by assembling a team around your proposal would greatly assist your chances of implementing this proposal successfully. Similarly, by breaking down your budget and describing how you would allocate the considerable sum of $60,000 would provide reassurance that the proposal had a strong direction and clear intent.

Overall I like the idea behind the proposal, there is simply not enough information provided to allow a reviewer to assess the feasibility. 

The proposal identifies one of the major challenges for the entire Catalyst ecosystem and seems to be echoed by many newcomers, however, the proposal does not provide adequate details on how exactly it would reduce that. There is also a disconnect between the funnel process that is explained in detail and then the final request for funding to run prize competitions to get individuals into catalyst. It is unclear to me how these two are directly linked. If the funding requested here is for the prize competitions then that should be more prominent across the whole proposal, with better explanations of how the prize competition then leads to success of the funnel. 

I also cannot assess the feasibility given the budget as there is no breakdown. Why would $60,000 be needed for this? Would this cover the development too?

The proposal effectively addresses the challenge expectations and would likely provide end users with additional options for integrating assets housed on other chains with the Cardano ecosystem. I am giving the proposal a 3/5 because it currently lacks clear indicators of success and how it will be measured. While the justification and potential impact of the proposal is likely strong for the challenge, it is unclear how these will be determined. This score could be increased by providing metrics or list of indicators that will help guide the project along its track and show how the achievement of deliverables contribute to each stage. Also, given that the catalyst funding request is only for part of the overall ask, it would be helpful to articulate exactly what that funding will go to.

Utilising a wrapped version of other blockchain's tokens and making transactions with them on the Cardano blockchain could generate a significant revenue. Cross chain transactions would stimulate growth and interoperability. To my knowledge, no service like this exists yet on the Cardano blockchain.

Bitcoin has accumulated great value and is actively traded. However, every transaction in Bitcoin/Eherium is burning Earth. Wrapping them in the Cardano chain and trading them as wrapped assess is a novel idea with far-reaching implications. As a decentralized exchange Cardano with its superior technology can host multiple wrapped asserts and can play a disruptive role in transaction volume in another old generation chain without degrading the value of Bitcoin/other old generation assets.

It is not clear what problem the proposal is intended to solve, the problem statement did not make this clear (there was no problem in the problem statement).

Wrapped assets are an important and popular tool, especially on Ethereum's blockchain where there are billions of wrapped assets, mostly USD and BTC. The introduction of wrapped assets brings more use options for blockchains that adopt them and enhances the use of dapps and applications in general.

There are no metrics or KPIs to measure the impact of the proposal on the challenge.

The proposal certainly addresses the challenge and is well presented and contains much useful information to assist the community understand the idea. Perhaps the biggest concern for me is the actual size of the project (iterated by the community in the comments section). I appreciate the team is already up and running and intends to progress with or without funding but believe they would allay community concerns by breaking down the project further into portions that the community would be more inclined to sample.

The experience of the proposers is well articulated and the links to their LinkedIn pages with additional professional information is welcome. 
I am giving the proposal a 3/5 on this component as well because there is not enough information on why each of the proposed positions are necessary. For example, in the budget that is provided, there are 3 engineers - why is 3 the right number? Could it be completed with 2? Why/why not? Also, the "founder" position is not described anywhere and I fail to understand what this position is, why it's valued at $76K and how it fits into the overall project design. 
Further things I'd point out under implementation likelihood are:
Under "Deliverables for first 4 months", it states that the partnerships with custodians will be finalized. The proposal could benefit from providing additional information on where/with whom those partnerships currently are, what stage they are at, what challenges may still exist, and what form the final agreement will take. This would help determine the likelihood that implementation would be successful. 
Moreover, since the catalyst funding represents only a portion of the overall budget and experience required for the project there is some uncertainty (or at least it's not overly clear) as to how the rest would be funded. I realize it says "crowdfunding" will be used but is only speculation. Would it be ongoing? Through further Catalyst funds? 
The proposal could be strengthened by providing additional information on what I note here.

The team has relevant experience to execute this and is pursuing to expand. The proposed WA token ICO would be set at the price of 1 USD per token, which is quite high. 
The requested funding to perform this is quite steep, set at 150k USD out of an available 250k USD.

The proposal is complex with big security-related risks. The proposed protocol required an in-depth audit before it is turned in into implementation. The proposers have impeccable credentials; however, there is substantial risk in the successful implementation of the proposal.

The team currently has 3 members, 3 new people will be hired to assist in the development of the project, after funding.

There are details about the team's experience and qualification in areas such as full stack software engineering and UX design, but it is not clear what the team's technical experience with blockchain is, more specifically with Cardano's blockchain.

There is a detailed and well-structured plan, but it lacks some important information, such as a clear roadmap and risk assessment that were not included in the plan.

Babel Fees will not be a reality in the near future, considering the use of Babel Fees as a reference today is not something tangible to be used now.

Legal/regulations risks have been addressed.

Wrapped tokens are an important and increasingly popular tool, however the introduction of wrapped assets with central custodians brings many risks to DeFi protocols, because when introducing a wrapped asset whose reserves are controlled by a centralized entity, the DeFi protocol loses its decentralization and increases dependency on trust, which is counter intuitive and against the goal of public blockchains. 

This dependency can cause instability and security risks to the protocol and these risks need to be considered.

This proposal is requesting a relatively high amount of the challenge's total budget, 60%, and describing a clear budget is essential to assess the feasibility of the proposal.

The proposal describes that the annual burn rate is $485,000 per year, but the values ​​described in the attached spreadsheet do not match, there are other reference values, and the annual budget described in the spreadsheet is $ 1,902,652.80

It is important to make it clear that Wrapped Assets is a for-profit company (will monetize the application) and will hold a crowd sale with a forecast of raising $ 15,000,000.00 as stated in the whitepaper, so I think it is essential that the team clarify why they are requesting treasure funding. whether to sell the tokens to private investors?

Overall the proposal is likely feasible and could be achieved with what is presented. To increase chances of being funded through this voting round, additional information could be included that provides clearer milestones and measurement indicators. Including these indicators will strengthen the feasibility score by showing to voters that the proposers have considered foreseen challenges and have identified opportunities to share their successes or failures with voters. 
Another issue that impacts the feasibility is the budget included and the disconnect between the total amount and the portion requested through this funding round. As is mentioned in the comments above, additional details on the role of each team member and justification for their involvement would be helpful. For example, together the budget and deliverables show that 2 software engineers would be hired within the first 4 months, yet the hiring of these two positions alone would max out the catalyst request. 
 The proposal's feasibility could also be better exemplified by adding additional use cases beyond just crypto. Are there more real-world assets that you can show using this same approach?
Overall good work and I look forward to seeing how this does in the voting round.

It is not clear how giving this proposal 3/5 of the fund will "provide the most value for end users in 2021", thus it doesn't seem to meet the challenge. The funds they are asking for with even their limited plan won't get the project to delivery, thus as it stands it is not a feasible project. A detailed plan which shows how the proposal will meet the challenge with the funds requested should be provided.
The progress can be audited. There is a need for a more detailed technical plan and task list. A security audit of the proposal by an independent body of experts is required.

There is no information about the project being open source.

There are details about the team, but it is not clear what the team's knowledge is to develop applications on Cardano's blockchain.

There is no clear roadmap, the deliverables described over 4 months do not indicate the potential impact on this challenge. There is only mention that a proof of concept will be developed and an MVP will be delivered during the 4-month funding period, but this does not indicate objectively what will be delivered. Does the MVP include the possibility to use assets wrapped in Cardano's blockchain?

Excellent information provided that gives great understanding about what the team is trying to achieve. The community validates the use case through the interest generated and acknowledging the potential. What concerns me somewhat is that the team appear to have misread the community appetite for such a large scale project. I feel this can easily be addressed by the team simply by reworking the size and scope of the project as a stand alone proposal. This will thus establish reputation and greater trust by then meeting the revised targets.

The proposal ID's important issues with community review process of ideascale and proposes sound solutions. This address the challenge as Project Catalyst is an important tool for effective Distributed Decision making (DDM) within the Cardano Ecosystem. I also like the fact that it will build the proposed solutions in line with community feedback. The reason i'm not given 5 stars is that this proposal wouldn't have a massive impact on the current DDM process, but a significant improvement.

Active members in the community identified a pain point in the process and are already building a tool to improve it even without funding. This proposals and the efforts by the team are almost the definition of this challenge.

The proposal aims to provide tools to CAs, vCAs and proposers. 
As we all have seen in F4; the threat of overloading is very real and a tool like this would help solve that important issue, while also making sure that overall quality rises. 
So far in F5, it has already proven an invaluable tool for CAs to distribute work flow. 
It is important that tools like this exist because as Project Catalyst grows, the tools can be adjusted along the way and adapt to the needs of its users.

This proposal is spot-on some major pain points of the rapidly growing CATALYST Community. I therefore fully support this initiative, but want to add some important ideas to be discussed along the road:
1) Can this be well-integrated with the CARDANOCATALY.ST landing page ?
2) Provide an answer, how this relates to IdeaScale ? Will all this grow into IdeaScale or are we aiming for a community-run WEBsite and toolset ?

This proposal will make it easier and lower the barrier to entry for CA and vCAs, as well as proposers. My only concern is the import/export method, but that was addressed in another comment as a limitation of the platform. These apps look like they could potentially be used at a later date as well (with alterations) if Catalyst moves away from using Ideascale in the future.

The four members of the team are active members of the Catalyst community and participate in the development of various improvements, such as the creation of documentation, scripts, websites related to Catalyst, among other activities relevant to Catalyst, however I think it is important that the description of the team be more detailed so that the community can easily check this information in a practical way and in the proposal itself.

There is a clear and reasonable plan, there are details on budget allocation. There are technical details of how the tools will be created and part of the project is already under development, and there is already a prototype demonstrating what the UI will be like.

Although the conclusion of the prototype is described for Fund6, the roadmap does not present any details and there are no milestones that allow us to understand the development of the proposal over time. It is important to consider that the development of the application will be iterative and based on feedback from CAs and vCAS, however it is important to define a deadline for delivery of a final version / mvp, as this allows us to understand the need for more funding over time.

The proposer has relevant experience in Project Catalyst, but most importantly the code speaks for itself. Looking as their GitHub Repositories (https://github.com/Project-Catalyst) shows they are actively working on building the framework for this solution. Thanks for making this tool available before you have even been compensated. Speaking of budget, the cost breakdown list seems very reasonable. I am holding back one star because I do not see much information listed about your experience or team before project Catalyst. You are clearly capable, just would like to know more about your background.

Proposal's team members are active members of the community with proven experience in various past projects within Catalyst and the detail of the budget presented is adequate for the tasks listed in the proposal. The proposal covers the technical details for the 3 solutions that comprise it.

Given the experience the team has on how the community proposal and review process works, the prototype ca-tool website and the active git hub repo I'm confident the team is able to deliver this proposal. A sound plan is presented including how it will be technically implemented ("Technical Specs"). A clear budget breakdown is presented, although it would benefit from a bit more detail for example when you say "Proposer Tool Frontend Development: $600" you could detail estimated hours of work. Also it's not clear what the funds allocated to "Project admin and management" will be used for, is this to pay for a salary of a Project Manager ? Who will that be ?

Maybe in the case of other proposals I would have liked to see a bit more info about the background of the proposers, but in this case the team has already built a functioning product which can only get better with funding. Success is already in the present for this proposal.

There's really no need to provide skills evidence of the team members when we already have a prototype ready to go.
I think that maybe the project would gain if it was increased some details into the roadmap like a deadline to give feedback (after fund5), then another one to the team analyze it, etc. If the use of the tool scale, which I imagine it will, this method could help the proposers to organize themselves.

There is a very high community demand for tools like this. Everybody profits. 
So in terms of feasibility, it is highly feasible of success. Maybe one minor recommendation would be to change the system of in-browser information storage. Many users in the decentralised space equip their browsers with plugins that clear the local storage cache everytime the browser launches to promote anonimity, resulting in a loss of the 'reviewed' counter information.

Behind this proposal is a very experienced and engaged team of CATALYST activists. A lot of effort has been invested to outline problem, solution, activities, roadmap and costs. I see a VERY high likelihood that this proposal adds excellent value and will succeed.

The members of this proposal have already created the app architecture with initial userflows, and from this have created functioning prototypes. It looks like it just needs refinement for UX, as well as some responsive UI added to it. So it's in good hands as they have already made a lot of progress.

There is clarity in the problem and the solution described. The proposal is directly in line with the challenge. The budget allocation is detailed and there are objective KPIs.

The roadmap has no details. Although the prototype is already in development and the delivery of improvements has been defined for Fund6, it is important that there are more details of the timeline to allow auditing.

The proposer provides sufficient documentation and proof of concept. Given the links at the bottom (https://cardanocataly.st/ca-tool/#/) they have already completed major parts of this project. Thanks for getting straight to work with these helpful ideas. I am utilizing the ca-tool to assess a proposal with zero assessments next. Glad I found this proposal relatively early on in my CA career. I am not a vCA so I can not speak much to those tools, but the code is linked on the proposal and is getting updated regularly.

The proposal addresses the roadmap requirement and connects it with the dates of the Funds, I would like the timeline to be a bit clearer with estimate dates and maybe the breakdown of the workpackges based on team members experience, but overall I believe there is a high chance the team will complete the proposal was presented, mainly due to past proven competence and commitment.

The proposal defines very clear KPI's that will allow the community to access it's impact. A roadmap is also presented with loosely defined timelines. It would benefit for having more defined timelines (e.g. X months) but what is presented is tangible.

As said in the "impact criteria", I think that the project would gain if it was included the success aimed behind the participation percentages suggested – what we would expect to see or find out with this percentage reached in order to validate the idea.
Besides that, include a homogeneity metric, to verify if one of the previous problems observed is being solved.

There is a clear roadmap in the miro. The requested budget is set correctly and broken down for clarity. The only thing that could be added to improve is a risk assessment where everything gets covered in terms of privacy and security of the users.

The proposers provide a good example of diligence and humbleness. Very detailed information is provided. This will allow good success-tracking and auditing. Moreover, the team is excellently networked within the CATALYST Community. This provides for precious interaction with a lot of 'friendly supporters' along the journey - micro auditing based on close collaboration.

They are already measuring KPIs for users that have used the prototype tools, so they just need to keep updating their data on measuring it. It looks like they have thought this through and it should be clear in auditing the progress and success of this project.

This proposal is an extension of advertising Cardano through marketing apparel.  This is looking to purchase machinery to perform the creation of goods by the proposer for resale and marketing.  Proposal direction is completely at the discretion of the proposer and doesn't necessarily address a gap as equipment/gear can be purchased online currently albeit at 3rd party retailers.
A Cardano SPO store for merchandise is a great idea, unfortunately the proposal does not provide sufficient information to determine whether it effectively addresses the challenge.

While it is indeed likely that the proposer will be able to rent office space and buy printers, no concrete business model is presented, which makes it doubtable that the plan will succeed. In addition it is unclear hiw the Catalyst community would benefit from that.
The proposal is a draft, not a plan.The proposer did not complete the self-assessment checklist. I recommend detailing the proposal in the next Fund so that we can provide feedback.

There is not enough information about the proposer background and also the roadmap to know if the proposal is feasible or not. The budget should also be broken down in order give a better understanding if the proposal is feasible or not. Also, a plan of implementation would help to understand the proposals feasibility.

The proposer is a current SPO and has experience with marketing goods such as t-shirts and mugs.  To date, this proposer hasn't stated if they currently develop Cardano goods or not, but appears committed to ensuring producing something if funding granted.  The amount requested is not referenced anywhere in regards to why this much is needed.

The proposal does not include any of the details from the self-assessment checklist, a broken-down budget, an expected launch date, definition of success. Recommend re-submission for a future fund with all the necessary details included.

The proposal lacks a roadmap, milestones, KPIs and metrics. It also should have a budget breakdown to improve the proposal's accountability. If possible it would also be good to have metrics to relate the outcome of this project with the increase of participation in Catalyst, which is the main topic of this challenge.

The proposal is rather scarce of information in terms of a roadmap or deliverable or even what the funding will do other than purchase machinery to create marketing goods.  Refinement of the proposal would be necessary to capture how and when milestones will be met.
There is no information on how this proposal could be audited. Given the significant budget being requested here, more details are required. Voters need to know how the money will be spent.

The goal within the "Proposer outreach" campaign is to attract entrepreneurs and companies from all over the world to learn about Catalyst and make them submit proposals of high quality. 

A key metric for this campaign is:
"Ideas submitted from new members of the community."

I fail to understand the connection between marketing for small SPO's and how that would result in new proposals for the Catalyst project. Therefore I will give this proposal a score of 1.

The idea states a problem which needs to be solved, however it is not coherent with this challenge. Maybe if you unite this idea with creating awareness of Cardano's environment to people outside this ecosystem and if it's clear for them that entering in this world, they will have the opportunity to be more than a delegator, because your channel creates awareness of small SPO as well, it might be more aligned with the challenge.

It is not clear how interviewing people that are already part of cardano in the role of SPO would help bringing ideas for future funds. I can imagine that it may inspire people to run their own stake pools, but that's not the goal of this challenge.

This proposal asks for 10% of the whole "Proposer outreach" campaign yet, there is no clear budget or time plan presented. The proposer mentions in the comments that the funds will go towards gear for high quality videos but I would like a detailed budget in order to be comfortable to support this proposal in the future. 
Another questionable factor is the proposers lack of experience and his disinterest to make videos before.
I do not want to be rude but this proposal is very low-effort and needs an elaborated plan of how you would implement your proposal successfully. With the information provided, I do not believe that this proposal will be successful.

You do not need much to create content on YT, if it's very basic, just need confidence, will power, a cell phone and internet. One of the biggest channels in Brazil, if not the biggest, start like this – will power and confidence (Whindersson Nunes). However, to create a well-produced, well-guided and written interviews, you need more than that.
Need more explanation why you are asking this amount of money.  
This idea needs to be lapidated and became an actual project.

It is really hard to start a Youtube channel from zero. Given that the proposer has no experience it is hard to see the proposal beeing successfully. It would have been something else if there was already a youtube channel where you could check the previous videos. I would recommend to start such a channel anyways and then if it starts to take of maybe ask for additional funding.

The proposer only describes his past experience, but has provided no links to attest it. There is also no detailed plan, making it impossible to assess the project. Recommend a re-submission to a next fund, after the proposer is able to write a more complete project and maybe joins teams with other community members who have more experience on the video side.

This proposal lacks information about a plan for implementation and key metrics to evaluate the proposals success in the future. This makes the integrity of the proposal questionable.
I do not believe small SPO awareness videos would bring in new members and proposals in the future in an effective manner. The interview aspect of videos are an interesting topic but I think you would have to change the focus to address project Catalyst in some way, in order to address the goal of this campaign.
The aim of the proposal to reduce insurance fraud using blockchain is good however the solution offered is not clear or complete and the process to prevent the fraud has not been explained clearly.

In my opinion this proposal is a real implementation in insurance financial services that could improve the transactions volume on cardano blockchain, but It isn't clearly articulates how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and for the stakeholders (in deep detail for users, insurers and so on.. ). However the objective of the proposal is very interesting. The prototype is nice and funny, but there isn't any screenshot or demo available. I think there is a value for the customers, in security and simplicity

First of all, the proposer has stated in the comments that this proposal is a duplication of his own first proposal. This means that this specific proposal is a copy of another one. I have checked and the original/first submission is at:

https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Insurance-Claims-Processing/350998-48088

Hence, as this proposal is already a copy of an existing one - according to the proposer - a copy will not address the challenge effectively - and I am downvoting it as a copy. So that the original proposal (according to the proposer's own comment) can be assessed

(This is a duplicate of another proposal by the same team) The proposer claims to be wanting to build a dApp that tackles insurance fraud, but he offers no description of the actual dApp, why it would be necessary to be built on the Cardano ecosystem and how it would increase utility and adoption of it.

The plan is still a draft. There are no details on how the proposal will prevent fraud. There is little information about the team, I recommend providing details about how many people will be part of the proposal and details about the experience and qualifications of each one, also indicating what will be their role in the proposal. It is important to detail the budget allocation better. If the budget is used in its entirety to pay developers, I recommend detailing the work to be performed by the devs and an estimate of hours for the work to be performed.

I also recommend that the team follow the Catalyst documentation as a reference to prepare a proposal.

*The team submitted 2 identical proposals, so I am submitting the same rationale.

The proposal team seams  skilled and expertise, so in my opinion will able to make a good pilot. In relation to the possible success of the initiative, there are poor indications related to marketing and communication for the product launch, neither about the customers adoption. Further I think it's important to improve details about the process related to the issue related to the market or capital risk

Extremely limited information in the proposal, especially given the very high fund request. Some information I'm missing: who are the team, what are the deliverables, how do the timeplan look, how will the requested funds be allocated.

Some information about the team has been described, but other than that, there is no information to audit the proposal. I recommend that the team read the Catalyst documentation and adapt the proposal, including metrics, roadmap, KPIs and the other items present in the documentation.

*The team submitted 2 identical proposals, so I am submitting the same rationale.

Draft proposal. There was no problem in the problem statement, which makes it difficult to assess the value proposition and alignment with the challenge. The lack of a plan makes it impossible to assess the impact of the challenge and the potential for improvement for Cardano. It is important to include more details so that it is possible to give appropriate feedback.

The core idea that transpires from the very little information that was written down has the potential to go in a good direction, that would eventually lead to a wider adoption of the ecosystem. However, the proposal needs to be re-submitted in a future fund with a clear plan, budget, metrics and so on.

This proposal is likely to fail. The requests Budget of $150k is not only very high but additionally it was never explained for what it is needed. Given that sum, I would expect an adequate description on how this budget might be used. it needs more editing and a more work to make it proper assessable.
Additionally, there is no timeline presented on how long it may take to build this DApp.
As there is no information about the qualifications of the proposer and possible team behind him/her a proper assessment is not possible.

Even though the proposer has relevant experience in Phyton and Django there is no more information about the team behind the proposal or if the proposer is working alone. For 150k a more detailed description is beneficial.

There is no plan and budget for the requested funds
There is no detailed description about the project in the proposal, the self described experience is not backed-up by external links that would help verify the assertions.
Roadmap and milestones are missing. There are no KPIs mentioned on which the project should be audited by. The proposal leaves one wondering what needs this DApp idea would satisfy.

I found this idea very interesting because it intends to make the relationship between companies, customers and workers more just. It is known that with the pandemic, small companies lost customers and many had to end their activities, while larger organizations grew, in a way, as the author cites in the text, exploratory and prejudicial to workers.
