When building an application in which companies can create personalized contracts, get in direct contact with customers, etc., as mentioned by the author, review various business practices, it may be possible to make the situation fairer for everyone. Regarding the impact of the project on the Cardano community, I found it a bit confusing where our group's activities would fit. It would be beneficial if the author clarified these issues better.

The proposer described experiences  with marketing and sales and as an entrepreneur,, but did not indicate sources to support these claims. It is important that details about experience and qualification are made available, so that the community has easy and transparent access, a link to Linkedin can be an effective way to resolve this.

Considering that the idea of ​​the project is to create a dapp, it is important to include the number of developers required to create the application and the qualifications of each member of the team. (This was not described in the proposal)

The plan has a well-articulated rationale on the problem and ideas on the solution, but there is no concrete plan for implementation. There is no budget breakdown.

The issue of compliance with regulators and local governments was mentioned, but one of the problems with apps in the gig economy is that their dependence on government regulation creates a weakness related to taxes model, this can make the project's economic model unfeasible, as occurs with Uber in several locations. Jurisdictions where Uber is subject to regulations where there is a considerable increase in tax burdens often cause Uber to simply stop operating in these jurisdictions. In addition, regulation ends up creating a problem with labor ties that may force dapp's creator to bear the costs, which would imply a transfer of costs to users, compromising the supply and demand relationship and putting pressure on dapp's financial viability.. Without a sufficiently decentralized model, this type of project may not be feasible.

I recommend detailing the proposal with the mentioned points and elaborating a new proposal based on the Catalyst documentation.

You are doing great work here, but you need a great team to make this proposal succeed. The budget needs to be defined. Keep looking for team members with relevant experience and hopefully next fund your proposal will be in better shape and even more attractive.

The proposal does not break down the fund allocation. How is the proposer planing to attract talent that can implement the vague proposal? How does the proposal, if implemented, account for gig workers outbidding each other and thus worsen the problem that the proposal aims to solve? How do you onboard businesses that do not want to negotiate individual wages? It is also unclear how the proposer plans to be in compliance with regulations (something that is mentioned in the business plan). How much money is allocated for legal services?

The information provided is insufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

The only part of the project that has a very detailed action plan is marketing. I believe that because of the author's training. In relation to this, it is very clear which paths to take and why. However, there is a lack of detail in relation to the rest of the project, how this application would be built, how long each step would take place and so on. Also, it would be beneficial to include an explanation of how the financing money would be used, nothing is mentioned about it, which, unfortunately, makes the execution of the project very abstract, not measurable.
There is no information to assess auditability. Include metrics, KPIs, roadmap, budget breakdown according to the Catalyst documentation.

The vision of what Youbiquitor wants to be is clear. When more team members are on board I'm sure there will be better defined metrics in place.
Launching the app in a new country every year seems doable, but more potential challenges/risks needs to be mentioned and addressed. You are already solving some problems, but what about new potential problems 
that might surface. Ex. The gig world involves a lot of people that still needs some crypto savvy. How will they acquire and hold ADA for your app?

All I get from the proposal is that somehow the DApp is supposed to support the great green wall by charging polluters and paying workers on the great green wall with it? Listen, I love the concept of the great green wall and I greatly appreciate the idea of supporting it, but since this proposal does not have a concrete plan on how it will be designed and how it is going to work, I can only give it 4 stars. In addition to this, judging from the comments you seem reluctant to onboard african devs, which is a bit disappointing, considering it would benefit people in africa even more and spread cardano there.

I would like to see more detail about how the website and your proposal leads to the outcome you are looking to achieve.  I think that the proposal has some admirable goals, but the steps  between the funding and the goal are not clear to me. I wasn't able to view the website listed, so it was hard for me to assess relevant experience of the proposer.  The administrative costs seem high when compared to the amount needed for programs.

There is no real plan, currently its just an idea. More work needs to be done to flesh out exactly what needs to be built on both a technical and legal side. This who idea rests on finding people outside of africa who will pay people in africa to grow things. There is no plan on how to execute this side. The propoent shoudl find some people/entities to link up with to help on this side and present a plan linked with the experience to deliver it.

The author of the proposal does not reveal much about himself, only that he is based in Essex and Ontario. It is not clear what his exact background is, if he already has experience with application development, for example. It was important to know this information, so that there would be confidence in the future work. The author claims to be active and determined to help the community and nature, but does not point out how he does it. I believe that the attached website could clarify such issues, but unfortunately the link does not work. It is necessary to know a little more about the training and experience of the people who propose to carry out the projects at Cardano.

You seem like person experienced in a couple of fields, which indicates that you might have some versatility, skills and most importantly passion to bring into the project. However, the plan for this project is not very detailed and the budget is very high. If you demand this amount of money you should maybe have a very detailed, convincing proposal that has already planned all the single steps and considered all the things that need to be minded. And maybe also have some of the groundwork done in order to identify the problems and challenges better and have a better idea of the feasibility.

The proposer is asking for a budget of 150000, which seems very high for the described DApp. Most of the budget is allocated to the salaries of a few members of the team, and marketing, with only a small fraction allocated directly to development. There is also content that needs to be produced, but no budget is allocated for that. It would be useful if the proposer could identify project goals any possible roadblocks so it would be more apparent why certain roles are required (like an accountant)

The author provides information about how the project would be carried out according to the months, and also how the requested money would be divided. However, I thought that the amount requested was very high, the project is of potential, but in my opinion it would be safer to carry it out on a smaller scale and in case of success increase inventories.

I find this proposal to be not sufficiently mature, although the idea of a  social platform is worthy of consideration. However, it is important to keep in mind that many social platforms exist even in the centralized world and most of them are worth nothing. The very problem statement might be a problem for me as it specifies that "most low level users in crypto's first and only experience with crypto is on Coinbase and then nothing after that". Not sure how big of a problem is that and whether the statement is true at all. Is a general statement and the the proposal is designed to solve that " problem statement". Most people's experience with cash is to use it as much as they need and that in my view is not a "problem". The problem might be providing more different uses that will make crypto useful, not inventing new ways of engaging consumers in order to "fool them" (my words) to use it more. The proposed solution "creation of a platform that anyone can join, buy crypto and actively transact on the blockchain (maybe without even knowing it)" seems impossible because of the effective legislation that is in place around crypto. Most crypto exchanges will require cystomers to go through a crypto KYC (Know Your Customer) process before buying and cashing out and just swapping an exchange for a "world building social platform" will not exclude this platform from KYC requirements. This issue does not seem to be addressed although the proposal does propose a platform for buying crypto. So I am not sure whether the proposal will be able to result in a novel and viable application that will attract users in real life. So, I would include more information about the restrictions in buying crypto and trading it and how this will be addressed.

The problem description and solution are reasonable.

The proposal described is within the scope of this challenge, as it would be an application/dapp inspired by Patreon, OnlyFans, which are centralized subscription services that are increasingly popular.

The absence of metrics and goals makes it difficult to assess the impact of this challenge, so I recommend that the proposer include these items.

The core idea could be promising to the objective of the challenge of expanding the Cardano ecosystem by attracting new users and driving adoption. However a clearer implementation plan and more details would be required to fulfil the vision outlined in the proposal.

"Presenting cryptocurrency to the masses in a fun and creative way", as the author of the proposal itself exemplified in his text, is the main objective of this idea. I found this proposal very interesting, because it intends to create an application (as I understand it) where people can choose to make a "kingdom", with different contents, or participate in an existing kingdom, and within these "universes" transactions are made via ADA, NFTs and etc. It is a proposal similar to some things that already exist, such as OnlyFans, but which innovates when it intends to include the blockchain of practice in people's daily lives, who often see this type of activity as something a little distant from their realities. I just don't know how the issue of making decisions would get involved in this app, in my opinion it would be another way of attracting new members to the community.

The proposal is applying for USD250,000 in funding and in such a proposal I would expect to see much much much more detailed information about timetables, detailed professional experience with links verifying successful projects completed and a super duper budget breakdown that is clearly itemized and easy to follow and understand. There is a lot of information about the social world/platform - but an idea is different from a funding proposal. A successful funding proposal needs to be on the cusp of realization, one step away from full implementation - practically ready-to-go as soon as funding is made available. In this case, I don't see those required elements. The experience listed states: "I have been developing apps for the last 5 years and have helped scale multiple saas companies to 50k+ mrr." My quibble with this listed experience is that anyone can develop apps, what would prove relevant experience is successful apps or a trend of building better and more successful apps. What I am trying to say is that verifiable app building experience is best demonstrated by showing examples. Also it would be great if those multiple saas companies that have been helped to scale to 50k+ mrr were listed by name ... as well as the exact contribution of the proposer. Finally, I also do not think the  proposer has demonstrated that he sufficiently considered challenges and risks that might derail his ambitious project.

The proposer described his experience in developing apps for the last 5 years, but there are no details about the work done or a link to make it possible to check his qualifications / experience.

There is no mention of experience with development in blockchains or smart contracts, I recommend clarifying this point.

There is a reasonable rationale and a promising concept, but it lacks a structured plan and within what we expect from the proposals in Catalyst. I recommend including a roadmap, details on budget breakdown and other information described in the Catalyst documentation.

The proposer doesn't provide enough information about his background, credentials or links to previous works. The proposal lacks a detailed plan, roadmap or broken down budget. I would advise adding all these elements in future version of the proposal, as well as an estimated start date.

The author says he has more than 5 years of experience with application development and with the growth of some companies, which is certainly beneficial for the project. However, I believe that this proposal is very complex and needs a large and experienced team to work, because here it is intended to create a new kind of social network, which is also a game and a means of establishing financial transactions via ADA… there are many variables that will need professionals in the areas of technology, design, finance and etc. Therefore, I believe that the author is indeed qualified to be part of the team, but that this needs to be better planned.

The auditability of this proposal is relatively weak. I do not see a well-defined roadmap that would inspire confidence in a Project Catalyst voter. Voters are essentially deciding to delegate treasury funds for proposals. Any proposal stands a much better chance to be voted for if it includes specific milestones and a timetable with key stages linked to time for realization. 

The inclusion of key metrics for success and performance would have helped make this proposal easily auditable and it would be easy to assess its ultimate feasibility. As it stands now, it would benefit from a more targeted vision on the nitty-gritty details concerning realization.

It is good that there is thought of possible restrictions to the execution of the plan. But as we're speaking of a DApp with a large amount of personal content, it could get complicated in terms of copyright. So there is a need to incorporate legalities to make sure that everything is covered. 
Furthermore I'd advise to include a budget breakdown to justify the requested amount. It doesn't really matter if the amount is high or low, but it does matter if there is an explanation to it so the voterbase understands why something might cost any given amount. 
Finally, creating the DApp, onboarding other platforms and users and supporting it post-release would total to quite some work. A roadmap is needed to keep track.

No information has been included to enable the proposal to be audited. I recommend including roadmap, milestones, metrics, KPIs, details about the team and budget allocation, as stated in the Catalyst documentation.

It would represent a challenge for the community to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposal in addressing the goal of increasing adoption of the Cardano blockchain as long as no metrics for auditing the proposal are included. I would suggest including a clear set of KPIs and defined deliverables in a future iteration of the proposal.

In this part, the author did not include how he intends to carry out his project, did not establish steps or an intended budget. Unfortunately, there is no information to be analyzed. If an action plan was included, how the money would be spent, some expectation of return on investments, we could have a basis for the next steps to be taken in this project.

The challenge is effectively defined to attract proposals to  encourage more meaningful participation in Project Catalyst from community members in the next two funds. Although this proposal is well meaning and clearly the proposer wishes to promote the blockchain technology and Cardano ecosystem in particular, it is unlikely that it will achieve the aims of this specific challenge as the proposal seems to be defined too broadly.

I would suggest that the proposer focuses specifically on Catalyst and how to attract specifically stakeholders to Catalyst (proposers, entrepreneurs, developers, programmers, community advisors, etc...). A guiding question for this challenge specified that it aims to attract meaningful (!) participation from proposers, advisors, and voters. So, explaining the advantages and attraction of Cardano is a noble endeavor, but not immediately aligned with the challenge.

The idea of the project is very interesting, I am Brazilian, and in fact, here there is not much dissemination of information about cryptocurrencies and their technologies. A youtube channel is a very good way to learn about any subject, including this one, and this platform is already widely used for educational purposes in the country. I agree that teaching in a didactic way the pillars of the Catalyst ecosystem, such as what is blockchain, what are cryptocurrencies and etc., is the best way to involve people and inspire them to join the community. In this sense, the theoretical part of the project fits well with the objective of the challenge launched here. The author even explains that he will use DEADALUS as a gateway to Cardano, a potential direction that was mentioned in the campaign description.

This proposal is intended to help educate the Portuguese-speaking population, but the content desired to be built is a bit broad.  Educational content like this may be beyond the desired intended scope that Catalyst was designed to serve. The main goal though is to generate marketing content for their stake pool and is not really a community-based goal.

The proposer already has a YouTube channel with dozens of videos about cryptocurrencies, but a small part (less than 5%) are videos dedicated to Cardano.

This shows that he has experience in creating videos, but does not show his involvement / knowledge of Cardano.

There are no more details about the proposer's experiences and knowledge that allow a more detailed assessment. I recommend including more details about this and so that the community understands the proposer's ability to produce relevant materials about Cardano.

The proposer mentions the intention to hire people to help with the proposal, but does not mention how many people, what kind of help they will provide or what budget is dedicated to these people.

The budget will be used for the purchase of equipment and payments for the creation of content (videos) and the creation of at least 1 video per week, but there are no details on the budget allocation or on the duration of the proposal(no timeline/roadmap). It is important to be informed of the period for which the proposer will commit to creating videos or the number of videos so that we can judge the feasibility of the plan and the budget.

I feel that the proposer has the necessary skills and experience to implement the proposal should funding be granted. The request is not for an excessive budget but the query about choice of challenge remains.

Although the proposer does wish to promote Cardano, I do not think that the proposed plan has considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful attraction of new proposers/developers/entrepreneurs/advisors to Catalyst in the next two funds.

No metrics that would be able to assess the impact of the Youtube channel on gaining meaningful participation from Brazilian proposers, advisors, and voters are proposed. 

Also as regards the budget, the proposer states: " For now only I am producing content, but with the money received I intend to pay some people to help me." It would have been helpful to know which kind of skills and how many people are needed. How much would these inputs cost and what is exactly required.

In this part, the author does not appear to be a person technically very prepared to make the videos. It was not clear what his background was, what his professional field was, what his experience in teaching, what his didactics… All of these points could have a positive impact if they were better clarified. It is known that he already has a certain experience with youtube, since he already has a channel with more than 15 thousand subscribers, but working with youtube today requires a lot of planning, study and strategy, due to the immense range of pre-existing content. How to make this channel stand out and be seen in fact among Brazilians who are interested in technology and economics? Therefore, it would be necessary to be more confident about the technical preparation of the author and his abilities to progress on the chosen platform.

The proposer already has a experience in creating videos and content for internet as it's presented in his own youtube channel. It mentions that weekly videos would be created to inform Brazilian about Cardano in general, but it doesn't say for how long he would do that. It would be good to have a budget breakdown to explain the cost of each video.

The proposal description does not demonstrate how it will address the challenge in a relevant way. The challenge is to improve value onboarding in Catalyst and there is no mention of how it will be done, I recommend that it be modified to suit the challenge.

There is no budget breakdown, no roadmap / timeline, no solid metrics. The KPI of 1000 views per video alone is not a reliable indicator for auditing the proposal, for two reasons, first because this number can be manipulated by bots, second because the number of views is not a good indicator for checking engagement numbers. of voters, CAs and vCAs.

One of the established goals is to increase the number of investors in ADA, and consequently of delegations in the Brazilian Pool "CARDS", I do not think that recommending a specific pool is recommended, as this may suggest bias.

The number of tutorials are not offered and although the weekly frequency of videos is supplied, it is unclear how long will it last as a whole.

The issue of quality is also lacking and how prominent will the Catalyst segment of Cardano feature? It is unclear. As such I think that it will be difficult to audit the proposal's implementation and its ultimate effect on deepening meaningful participation from proposers, advisors, and voters. It is clearly a proposal that has its own merits, but in my opinion it - in its current form - does not align well with the challenge and is difficult to audit in terms of contribution to Catalyst.

The proposal needs a clearer roadmap, since it only says that a weekly video will be produced but not for how long. Also, the budget will be used to produced videos and for marketing as well, but it is not clear how much would go for each one. There are no metrics related to the challenge goals of onboarding people into Catalyst, only a single metric which in number of views in youtube. More information should be included to facilitate the auditability of this proposal, specially those more relevant to the challenge itself.

Generally, yes. I think the cointopay plugin may already be able to pay with ADA. An advantage here would be to create an app that is similar to a wallet to wallet payment and does not incur any extra fees (cointopay 1% extra). I am currently still missing these points.

Draft proposal. The proposal is about creating a plugin to integrate the Magento marketplace and allow payments in ADA, in theory the concept could address the challenge, but there is no plan that indicates the alignment of the proposal and there are no goals / metrics that indicate the impact in the challenge. I recommend including a detailed plan according to the Catalyst documentation.

Availability of ADA payment plugins in Magento 2 will enable websites to use these and thereby improve the adoption of ADA as a means of payment. The proposal however has not included and technical details and had not brought out the steps involved in the execution of the process.

There are indeed 170k online shops built on Magento 2, so a plugin that would enable payments with Ada could indeed increase adoption of Cardano. But the proposal is very short, beyond this initial idea, there is not much info given, making it hard to assess.

One point is to create a plugin, another a successful plugin. I am missing some details in the technical description and a concept to not only create this plugin, but also to update it. For a billing plugin, security is a key factor and so I need to trust the developer.
Details required to enable the assessment of feasibility. Detailed plan with milestones and evidence of proposers capability.

The proposal has not listed the steps in creating the plugin and how they will be promoted for adaptation by the sites using Magento. The proposal only aims to create the plugin. The technical challenges in wallet integration and security have not be analyzed in the proposal.

There should be a clear explanation about what Magento2 is so that everyone understands the scope of the dApp. Afterwards, there should be a description of the plug-in, how it works, how you can buy it, what it can achieve. For a future re-submission, there should also be included a detailed budget, a roadmap, metrics, everything included in the self-assessment checklist.

A DEX aggregator is an important project to assure the liquidity of ADA related exchange pairs and will provide a lot of additional traffic on ADA related decentralized exchanges once they actually exist. At this moment however this is not the case, which is the reason for the 3 star rating. Funding and implementing of such a project will only make sense once decentralized exchanges exist on the Cardano network. If this was the case this assesment aspect would get 5 stars.
proposalTitle: A DEX aggregator built on Cardano

assessmentNote:
The problem statement is subjective. DEXs like Uniswap or Sushiswap have billions in liquidity among the various pooled assets, is this considered a lack of liquidity? I do not know, because this is subjective. 

Regardless, liquidity aggregating protocols like 1Inch or Paraswap are very useful in increasing liquidity between different DEXs and are an important part of DeFi.

In the plan(described in the attached file) there is no information about the development of a DEX aggregator, which makes it impossible to evaluate how the proposal will address the challenge and the suggested problem statement
proposalTitle: A DEX aggregator built on Cardano

assessmentNote: The plan presented is for a much larger project and it isn't clear how this money requested will be used within the larger ecosystem. If the proposal depends on the success of the remaining project scope then it may fail as a whole even if this one dex aggregator is successful. There is no detailed budget, scope, or timeline identified within this proposal. the team that would do the work isn't disclosed so there is high risk of failure.
proposalTitle: A DEX aggregator built on Cardano

assessmentNote: No details given. Please provide detail of what you are doing and how this fits in the competitive landscape. Provide a detailed budget to justify your $250,000 request, which is the entire fund budget.
proposalTitle: A DEX aggregator built on Cardano

assessmentNote: While the information provided gives extensive information about the background and credibility of the company and about a money transfer service provided by it, there is no actual information given on how to implement the concrete proposal and no rationale for the budget. The proposal basically is non-existent and working on a topic that is at the moment not implementable atm because no decentralized exchanges exist on cardano at the moment.
proposalTitle: A DEX aggregator built on Cardano

assessmentNote:
The plan presented in the attached file is very well detailed, but it does not appear to have been developed for the Catalyst proposal. The proposal is asking for $ 250,000, but there is no detail on the budget allocation.

No metrics, KPIs, roadmap, milestones related to this challenge were described. The absence of this information compromises auditability.

I recommend creating a plan specifically for this proposal.
proposalTitle: A DEX aggregator built on Cardano

assessmentNote:
It would help to add more information about the Team behind this proposal. A DEX is a complicated undertaking which needs quite a bit of work. If you already did a DEX 3 years ago why is the name of the DEX not in the proposal. Is it still alive, what about the code?

There is no roadmap or budget in the proposal.

If there is already a working product, the budget of 250k is unfortunately to much.

First, the proposer claim to have a couple years experience in Dexs and in making partnership & integration with Financial institutions. I can't access the instamo employees linkedin profiles witheout being part of their "network". 
Still, the proposer's name is matching with the one quoted on instamo website, and, he do have a linkedin profile. It would be great to have those links written down in the proposition so the CAs don't have to search for too long.

The plan: 
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/17VYtHD7nfxCyDJ9O-E2sV8rzyd61tb3ByTttbNjJA_0/edit?ts=60174d60#slide=id.gb92a66b0cc_0_145

I must say it is interesting, but some pages are a little bit too blurry, like some bad copy-past. It felt like it when i scrolled down to read more deeply about the proposal.
It could be more trustworhty, as we are all very aware of internet scammers. No offense to the proposers, it is just a fact.

The idea is launched by the "Africa Blockchain Institute", a group already experienced in decentralizing knowledge about these technologies. Attached is a website that talks about the group, shows photos of the members with their respective performances and explains very well how the activities are carried out. Through the attached website, a lot of confidence is given to the team that proposes to carry out the camp, the idea of who is there and doing what is very well structured.

The dates of the camp are given, but the way there is missing. To organise this in 3 months is quite intensive and since the dates are given I would look for more detailed plan about how to get there. I really hope that it exists and the voters will see the potential of this project.

A document was attached with an exact planning of the camp's activities, which would happen on which day. All separated into clear topics, the information is passed on very successfully. It is certain that the group has well-established goals to fulfill, which is fundamental for the success of any project. I have just a few observations: it would be interesting to better understand how the money received for the investment would be used, how much would be spent at each stage, where the camp would take place, how many young people would participate in the project and so on. They are details. I also missed a bit of lightness in the event's schedule, after all we would be dealing with young people, and introducing the subject in a light, didactic and escalating way with recreational activities would be very beneficial. But overall, I really liked this project.

The idea is very interesting, it is the first proposal that I evaluate that seeks to generate a token from something physical, as was mentioned in the text, the first project would be aimed at a football club. In this way, the use of tokens can be innovative and bring new uses to the cardan community. As it is a new activity, I believe that the process of implementing this practice is a long way, but it is beneficial for the author to have an example to start with. In fact, according to what has been said, this project already has investors from outside the Cardano system, but the author finds it more beneficial if the idea is made within our community. Because we already have an investment, we have more security in relation to the value of the project. The only thing that was still a bit confusing to me is how this project fits the challenge of the apps, I didn't understand where these tokens would be generated, what would be the chosen platform and so on.

Standardization of Native Token to represent a physical assert will provide a template and enable easier app creation in the future. There is a NFT DAO which also looking for standardization, however, a independent initiative to create a standard for a use case can play as a framework for others.

This proposal is lacking technical aspects due to much of it's intention being to flush those details as part of the scope of the proposal itself. I see this as a proposal to explore the idea. Also, the scope is not a deliverable for production, so it is very difficult to asses if this specific component would be useful in the ultimate delivery.

We have here, organized in a numerical list, the future actions that will compose the practical development of the project. In this way, we can have a very clear, objective and chronological view of what is to come. There is also a total estimate of time (2 months), which I believe encompasses all the actions listed numerically. However, it would also be interesting to determine a sense of how long each would take. The author says that the 10k requests for funding is an estimate. It would be safer if we knew how that money would be shared between the parties, from the shares and the participating professionals. Another positive point is that some success metrics are established; the author also claims that there will be feedback to the community, in the form of different media (from what I understand), something that I found very interesting, I did not see many proposals concerned with this part of the project. In this way, I believe that the applicability of the project is well structured, with only a few points missing to make it ideal.

Trustlessness is certainly useful component in crowdfunding but I feel this proposal misses the decentralised component and replicates instead legacy business model missing out on P2P components of Cardano swarm supports already available through the work of the Foundation and Catalyst. I would like to see more creativity in determining 'funding' values and encourage team forming around proposed projects such as IdeaScale and collaborations on the crowd supported projects.

The proposal if successful would attract participants to an ADA centered economy.  It has the potential to grow transactions and token usage. If successful in attracting participants and gaining trust, the volume of ADA involved could be large.

This is a great concept with huge potential interest.  Also a great name!
The potential for driving adoption is high, and this solution would contribute to democratized innovation, which is of value.
Some suggestions for future consideration:
- the funding / smart contract protocols 
   and the associated process become a 
   differentiating factor for this platform 
   (vs. Kickstarter).  This may be part of the 
   prototyping:  how can you use the capabilities
   of smart contracts to allow the funders to have
   unique influence or to get increased "stake" or
   return over several phases of the project-to-be
   -funded?  Be prepared to evolve over time.
-  Governance function is currently focused on the 
    governance of Crowdano.  Would suggest this
    is a lower priority for initial releases and 
    focus should be on the "funder's" influence
    on the "funded project"s phased evolution.

Yes I believe that this Plutus pioneer could replicate existing crowd funding principles and with the help of the community save most of his costs in marketing however I don't like that he is completely forgoing his fees and would prefer to see him collaborate with Catalyst team developing components of Cardano onboarding within the existing community systems and in continuation to them.

The specific outcome is not clearly described and so success is difficult to measure.

I would suggest a more limited and clear MVP (e.g. a prototype with a single fundraising campaign and no governance?).  

Be prepared to enhance Crowdano through several funding rounds, and iterate ideas through expanding prototypes.
The proposer seems to have the necessary toolset to complete the work, however being a single developer with an ambitious timeline, it might be a little risky.

The proposal certainly has support from the community and over time it may well be developed. The information provided is reasonable but would benefit from greater detail. It appears to be at the research phase rather than the ready for submission stage although I sense with the correct connections this could be addressed quite quickly.

The outline of resources is well-thought out and reasonable.

Without a high level development, testing and implementation roadmap, it is difficult to audit progress.  The state outcomes need to be more specific in order to gauge the success of the proposal.

A more specific an limited MVP would make for a more successful proposal.

The proposer seeks to remedy the problem of allowing a developer to contribute to open source projects while working on their own projects. This doesn't seem to be a problem for most developers, and is not something that is specific to Cardano. As a developer, I am finding it difficult to understand what utility this approach affords over the regular workflow of using git and submodules for my own projects, and pushing change requests to contribute to open source projects. The discoverability of useful Cardano-related libraries as well as documentation of what problem that library solves and examples of how to use it would be very helpful, but I am not sure if that is what is being proposed here.

In theory the usefulness of such a library to the subset of the JavaScript developers working on Cardano could result in improvements to their experience and effectiveness. However, the impact of this proposal is very much tied to the quality of the resulting deliverable, much more so than in the case of other projects and the plan provided does not point in that direction.
The project makes sense as more Javascript developers begin working on Cardano. However without a lot of community adoption, its is hard to say whether it will achieve its intended impact.

Looking at the github repo, a lot of what is described in the proposal has already been accomplished. How does the proposer plan to get other developers to use and contribute to this repo? How many libraries and projects will be added to count this as being implemented successfully?

No verifiable links to the proposers credentials or previous works. Metrics are not defined and a definition of success is not clearly established. I would suggest given every aspect of the proposal more thought, engaging more with the community, as it's a proposal that's dependant on community collaboration and input, and possibly resubmitting it to a future fund. Even if the proposal would produce some deliverables, the overall success of the project would depend on their quality and in its current form it doesn't inspire enough confidence.

The author appears to have the experience necessary to move the project forward and the end product could potentially be of benefit to the Dev ecosystem but its difficult to assess that at this point as the plan is lacking in detail. I would like to see ongoing collaboration with the community and team building to give this proposal greater robustness and sustainability.

The tasks described in the plan set forth in the proposal do not specify any clear metrics  that could be used to check for accountability. What does the proposer envision the repository to look like at the end of the allotted time? Not knowing the answer to that question, it is difficult to decide if this project would provide utility to Cardano developers

The project doesn't include an estimated starting date. Two months are mentioned in the budget, but when would that timeframe elapse? No clear roadmap is given. Contributions to the library could be measured by the community, but a clear assessment of their quality would require a deep dive or rely entirely on self-reporting. The deliverables are clearly describes and that represents the strongest point of a proposal that could be considered in a future fund if improvements and refinements are made to it.

It is difficult to predict what the results of the 13k and 2 months work will produce.  I think the proposer would have more success on Catalyst if the repo established some more activity and participants organically.  It would be easier to justify paying a salary to the organizer if there was already some momentum and a clear plan. As it is, it will be hard to judge the return on intention of the funds.

Good solution to a nightmare of a problem in the current world in doing this type of freelance work. I think a lot more people would get into freelance if there was no centralized host that took 30% revenue (which is crazy!)

Would be nice to have some evidence of experience (LinkedIn?). Only a placeholder website provided. A key component to this working is the dispute resolution. How will smart contracts solve this? They are only as good as the data going in? Where does this come from, how is it validated? The dispute panel could quickly become overwhelmed and 3% fee may be nowhere near enough to cover this.
From what I can tell there is a single experienced developer to work on this. That is great but I think given the scope of the project it would be beneficial to look into having a team of people.

I believe the project will be successful my only concern at this time is the timeline of how long it will take to accomplish. The details and roadmap are great. The website is also a nice touch and I will be keeping an eye on this to see how it is coming along.

If correctly implemented this could be a strong candidate. It would obviously take someone with political connection to get it accepted in individual countries, however this could potentially be done by the Cardano team once the PoC is developed. First use could be for smaller countries operating a travel bubble such as Singapore/Hong Kong.

The proposer is a SPO with marketing experience. The proposal involves solving multifaced app development, government interaction, and medical record collection. There might be a requirement for a team with relevant skill sets to accomplish the task. The task analysis needs to be carried out more thoroughly.

The three-phase plan is not described in sufficient detail: in particular, "technical system including front end" needs to be elaborated into a development roadmap. Additionally, the second step of the plan puts Charles Hoskinson on the critical path to success, but the plan doesn't assert that he would assist. "Marketing for rest of world" also needs specifics. Finally, no evidence is provided that the project team has development experience with Cardano development and identity/trust management practices.

The three-stage plan is too vague to audit in detail for progress and the proposal does not provide a timeline. The final goal is described too abstractly: the proposal would benefit from a more detailed description of how immunization credentials would be validated prior to their inclusion in transaction metadata, since validity is the crux of this proposal's success.

For this project to add significant value relies on achieving a very large scale. I don't think Cardano is mature enough at this point  to attract that kind of interest. Developing such a platform could help developers in the future, though, so I do see some value.  However the proposal is too ambitious and costly at this stage, in my opinion. A proposal with more modest costs  would be better matched to the expected immediate impact.  In fact, the goals for success are only numbers of listings or sales on the platform. Since the platform already exists, it seems like a small marketing team could achieve these goals without investing in an office etc. Once Cardano is more developed, this industry-friendly appearance will be more important, but that could come in later funding rounds.

The proposer appears to have access to a qualified pool of developers although little specific details are given. The project website provided is functional and of high quality, which gives confidence. The proposer participated actively with the community during the refinement stage, but the proposal could be much more concise and organized. This makes me wonder how well defined and thought out the proposal is.  The proposal has a lot of cost overhead and moving parts, and I'm not convinced the proposer is qualified to execute such a complex initiative efficiently.

There are no details about the core team. How many people will be involved in this proposal? Who are the team members? it is extremely important that there are details about the team members so that we can evaluate their experience and qualification to conduct and implement this proposal.

The proposal describes a rationale for why blockchain technology is important for IBOs and DEFs, but there is a lot of generic and unrelated information to the proposal itself. I recommend more objectivity in describing the proposal and focus on the plan and how it will address the challenge.

The plan is not clear and is not structured. There is no roadmap, no details on the technical aspects of the proposal.

There is a budget breakdown, but the absence of a detailed plan makes it difficult to assess the feasibility of the budget.

Why will there be a cost with facilities? Today the vast majority of Catalyst projects operate remotely and there is no clarity as to the need for a physical location.

What is the purpose of allocating part of the resources in giveaways?

USD 7,500 is allocated for software licenses. What software will be used?

The budget mentions the development of an NFT auction model and there is no information on NFTs in the proposal plan.

My point is that without a plan that explains the proposal and its technical aspects in detail, it is impossible to judge the feasibility of the budget.

I recommend that the above points be addressed so that the proposal more clearly indicates its viability.

The proposal claims experience in development; however, the proposal has a huge scope, from development, blockchain integration, smart contract development, and most importantly, security audit. The proposal has not presented past accomplishments of the proposer or any of his team members.
The project is feasible. It is not clear how it addresses the challenge. this is a market place. How does it help developers focus on building successful apps?

This proposal lacks a lot of information to indicate its auditability.

There are no details on the number of people in the core team and their qualifications / experience. There is no roadmap. There are no KPIs. The lack of a structured and technical plan makes it difficult to understand the budget and this compromises auditability.

The metrics of success (3, 6 and 12 months) are not clear, what would be completed orders?

I recommend that the proposer use the Catalyst documentation as a reference to prepare the proposal.

Based on the alleged experience, roadmap and also in the budget breakdown that allocates $10k to the dApps developer, I believe that this project is feasible with the proposed budget. The team is also already engaged, there is a running website with good information and well designed. I don't see big challenges in implementing this, besides some legal risks involved that might be there but were not foreseen.

Sounds exciting idea and another Ethereum person to have on board and I prescribe integration and landing process to accommodate Cryptoceaser into the P2P environment and join the community in a more collaborative style. Details of his proposal are virtually non-existent:(
Draft proposal. There is not enough information about the proposer and there is no plan. There is no way to assess feasibility. I recommend including more details for appropriate feedback.

This is a great use of the immutability of the blockchain. An additional use could also be for anyone who wants to timestamp an idea they don't intend to patent, but put their marker down so that someone else can't later patent it as the "prior art" has already been registered. I could see the open source community embracing this.

The requirement for an integrated low-cost patent processing platform with an inbuild "Proof of Existence" feature, exists in the environment. The concept of the proposal presents a plan to fill this gap. It has a very practical use case for the Blockchain.

Although there is a compelling need for low-cost patent applications, this proposal lacks a deep connection to the Metadata Challenge. Posting the hash of a document into transaction metadata in order to validate time and content does fall within the scope of the Challenge, but building a full system to construct and submit patent applications exceeds the scope.

The idea is a good application of the blockchain technology. I would like to see something that completely proves that an idea is owned by someone independently of regular authorities, but I think this would take much more time. Since the idea here is to lower costs related to the creation of patents using the current system, I believe that this a very good approach. Although, I would like to have more information about the details of the process because it was not completely clear to me, based on this text only, about how this process would completely eliminate the need for a attorney, because there are some nuances to patenting that might not be easy to know about is you are no experienced (I've struggled with this in my day job a couple of times already).

Having patents validated on the blockchain in order to simplify costs and hassle for inventors is a great idea, that makes extensive use of the need of authenticity for metadata stamping on the blockchain.

The proposer claims experience in development and entrepreneurship. The proposal is complex and will require substantial product development and marketing effort to realize the full potential of the idea. Information regarding the plan and time plan for implementation is limited in the proposal. Verifiable credentials of the proposers' experience could not be found with the proposal.

The team has relevant marketing and content development skills, demonstrates knowledge of the patent system, and plans to add software skills, but the project tackles inherently legal issues. Having a qualified patent attorney (or at least consulting extensively with one) seems essential to  providing users with high assurance that their patent applications would be valid. Without that expert review, the project might only nominally succeed in accomplishing its planned four steps.

The proposers allege to have experience in marketing and content creation, which are not directly related to this development, but are good backgrounds to advertise it and bring more users. It would be needed to include someone with legal background (an attorney, for example) just to ensure that the process really accomplishes its goals. Also, the proposal mentions that 1 full stack developer will be hired, but there is also a need to have someone with blockchain developing experience. These people are not yet engaged with project, which is a down side. I believe that the proposal could be better prepared in this regard, about people that need to be involved. And also a budget breakdown to explain how the money would be spent in each area.

While the proposal offers a lot of information regarding the patent validation process, both on paper form as is now being done, but also on blockchain there are some missing aspects of the detailed plan, that are valuable in the assessing process: the budget is not broken-down and explained, expected launch date and very important, the detailed experience of the team, backed by some external links to prove them true.

The idea is unique and is clearly explained. However, the implementation plan along with cost estimate and project risk assessment needs improvement. The number of developers required and the preparation of software specifications and its audit requirement need to be assessed. The cost estimation is rough.

The proposal's four-step plan contains sufficiently detailed activities and products to effectively assess the progress of the work. The proposal would have been stronger if it had included a plan for a patent attorney to audit and critique the project's results to verify that it would indeed produce valid patent applications.

There is a description of the process in the platform, but the proposal lacks a roadmap of the development itself. Also some milestones and dates associated with them, and KPIs/key metrics to measure the success of this project. A budget breakdown would be good to understand how the budget would be spent in each area, it says that most of it would go to the developer, but anyway it would be good to see some numbers there. Also, the proposal needs some deadlines for deliverables.

The proposal plan describes a valid need for a large audience of people and from all the information that was written I can see a valuable proposition being constructed. However, the missing details that would define the auditability of the project - that are also verifiable in the self-assessment checklist - compels me to suggest a re-submission for a future fund, as the main idea behind the proposal is actually interesting.

This could be an interesting idea, however it seems to mainly be an idea for a piece of software for one specific political party in the Netherlands. Does project Catalyst want to fund this? How are you making it widely available? Given it is initially being developed for a party in the Netherlands, what language is its UX in?

It definitely is addressing the challenge effectively, I am just putting 3 stars because in the comment someone stated that it might be illegal, thus, it needs further review from IOHK whether it can be done or not. Yet, the proposal itself is a good one.

The problem the proposal addresses is a real one for developers, but these issues will most likely be addressed by IO internally at an appropriate time. The proposer does not make a convincing proposal commensurate with the funds requested, or outline and details as to how the project will be executed and adopted. For these reasons I do not believe the proposal would have a significant impact.

While in essence the proposal addresses aspects of the challenge, the proposal fails to acknowledge that very similar tools are being implemented under the direct guidance of IOG. I would suggest providing much more detail on how the proposed solutions differ from the ones currently being developed.

The proposal suggests creating a bridge between the programming language used by Cardano and other more common languages, which could be beneficial in the sense of attracting new developers who do not work with Haskell. In this way, the idea meets the challenge's objectives well, because in addition to attracting possible new programming professionals, it would encourage them to work in the community, since they would continue with the context (language) they are already comfortable with.

It is not clear if  the proposal will be within the challenge goal, because the information's needed are not clear exposed with minimal descriptions. At the same time the statement of how problem is to be solved (e.g. "…The idea is to have wrapper libraries of the type PyCardano, JsCardano, PhpCardano, …") is not deep specified and remain vague. I suggest to better introduce and explain HOW and WHAT, through use cases related to user's operations
It is hard to say if it will be successful as the proposer has not yet decided what languages to bind. It is not detailed how that choice would be made.

Insufficient information to properly judge both the team and the deliverables intended to be created by the proposal. In the future I would suggest including at least the information required when doing the self-assessment checklist, i.e. detailed budget, approximate public launch date, a clear definition of success and information about all the team, their background and links to their previous related works.

I believe that to execute this idea the necessary skill is unique, the experience in programming, which the author claimed to already have, citing the language he has previously developed. Now, to implement the project with the Catalyst system, it would probably be necessary a more specific planning, for example, how would this new adapted language reach the programmers? I believe that for more bureaucratic issues it would be necessary for someone else to be hired, which is not mentioned in the text, perhaps the author has focused a lot on the technical part and overlooked this detail.

The proposer team states that it has the necessary experience in developing technology (not a lot of languages), but I don't discover team member with experience in blockchain. The given metrics measure what the proposer wants to do, but the success of his actions is not defined. As mentioned above, the description of the solution is not well explained (e.g. how the funds will be spent, how the developers manage their benefits …), so the progress of this proposal is not simple to assess
The proposal should specifically state which languages are going to be bound and a plan for how/when that will be done.

In theory progress on technical development would be straightforward to audit, however the proposal doesn't include any metrics to measure success by, an estimated project roadmap and timeframe nor a clear description of deliverable.
Draft proposal. There is no data or information that would allow us to audit this proposal. I recommend that a new proposal be developed based on the Catalyst documentation.

Regarding the applicability of the project, we are basically not provided with any information, only that the author intends to "connect" Haskell as initially 3 other languages. However, as it is a mostly technical action, I cannot imagine how it could be more detailed. Perhaps include a schedule of dates in relation to the progress of the project, for example: in X months, 50% of the schedule would be complete. Another question is regarding the financial amount. It is not said whether all the money would be used to pay for the service of creating the schedule or other things as well, and it is a very high amount.

Roadmap and milestones (incl. time horizon) are not described. The budget provided is very general and therefore I cannot say whether it is appropriate or not. There aren't more details how the budget is going to be spent, also I'm trying to discover attachment to deep dive the solution. Furthermore there aren't information about the connection with blockchain application or benefit for Cardano community...

The team describes experience in IT and finance audits, but it is not clear whether these experiences include smart contract audits and what the team's expertise with Plutus is. As one of the goals is to create a utility token it is important to understand the team's experience and aptitude in developing a tokenomics model, as the feasibility of the proposal will depend on the utility of the token.

It is important to say that costs with audit of DeFi protocols are extremely high due to the need for staff with great technical knowledge, so that the DAO has people qualified to carry out the audits. The absence of a robust tokenomics model hinders the project's feasiblity. The dependence of revenue on a possibility of interest (in protocols that do not yet exist at Cardano) of a token that does not yet have a robust model of tokenomics brings a lot of uncertainty about the viability and sustainability of the project.

There are details on the budget allocation.

Some risks are not being taken into account, such as:
1- The dependence on protocols to generate yield (protocols and dapps that do not yet exist at Cardano)
2- There is no guarantee that the SCAT token will be listed in dapps as an asset to generate yield.
3- Auditors will receive competitive rewards for auditing smart contracts, but this is based on a tokenomics model that is not yet well structured and may not be enough.
4 - The audit of projects by DAO does not remove the risks of fraud and collusion. There is no mention of a reputation model for auditors that can mitigate this problem.
proposalTitle: Smart Contract Audit Token SCAT DAO

assessmentNote: The experience of the proposer is limited to working in the field of river transport. Are there any technical people in the team that have experience around blockchain. This would certainly help. There is a roadmap but it is kind of vague. The same goes for the budget it would be nice to be a little more accurate. It feels like the proposal tries to achieve a lot but has not yet figured out a clear path.

This proposal takes aim at reducing the cost of trust in usage billing in the utility sector. In developed nations this is a basic part of life and improvements here would impact a large amount of users and it intuitively makes sense. What isn't clear is just how large the cost of trust in current systems is, and how blockchain will address it, and how many users are within the targeted market. Would like to see an estimate on how much transactional friction exists, and what the biggest struggle for current utility billing is. Late payments, complex fee structures, overdrafts, inaccurate measurements, misaddressed bills all come to mind.

This proposal absolutely addresses the challenge of scaling up the DeFi ecosystem. Also, this is a great example of "real finance" or "RealFi" as described by the Cardano team. We are not looking for yield farming or how to make a quick 10x, but actual real world decentralized financial solutions. Paying monthly bills is a chore everyone can relate to and those $3-$5 service fees add up over time. The proposal is well crafted with copious details and full cost breakdown, however I do believe you might be a little optimistic and will explain what I mean in the next section.

The problem and solution are reasonable, the proposal can be related to DeFi, but the plan and goals established don't make clear the impact of the proposal on the challenge, in fact everything that has been described indicates that the proposal will deliver a proof of concept in the first 6 months and this doesn't demonstrate a significant impact on the metrics established in the challenge brief.

The experience and plan presented is complete with funding details. However, more development around the problem that the AP/AR office faces would bring clarity to the plan and reduce risk of applying a great solution to the wrong problem. The proposal identifies this complexity risk, but doesn't identify how it will be reduced.

40 years of experience as a developer, IT project, and programmer manager tells me you have seen software grow and evolve since it infancy. The proposal mentions the complexity of the problems you are attempting to solve. I think you do a great job of recognizing the problem and the potential for mass adoption with stating "literally attract billions of Defi users." My concern is with this next statement. "Initially I expect a lot of solution help and developer support from the Cardano development community with the SME skills needed to delve deep into how this solution could work." This seems like a big if so what if you receive funding but that support is not available? I think it would be wise to continue making contacts in the blockchain development community so that you will be ready to go once funding is secured. Also, on that note I would like to see more information about the rest of your team.

The statement "I cant pretend to understand the full details of this as yet and there are no doubt many options that can be explored." demonstrates that the proposal still needs to be more refined.

Creating DeFi dapp involves complexity in the development of smart contracts, introducing an element of integrating DeFi with CeFi increases the complexity of the project.

The dependence on an oracle creates additional complexity, as currently there is no reliable oracle model on Cardano's blockchain and options would have to be studied / developed which would decrease the feasibility of the proposal in the next 6 months.

The budget for the proposal was set at $ 323,290 and half the amount ($ 161,645) was requested as a fund for Catalyst. The remaining half will need alternative methods of funding, an ICO can be an alternative method. I believe that the budget is not reasonable, as there are fundamental aspects about the plan that are still unclear and this creates doubts about the definition of the budget. The fact that the requested amount fund only half of the development compromises the auditability the proposal.

Compliance and regulation risks were not considered and this is a key aspect to assess the feasibility of the proposal. Integrating DeFi with government-related systems is a major challenge and projects could take years to establish a framework. IOG's own partnership with the government of Ethiopia demonstrated the great difficulty in inserting solutions created in public blockchains to the government. When observing the development of blockchain-related technologies by governments out there, the delay of governments in the development of CBDCs is notable and the bureaucracy involved in the process makes integration difficult. In addition, there is a great preference for governments to use private blockchains. These risks need to be taken into account as they bring risks to the proposal's success and there is still no plan that demonstrates how this type of risks will be faced.

The use of blockchain for bill payment brings additional risks to users' privacy, and there is still no private computing solution available at Cardano. The lack of privacy in these transactions can bring risks to users of this model, because when making payments the user exposes his balance.

Receiving payments in ADA implies that the recipient will have to deal with volatility. There is still no decentralized option for converting ADA, as until July (until Alonzo HFC) there will be no DEXs and stable coins on Cardano, which creates friction in this model. This could be circumvented by using someone to take custody (centralized exchanges) but it would go against the purpose of DeFi and in the opposite direction to the basic concepts of DeFi, which deal with removing intermediaries, removing trust and bringing more costs.

Detailed budget provided, but there is not a detailed execution plan. It opwuld be good to have some evidence of the experience of the proposer (LinkedIn Profile?), especially given the size of the funding request.

A very detailed plan is provided which provides confidence that the project will be successfully implemented. The first month is focused on identifying partners and developers, which creates a significant risk for the project. If a least one customer and one technical partner had been included as part of the proposal development, the probability of success would be significantly higher.

The proposer provides a clear and well articulated plan for how to develop and implement this project. The proposal present a timeline with goals and metrics up to 6 months. The cost breakdown is also accountant able for the 6 months of potential development. I understand the 6 month timeline comes from the mission of scaling up DeFi in that window, but I would like to know more about what happens once/if mass adoption for Adabillr is live. I would have liked to see more details about where the other $161,645 is expected to come from since you are only requesting half of the budgeted amount. I believe this idea/project has the potential to be very profitable so please consider a way you could share profit back into the Catalyst fund. Making the ICO a governance token is clever and increases accountability for the system you are attempting to build.

The budget for the proposal was set at $ 323,290 and half the amount ($ 161,645) was requested as a fund for Catalyst. The remaining half will need alternative methods of funding, an ICO can be an alternative method. I believe that the budget is not reasonable, as there are fundamental aspects about the plan that are still unclear and this creates doubts about the definition of the budget. The fact that the requested amount fund only half of the development compromises the auditability the proposal.

Considering that the requested budget corresponds to more than 50% of the amount available in the budget for this challenge, it is crucial that there are details to indicate whether these values make sense. Although there are details about the allocation of resources (mostly staff costs) the lack of a technical development plan makes it difficult to assess the budget and allow auditability.

Positions like Crypto Soln Architect, UX designer, Team Lead, Business Lead, testers have been described as part of the development of dapp, but there are no details on the development of the PoC dapp itself, which compromises auditability of the budget in relation to the staff costs.

There are no KPIs. The roadmap establishes some goals, but these are vague and not very objective, which hinders the ability to auditability.

In general, the proposal describes a valid problem, but one that requires a complex solution, due to technical factors and difficulty in integration with centralized government systems, which increases technical complexity and inserts compliance and regulatory elements.

The proposal needs further refinement to indicate feasibility and auditability.

The proposal provides very specific information regarding the allocation of funds over a six month plan. The budget ($323,290) is higher than the requested funds ($161,645). The proposal indirectly suggests that an ICO will be used to cover this gap; however, that seems to be a risky assumption in such a short period of time. Nevertheless, given the extensive details provided, the proposer has clearly defined the objectives and measures of success.

Millions of websites use WooCommerce. The payment plugin has the potential of increased adoption. Market creators always look for more ways to make money. If I used WooCommerce (and regulations are more clearly in my jurisdiction), I'd use something like this, too.

In integrating Ada payments with a major e-commerce plugin, this proposal meets the challenge requirement. Being able to pay for online shopping with Ada would greatly increase Cardano adoption and provide utility for current users. The proposer mentions using an API  to simplify implementation which is great, but I'm concerned that getting users to register for their own API key would cause a lot of friction.

The proposal presents a good solution to offer an ADA payment gateway for small/emerging businesses, which are often overlooked in the early stage of any global-level product. The claimed 5 million users of WooCommerce is a significant number of people who may be introduced to the Cardano world and this means a secondary benefit of spreading the word further. e-commerce plug-ins, as I understand, are not that complex to complete and the team's use of the API provided by Blockfrost.io, a Cardano-focussed provider, lends this solution a level of credibility.

The proposal identifies the challenge as building a plugin to the Woo Commerce suite that enables payments using ADA tokens.

I believe that the proposal effectively addresses that challenge by using an already existing API layer which is something that I feel makes this project much more feasible.
The proposer appears to have the necessary experience to implement successfully. The plan, while not fully articulated is not overly complex and the budget seems to reflect this aspect.

The proposer documented experience with the Ethereum blockchain via website and also identifies as a stakepool operator. Accepting payments should be trivial through blockfrost.io.

It appears the proposer knows how to leverage existing solutions well; but this is also a risk as the proposers rely on the continued service of a third party.

The proposal outlines the necessary steps to take.

The proposer has plenty of relevant experience to implement this idea. The plan presented has a very clear goal and given the budget and proposer's experience, it seems very likely that they will be successful in accomplishing their goal.

The information on the main website provides enough background to give a high degree of confidence that this product can be developed. The proposal however can be further improved if each step of the development pathway and milestones is provided, including a breakdown of resources and a per/hour listing. It does not seem insurmountable given e-commerce plug-ins are now more easily produced particularly for Wordpress, but for voters unfamiliar to what's required to achieve the solution, this information would be beneficial. It may also be prudent for the proposal to pre-identify which blockfrost plan it is aiming for to set expectations on how well or how slow the uptake of the payment gateway would be. Quantifying the measures of success of the solution would also be of benefit.

The idea to use the blackfrost existing technology is a good idea. Best to not re-invent things if its not necessary. I believe it will be successful given the narrow scope of the project and what it is looking to achieve.

The proposer/developer lists plenty of relevant experience and the proposal is written very succinctly.  I think that both of these cause me to look favorably on this project.

The project also seems to be far simpler than some of the "let's re-shape the universe! (for $10K)" type projects.  Which also makes it much more likely to be successful.

I would like to see some marketing, but I feel that's best done in a separate proposal (maybe in Fund7?) so I'm not deducting a star for not including it.

The proposer clearly sets forth a set of deliverables - an open source plugin for WooCommerce, documentation and a support forum. It would be useful to give a timeframe on how long each of these will take or when it is expected that they will be done.

There is enough here to provide confidence that the project can meet success and be traceable. But there are other details it can add in order to provide full confidence. Feasibility of Wordpress plug-in is not in question but itemising each step, however 'regular' or 'easy' it is for the proposer, could only give voters confidence that the fund requested is going to be well-spent. The challenge also has the benefit of introducing Cardano/ADA to the claimed 5 million users of WooCommerce and utilising blockfrost, a familiar Cardano main-stay is an integral part of this solution and provides a better confidence that the challenge can be addressed.

It would be nice to see some metrics on how big woocommerce is for people who are not familiar with it. How many users or $/day go through it. This would enable decisions on how useful this integration would be for the Cardano ecosystem.

What I would like to see is more details on how the funds will be used. The amount chosen seems to be a high amount given its using blackfrost. How many developers, how many hours etc would be nice. Also details on the roadmap would be appreciated. Would there be a simplified initial version for proof of concept?

I feel that it should be quite easy to monitor the progress and success of this project.

Did the Plugin get built? - Can be monitored on GitHub
Does it work? - Can be monitored on GitHub and also via the online support forum that the proposer will build.
Does it have impact? - Can be monitored by looking at how many Woo Commerce suite users (stores) install the plugin.
Does it increase the number of transactions on the Cardano Network? - Can be monitored by looking at the volume and number of sales processed via this plugin.

The proposal meets the objectives of the challenge very well, because it intends to create a very comprehensive wallet, it can be said. The intention is to build an application that dialogs with the diversity of the public, whether through languages, education level, the fact that on the continent it is common for more than one person to use the same cell phone, etc. All these factors would be taken into account , I found a project that seeks to mold itself to the shape of its audience, which is very positive.

The proposal clearly states what is the goal (biased results of trained AI) and how to achieve it (blockchain-decentralised, trusted solution).
The best KPIs are tangible, and the team will send several robots to the Cardano community to evaluate the results. That will provide very clear evaluation results first-hand from the interested members. Can not wait to see posts about the performance.
It would be nice to have more info on the global impact estimates of this work, in example number of users and how these can be measured/monitored. More tangible results after the delivery.

A very innovative idea to empower african citizen developers. This proposal will be incredibly effective if successfully implemented and have transformative potential by combining the potential enable new people to produce and integrate applications, giving the African continent business opportunities that even the EPAs can't interfere with and gravely forward the cardano project.

No-Code development has a very low entry barrier and high return for most of the software development requirements. Training people in the target region in no-code development in blockchain will provide a substantial boost to the availability of developers from Africa thereby fueling the adoption of Cardano.

The proposal for no-code could be applied to other regions as well, but it fits well in to the Africa challenge. If successful it could seed widespread interest in Cardano, and facilitate the development of localized smart contract products which would go on to increase adoption.

An existing application is deployed and taught to new users in cooperation with WADA, which makes this a very attainable project. The creators of the product are very competent considering they have already created a valid product that is able to run on blockchain. The plan is actionable. It is highly likely that this challenge will be implemented successfully.
