Q-modeler is an existing platform with a track record in blockchain. The proposers are experienced in working in developing countries. The partnership with WADA should catalyze the potential of the proposal. I believe the project is feasible and has potential to add much value.  One potential issue with the timeframe is the  uncertainty of the release of smart contracts on the mainnet.

The progress is quantifiable. The proposal aims to train 1000 persons in writhing smart contracts using Q Modeler in 12 months. with a rate of 20 $ per person to teach Smart contracts. This is measurable and auditable.

The proposal hits head on with a trust issue that every person that has had a time tracked job faces. Both parties face a level of mistrust that is currently mitigated by 'time cards' and 'pay stubs' which for many employers can take days, and the administration cost for these is significant. For my small business pay roll processing with ADP costs $100's of dollars a month, and isn't 100% trusted. This would simplify that process and build trusting using escrow - something that is currently too expensive on the admin side to pull off. I challenge the team to do shift by shift payouts. if proposal reduces payroll costs enough there's no reason to batch payments into a week or more.

If users are going to be making a career on blockchain jobs then it makes sense to incorporate how they record time tracking as well on the blockchain. This app could help all developers in the ecosystem looking to earn wages. I will be following this idea as it goes forward.

The proposal plans to create a system to handle the time tracking/billing system for workers and organizations using the Cardano blockchain.
The main idea is to simplify this administration process introducing trust and transparency with the help of the blockchain and other related Cardano technologies (like DID). The mechanics of the system will include an escrow smart contract to handle automatic payments.
With all this elements the proposal clearly addresses the challenge because could create adoption by companies and organizations and consequently by workers that will be asked by the employers to use the system, thus bringing new users closer to the Cardano Ecosystem. Furthermore every single active use of the Dapp will create transactions to track the progress and to make payments. The presence of internal token it also reinforces the belief that this dapp can really generate a lot of traffic in various ways.

The proposed application might be a good fit and there are no similar blockchain-based application that I know of. I deduct one star because the  advantages of blockchain for stated use-case and the advantages to the end-user are still a little doubtful.

The proposal implements a popular use case and might help in the adoption of Cardano in a large environment. The proposal aims to build a working prototype in three months and a user trial with a hosting company. There are many technical challenges however the experimentation is worth the Cost involved.

Time tracking is a great Dapp use case, especially on an inexpensive block chain.  successful implementation could bring large scale adoption.  Its not entirely clear from the proposal funds will be stored and transacted in ADA itself but the assumption is that the project will participate in the ADA DeFi ecosystem.

The proposal appears to meet the challenge criteria and offers a valid use case scenario. Difficult to gauge the level of interest from the community at this stage although it may be a niche product that will grow engagement over time.

This proposal is a great and complex implementation that improve many software module of the cardano foundation (like ATALA PRISM, cardano blockchain, cardano smart-contracts, etc…). The proposal clearly articulates how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and for the stakeholders (in deep detail for users, companies,.. ). However the objective of the proposal is based on real idea that Is just implemented, so I think it's a god starting point.

This proposal meet fund 5 DApps and integration challenge. This solution will use the different layer built on Cardano such as identity on Atlas, Cardano blockchain, and payment.  I would recommend looking into Ada pay as a possible integration for payment.

Team seem to have the experience to deliver. Would be nice to know more about how they intend to drive takeup. Also how are they going to manage the release of funds? Is this purely just the employer statinghte work is done. What if there is a dispute about quality? Have you thought about reputation tracking metrics (workers and employers). These could include speed and quality from the employees, promptness of release of payment and evaluation by employees of employers? Is this going to be a market place, or just software employers can use to hire contractors/employees?

The team here looks experienced in being able to accomplish the task. The presentation is a good resource in explaining what they are trying to accomplish. The only uncertainty I have at the moment is the timeframe they are looking at. I think key parts like atala prism will not be available for consumer use in the near future.

The proposer brings clear evidences of skills and experience (the Dapp is already published in Google Play Store and iOS store and works in a centralized way). However if would be really useful to add some technical details about the implementation (I found only a single reference to the Marlowe Framework in the slides), a detailed descriptions of the tokenomics and what we should expect as a final product (it will be a website or a mobile app? How it will interact with wallets and the blockchain?).
It would also a nice add to have a detailed costs breakdown: it is ok to indicate that the fund requested will cove the full time wok of one person for 3 months but it would be great to add how many times/funds are intended for each development stage.
Furthermore, the project is also based on the use of Atala which is not yet ready and available for the public. It would be very useful to present alternative strategies in case this technology continues to be out of use in the coming months.

The Team has shared their linkedin profiles, and are involved in realized non-blockchain integrated timekeeping projects and functional languages. Developers are based in Cardano-friendly Netherlands so I believe acquiring inital participants will be feasible. More refinement is clearly needed, but I believe the team can succeed in the initial prototype stages and seek more funding and expertise as they go along.  One question I have it the tax implications and how this may affect adoption by employers.

The team appears to have the skillset required to make the proposal likely of successful implementation. The query for me is the author appears to suggest that further refinement and verification is required from potential end users and there is no guarantee that the resources required will result in success. Perhaps a smaller budget with a focus on this research of this nature would be more appropriate at this stage.

The fact that the team already has a working product on the market, ProjectHours, instills confidence that the adaptation to Cardano can be done. The project is for an exploration phase that if then turned into an actual product plan could pay dividends to the Cardano community. I would have liked to see a broken down budget that more clearly justifies the amount, but given it's a relatively small sum, and an explanation is given, it should suffice for now.

The proposal team is completed skilled and have a good trade off  between business and technical knowledge, so in my opinion will able to make surely a good pilot . In relation to the possible success of the initiative, I think that tracking hours and more in general job orders functionalities are useful, so there are a lot of possibilities for the adoption by the companies. Further I think it's important to improve details about the process related to the issue related to the market or capital risk.

A generic roadmap for the whole project is presented, but it would be great to add a specific roadmap with milestones for the first stage (the one for which funds are requested). KPI are completely missing: it would be useful to add some hard numbers/goals to better evaluate the success of the project. For example: what are the technologies selected in the prototype? What are the features of the "basic smart contracts"? With the working prototype how many user will be involved for testing? How many transactions could we expect will be generated from the prototype?
All these kind of elements would be a nice add to the proposal and a good guide to evaluate its success.

The roadmap is stated and the stated milestones make sense. The time-frame of the months for a prototype is also reasonable. The requested funds are for validation and verification of the proposal and the creation of a prototype. What I miss is the cost-basis for the requested funds. Is there a hourly rate that was used to calculate the requested funds and could also potentially used for auditing?

Creating the application and configuration of the existing app to run over Cardano is explained in detail in the project. There are details that need to be gathered to arrive at the final design in this evolving proposal. However, the project will be monitorable and auditable.

This fund is for the first 3-month stage of the project which expects to produce a working prototype. Pilot projects will be part of future funding rounds.  The technical aspect of the project is not very detailed so it will be difficult to audit the progress.  Clearly some of these funds need to be spent gaining expertise in the appropriate blockchain integration.  in this sense 20k seems like a lot to produce a prototype. But if they are successful in producing it, we can be sure that they have learned a lot a long the way, and will be able to execute effectively the goals of future funding rounds.

Strong proposal supported by good information that does leave a window of questions still to be answered. An assessment of successful implementation is difficult without further understanding of the results from validation the author describes. I would have liked to have seen this aspect further developed or a slightly changed proposal where this was the focus of the funding requested. This would entail a research based proposal which clearly articulates the validation metrics being sought in order to promote the end product being proposed.

The progress on the proposed prototype app could be easily followed by the community and the deliverables verified. The included high level road map makes sense, and the time estimated for achieving an MVP seems reasonable. I would have liked to see an estimated start date for the project.

The proposer provides a step-by-step plan for the implementation with clear milestones and a defined time horizon. The only thing I miss in this area is that the proposer has not mentioned possible difficulties and how to deal with them.. The proposal offers a realistic timetable to complete the work. The proposer has considered well challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation for invoicing companies, so I think that they require to do a business plan

It is not entirely clear what the proposal is delivering. 30% of the funding is to set up a charity. What is that charity doing? The main project is to collect and publish data on African stake pool operators.

The decentralisation of stakepools and supporting SPOs is an important goal, however this proposal lacks concrete recommendations on how the cooperations are going to work and on what aspects the SPO evaluation system should be focused. I feel like the connection to the africa challenge is a bit loose.

The proposal is based on creating SPO more compatible with the different communities and cultures present in Africa, respecting the diversity of each one. Therefore, it seems to me a very relevant and promising idea, since SPO are essential for Cardano's activities to take place and most of them are concentrated, as the text itself says, in the USA and Europe. Through their creation in Africa, both the cotinent and the The Catalyst project would benefit.

It is clear that the proposers have some experience with staking and stake pool operating. The plan is not very concrete and somewhat open ended, which makes it likely that something will be implemented, however the success criteria are very loose and milestones don't exist, so a lot needs to be formulated more concrete to ensure that what is implemented has high value.

The main focus of the proposal, the "Prototype of system to collect and describe diversity information of stake pool operators" is not described in detail, thus it would be hard to forecast its implementation.

In the proposal, the author claims to be a product manager at FAANG. It would be beneficial to include a website for that company, because different reviewers, like me, may not recognize it. In addition, we can find out, through an included website, who the other members of the team are: the ABC Stake Pool, which is made up of professionals with over 20 years of experience with cryptocurrencies. And on top of that they have a group on Telegram, in case anyone wants to ask questions. That is, they support the public very well, have a lot of experience and seem to be accessible and prepared to carry out the project.

The approach of the proposal to the problem is not entirely clear.  There is research and organization involved, and some proposed tools to help delegators find pools. I have some unadressed concerns. 1)Creating many African SPOs will not be sustainable without large delegations. 2) what are the standards for network/hardware quality? will pools run by Africans on global virtual server platforms be considered African, and would they really enhance the decentralization of Cardano? to me the goals of the proposal should happen organically over time and are difficult to bootstrap.  I think a small proposal including research and communication with African organizations, with a much smaller funding request, would present a more feasible initial step in future funding rounds.
This proposal doesn't include any details on team, team skills, or team relevant experience. Please describe the team that will implement this proposal.

I am providing a rating of a 2 to the project due to proposed creation of a charity.  Creating a charity is a nuanced and technical legal undertaking, regardless of country of origin or size of the proposed charity. None of the experience listed in the relevant experience section indicates anyone currently associated with the proposal has legal expertise, experience creating a charity, or experience running a charity; nor does the proposal indicate how the project would obtain this advice.  I may not have the same technical background as many in the Cardano community, but I do have legal training in the United States, and have had experience helping draft the articles of incorporation for a charity, obtaining a 501(c)(3) tax exemption from the IRS, and participating on the board of a charity for multiple years.  There are significant legal issues associated with charities that can sink a charity if they are not properly navigated.  Simply requesting $3,000 for the charity without further explanation of how those funds will be used or how the charity will be organized and run does not provide sufficient information to agree that the charity is a feasible component of the project. I agree the other aspects of the project are feasible; but because the charity is a significant part of the project budget, I cannot agree the project overall is feasible.

"Increase African and Societal level decentralization through adoption by staking information services (has dependencies)" - this is a good metric, which can be used for multiple ways, yet not stated, such as increased number of stake pool operators or number of Cardano staked

The proposal definitely tackles an interesting subject, though it doesn't accomplish enough clarity to be able to be clearly assessed. I would suggest a re-writing for a future fund, if not backed in this one, as the idea in the problem statement is worthy of being remedied.

Much information is provided on how the plan would materialize. The authors explain by topic how they would solve the problem in question, that is, what steps they must follow in order to achieve their goals. These are also explained, and the financial amount requested is divided into 3 parts, each with its purpose. In addition, they outline plans for future work, which is very positive, as it shows the intention to continue the project. The only thing that could be added is a time schedule, that is, how many months each step would take place, possible delivery dates for results, etc., in order to facilitate the monitoring of the project. But other than that, everything is well cleared up.

The funds are directed to a 3 tasks.  3k is allocated to setting up a charity, but no details as to the jurisdiction or nature of this charity are given. 6k for the prototype of "system to collect and describe diversity information of stake pool operators" seems excessive without a more detailed description of the proposed product.  The remaining 1K is dedicated to hosting and operation of the product. I don't see a clear path from this proposal to the "What would success look like?" goals.
The proposal is unique and it is abstract to measure diversity in SPO distribution. It will be difficult to monitor and measure the progress of the project.

I do not believe the information provided provides sufficient information to audit the progress and success of the proposal.  As mentioned earlier, the what does success look like section fails to contain concrete metrics like SMART criteria that can be used to measure outcomes within a specific timeframe.  I think the proposal is very close, and I think it would be beneficial to speak with some of the identified stakeholders now to try and identify some more specific criteria to measure what success would look like.  I also think the lack of information on the charity (other than the inclusion of $3,000 in the budget) makes it impossible to evaluate whether the charity will be a success. It's 30% of the budget, but it's only mentioned once in the entire proposal. What does the charity do? When will it be established? Where will it be established? Who is the charity serving? What does success look like for the charity? There is just not enough information provided to be able to reasonably audit the progress and success of the charity or the other proposal elements.

Challenges is general and not a problem statement. It is a hype related statement.

However goals are being mentioned point by point.

Few of the biggest challenges in NFT marketplace are:

1) Searching ability
2) Fraud and spam content
3) Expensive fees

The only challenge mentioned by the project goals is to address the expensive fees.

Proposer should tackle the other two issue alongside with the other challenges counter with the goal mentioned.

A NFT marketplace at this point in time is in alignment with the overall goal of driving adoption. However, it appears that many of the criticisms of other marketplaces would apply to this project as well (centralization / high bar of entry).

Every blockchain is striving to follow the tradition by having NFT marketplace themselves. However there are few marketplace which support multiple payment type.

Proposal is addressing fraud, community over product, open to all and user driven.

User drive been addressed in detail by having council, voting (governance) and how it can accessed to all.

Fraud prevention and detection had not been spelled thoroughly in the proposal. Yes, it is tough to ensure the platform free from fraud. Proposa didn't specific what technology or methodology planned to overcome this challenge.

Unfortunately, the proposal reads more of a list of lengthy promises than a plan. While the team has related experience, it is unclear if they can execute on this proposal. Secrecy is often used as a vanguard for not having a clear vision. How will you handle discoverability? Why has nobody solved it and what will you do about it? How does your solution address its own biases in yielding results to your users?

Reasonably detailed plan, however governance seems to be a key point and you are not detailing how you will deal with it. It would be nice to have some evidence of the teams capability (LinkedIn profiles perhaps?) Linked Github repo has no code.

I personally like the idea of creating a real-time traceable supply chain DApp for all insect related products. It is great! The idea is massive and its implications.

However, while the idea is great, the proposal has some weaknesses. 

In effect the idea is great, but a Catalyst proposal is a step up from an idea. The proposal is being assessed here. 

The proposer does identify a very big global market (and an initial one in Southeast Asia) that the DApp would focus on. I am wondering whether centralized Apps or traceability services exist for this market that this proposed DApp can be compared to? If yes, it would have been good to be able to compare their specific weaknesses and how the proposed DApp would address those issues and provide users with additional value. 

If these centralized Apps or services do not exist yet, is there a reason why they are not available? 

Building a DApp (or application) is just one part of providing any true product traceability - it seems to require integration with a comprehensive traceability system with procedures and guidelines. 

It is unclear to me whether this is a DApp that is part of a wider proposed system. Or is it a DApp that will also be able to integrate with existing traceability platforms. If a new traceability system is being proposed - I fail to see the details of that system in the proposal. 

A real-time traceable supply chain DApp would be one component- however the proposal would have benefited from fleshing out other aspects - such as strengths, limitations, and risks of the new traceability system or others that it will integrate with. The ultimate success of a decentralized insect related traceability system may not depend only on the DApp itself. 

I would have liked to see other components of the bigger jigsaw addressed as well - in order to assess its full impact and whether it will be able to add value to the Cardano ecosystem. 

The issue is that if the proposed traceability system is not up to par as a whole, the DApp might not add value to the Cardano ecosystem. How will compliance be ensured? How will consumers be able to rely on the soundness of information that is accessible via the DApp? How will identity be managed? WIll Atala Prism ( decentralized identity solution built on the Cardano blockchain) be used? Etc...

The proposer specifies that a full pitch deck and plan outline are available on request. The proposal would have benefited from their inclusion - as without them it is difficult to assess the impact of a DApp alone on such a sector. The DApp is a tool - but the full solution of the proposed traceability system (or integration with other systems) - is key to measure the potential benefits to the Cardano ecosystem. 

The platform may be able to connect consumers, brands, and farmers in real time, removing the need for trust in institutions by transparent verification of the entire process - but the issue of trust among the participants remains. Maybe institutions do not need to be trusted, but how is the new DApp verifying that the information on the blockchain is correct? How are key elements verified (quality, volumes, sourcing, deliveries, etc..)?
proposalTitle: Farm to Fork Supply Chain - Insects

assessmentNote: Currently no plan. this is a request for developers to join the proposer and come up with one. Thus as it currently stands it is unlikely to succeed. Please find collaborators and produce a detailed plan.
proposalTitle: Farm to Fork Supply Chain - Insects

assessmentNote: At this stage it is difficult to rate the proposal higher as it is lack key ingredients for successful implementation; namely developers to produce the Dapp. I also note the author is engaged in finding a team which will greatly improve this application and the plan that needs to be filed with that. Any further updates would be appreciated by the community I feel and improve likelihood of project going forward.
proposalTitle: Farm to Fork Supply Chain - Insects

assessmentNote:
This proposal in my view is heavier on the idea and general concept side, but weaker on the specific implementation side. It does provide a very general roadmap with milestones and a time horizon for achievement. However, there is not enough information about the proposed DApp and its specific functionalities that would result in a successful (!) traceability system. The design and characteristics of the DApp are key to its success and to being able to assess how effectively it addresses the challenge, as well as its linkage to a good traceability system. 

Success in this challenge is not just building a novel application of top of Cardano, but the application also has to be viable in order to attract users. 

The proposal lacks sufficient Metrics/KPIs that would help define the success of the proposal. To me the proposal would need to drill down on metrics and KPIs more, as building a DApp is not sufficient for the proposed system - it is part of a larger farm-to-fork traceability endeavor that is being proposed. More Metrics/KPIs are needed to assess success and feasibility.
proposalTitle: Farm to Fork Supply Chain - Insects

assessmentNote: Here we see something that, unfortunately, happens quite a lot during the launch of proposals. We have a very extensive and interesting explanation of why this idea is relevant, but few lines intended to explain how things would happen in practice. We know that the intention of this idea is to create an App that enhances the trade of insects, makes the contact between producers, consumers, distributors and etc. more direct and simple. But how, exactly? I think it would be good to explain in more detail how the App was going to be built, by which parts. We are informed of the first steps, up to 5 months of action, of what would happen. However, in a very superficial way ... I felt it speaks of a more detailed, more complete action plan, that would guide the action beyond the first 5 months. In addition, the money requested is not quoted, it is not explained how it would be used, in which parts it would be applied and so on. Unfortunately, much detail is lacking in relation to the practical application of the project.
proposalTitle: Farm to Fork Supply Chain - Insects

assessmentNote: As mentioned above, this project covers only one half of it, the half about app development is not detailed as the proposer lack the knowledge to provide it. Therefor I cannot assess the proposal correctly and I would highly suggest that it be re-submitted for the next fund. And maybe in the meantime he can get in touch with a developer who could at least help him in formulating a clearer plan.
proposalTitle: Farm to Fork Supply Chain - Insects

assessmentNote: The proposal aims to integrate Mobile Money with Defi for enabling lending and other Defi activity in Africa. This proposal can open a large population with smartphones to reap the benefits of DeFi. There is a scope for utilizing DeFi in the underdeveloped sector enabling microfinancing and other related activity. It is also better to have more than one project in this space to increase the reliability of delivery.

My stance is neutral, because the general idea of implementing defy in Africa on an ACTIVE network platform is adressing this challenge, but I disagree because after reading through the proposal, a lot is written about general viewpoints on situation in Africa, but no factual remarks about how would this project help mitigate these to make a stance for the proposal. The add.xyz web page is not functional. I was not able to address the Developer Team because the hyperlinks on the webpage are non existant, I could not open 'About US', and any other link on the page.

The proof of concept seams reasonable but I cannot really judge if it is legit and it is only a UI. The Budget does not add up. The Team asks for 85k and wants to buy 35k x2, 20k x2, 15k and 10k from it..
The Plan to hire experienced Plutus Devs seams to be doomed since those do not really exist in large numbers.

The proposer has founded ADD.xyz only in 2019 and limited experience in large software development projects. The proposal will largely depend on fortmatic for security and freshly hired developers for relalissing the project.

I cannot aggree with this statement because there were many inconsistancies with the statements in the proposal. Stating that add.xyz in August 2020 has secured an integration and operating partnerships with major banking providers in Kenya and Nigeria though there are no proof of this to find in the proposal nor on the add webpage. Further stating that Research of Q3 2020 for defi lending into Africa via mobíle Credits is complete yet no links or proofs of this research is provided. After reading all of the proposal I cannot make a picture how would this team make this happen so I must disagree, there are no concrete concepts provided in this proposal, only reading about general situation in africa and how defi would be accepted in the countries mentioned.

The proposal gives a lot of Information but do not feel empowered to answer how likely it is to succeed with the plan. It depends a lot on hiring good devs but those will be hard to get. 
The effectiveness to the challenge is pretty clear and it is obvious that the proposers know the system they want to innovate with this proposal.
The proposal needs a technical roadmap and a feasibility study prepared by people with experience in blockchain development and some Cardano development experience.

The budget is broken down in 4 parts. 3 parts are costs for developers and one part is the cost for marketing. What tasks will be done by them ist not really provided, at least not in a way that would allow to audit the progress. No KPIs or criteria of success is provided. There is a lot of general information regarding the proposal and the concepts that are used but very limited information that can be used to audit and progress the success of the proposal. There is potential for it. Numbers are provided regarding the people that use Mobile Money and a certain percentage of the might use the Money Bridge. This sounds like a pretty good KPI.

As some other Ideascale members have commented, the proposal is approaching two separate issues, so for clarity and better integration into the challenge I would suggest that it should be split into two separate proposals. The first one should be about generating awareness about Project Catalyst and the second about "finding people who will accept payment via ADA" and see how that second one might fit into this category.

The plan is too general, it covers most points, but none explicitly. A lot of good ideas have started to emerge, but none was described in detail. There are several mentions of raising awareness, but no detailed description of how that would be achieved.

Since you are already running with the project and the platform is working, I feel that it would be great to detail even more the spending, once you are requiring all the fund value – which allow other projects to coexist.
One thing that made me curious in the "what would be different" section is: are the project aiming on training a team which is capable of bringing solutions for SB? Because I think that this might be not scalable and the costs would be huge. This idea could culminate in the community participation, where you can open to the community to find a solution and maybe a partnership with the business, or even a reward – which I think would be less spending than have your own team and would show how the community works together.

Other than that, if you win this fund and start this project together with the Catalyst it is of your intention to make it annual, the "Culture of Innovation" – however it has costs, as you've shown. Therefore, how are you intending to continue with the Catalyst every year?

The experience of the team is difficult to qualify for such a large task that is being proposed. I have no concern about the business acumen that relates to mentoring SMS/s but am unsure if this will translate directly to proposals from those SME owners. The plan seems a little unwieldy at this stage and would likely benefit from being broken down into smaller parts. This I feel would be well received by the community and allow for a greater degree of trust building that such a large project necessitates. It would certainly assist with the budget request which seems excessive given the niche market of the proposal.

The budget is not detailed, they admit to not knowing exact costs "These are best estimates and we have not secured direct costing". The metrics are not clearly described, the project has no clear direction, it will be a platform for small businesses, a hackathon, a pitch fest, a showcase of previous Project Catalyst funded projects etc.

I missed some KPI and metrics to validate the correlation between newcomers and this project. How are the team willing to measure this?
Furthermore, a more explained budget would be great to add value in this proposal and a form to verify the spending.

Generally the information provided is sound and allows some grasp of the big picture. There is room for greater detail which is applicable for a project this size. I feel the budget requested is asking a lot of community. Should the proposal be staged with smaller achievable milestones it would likely be well received. Provision of examples of the educational/training resources for example would assist the community to make a better informed decision when voting.

The proposal is at the right place, addresses the issue of having a metamask like wallet for Cardano. Metrics, goals and time plan is however not available. I would welcome a bit more in this part, because the proposal has a good potential.

Intuitively, this is a sorely needed thing in the cardano ecosystem. There is stiff competition between Gero and Yoroi. With dcSpark being launched it may be completed. However, this project doesn't provide any examples of what cross chain swaps, how EUTXO will be used to facilitate it, how the wallet will be used for all the other purposes listed in the lite paper.

The problem and solution statement are reasonable and are within the scope of the challenge. The use of infographics can be an important tool to improve the communication process regarding Catalyst and allow a better understanding of the calculations for defining the ranking of proposals in the voting app, it would be interesting to have at least 1 prototype of an infographic to demonstrate the concept more clearly. The idea has the potential to quickly improve voters' decision-making and improve understanding of Catalyst, as the development time is set at 10 weeks.

Information presented visually is much easier for humans to process. The proposal will improve the community's ability to stay informed and help new community members ingest information about Project Catalyst, enabling them to become active members more quickly without losing interest. This in turn will lead to the improvement of the whole Catalyst process. Less time spent on repeatedly answering the same questions will mean more time dedicated to other aspects of the process.

Availability of a good infographic will be a good force multiplier in onboarding and help implicitly in decision making. The process and the number of funds are currently intimidating for new members and take some effort to understand.

The idea is very good, because in fact, the Catalyst system is very complex and diverse, and new members of the community may find it difficult to understand the parts that comprise it, as well as how they relate. I myself think that I would benefit from this project, because my entry into the community is recent, and even today I feel a little lost in relation to the whole. By understanding the parties better, new members (and old ones as well, if they have some better clarified concepts) will feel safer to make decisions and contribute in this way to Catalyst. Thus, the objectives of this challenge would be achieved.

I strongly support this proposal. Infograhics (especially dynamic ones) can very effectively support the life of Community Advisors AND VOTERS. I provided the following improvement ideas to this proposal during the feedback phase: 

"I would dream of a clustered project-funnel, which shown the various projects in its stages over their lifecycle, clustered according to the nature/scope of the project, maybe in COIN360.com style and e.g. colored according to ROI achievement (following different KPI mix along the life-cycle).
But maybe this is could be a direct IdeaScale feature, where active drill-down would be supported."

The proposer, Phil, is one of the most participative members in the Catalyst groups, has an excellent understanding of the process and already participates in the development of several projects for Catalyst improvements, such as the development of the Landing Page, tools for improvement in the assessments phase and collaboration in documentation development.

There is a link to Evgeniya Tranevskaya's Instagram, the designer who will be responsible for creating the art of the infographics, where we can see some of her works.

There is a reasonable plan, with a clear definition of timeline and budget.

The team producing the deliverables is without a doubt capable of producing compelling visuals, they have already proven this. I have no doubt about the successful production of the visual materials. I only have slight reservations about how those visuals will be distributed.

The proponent has demonstrated engagement with the community and participation in the processes that they are interested in supporting (Catalyst). Furthermore, the proponent provides examples of their own work and that of collaborators. Nevertheless, I  find that evidence and the plan presented insufficient to be confident of the successful execution of the project. In particular, I am concerned regarding the absence of evidence of previous successful execution and the little use of visual communication resources in the examples provided (Catalyst's landing page and teleolog web page). I found the following statement concerning: "A full list of proposed Infographic will be developed at the time of funding". The proponent has demonstrated experience with the process but nevertheless could not, or, chose not to, enunciate or demonstrate their understanding of the requirement for visual resources to explain it.  Furthermore, there are incomplete and undeveloped statements like "Look at build out a more detailed process of funding graphics and engaging a wider range of graphic designers - for future funding rounds.", which seems to be leftover from a previous assessment. With the experience of the proponent, this proposal would benefit greatly from a little bit more descriptiveness, i.e.: a more precise description of the deliverables to be expected.

The proposal is coming from a single individual who has more than enough technical and community involvement in the Catalyst space.  They have already worked with the Catalyst team to help develop and maintain documentation and infographics in the past.  The budget is a reasonable amount for the development project.

The author claims to have experience with business and design, as well as being a very active member of the Catalyst community. To carry out the assembly of the infographics itself, from what I understood, the designer @etranevskaya (her name was not said, but the profile on instagram) would be responsible. In relation to design, the professional to be well prepared, talented and capable, according to their work posted on the social network. However, in relation to the selection of information that would be included in the graphics, I think it would be safer if someone specializing in blockshain were hired as well. Because despite being very involved with Catalyst, it is not certain that the author has deep experience in cryptocurrencies. In my opinion, the ideal would be: to keep the designer, hire someone for Motion Design (as he also mentions), keep the author and hire a specialist in blockshain / ADA.

The problem and solution described are in line with the challenge. The proposal does not involve great complexity and the roadmap and milestones described are clear enough to allow auditing of the proposal.

There are details about the proposer, his experiences and qualifications, information about the designer's portfolio and details about budget allocation.

There are no elements / KPIs that allow us to understand what the impact on the community's decision-making was.

My only concern is that there is no concrete plan to effectively get the infographics in front of the people who would need to see them. Producing compelling and informative visuals is only part of the story, distributing them successfully is what will actually improve the Catalyst experience and lead to more informed, better decisions by the community.

For example: it is said that the intention is to make 2 charts per week, for 10 weeks. But which subjects would be covered in each graph, exactly? There are many topics to be addressed, it would certainly be beneficial to clarify better how and in what order they would be addressed. Another point that I thought was that it is not said where these graphics would be available, how they would reach the public, since the ultimate goal is to better guide the members of the community. Regarding the division of expenses, it is said that an amount would be shared in 50/50 for the designer and the author, who would do the research. But for example, if someone else was also hired, that account would need to be rethought. Suggestion: 50% for the designer and 25% for each researcher, because the work of visual assembly is very complex (I am currently a graduate student in design) and would have to be done by a single person, whereas the research would be divided.

While it seems that there may be some controversy regarding competition (ideas etc) I found the proposal effectively addresses the challenge. It is reasonable that two similiar projects can co-exist in the Cardano environment. May even be healthy from an innovation sense.

Having a dapp store is important for enabling potential users to see all other Dapps in the eco-system leading to improved utilization. The issue of plagiarism raised in the comment is not a major issue since it is always better to have a alternate site to improve competition.

The proposal described doesn't clearly demonstrate how it will address the challenge. The idea is to create a website to inform about Cardano's userbase on dapps and development updates and relevant statistics on the projects under development. The proposal is not within the "Potential Directions" set out in the Challenge Brief for this challenge.


The focus in this proposal is not on developers, but on providing information to the userbase about dapps and projects under development.

Although I believe that this proposal has an interesting potential, there is nothing to indicate that it could have a relevant benefit for developers. No targets or metrics were included that indicate impact on this challenge. If we analyze the case of Ethereum where there is a large ecosystem of dapps and projects we realize that there is no central hub to find information about dapps, but  different initiatives and in many cases the projects disclose developments on Twitter or Medium. Using a specific website ends up restricting the reach.

The qualifications given are not verifiable. However, the funds requested are modest and the implementation not particularly difficult. The question is whether the platform can gain users and network effect. Marketing experience and strategy would make the proposal more convincing.

The team describes experiences in Web development, project and business management, but this is insufficient to indicate their aptitude to execute this proposal.

In the link "https://adaption.us/about-us" there is more information about the team, but only vague descriptions. To assess the feasibility of the team implementing a proposal we need solid evidence of expertise and links / references to previous work.

There is no budget breakdown. The plan needs to be better structured, there is no roadmap.

I recommend that the team develops the proposal based on the Catalyst documentation.

The information provided was sufficient and the idea is feasible. Greater detail about team members, a more detailed budget and possibly future aspects as I feel that this is a project in the early stages.

The 3500 in funds will be used to build the web platform. This includes Dapp listings, a news feed, and statistics. No time frame is given.  A specific time frame for each stage would improve my rating.

The proposal describes how it will grow the number of students that will learn about Cardano, but doesn't go any further, in explaining how that will translate in the growing of the Cardano community and most importantly into their growth. What are their possibilities afterwards to make use of their knowledge? How will it help, what will they be able to do?

The plan is well described and has most of the information needed. However, it doesn't have a further purpose beyond the growth of college students learning about Cardano and how that could impact their life. And this is a question that needs to be answered in order for the project to be successfully implemented as that is the same question that those students might also ask themselves: "Why should I devote my time to learning about this, if I don't see how that would help me further along the way?"

the proposal sets for a clear timeline, budget and scope which gives it a clear place to audit success from. The only thing that could be improved is being more explicit with the goal to on board new Cardano wallets.
I think that would be of a great help if you could add a gantt chart to give a more visual way for us to verify what depends on the voting of the f4 and what this will affect in the final product.
proposalTitle: Open Ideas and Data For Cooperation

assessmentNote: This seems like a reasonable project to promote Cardano in Ethiopia. Perhaps rather than a monthly  event in one city it should move around the country or the continent.

Having networking events might be tricky. 

One thing is to organize such an event, the other is to create an interest in it. It can end up with empty meetings, that is why I took one star away. 

also, the budget vs outcome feels overextended.

If we exclude the current situation with the pandemic, where larger group gatherings are not recommended/allowed (depending on each country's policies), this proposal could potentially help grow the Cardano community in Ethiopia and at the same time, help students and entrepreneurs discover the potential of the Cardano ecosystem and grow alongside it.

The proposal fits well with the objectives of the challenge, because it promises to promote face-to-face meetings in the capital of Ethiopia in order to discuss issues pertinent to the Catalyst project. The number of purely African participants would be considerable, most of the public and the organizers, and the idea fits well with the questions of novelty and adequacy, because in the city there is not a good circulation of information about the community and this new event would be very positive.

The idea is very good. Since Ethiopia is a country where Cardano is probably going to have, at least proportionally, the greatest number of users, it makes sense to try to take advantage of it and improve even more the participation of the community. I believe that the budget could be a bit smaller, and that's my only negative point about the content of this proposal. Maybe half of the events and half of the budget would have a best cost/benefit relation.

The brief experience description that the team has put together could be enough for this proposal, though it would have been nice to have some extra information in that regard. While the event in itself is sufficiently described, the marketing side of it is lacking entirely. It's not enough to have a good idea for an event, if there are not enough people who can discover it and join. Maybe the fact that they consider partnering with the Addis Ababa University could help jump-start their marketing efforts.

The budget is straightforward and sensible. The number of participants per event is a metric that is easy to evaluate to get a sense of the project's success. The plan is realistic and even with some of the lacking information, it could still be implemented and easily verified.

This auditability of this proposal is as simple as checking if the events have really happened, and also the costs related to them. Also, some key metrics are mentioned and they are good to measure the impact of the proposal. Budget breakdown is good to understand how the budget will be spent. Some challenges should be assessed, like having enough people to present on these events, even thought this seems to be a very small risk.

The proposer clearly understands the business  in question, but it is less clear that they understand the blockchain technology to execute it with.  There is no clear roadmap or timeline.  I think the proposal needs more refinement.

No detail on how this would get accepted by large financial institutions who are developing there own solutions. It is not clear it addresses the challenge. Even if it was successful it would take more than this year to get accepted. and it focusses on large financial institutions. Whereas the challenge is "What applications will provide the most value for end users in 2021?"

only 5k in funds is requested for what appears to be a very ambitious project. There are no timelines, roadmaps or metrics for success provided. it is unclear how the funds would be allocated or what products we can expect.

The Roadmap is missing. This proposal needs more details on the step-by-step action plan, including milestones and KPI'S. 
 When do you plan to release the product?  Who will build this project?

The proposer provides a timeline but the description of what will be accomplished at each stage is very vague. What does it mean to build a data platform? Are all the services being worked on at the same time? I'm concerned that with the scope of this proposal and its multiple services, a team of a single developer working 4 hours a day for 120 days would be hard-pressed to accomplish everything outlined here.

The roadmap is clear and well explained, and milestones are also there linked to some dates, which is very good. The budget is broken down, but it's almost all for developer costs, which would be ok if developer part was not that high. It seems a bit too much for the proposed solution. Also, the proposal would benefit from some KPIs and estimations related to the usage of the tool, how much time this would save for new comers and also how many people would eventually be impacted by it.

This proposal tackles the murky water of real transactions, mixing the discrete with the indeterminate reality of transaction in the real world.  This provides a foundation for protection of transactions against bots.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote: The proposer fails to recognize that Cardano was purposely built for the eUTXO instead of the Ethereum Accounts style and that the eUTXO model allows you to parallelize/thread multiple contracts at once that sync up at a later time, thus eliminating the race to singe utxo issue they highlight here. Trying to rebuild Ethereum accounts on top of Cardano's eUTXO instead of building the correct design patterns/contract structures required to mitigate this a poor allocation of Catalyst funds.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote: As the proposer stated, this proposal meets the challenge in a roundabout way, by removing a problem which could render many DeFi solutions vulnerable to manipulation.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote: The statement of the problem and solution are reasonable and are aligned with the challenge. The proposal has positive impact potential, not only in smart contracts related to DeFi but also in smart contracts related to NFTs. The deliverables described could be used by Defi and NFTs projects as an important infrastructure to improve quality and safety of protocols / dapps.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote:
The team presented link to their GitLab, where it is possible to check the code developed by MUKN. They have been working with Blockchain scaling solutions for 3 years, and have successfully launched the dapp language Glow in partnership with IOG. I recommend including links to LinkedIn of the people involved in the development of the proposal.

Despite the complexity of the problem and the proposal, there is an extremely articulated and structured rationale. There is an objective plan described in Step 1.

Deliverables are good indicators of success. There is a simple and objective timeline, within the application for this challenge.

Risks for delays in the Alonzo HFC were considered and there is a plan for development in the future.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote:
There is clarity in the description of the problem. The described solution addresses the problem and challenge.

There are details on budget allocation, there is a link to the team repository, but I recommend more detailing on the team members' experiences. Add a link to members LinkedIn allows the community to have access to more information about the team's qualifications easily and transparently.

There are reasonable deliverables. There is a clear and objective timeline. No KPIs were described.
proposalTitle: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model

assessmentNote: Really like the concept and feel you have identified a legitimate problem that requires attention. Encouraging delegators to commit to small pools is definitely an issue that will benefit the Cardano community. It is evident that This proposal may require further revision as it is certainly a difficult problem to resolve. I'm not entirely sure I fully understood the penalty aspect of the delegator changing their mind...blocked from further use of the Dapp? Also I sense you may have supply and demand restraints on large ADA holders which appear to be necessary for the concept to work.

From what I understand out of the proposal: a pool would start if it has a chance of success and there are sufficient users committed to the pool to avoid having a multiple epoch wait for rewards. Users would then get notified to redelegate their respective ADA to the pool and start the epoch. So users get pulled out of existing underperforming pools to a combined pool in the SPRD framework. Said pools could then band together in SPRD to have a higher chance of minting a block and dividing the rewards. The idea is good and could help small stake pools to have a more steady income, which in turn could power projects.

The main goal of the category is to attract users to the Cardano platform.  The proposal doesn't exactly address this challenge, but it could increase participation of Cardano holders staking with small pools. The incentivization model is an important factor in adoption. If the tool could become a hub where delegators search and choose stake pools based off of incentives and other criteria, and perhaps have access to educational resources about staking, then the project could be a success. It could increase active participation in the consensus mechanism by delegators.

The proposer has demonstrated technical ability through their beta version of the software.  While I believe the smart contract aspect is essential for the success of the project, with the testnet coming live soon I have no doubts that the proposer could implement the technology even with a very small team. Long term success will depend on adoption so the incentive strategy is a welcome addition to the proposal. If the SPRD system could become a popular starting point for new delegators it could have a large impact on the Cardano proof of stake ecosystem.

Reasonably detailed plan. How will it deal with users removing funds from their wallets or committing to multiple potential pools? I would be great if a user could set up a waterfall of commitments? It would also be good to have tools for users to see potential commitments to a pool and other info such ahs historical fees (to see if pools are changing their fees). Alerts or commitments to automatically swap out of pools based on fee or commitments levels could be interesting as well.

Apart from a few thorny problems that I feel still need attention This proposal provides quality information and the author's identification of a worthy problem to solve is commendable. Would like further breakdown of budget and collaboration of addressing delegators that change their mind.

Impressive website. On the website it says the milestone for April is not reached yet, but in the proposal it does. So it is unclear if you've fallen slightly behind or are on schedule. 
Most additional elements are present but the risk assessment under 'Funds' could have been elaborated more. 
There is also a definition of success that is missing. (How many 'committers' are you trying to attract to call it a success?)

Blockchain-friendly native token-based authentication opens a new use case for metadata. The is a requirement to carry out an independent security audit of the proposal in later stages. However, the idea is unique and can result in better use cases for the native asset.

Good interpretation of the Metadata Challenge. Whilst I am not an expert in the technical underpinnings. I can see the use of a tokenised authentication system as key in the cases provided here in terms of access to API's (which in turn lowers the bar to new developers as mentioned, could have a great impact on the system as a whole). Could this this idea have further use cases in the non-developer world, such as a patreon style subscription service to content etc and if so if could be worth mentioning that, as this increases the impact for a wider number of potential users. (Just an outsiders thought)

This proposal addresses the critically important use case of utilizing transaction metadata for authentication. The proposal would be stronger if it employed (or demonstrated awareness) of well-reviewed standards and approaches such as the W3C's Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs), which have been explicitly designed to handle such blockchain use cases.

The experience given and the video and diagram seem to show that this is a well thought out proposal. The integration with Dandelion is promising as they have already had some success in facilitating blockchain projects. Working with the community is key here and maybe forming a more concrete team around this project may help, both in the development and tutorial stages of the project. The budget seems feasible and sensible for the task described

The proposer has solid experience to implement the proposed solution, which provides sufficient detail regarding the approach. However, the proposal does not include a plan to have the authentication protocol audited from a security perspective (or at least include an authentication expert on the team), which is particularly important because it appears to be an ad-hoc protocol and the proposal states that it would rely on a "temporary (few minutes) secret" to establish a secure channel. (The proposal's gitlab link leads to a 404, so I could not review the work in progress.) There is a large body of literature, best practices, standards, and implementations for initially securing channels, but the proposal does not demonstrate consideration of that. Without leveraging that, there is a significant risk that the proposal would nominally succeed in its approach, but have significant security vulnerabilities.

There are no technical challenges that are yet to be overcome in the implementation of the proposal and the proposer has developed a reasonable roadmap. The proposal is feasible to implement and has a high potential to address the challenge. The proposer is releasing the project as open-source which enable independent security audit which is a critical requirement for all authentication related projects.

The roadmap and milestones give the project audibility in terms of progress, and the KPI of having a successful integration with Dandelion should also help. The "Success" of the Documentation and Evangelism stage is harder to Audit, apart from maybe numbers of interactions with Dandelion, and overall new developers brought into the system. Potential challenges and risks for the proposal haven't really been thought through, that would be my only note here. But overall the proposal meets the challenge in a novel and potentially very impactful way.

The roadmap and solution are sufficiently detailed to measure and assess the progress of the proposal, but its true success cannot be assessed unless the plan were to include a rigorous security audit of the implemented authentication protocol.

It's not clear how a website like this would attract proposers to Project Catalyst. I do not agree with the claim "This project can only exist in the Cardano ecosystem, because of its cheap transactions, multi-asset transactions, and secure contracts". On the other hand, If this goes viral it could indeed create brand awareness, but it looks a bit like gambling to me, since if that does not happen, there will be almost no return for cardano and catalyst.

The experience presented is relevant to the project but there are IMO some critical issues.
* Some portions of the budget seems not very balanced (e.s. 10k$ for hosting)
* The main selling point, charity donations, are not very well defined and there's some risk of not actually adhering to promises, given the extreme centralization of power (tokens and value ) in the hands of just one person. I.e. there's no guarantee that the proposer won't run away with the money once the project is successful, possibly hurting the image of cardano
* one of the proposal is to use 500k$ worth of ADA to recoup losses, maintain the project and pay off student debts. Apart from the student debts part, which may be ok provided it is the outcome of a public vote, why should there be losses or additional resources needed outside of the budget? What does that cover then?
* The conversion between ADA and $ is not defined. What would happen if that drastically changes?

The budget is partitioned and there is a plan, even though a timeline and success metrics are not defined, making assessing the success or failure of the project a bit hard, especially since there's no obvious way of determining impact of it on project catalyst (there are however some proposals for doing that in the comments that seems ok)

He is proposing an off-internet/PC full blockchain portable solution…… although I fail to see what it is a solution to. He was frequently asked in the comments section for use cases, that he has failed to supply. So at this point the answer is No, I fail to see how this will bring more Defi  teams to build/deploy open finance solutions on Cardano.

Clearly there is some tech in this proposal, however what problem it solves is unclear. The proposal would benefit by providing a clear description of what problem this solves, who it solves it for, how big the problem it is, and how it would address the goals of the Scale-Up of the DeFi ecosystem.

In my opinion this proposal is a real implementation that could improve the transactions volume on Cardano blockchain, but It isn't clearly articulates how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and for the stakeholders (in deep detail for users, traders and so on.. ). However the objective of the proposal is very interesting. The prototype is nice and funny, built with a lot of passion. I think there is a value for the customers, in security and simplicity

"Daedalus Wallet Node SBC Devices" is an ambitious hardware/software development project; however, the proposal has no relationship to Decentralized Finance, which is focused on autonomous marketplaces for financial services.

He states his experience is 'MCSE. 30 years of code work. Make my own equipment and programming' – I've omitted the rest because it is not relevant – There is no evidence to back this up. There are also  no details of the App developers and so I cannot judge whether that the App or the hardware will be created successfully.
The plan itself just looks like he has just thrown it all at the page and hoped some of it sticks!! It feels like he has written down his thought process and then straight copy and pasted into the proposal, it is not clear and concise, has no real flow and so is very confusing. 
The proposal is in an unfinished format that does not instill me with a large amount of confidence that this will be carried out successfully. If he is indeed serious about this proposal then I think it should be tidied up and placed in the correct challenge, I also suggest that the monetary amount is reduced by spreading it over more than one fund cycle.

The proposal team is completed skilled and have a good technical knowledge and expertise, so in my opinion will able to make surely a good product in production. In relation to the possible success of the initiative, there are poor indications related to marketing and communication for the product launch, neither about the customers adoption. Further I think it's important to improve details about the process related to the issue related to the market or capital risk

While the proposal includes a demonstration of a working bit of tech, it doesn't include a clear path to building the community which is required to get this to work. To address feasibility the proposal should identify a target market of early adopters with concrete data points which demonstrate how much demand there is for this type of product.

The proposer doesn't provides a step-by-step plan for the implementation with clear milestones and a defined time horizon, so what is the plan forward and roadmap? In my opinion it's not clear and well detailed what exactly is the problem statement and value of the solution to scale-up DeFi. The proposal doesn't offers a realistic timetable to complete the work. The proposer has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation

As stated by the proposer "successful consideration is difficult to understand." Indeed. The proposee demonstrates a high degree of technical expertise and great enthusiasm for the Cardano ecosystem. To achieve a better proposal, which is easier for an audience to understand, it would be good to discuss his ideas with others in the community and work with a partner who can assist in defining an objective better aligned with the community requirements.

If carried out correctly I think this will be one of the go to tools in the NFT space, by bootstrapping this, it will save developers time and resources that can be used effectively elsewhere and as such does aid in addressing the challenge.

In my opinion this proposal is within the challenge goal that will enable developers to capitalize on the interest in NFTs to drive integration, adoption, and user growth in Cardano adoption. Furthermore the relation with Cardano blockchain services it is well done specified. The proposal clearly articulates how it will add value to the stakeholders (in deep detail for users, developers and so on.. ) with examples and use cases

NFT based access control has a number of advantages and opens up a large number of usecases. Gifting of exclusive web accounts, selling games, and as a Membership badge. There is an urgent need to develop such capability in Cardano.

Proposal seems to effectively address the challenge and certainly has engagement from the community on this level. The team certainly appears to be taking a collaborative approach to the project and states it has more in the pipeline.
The proposers seem to have the experience and have thought through the issue involved. They are possibly looking to hire people thus there is a risk there that they don't get the quality they need.

I would have liked to see concrete examples of the proposer's past experience and links to previous works. Other than that the plan, budget breakdown, metrics, release timeframes all are very clearly presented and make sense.

The proposal team is completed skilled and very well described on role and specializations, clear documented also other fundamental experiences on cardano blockchain (since 2019 and cardano stake pool operator). In relation to the possible success of the initiative, I think it is well described on the application side but not completely in the business side, so I suggest to integrate information's and business case to improve details about the process related to the issue related to the market or capital risk

The proposer team is strong and has been involved in the Cardano ecosystem. They are in collaboration with all related stakeholders. There is substantial technical challenges in realizing the proposal but it is possible with the given team composition.

I believe this is very feasible from the information provided. If carried out correctly I think this will be one of the go to tools in the NFT space, by bootstrapping this, it will save developers time and resources that can be used effectively elsewhere and as such does aid in addressing the challenge.

I would be interested to know how they are going to manage the database. Is this going to be privately managemd by them? Or is their a distributed option they can provide that provides more long term safety for users and developers relying n it.

The proposer provides a very detailed plan for the implementation with milestones and a defined time horizon; the proposer also adds some information about adoption and delivery of the solution, also the proposer has mentioned possible difficulties and how to deal with them.. The proposer hasn't considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation

The progress can be monitored by analyzing the code base, and success needs to be measured by the number of services utilizing the NFTKey. It will be possible to do these two in a very reliable manner.

Solid proposal that provides good information without delivering all requirements. There appears to be a small number of points that require further attention to provide an adequate level of certainty to the success of this proposal. Having said that I was impressed with the level of collaboration already achieved and subscribed to by the author. This proposal may simply need to reassess its size and budget allocation to meet all the metric requirements.

The proposer doesn't provides a step-by-step plan for the implementation with clear milestones and a defined time horizon, so what is the plan forward and roadmap? In my opinion it's not clear and well detailed what exactly is the problem statement and value of the solution to adopt insurance app and which is the benefits for the customers. The proposal doesn't offers a realistic timetable to complete the work. The proposer has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation
The proposed use case has validity, but the proposal lacks any data to support the legitimacy of the project.

This proposal can provide benefits to the insurance industry and some to participating users. However it is too expensive with the funds demanded. THe proposal is not detailed enough to determine the exact use it will provide.
Please provide a detailed plan with milestones. How will you asses honesty? Why is an honesty token worth more than the large payout for dishonesty under an insurance contract?

No plan for the implementation is presented. The somewhat relevant experience (the claim of operating a Cardano stakepool and having systems dev experience) is not presented in a verifiable manner. The budget of $150k has no breakdown.

The proposal required a strong team to secure regulator compliance, development, marketing, and adaptation by established users. The proposer has not brought out how he will develop this team and how they are going to be managed.

The proposer explains in a comment that this proposal is a duplication of his own first proposal. The proposal that the proposer wants to be assessed is the first one that can be found below: 

https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Insurance-Claims-Processing/350998-48088

However, in addition to that fact, I would point out that the plan and budget and timetable and experience are given in the most general of forms and it seems unlikely the proposal would be implemented successfully.

Not enough details for the proposer's experience, he provided a link to the phone app that he's working on, but even there I couldn't find anything regarding his prior experience. The proposal needs to be developed further, this is more of a draft. I understood from his comment that this is a duplicate of another identical proposal, but he should have withdrawn it when he noticed there's a second one.

The team has developed a (not yet live) insurance app and run a stake pool. No technical understanding of the blockchain implementation is expressed in the proposal.  There is no roadmap provided and the proposal lacks any detail. For this reason I do not believe the proposal will be successfully implemented.

The problem and description are reasonable and are in line with the challenge. The proposal aims to audit the release version of Liqwid and is a crucial step in ensuring the reliability and security of DeFi projects.

The metrics and goals described indicate the alignment and impact on the challenge.

There are details on the experience of the team and external collaborators, indicating their aptitude and the extreme quality of those involved in executing the proposal. The teams involved in the audit are specialists in Haskell and Plutus, with one of the consultants being Duncan Coutts, one of the main technical references at IOG.

There is a clear and objective plan for the process of auditing, the parties involved and the time needed to conduct the audit.

The budget described is reasonable and has details on its allocation.

The approach is a traditional security audit.
It's unclear to me how continuous code review improves security and why code review was not in place from day one.

Simple to audit whether hours are done. Whether the security audit found all bugs will only be known in the future.I'd like to see the proposers provide some measurable KPI's as to how this project meets the challenge goal of scaling up DeFi in Cardano in general/

There is clarity in the description of the problem and how the solution presented will address the challenge.

The development of the audit is already underway and the deadline for the audit of the final version is scheduled for July. There is a clear, objective timeline.

There are objective metrics and deliverables.

There are details about the team and budget allocation.

The proposer provides some experience, but it does not seem very relevant for the problem domain. For example, specifying experience with Web UI development, ReactJS, or perhaps iOS or Android app development might be more relevant. The budget outlined mentions training a team but it is unclear how members of the team will contribute to the project. The proposer's links to github show some related work in their repos.
proposalTitle: Mobile Plutus and Marlowe Dev Tools

assessmentNote: Whilst the proposer has many years programming experience, it seems this is an idea and 52 weeks should be enough to do it. Thus it is hard to say if it will be successful.
proposalTitle: Mobile Plutus and Marlowe Dev Tools

assessmentNote: The proposal does not contain much information to evaluate this, the linked github repository is not very active, and there are not much information on the rest of the team.
proposalTitle: Mobile Plutus and Marlowe Dev Tools

assessmentNote: The timeline and deliverables section of the proposal are detailed.
proposalTitle: Mobile Plutus and Marlowe Dev Tools

assessmentNote:
The problem statement is reasonable and the proposal is within the scope of the challenge. I recommend modifying the solution statement, as it doesn't describe a solution, but the experience of the Credmark team.

Analyze, model and simulate default situations for borrowers. This allows analyze the settlement process and understand the protocol's reliability, which is essential to ensure the security and resilience of the Liqwid protocol. In addition, the creation of a pooled liquidation model to optimize the settlement process. These implementations are within the scope of the challenge and will allow Liqwid to operate more safely.
proposalTitle: Liqwid x Credmark R&D on Loan Risks

assessmentNote:
There are several details about the teams involved in the proposal and their qualifications in key areas  such as development of risk-adjusted models and the development of smart contracts in Plutus.

The budget is reasonable and detailed.

The plan is reasonable, there is a clear and objective timeline for delivery (2 months)
proposalTitle: Liqwid x Credmark R&D on Loan Risks

assessmentNote: More detail on the models beingg built. Are they implementing already known models (if so which) or are they researching new ones. What data is being used? What is the process going forward to keep the models and data current. All banks and insurance companies have large teams involved in model and data verification. What is the future model to fund these in an ongoing basis?
proposalTitle: Liqwid x Credmark R&D on Loan Risks

assessmentNote:
There is clarity about the problem and how the proposal will address the problem and the challenge.

There are details about the teams, their qualifications and the budget breakdown.

Solid metrics and deliverables have been described. There are no KPIs.
proposalTitle: Liqwid x Credmark R&D on Loan Risks

assessmentNote: This would be very beneficial for developers using token based in game assets. The drawback would be the high funding request that may limit other equally beneficial proposals to get funding.
proposalTitle: Native Token API for Game Devs

assessmentNote: Potentially opening up the Cardano ecosystem to game developers by creating a bridge that would motivate them to implement blockchain technology could have long lasting, very positive impacts on the Cardano ecosystem as a whole.
