This is even more relevant as the developers themselves seem to have asked for the development of the SDK as mentioned in the proposal and comments section. My only small concern is with the relatively small numbers of developers that this solution would be impacting, but given the low investment required I don't see this as a major issue.

The team behind the project already has proven themselves within the Cardano community. The proposers are probably the best qualified to take on development of the SDK as it will be an addition to the service they are already offering the Cardano community. The metrics, budget, roadmap and deliverable are clearly laid out and broken down. I share the belief of the proposers that developers working within the Cardano ecosystem should be fairly compensated for their work
The definition of success is missing, but the fact that there's a free plan on blockfrost means some technical persons could follow the progress

The problem and solution description is within the scope of the challenge. Offering financial incentives through tokens and bounties is a way to encourage community participation in the discussion of improvements for Catalyst and in my view having more people actively participating in Catalyst is a step towards wisdom of the crowds and an improvement in the ability to decision-making in relation to Catalyst itself. The proposal goes beyond creating solutions in decision making, being a promising idea to organize and distribute the workload. 

The distribution of contribution tokens to poll /proposals participants can help increase community participation in internal proposals for improving Catalyst and create a reputation model where members with more tokens end up being seen as more participatory, but as one of the objectives of the proposal is creating a tokenomics model there is still no way to know the effectiveness and impact of this.

This proposal seeks to use incentive to drive contribution and recognition. It is something that is a great thing to try on NFT-DAO first then hopefully it will work on Catalyst. This is a prototype reputation system before DIDs. What isn't clear is how the tokens will be tracked and verified that the current holder is qualified to hold them. What if someone sells them? they will have immense reputation and credibility associated with them, how to protect from imposters?

The NFT-DAO EZ-Honor is an effective proposal that is seeking funding to grow an existing (claims 300+ members) DAO. The proposal if funded would seek to research and develop the tokenomics of participation awards. Presumably, the reward tokens would then be required for influence in community activities, as a token has to have utility in order to establish value. An unaddressed question is how the authority would be established to require tokens for voting or other activities.
The proposal is from a strong group already committed to this task. It is well detailed and thus highly likely to be produced if funded.

given the clear plan and strong team there is little doubt left. This is the first proposal I've seen that actually recognized the key funding dates within Project Catalyst, which signals that the team is in tune with the community and what's important.
The proposal provides clear goals and expectations, and the success is auditable via blockchain data to find the token transactions as well as how they are being used in the community.
This is perhaps my only query with this proposal, does it address the challenge? Seems more like an administration challenge proposal than onboarding given onboarding can be widely defined.

The proposal is very interesting, because it uses something that already exists (Cardano's discord channel) and intends to improve it, with the aim of benefiting communication between members of the community. I don't think, however, that this idea will attract new people to Cardano (one of the goals of this challenge), but rather to make members more engaged and increase the chances of staying in the community. So, in the end, it remains very positive, in my view.

The proposers are moderators on the Discord Catalyst server, are already involved with the Catalyst community and participated in Swarm Sessions. The team is involved in the development of Landing Page and other improvement initiatives in Catalyst. The team has skills to execute the proposal.

The described plan is simple and sufficient due to the low complexity of the proposal. On the Miro board there is more information about the rationale of the proposal and the plan. There is a reasonable, week-long timeline.


There are details on budget allocation on the Miro board and the hours needed to carry out the different stages of development.

The proposers seem to have a lot of experience with the structure of the Discord, however not with programming (at least it is not mentioned under relevant experience). A realistic time budget is presented.

Regarding the team that proposes this project, in my opinion, it is very solid and well prepared to successfully carry out the idea. They are people from different areas, such as developers, engineers, designers ... it seems to me that all fronts of the project will be well underway with such a diverse team. The only observation I would make is that it is always valid to show some examples of work done previously by those involved.

Since the proposer is an experienced Discord channel admin, I see that this proposal is completely feasible in the defined time frame. Also, each step is clearly detailed. Although, the proposal states that this is a mini proposal that would cost 3000 ADA, but is asks for 500, but maybe it's a typo. Also, I didn't understand the roles that were mentioned in the text. It seems like a general text that would fit other mini proposals, but it could be clearer. Obs.: This assessment is very similar to the one in Bot to Assign Roles, because the proposal text is almost the same as well.

Hard to say as the proposers are asking for minimal funds but need to find people to do it. Unsure whether they will. Not clear what the funds are for. Is this to pay server costs or for peoples time?

The information provided is sufficient. The proposal itself is not overly complex or requiring a huge investment of time. My only concern is whether onboarding challenge is correctly explained and its only a minor concern.

There is clarity in the problem, solution and alignment of the proposal with the challenge.

There are details on the number of hours required for the development of each stage of development, the budget is reasonable and there are details on the allocation of resources according to the hourly load x hourly payment.

There is a simple one-week timeline. There are objective KPIs.

As the proposal involves low complexity, the audit is relatively simple and there are sufficient elements to carry out such an audit.
The proposal all in all is detailed enough to be able to be evaluated, however some important details are missing, like details on the functionalities of the bot.

There is attached a picture of the miro application with a lot of detail about the project, which shows that the team has been very clear about everything that will be done, all the technical details and so on. However, this picture is a little confusing and difficult to understand for outsiders, I think it is always more interesting to make a timeline of the time when we can understand what will be done and when. As it is a small proposal, they measured the steps in hours, which is very interesting, because it shows total planning in relation to what should be followed.

Since this project is very simple, it would be easy to audit and confirm that it has been performed according to the plan, specially because it would be an open source development. Also, KPI is clearly stated and it is sufficient to evaluate the proposal impact. Although, risk of spamming was not accounted for and should be assessed. Obs.: This assessment is very similar to the one in Bot to Assign Roles, because the proposal text is almost the same as well.
Main issue is who is doing it? if the proposers aren't doing it, then what is the plan to organise the people who will?

A must-address-now project which would make it easier for us as a community to resolve when Cardano progresses to the level where external filing systems would need to be addressed. Kudos to the team for having foresight and proposing a solution, albeit short-term.
This sounds like an important project, however it is not clear that it directly meets the fund challenge.

Reliable decentralised storage would without a doubt improve the experience of developers working on Cardano based projects. Having a place to store the files needed for their projects would eliminate a lot of time spent searching/implementing storage solution. Both users and developers on Cardano would benefit greatly from a free automatic IPFS pinning service.

The proposer clearly presents its credentials and, taking the 'Comments' attached to this proposal, have also identified current Cardano clients and users of its temporary system (i.e. pool.pm). Their relationship with Emurgo and the Foundation indicates a solid background and proven deliverer of solutions. Providing their url and additional information on ipfs for the newbies also provides additional confidence that they've 'done this before' and can execute the plan.

Blockfrost is already an established company in the Cardano ecosystem, as such the likelihood of the team successfully implementing the scope of this proposal is very high. The budget presented is clear and understandable. The deployment date is outlined, what success looks like is clearly described. The service already exists, the funds from Catalyst would only improve it.
There is a clear picture of the general need and usefulness of the proposal. But it is short on details.
Nice germ of an idea for a defi project. No real detailed plan on how to implement or achieve the goals.

I think there are already too many videos (channels) if someone just types "Cardano" into youtube, so I think marketing would be much more than 2k, to be the most searched, or displayed. 

The time frame is not very detailed, the goal is to "create a channel with news to Cardano and its positive impacts" - I think there is much work that has to be done, to provide a better picture how to achieve it, and how to obtain increased proposers.
Being a video maker is a plus, would have better to know the marketing skills

I did not find any metrics on how to assess efficiency and feasibility. Also, I believe, that having channels or videos as a final product is very tricky. It can definitely help out to reach more people, but we (almost) never know, how much impact it had.
Measuring the success from a youtube channel should have been addressed in the proposal
The problem and the solution are reasonable, the Partner program with Discord would bring relevant improvements to the Discord channel and these improvements would bring value to the onboarding.
Seems a reasonable plan from current discord moderators for a small sum of funds

The proposal is a valid attempt at addressing the challenge with a focus on improved electronic communication. The problem is well defined and there appears to be a high need for improved interface for the community.

The two proposers are moderators on the Discord Catalyst server and are participatory members of the community, having involvement in other proposals for improvements to Catalyst, such as Swarm Sessions and Landing Page development.

The problem is that there is no clear description of the plan to generate the necessary engagement to reach 7000 members and that will be an important factor. The risks of this not being reached in the following 2 Funds were not considered, which would cause the proposal to escape the deadline established in the challenge.

As far as I could understand, this Discord plan can also be achieved with a subscription of $ 150 per month, wouldn't it be more practical to request funding to pay for that subscription until we reach the 7000 member mark on the server?

The experience of the team is strong for the proposal being submitted and this suggests that a successful implementation will follow. The plan seems straightforward and is not excessive in terms of promising to deliver an achievable outcome that will be subject to community interaction and comment.

The link to the discord partnership program they provided states that to be eligible, the server would need 500 members, not 7000 and Catalyst already has more than 1900. Is there another link with those numbers?
The metrics provided are easily verifiable, discord is open to anyone so it would also be easy to monitor their progress.

Despite the simplicity in the purpose of the proposal, there is no reasonable plan for how the server will reach 7000 members in the set time. Objective KPIs have been established. There are no details on budget allocation. I believe that the information described is insufficient to audit the proposal efficiently.

Its not clear the mechanisms for how this will actually drive meaningful participation and how the rewards will be handed out. It would be good to have detail here. Saying that it is a modest request.

Well, the proposer is IdeaScale. I have no doubt that IdeaScale's development team is well-suited to make these improvements successful. I am rating this with (5), even though a bit more precise 'definition of done' and a bit more background info about how this fits into IdeaScales overall release-planning would have been helpful. I am furthermore still lacking answers to questions raised during the feedback-phase: How were/are improvements of IdeaScale funded until now ? What is IOHK and/or the Foundation paying to IdeaScale. Is this something extra, or will that be our new future way of handlIng IdeaScale improvements ? Will we therefore see such proposals repetitively ?
An approximate timeline would have made this proposal even stronger.
The proposal is feasible. It is not well detailed how these modifications meet meet the challenge.
Based on the credentials that Ideascale is hosting Catalyst. It is almost certain that the proposal will be implemented.

I am giving here some special credits to the IdeaScale team. Any other proposer would get a 2 or 3 ranking from me, since - besides the description of the proposed improvements and the total costs - there is not much auditable information added. Knowing that IdeaScale is a professionally working company and knowing that the good relationship with our CATALYST community is very important to them, I accept that we can apply very rudimentary auditing in this case. For future proposals it would nevertheless be very helpful to be more transparent (So that we can be sure that CATALYST proposals are funding specific CATALYST improvements, and are NOT a way to finance general improvements of IdeaScale).

The proposal presents minimal documentation for a protocol as complex as an Insurance AMM. The proposer should consider including a Whitepaper or technical docs describing the protocol mechanism design in detail.
The team have relevant experience in insurance and technology sectors. But the information is quite limited.
There is no basic technical documentation included, no benchmark/KPI to existing insurance protocol and the Budget timeline is lacking any semblance of detail.
This proposal is an interesting concept but needs a lot more than a few 2 minute Medium articles as the technical documentation describing the system in detail.
this proposal provides sufficient information to assess the performance of the product.
Couldn't find any information about the team and its expertise/experience

It would be good to see some information detailing The random number generator to be used and how users can be guaranteed the lottery is conducted fairly. Can the blockchain itself be used here somehow?
The proposed work should help on-boarding new developers and expand Cardano's developer ecosystem.
The proposal is to create templates for this mini-projects, and dedicate funds.  The plan doesn't explain why would voter be interested in reviewing the mini-proposals..
In-depth explanation of a DEX, something that I deem necessary for furthering the Cardano ecosystem and driving adoption.
Detailed proposal, though no clear it as a DApp/integration. It is an exchange which will trade all manner of cryptocurrencies.

To effectively bring more user engagement and increased adoption of cardano blockchain offering all form of financial services through decentralized exchange, the proposals effectively contributes these goals.
Not a lot information about the team. The registration date and contribution by the sole Gitlab organization member does not convey confidence.
The proposed plan to host various financial products is very ambitious. The proposer seems to be optimistic and confident.
Whilst I appreciate the proposers comments around anonymity, this is a very complex project and without more info on who they are it is hard so say they have the ability to pull it off.

I'm not so sure of this, i see a lot of content here but not so much about history and skillset of the team. I didn't see any info on the team. They seem to cover pretty well various outside aspects like marketing, regulation avoidance, and governance.

The request for funding is well-categorized and quite reasonable, but the timeframe the investment will support is unclear.

Similarly, the "definition of success" provides a great framework for implementation and delivery planning, but does not link directly to the funding so it's difficult to measure progress and success.

This is a great approach but needs to be more specific and realistic about delivery milestones for initial phases in order to be able to judge success.  This would be helpful particularly given the very broad and complex nature of the functionality described in the vision.
The proposed project seems to be at the initial research and exploration stage, which poses relatively high risk and potentially high reward.

As mentioned above, the delivery milestones outlined in the "definition of success" are a great starting point for a delivery plan.  It is unclear how these goals relate to the technical delivery elements of the "Roadmap".

The proposal could be more clearly measurable and auditable with more specific and more focused milestones.  The vision is broad and powerful, but will encompass more time and effort to realize than is outlined.  The resources don't clearly match expected outcomes as they are currently described, which reduces confidence in proposal success.  

One way of addressing this could be to focus on the first 12 months with a clear outline of the functionality to be delivered in each phase.
The team seem to be professional and experienced. They have established history of delivery on their works.

The case has not been made how a general viral  comedy targeted at Chile using 40% of this funds capital will make a significant increase in global proposals from outside the Cardano community. More information should be provided on how the campaign will target proposers.
proposal provides enough information how it show be done and it is really feasible with potential growth of Cardano and IdeaScale community, but it is only one-time campaign
The presentation is almost perfect and obviously there is capacity and experience to deliver this project and when necessary get more expertise.
There is a well presented road map and milestones that can be used to track the progress of the project.
There is sufficient information, including updates, to enable auditing of this proposal.

It is indeed important to have a multiplicity of reliable and secure rails for interaction with the legacy financial system. DBS and the Monetary Authority in Singapore are looking at a blockchain ledger agreed by traditional finance participants to manage foreign exchange in Asia and there may be opportunities for example for Cardano and its rails, whether by DEX or other means, to interact with it. It may be worth thinking through particular proposals for use as a currency which your proposal seems to be focused on. It is worth pointing out that there are many blockchains and other networks competing to be financial rails for interaction with the payments system, including all three of the main payment services providers globally, and Cardano may be more likely to be adopted for back-end interoperation and specific use cases than for general retail "front end" payments. That said, partnerships such as that with COTI are interesting and are definitely worth encouraging.
I think so. It is all well organized marketing strategies to sell the awesome benefits of the DID technology in different use case scenarios to the world.
Since this topic is very multi-faceted, the Catalyst community should have the perfect mix of competencies to adress this.
The metrics are quantified, easy to measure, and in alignment with the impact measures of academics (for better or worse).
Most of the metrics are already applied on all standard portals for papers, so the metrics are adequate and measurable.

NFTs are an important feature of any blockchain with smart contracts. NFTs have a wide range of different use cases, from high-value applications such as financial applications and high-value art tokenization to lower-value applications such as in-game items and ticket tokenization.

Cardano is a blockchain that stands out for its great security guarantees due to the functional language and security brought by Plutus, so we will have a promising environment for the tokenization of high-value financial assets. But scalability is also an important point, because although there are several blockchains with great TPS capacity, Cardano has a competitive blockchain and will be even more so with Hydra.

I recommend changing the name of the challenge, I believe it is very simplistic and vague.
Only a part of the devs on the catalyst community will be able to adress this challenge, as it requires in-depth understanding of the functioning of NFTs and smart contracts.

Part of the challenge KPIs are for measuring the success of the challenge, not for measuring the success of the proposals that would be entered in the challenge. I also feel that some of the other metrics are too general for the community to be able to effectively measure them.

Staking and the rewards connected to it are a good mechanism to spread awareness about cardano and teach operators something about the network. In addition to this, the network aims for decentralisation, so this challenge is a good idea. However, since staking usually slso is available without a stake pool in the country of a delegator, this challenge is currently not the most critical issue.

This challenge is fully aligned with the objective of any decentralized public blockchain, especially Cardano due to Cardano's own ethos in promoting decentralization in the protocol's own incentive parameters. One of the essential properties of public blockchains is decentralization and geographic distribution plays a very important role.

Cardano's current trajectory is evidence of organic growth and future mass adoption. Amongst Cardano Ambassadors, Local Community Centers, Community Managers, Cardano Foundation, and development arms of Cardano, the ecosystem has ways to reach global distribution on its own.
The community would definitely encourage diversification of stake pools and bare metal implementation, but it may not be very interested in stake pool promotion with Treasury funds.

It can be seen that a lot of work was put in this proposal in defining success criteria and discussing how to measure success of the project. The challenge proposer made clear that individual propositions would be audible and clear criteria are set for success
The community has the capability to either do this now or attract people who can.
While NFTs are certainly an important part, this challenge reads more as a specific proposal.
Its not clear that the community has the ability to make an art piece that would satisfy the goal.
The metrics are broad to invite for more creativity at the cost of ambiguity.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: It would be good to develop concrete methods and tools to easily measure the proposed indicators.
I believe that the community has people who can teach people in Brazil how a computer works.
If approved, I foresee several proposals by capable developers to be submitted for Fund7 on this challenge.
metrics are very detailed and implemented very well. No objection here.
This sort of thing might be a nice to have but its not clear it is core to Cardano's mission
As this challenge would specifically address current or future proposers in project Catalyst, there shouldn't be a lack of proposals submitted to this category.
The line between operational and other costs in itself is blurry.
These are decent metrics for feedback into the effectiveness or otherwise of Catalyst, as part of the broader picture.
It is important to bring more developers into the ecosystem. Educating new ones is one path.

Catalyst and the broader Cardano community already have started equipping themselves with the tools needed to succeed today. As of right now, several winning proposals are working on creating a central source of information for all willing to challenge themselves and learn new skills.
Diplomas are per se not a great indicator of an educated workforce, but the sentiment is understood.
The diverse background and competencies will enable the community to audit the progress of projects on many different aspects.
The metrics are sharp and captures the essence of the requirement.

The rationale for this is hopefully obvious. The Catalyst and greater Cardano community has showcased positive outreach and bringing people together. This is a more focused effort  of the ongoing work.
The key metrics and criteria are clearly defined and measurable. These metrics are also a good indicator if Cardano adaption in involved communities.
Since this is just allowing one more avenue for collaboration, the community is well positioned to address the challenge.
We have the necessary talent and resources to address this if prioritized.
As this is a complex task and the proposals probably won't reach the measurable criterias then the success will be hard to measure.
Wider use of NFT's as a way of easily access the immutability of the blockchain will provide a real reason for the wider population to interact with Cardano
NFTs on Cardano are very important, but the need to use Cardano as the platform should come more from other incentives (like lower fees for example).
Across the community there is definitely the ability to propose and deliver project which meet this challenge. Every additional NFT use which is useful  can add to the value of the Cardanao ecosystem
For this topic, it is important that strong teams are promoted that combine technical and commercial skills.

There is no technical documentation, metrics or timeline included in the proposal, the author does have prior experience as an IOHK PM but for the budget requested their needs to be more content unpacking the 'how' behind this integration.
proposalTitle: Cardano Support for Point of Sale

assessmentNote: The proposal is for building a web application, mobile app, and integration with Cardano. These will enable the conduct of treasure hunt events. There progress and success of the proposal is not limited to the steps to reach the treasure hunt event. It will be extremely difficult to measure the improvements in dev ecosystem via this proposal.
proposalTitle: Devs for Awarenes Event West Africa

assessmentNote: When joining Ideascale, probably a lot of people don't already have a proposal in mind. Being able to have a database of collaborators that is easy to use and understand will help them find their place faster and together produce high-quality proposals, that themselves would generate interest from other entrepreneurs and bring them to Project Catalyst.
The described escrow App would definetly add a lot of value to the cardano ecosystem. As the Cardano NFT (CNFT) market comes to live there will be a huge demand for an easy and safe escrow service.
An escrow account looks to be one of the missing piece in bridging between fully decentralized ecosystem with commerce that requires physical goods delivery. This proposal address that gap.

The proposer doesn't seem to have the techincal skills to build the DApp. Thus it is hard to state it will be successfully delivered as the technical path has not been laid out. It would be good to inlude recrd keeping of donation amounts (and recording ADA value in FIAT on the date of donation) to allow for tax reporting in countries where donations are tax deductible. This may also required choice of registered entities by reporting countries for eligibility.
I quite like your idea and its not an overly complicated task. There is certainly a need for a calendar that highlights all dates but I do think it would need constant updating as dates will change.

Given the experience stated, the plan provided and the resource links viewed I am confident that this team could deliver on this proposal. My one query might be in relation to synchronisation with the IOG team(s).

This is both feasible and addresses the challenge effectively. People need clear information to understand how and when they can get involved. The impact per Ada spent on this could be great for Catalyst.

The team has a rough roadmap in place and project updates captured, but an additional place to state target milestones/deliverables would help create additional auditability metrics.   Basic KPIs/Metrics would help to measure the velocity and completion of the project as well.

The team that intends to develop the project is presented in a complete way. All members have an attached profile, where we can learn more about their professional trajectories. In addition, there are several attached media, which show us how the project is already structured and how the team has complete control over it. In this way, it is very safe how the project is in good hands to be carried out.

Although a great deal of specific information is provided in the proposal, much of that is background information about capabilities that the proposal would leverage. For the proposed proof of concept, quantifiable metrics for auditing progress and assessing successful completion are somewhat lacking.

Something like this would be a good idea. Improving the formatting and categorisation of proposals would aid community engagement in the reviewing and voting side, and also help proposers find and collaborate with similar proposals.

The idea is good and it would make it easier to understand the teams involved in proposals and also to find related proposals. The improvement of aggregating several proposals that are related to the same problem is somehow limited since there is a small number of projects that would benefit from it. Categories already are a good way to classify proposals, but I agree that some more classification inside each challenge would be even better.

I think this proposal will help to circumvent some of the inherent weaknesses of Ideascale in terms of proposal presentation and also of accountability of proposers. Furthermore, Community Advisors need a way of following up easily on proposals that are part of a package of proposals that were submitted by proposers - and this new website that is in the works could be just the tool to complement Ideascale. 

I think this project could deliver on the task of informing and directing new participants towards increased and better contributions that will ultimately improve Catalyst's ROI.

More transparency, more abilities to scrutinize and develop a proposer's ability to deliver and complete projects will help the ecosystem. I like it. This could become one of the go-to places for in-depth views of proposals and their background teams that are working on them.

The deadline for implementation of the project is clear, steps and milestones are included as well, and there are some success metrics that are good but could be improved, like the % of proposers that actually use the platform to improve their visibility and ideas, and the number of proposals using the website that actually got funded.

The identified problem has already started to manifest in Project Catalyst and if not addressed sooner rather than later it could become unmanageable or much harder to address. This is a prime example of members of the community actively trying to improve the decision making process for the whole Catalyst community.

Yes, this is highly needed. It is difficult at the moment to know what the previous projects that got funded are doing and where to find information about them. Also for accountability this is important. We want to give funds to the people actually improving the ecosystem and helping other entrepreneurs build their products later on.

I do like the idea of the team be diverse and experienced in their areas. The budget is well structured, taking into account even the hours of work per week (which is not a common thing we see here).
It was not clear to me the method they will use if the project scales up, meaning that how they are going to allocate all the data needed to provide all the information that they intend. Maybe include this in the proposal will make it more credible.

There is clarity in the problem and the solution described. The proposal is in line with the challenge.

There is a detailed plan, there is an objective timeline, success metrics and details on budget allocation.

No KPIs have been described. I recommend the inclusion of links to Linkedin for all members, so that the community has access to more information from the proposers in a transparent way.

It is very clear what they are aiming and since it's an open platform, meaning that will be lots of users, it will be easy to verify if they're complying. Another thing is that there are already tracking their development, which is good.
I think it might help if you use as matric the, hopefully, increasing number of successful projects along the time – since the aim of this idea is to create a better environment for decision making and a credible place for proposers extract information and better develop their ideas.

There is a definite need for more visibility in the music industry which your proposal addresses and has some solid ideas to benefit everyone involved. You clearly need to develop this idea further which I will explain in the next two notes. Also, I think you should consider how NFT development for artists can be incorporated in the next proposal.

Developing an app for live music events, where crews and musicians would be paid through the Cardano blockchain could prove beneficial for the ecosystem. But the proposal is too short and not too descriptive, so it would be hard to say exactly how it would turn out and whether it would pull in more adoption

Certainly the proposal addresses the challenge and received good interaction with the community. There may be some proposals already in progress but it is difficult to gauge where they are up to in development so in no way does that rule out this proposal. I would highly recommend that the author continue to research collaborations with others in the CP community to look for potential niche areas and/or team forming to go forward.
Industry experience is there, which is very good. However no requirements and no implementation team yet. This gives me low confidence in success.

There is no detailed plan and the proposers does not have the technical knowledge to build it. It is unlikely it would be successful without at least first developing a detailed plan and budget with milestones

The proposer has music industry experience but would depend on finding a team to complete the project. Not a lot of thought has been given to the technical aspects of the application or the marketing strategy. I think the proposal would appear more feasible if there was an assembled team, some defined goals, and a strategy for gaining traction in the industry.

The proposer described experience in the music industry, but the execution of this project requires developers, but there is no detail on how many developers will be needed and their expertise.

To evaluate the feasibility of the proposal, a solid plan is needed. How was the budget defined? There is no detail or rationale to justify a budget of $ 100,000.

I recommend detailing the plan and including the items mentioned in the Catalyst documentation.

Your 20-30 years of experience would certainly be beneficial as would the connections to famous rock stars, but the details for this proposal are lacking. I need to see a clear cost analysis of how that 100k will be spent. This is a major undertaking with the possibility to introduce Cardano to a major market. I believe waiting for smart contracts to be deployed will be critical for this proposal to be implemented successfully.

The author is able to carry out the project in terms of music, as he has worked with it before. Having a command of how the relationships in question work is fundamental. However, it would be beneficial if the author showed himself with the intention of forming a team with both programming professionals, designers and people specialized in transactions via ADA to complete his project, since he does not appear to have experience in this part. So, not a lot of security is passed in relation to a whole about realizing the idea, unfortunately.

The author has excellent music industry experience but admits he will require developers to bring the Dapp to fruition. This needs to be further along to receive a higher score for planning. The budget lacks any real detail so difficult to assess how the budget will be spent.

The proposer claims to have 30 years experience in music industry as tour manager and in other roles. The proposer is having limited experience in managing software development and will require a team to handle the same. No verifiable credentials of the proposer in this respect are enclosed in the proposal .
While music industry experience would be valuable in gaining attention after the DApp is completed, I see no experience in writing code at all or any plan to hire the needed help.

No requirements, but a platform is promised within 12 months. No success criteria either. It would probably be advisable to split the project in phases and do the requirements gathering first. Success criteria would then be whether the subsequent design and build phases get funding.

a large amount is requested and there is no breakdown of fund allocation into steps or checkpoints. There are no specific goals proposed except a vague "product in 12 months". I dont see any way to audit this project or have confidence that Catalyst funds are used successfully.

I fully agree the need and benefit of live music, but developing the platform vaguely described as "Uber for music" is not enough. People have developed a fear of crowds and many venues will have to adjust to this new normal. A focus on outdoor venues should be considered. Please continue to make connections and learn more about the DApp creation framework so you can provide more details if you submit another proposal. I need to see clear goals for 3, 6, 9 months in and can not just rely on a 12 month development window.

There is practically no information on how the idea would develop in practice, because there is no action plan for the text the author wrote. There is no division of parts, a plan of goals for a certain period of time, an explanation regarding how the money would be divided and used (this is quoted in a very vague way)… We only know that the intention is to create a unique token for the transactions in question, but it is not enough to establish a sense of how the project would come true, unfortunately.

The proposal certainly received positive contributions from the community however, there is a lack of real detail to the information supplied. While it seems valid to suggest there is a need for such a Dapp in the music industry, it was unclear whether this proposal is the answer at this stage. I would recommend further refinement of the proposal with emphasis on collaboration, team building and better budget description.

Monitoring the development of applications is possible.  However, the proposal has limited information on how the development will be carried out. The proposer will be dependent on a team to come up for building the application, likely

For the amount of money being asked for, much more information is needed to justify this price point. With the given  information, I do not see this proposal coming to light in 12 months. Even if a UI and basic DApp was created in the time, I still do not have confidence based on the available information and cannot recommend this project.

The problem and description are within the scope of the challenge. The proposal is intended to guide interested people throughout the entire process, from attracting interested people, to creating proposals or registering new members as voters or proposers. So I believe that the proposal has great potential to impact the challenge.

The proposal addresses several improvement points for the Catalyst on-boarding phase. The need for direct communication, mentoring, if done right can lead to a clear upgrade for both the proposers and the proposals.

The proposer is already a member of the Catalyst community and is involved in some important projects and implementations, such as contributing as an organizer and facilitator of Catalyst retro sessions, participation in Swarm Sessions, as well as having other proposals for improvements in Catalyst.

I recommend including more details in the bio, so that the community has access to knowledge / expertise in an easy and transparent way.

There is a rationale for how the proposal will cause an increase value onboarding.

There is no budget breakdown. The funds will be distributed to a treasury and will be distributed to reward contributors manually (in principle), in addition different funding models will be explored in order to make the treasury self sustainable. I recommend including some structure / criteria / rationale for contributions, because without a solid model, dependence on trust would be high.

There is no timeline described in the proposal and this makes it difficult to understand the budget x time relationship.

Although in this proposal the author did not give evidence of skills, I do believe it may be feasible due to his previous experience in the challenge.
However, I have lots of doubts accounting the budget: how it would be distributed; if it's stated that a self-sustained environment needs to reward who is willing to help, how much it would really make a difference to the dedication; if the project scale, how the project will pay everybody; how it will re-monetize itself; etc.
Maybe adding a more detailed plain, actually explaining all the steps would be of a great value to this idea.

The proposer's experience as a long-time member of the Catalyst Advisor community is what must have led to the genesis of this project. He structured his proposal into 3 main points and all have been described in detail. My only question regarding the proposal is: if we reward people for the number of recruitment, how do we incentivise quality over quantity? Maybe implementing a system similar to the referral program in Catalyst, where only the funded proposals get the incentive?

The problem, solution and proposal described are clear and address the challenge.

There is no roadmap, no milestones, no metrics, no KPIs.

There is no budget breakdown, it must be emphasized that the idea is that the entire budget is allocated to a treasury and that this will be distributed for contributions, but I think it is important to describe some rationale for the criteria for the distribution of these resources or perhaps the disclosure of expenses. Some model that allows auditability.

I believe that the proposal has great potential, but needs further refinement to indicate auditability.

In order to be auditable, it should add a detailed roadmap, some metrics which contain the growing number of participants, some sort of verification of relevance (since the platform is paying in advance, should be some fraud method), etc.

The on-boarding process is properly described, yet there are not enough metrics or information that would help the community measure the impact of the proposal. The proposer doesn't require any funds for this initiative, all the money will go into a treasury, that will be used for the rewarding of the volunteers. Yet, how will the contribution of each member be measured in order for him to be rewarded? Will it be a pay-per-participant, pay-per-proposer, pay-per-successfully funded participant etc? What if a CA spends a lot of time with a person, that eventually doesn't sign up, will his contribution be taken into consideration?

The project ask for funds that it will then decide on how to disburse to "meaningful participation and contributions". A plan should be provided on how this will be done and governance around it. Otherwise it risks corruption.

Since this proposal has a general and broad idea so far, and the details are not so clear, the auditability of it is somehow prejudiced. Some metrics should be included, like estimation of people onboarded in a defined period, number of veterans participating, mentors commited to the program. Since there are no concrete plan so far, it is not possible to audit the proposal properly if it's funded.

The theme of the proposal certainly is about improving distributed decision making but the how, where and by whom are very unclear. There are definitely some good thoughts presented in the proposal but a plan to turn them into actionable items is for the most part lacking.
The proposers have the experience the to deliver, however the plan lacks concrete deliverables thus successful implementation is hard to judge.

It's very hard to judge the experience of the proposer as no reference point is provided. As for the successful implementation of the project it's hard to judge what the project will actually attempt. There are hints at some actions like fostering collaboration and research, but not an actual plan or auditable metrics.

The proposal does not contain any milestones or success criteria. Some good questions are asked but no path is shown how the proposed project might answer them, other than curating unspecified onboarding materials and compensating people for unspecified contributions.

Without a detailed plan and the fact the proposers intend to hire developers, it is hard to say that they are likely to be successful. Please provide a detailed plan with budget and milestones breakdown.
proposalTitle: NFT for each CARDANO Smart Contract

assessmentNote: The information presented lacks a detailed action plan. The burden of development is shifted as the proposer appears to manage funds. The requested amount was significantly reduced, but does not detail the work that is required to achieve success.
proposalTitle: NFT for each CARDANO Smart Contract

assessmentNote: The proposers are planning to hire developers to implement the project. The proposal involves adding code to Marlow's backend and is likely to a complicated process. Therefore there is a high risk in implementing the project.
proposalTitle: NFT for each CARDANO Smart Contract

assessmentNote: While the proposers are professional and enthusiastic, It seems as if they lack a technical understanding of what their proposed implementation would entail.  This makes estimating the costs of the project difficult, and it is unknown if they will find enthusiastic developers willing to work with them. I'm worried that the project would never get off the ground.
proposalTitle: NFT for each CARDANO Smart Contract

assessmentNote:
The way I understand this, the goal is to assign property rights to financial contracts created with Marlowe by means of an NFT. However, it is not specified what owning a smart contract even means. Is is the IP related to the source code or is it related to each deployment? What rights or permissions does the owner of a smart contract NFT have that others don't? Does the NFT somehow allow to control who can  or cannot use a contract?
How are these NFTs intended to be used?
Besides the fuzzy problem description the proposal does not say how the requested funds will be used and what the deliverables are.
proposalTitle: NFT for each CARDANO Smart Contract

assessmentNote: The 10k requested would cover the conception of the product and the hiring of developers. Since the proposers do not show a clear technical roadmap, I wonder how they can estimate the costs of the project. I suggest a smaller proposal in a future catalyst round focused on researching the use case to see if it is technically feasible and if the community sees is as a valuable addition to Marlowe.
proposalTitle: NFT for each CARDANO Smart Contract

assessmentNote: The proposal addresses the Developer ecosystem challenge and also supports one of the supposed in-demand DApp requests (i.e. NFTs). Having a guaranteed store and showing interoperability between Cardano and Filecoin is a positive.

Having an additional layer of back-up would certainly add value to the Cardano ecosystem as a whole. However I fail to see how it addresses the challenge of improving the experience of and creating a more appealing environment for developers on Cardano. Perhaps a future version of this proposal could be placed in a different category or adapted to more specifically address the needs of devs. I understand that devs, too would in a way benefit from improved storage options but it doesn't seem to address their needs specifically.

The proposal attempts to solve a problem associated principally with transfer and ownership of NFTs, not their development. 

The proposal identifies a potential data loss problem for NFTs that maintain off-chain assets on the Interplanetary File System (IPFS). 

The proposer correctly points out that an NFT can suffer data loss if the owner does not "pin" an IPFS object to guarantee its persistence as required by the protocol.

To combat this problem, a software solution is proposed that will migrate IPFS objects referenced in an NFT to the Filecoin network, manage payment and storage parameters for the objects on the Filecoin network,  and act as a host for "robust" retrieval of the objects.

Both the IPFS and Filecoin community have developed products and services, for audiences of varying sophistication, that guarantee storage and delivery of IPFS objects according to a policy such as Lotus, Powergate, Starling, Slate, Pinata, Infura,  etc. The proposal does not explain and it is not apparent how the proposed "in-scope" solution is different from these existing solutions or will materially reduce the cost or complexity of NFT development in additional ways. 

For these reasons, the proposal does not effectively address the challenge of improving the developer ecosystem of Cardano. 

This proposal may benefit from being recategorized and focused to deal with the problems of owners, purchasers, and resellers of NFTs.   A tool that identifies risks or problems with a particular NFTs integrity and potentially offers advice for the mitigation or resolution of these issues may be valuable to a less technical audience.

The idea is good, it addresses a real problem and it is a good application of the blockchain technology. I would suggest that this was created as generally as possible (I believe it will be done like that) to make it easier to migrate to a future solution of decentralized data storage in the Cardano blockchain, and also it would be good to pay attention to the scalability of this solution since it might need to store tons of data. Besides that, I believe it is a very good solution.

The proposer seems to have studied the problem of decentralised storage in detail and was able to provide adequate answers to all the questions placed by the community in the comments and seems very knowledgeable about the problem he is attempting to solve. Would have like to see more info about the proposers background and links to credentials and previous works and I would suggest including these in future iterations or future proposals.

The proposer does not describe their development experience with the Cardano, IPFS, or Filecoin ecosystems such that a judgment can be made whether or not the project can be completed successfully.

The proposal does not outline the challenges likely to be encountered during development so that the risk of not completing can be assessed.

The plan does not adequately explain why a "naive" implementation is useful to the realization of the "robust" final deliverable.

The plan does not lay out why the "robust" solution is a reasonable or necessary step to achieve the ideal oracle-based solution proposed for later funds.

The ideal oracle-based solution is not described in enough detail that its efficacy or relative worth can be evaluated.

The proposal alludes to the addition of smart contracts in future funds but does not explain how they can improve the solution.

The plan doesn't explain why it is necessary to purchase Fil tokens or how they will be used in the deliverable for this fund.

No discussion of the ongoing NFT standardization efforts is mentioned or accounted for in the plan.

Without an accounting of the direct or indirect experience of the proposer with the protocols in question or a more detailed plan for the evolution of the final solution, the likelihood of successful completion cannot be assesed.

In the future I would suggest the inclusion of an estimated implementation start date for the project and expected delivery date. The number of hours required, but a clear roadmap isn't given. Those hours could be spend 1/day or 10/day, without a clear roadmap it's hard to judge. Even if the project would be for a one-man coding operation an assessment of risks should have been made. However it would be relatively easy to verify the progress and deployment of a functional MVP.

The proposal has presented two simple and clear aims of creating a centralized bridge followed by a load-balanced revival of file coin object through public IFPS. The progress is clearly auditable, and its utilization will provide a measure of its success. 
The bridge will be open source and every user will be host it to pay for the gas fee in the filecoin network/

The steps of this development are clear, and this could also be considered as milestones of the roadmap. Although, I believe that the proposal needs to include some information about KPIs and key metrics in order to properly measure its success. And also to include some dates related to each step (or deliverable). Some scaling challenges should also be considered, and the cost of transactions between Filecoin and Cardano should be assessed as a possible risk, for examples. Other risks of creating such a bridge should be discussed.

The NFT minting has so far been the user-oriented process in an ad-hoc manner leading to many policy errors. The proposal aims to develop a reminting service and also a platform for multi-owner NFTs. With the demand for NFTs growing this kind of service is required to create competition and further innovation.

I would suggest including a clearer background for the proposer in a future version of the proposal with links to previous works. Being a member of the Plutus Pioneers program would certainly help the proposer stand out if proof of this would have been provided. Phase 1 is mentioned in the budget breakdown, but a clear roadmap isn't provided of all the phases envisioned and how they would play out. The budget is pretty clear and the implementation seems relatively straight forward.

The proposal lacks an estimated implementation date for the project or an expected delivery date. Phase 1 is mentioned but it isn't indicated what the deliverables of this Phase 1 would be. The proposal lacks a clear roadmap, and an outline of any sort of what the next phases would consist of. No assessment of risks is made. I would suggest including all these elements in a future version of the proposal.

The proposal is very positive for the inhabitants of South Africa, because, according to the data provided, this project could help to overcome this lack of access to the internet. In terms of novelty and adequacy requirements, the proposal is very creative and uses pre-existing means to exercise your idea, which is a very positive point. However, the author did not specify how he would give the project's feedback to the Cardano community, which would also be interesting.

The idea of providing free WiFi in cabs with a caveat that the user will go through a Cardano advertising app might be a workable solution. The cost for running this enterprise is proposed to be subsidized by running a "fun with electronics" shop. The idea is workable and can improve the awareness and utilization of Cardano.

it is very difficult to understand what the proposer is actually proposing. There is the shop for Cardano Open Source Store. In the comment it is mentioned, that the requested fund is for this store. The proposal does state, that the funds are for wifi for minibus taxis. And also something about nfts for art is mentioned. Each of these aspects may provide some value but it not clear what this proposal is specifically about

This proposal has wifi in mini bus taxis as the title but the proposal includes information about NFTs and grade 7 robotics without making clear what the connection to the wifi project is. The routers concept does seem to address the challenge of growing Cardano in Africa but the details of how are very unclear in the writing. The proposal does not tell us key metrics and goals nor how they will scale to address future challenges. I do like the idea but cannot award higher points due to lack of detailed plan.

The proposal is wordy and lacks focus. The initial free wifi idea evolves into something totally different so it seems like two proposals in one. They also note a launch date 4-6 weeks after funding, which seems unrealistic.  I think the team needs to spend more time refining their ideas before they will appear feasible.

The proposer claims to have sufficient experiance and seems to be associated with WADA. However it is not clearly emerging from the proposal. The project requires a ground presence on a continuous basis and has huge implementation risk. The identity and motivation of the implementor will decide the outcome of the proposal.

There is a massive potential for Cardano in South Africa, but this proposal needs further development in terms of feasibility. This proposal lack details on proposer's team experience, team skills, and Project plan

There is a budget outlined. The proposer states that the project could be profitable within 6 months but there is no rational, break-even analysis or evidence for us to verify the claim. It is unclear what the risks are for starting this business in South Africa (are there bureaucratic or business challenges to be aware of? why does the project need to open a brick and mortar shop?). The timetable provided is vague: only 4-6 weeks and 6 months offered within the writing.

The author describes in detail how access to the internet would be given, through an application with which it would be possible to establish the connection when riding in vehicles. He also explains what the application would be like, its content and the languages available. The proposal details the cost of each stage of the project's implementation: the cost of objects such as the router, services with installation, marketing ... It also considers the large circulation of minibuses as an existing factor, so the author took into account consideration the implementation part already during the elaboration of the idea. However, there is a shortage in relation to the description of the people involved and deadlines to be met (I identified some information about it, but little). Including more details about the actions of the project, just as it was detailed very well about the costs, would be beneficial.

funds are allocated to certain purposes, the timeframe and costs are vague. Launch is expected in 6 weeks, but the physical location is rented for 6 months. The cost of routers and 4g service do not appear to be included in this breakdown.  I suggest the proposers work on a more focused and limited proposal/proposals in future rounds. Small pilots and proofs of concepts will go a long way to securing more funding for expansion in future rounds.

The success of the proposal is implicit. The implementation is auditable by monitoring how many taxies are fitted with the Cardano router and the progress in establishing the shop. However, it isn't easy to establish clearly whether the initiative is successful. Sucess of the shop may or may not indicate impetus to the adaptation of Cardano in the region.

There is a basic breakdown of costs but no definition of success or possible KPIs that can be applied. For each of the listed projects it would be relatively easy to find corresponding milestones or KPIs. e.g.: Number of minibuses equipped with wifi. Prototype for Cardano Connect app created etc. If the propsal does not clearly specify which aspects are to be tracked exactly, this is also a big problem for checking the achievement of the objectives.

This proposal lack a roadmap therefore making the project hard to audit for progress. Please develop a step by step action plan.  When you receive fund what will be your first step? and after 3, 6, or 12 month where will the project be?  When will this proposal be completed?
The proposal lacks a detailed roadmap and key metrics that would provide auditability. We have no way of knowing if the project is successful based on information given.

There is no clarity in the problem described in the problem statement, I recommend making this definition clearer.

The concept described is within the scope of the challenge, but the absence of a detailed plan, metrics and goals makes it impossible to indicate impact on the challenge.

I recommend that the proposal be more detailed so that we can give appropriate feedback.

The development of the app started 6 years ago and it couldn't find adoption so there is no guarantee this is going to change after funding the proposal. I think it would help as well if the team or the proposer would be introduced. Then apparently the app is already finished or almost finished. 200k is a huge budget. I think it would help if the proposer would add a more detailed budget to the proposal the next time.

The proposer has created the app and had launched it. He must be having the required technical capability. However, the proposal's scale and scope are huge and will require a strong multifaced team to handle the expansion. There is limited information and a plan for role out of the project.

There is no plan. There is no information about the team (nor links) that indicate the feasibility and aptitude of executing the proposal. There is no budget breakdown.

It looks like the project (app) has been in development since 2015, but there are no details.


This proposal is a draft and has the potential to be a dapp in line with the challenge, but it is important to provide a detailed plan, I recommend following the Catalyst documentation to elaborate the proposal.

There is a need for a plan and team composition. There time plan and roadmap for implementation also required to be deliberate. Being a high valued project, these details will add clarity and audibility.
There is no information that allows auditability. It would be important do include details about metrics, roadmap, KPIs, budget breakdown, following the Catalyst docs.

The proposer's experience is very relevant as there is 20+ years as a software developer stated. It is not entirely clear if the proposer is intending to develop this on his own or with the help of a team. The requested fund only reflects a wage of software developer pegged to US standards. Which implies that the intent is to indeed develop this solo, however in the comments section it is stated that the author owns a software company. If it is the case that the intent is that this company develops it, it should be included in the proposal. It also raises the question as to how the initial server would be paid for.

The proposal is well detailed and displays some technical understanding of the requirements. The proposer participated in community discussion. The proposer seems qualified and motivated but I would like to see some additional team members with blockchain experience. The NTF-DAO has a similar project and I think I would prefer to see that team working on this problem with their technical expertise and vision of standardization.

This is a big proposal to fund several local hubs in different countries in West Africa. I strongly agree that the infrastructure provided by the hubs once they are up and running are very important for further operations in the region. It's a great start and has the potential to have a big impact by providing local presence to easier reach out to local developers, among others and educate about Cardano, all clearly stated in the roadmap of the proposal.

This proposal builds further on an approved project from Fund2. 
Providing infrastructure in previously installed hubs is essential as otherwise it would impede the functionality of those hubs and render them somewhat obsolete. So it is important that an approved project continues to receive support until it is self-sustainable. 
In a fund challenge that is specifically dedicated to seed and grow Cardano in Africa, the creating and sustaining of hubs to reach out to the local public is mission critical and can be used as a foundation for further operations in the future.

Yes it does but I'm scoring it a 4 star based on the rationale that it seems to be more centered on the Western side of Africa, what then would happen to the Eastern, Southern and Northern?
If this proposal is funded, I'm not sure will be able to extend itself to these other regions in the sense that the budget stated, ie, 125,695$ wouldn't be enough! However, if it's of the intent to tackle one region and making sure that it's yielding a better results before attending to other regions then the proposal is on coarse. 
I'm saying this because, West Africa has the most weird and hypocritical countries ever when we talk about Technological Advancement. And this is so because, leaders operating in various countries like Ghana, Nigeria, Cameroon, Togo and many others are just corrupt and continues to be corrupt with no remorse.  
Instead, the citizens are much enthusiastic about Technological Advancement and Development but their barrier is that they're not getting the opportunity to meet corporate organizations who's got this passion and mission of training people to becoming developers! And the painful aspect is, these corrupt leaders turn deaf ears to their demands as citizens too. If this project attacks from the root "citizens" and provide strong education to the leaders in order for to understand, it will be wise as once they're enlightened, it will be easy for adoption, acceptance and adjustments.
Also, cost of infrastructure is one blow to the eye. Office spaces which are just for rent (unfurnished) could cost more than 10,000$ for just two years and and furnishing alone could cost sometimes more than 5,000$. Imagine if 10 countries/hubs are to be created simultaneously, each hub might consume not less than 30,000$. So 125,695$ wouldn't be enough right?
This proposal addressed the issue of legitimacy. I'll commend that approach but my only advice is, they should be extra vigilant in carrying out that exercise else they might end up spending more than supposed to. This is so because, once setting up of new agency is involved, whether profitable or non-profitable, several institutions will approach trying to you know get a cut of the cake. In Ghana for instance, the only institution to receive a legit certification and approval is the Office of the Attorney General. Further research must be done vigilantly to ensure smooth operation.

This proposal, I recommend that it be voted for! It will be fantastic to see their operations.

When it comes to auditability, this proposal has a clear roadmap and a vision of what success looks like. The funding requested covers the first 3 months of the provided roadmap, which is to get the hubs set up and started. The budget for the different hubs, which is provided in a separate document, is detailed, so it will be easy to audit. The team has also clearly stated that they are aware of the risks like the final costs being different or rather higher than anticipated and have a plan on how to correctly prioritize the funds to get working hubs if that's the case. The challenge metrics are also very relevant for this proposal and I don't think it will be difficult for them to provide the numbers of how many people are engaged with the different hubs once they have gotten started.

A few metrics appear throughout the proposal but there is not a clear set of KPIs to assess. Even without the KPIs there is a road map and a clear plan to expand WADA and to add to the Cardano space. This proposal allows for us to accept that we cannot predict the specific projects that will come out of the work, the same way that in 2000 we could not predict the dominance the iPhone would eventually have in the world today.

The proposal has identified a suitable problem and somewhat effectively addresses the challenge but appears incomplete in terms of planning and design at this stage. Further development of the proposal will likely have positive results.

First of all, this is an excellent idea in general. Though this may not specifically target Cardano development echosystem, I suppose there´s where the adoption will begin. One risk would be that this could incentivize contributor behavior that is not optimal for the supported project.

Sufficient information was provided but I still had some questions not fully answered. The links provided did not always work and I just felt further work to tease out the proposal will deliver a much more polished application. I feel further technical collaboration would benefit at this stage.
The proposer should give more information to back up the case of how this proposal addresses the challenge. How does it help the developer focus on building successful apps?
The proposal contains most essential parts, what could make it even better is to add a set of deliverables and a rough timeplan.

This project perfectly adresses the challenge to grow Cardano in Africa, as it brings double benefits: Benefiting local community, fixing some of their serious problems, bringing wealth and adding a new blockchain to the cardano ecosystem.

This proposal is the full package. From solid waste to solid value. The complex mix of accounting operations involved requires a lot of trust in order to ensure that everyone involved is a good actor and block chain will address this concern.

The proposal is bold but provides and use case of Cardano as a add on. However there are very  strong reason for funding the biggest being the effect on climate. Cardano is planning to have a substantial presence in Ethiopia and this project can be a valuable add on.

The idea of sanitation microfarming has a lot of value, and the integration with Cardano seems like an interesting use case. However there are many unknowns about the project, and the scale on the non-blockchain aspects are so large, that I worry the project will stall before the blockchain is implemented and has the intended effect on Cardano adoption in Africa.

As a process engineer who already knows the excellent feasibility and flexibility of black soldier flies for similar purposes, I am amazed of the concept and think indeed it is technologically feasible. Storing information on the revenue on a blockchain should not be a problem either. I very much hope this project is funded, as it will provide a lot of great benefits.

The team behind this proposal has a wide range of impressive experience listed and they do a great job of mapping out the steps. Having a famous film maker like Bill Duke promoting this project increases the chances of success. The timeline is clear and seems realistic on the manual labor and logistics, but is more vague on the technical (Khepera coin, smart contracts, and NFT system). Great idea, great team, and clear roadmap to success!

The team has clearly spent many hours working on this project. The scope of work, plan, and timeline all have been identified. The risky bits are with the block chain implementation and how to provide authentic data into the block chain but this will be addressed with the funding and hiring IOHK. beyond that, there is always some risk involved with complex systems like these.

One of the most documented proposals in this challenge. The people behind it are experienced and driven to make the project happen. The attachments offer great insight into their ideas and demonstrate the needs and benefits, while also adding value to the Cardano blockchain.

The proposer claims indepth experiance in the field and the team has diversified members. The revenue generation for sustainable and commitment to return the investment are unique. The project has only the risk of technical challenges on the bio side. If we accept the claim that the prototype is already a success there is very good chance the project will succeeded.

The blockchain aspects of this proposal are still a little vague. It is mentioned that with the 150k initial funding after 12 months of operation they will return 300k profit back into the fund. Why not just get started if this business is going to be so profitable? It's not hard to find people who want to double their money. The proposal mentions "creation of blockchain assets: Khepera coin, smart contracts, product proof NFT system and integration with payment services to receive and fiat and turn local currency into crypto currency" and doesn't do enough to breakdown the technical aspects. I think waiting for those details will make this proposal more realistic in Fund 6 or Fund 7 or once Alonzo is deployed and smart contracts are live. This is going to be huge for rural Africa and I hope Cardano does not miss out, but it seems waiting for details on smart contracts is necessary.

This proposal offers a DEX as a launchpad for a token's IDO to help new projects acquire liquidity in their early stages. Which is a good idea if performed correctly. Unfortunately there is no plan on how to realise this.

The problem description makes sense and is reasonable. The proposal for a Launchpad + DEX is within the requirements for this challenge, however the absence of goals and metrics makes it impossible to assess the impact of the proposal in this challenge. In addition, the plan presented(attached file) is only a draft and doesn't describe enough details for the implementation of the proposal, which makes impact assessment difficult.

The proposal claims to offer a inclusive, transparent, secure solution. However, no technical/other measures to ensure security and fairness are proposed. In DEX and another token presale, the importance of security is of primary importance.

From the information provided, this proposal seems in the early stage of ideation: from the commercial slides available (the only attached document) it seems they want to compete with Catalyst. They want to do many great things but they never say how so as it is now, this proposal is just an idea without any concrete path to reality. If they could achieve all their claims it would have a very positive impact for sure but the team needs to go way further than providing a promotional slide deck to get seriously considered for funding.

There is no team mentioned to determine if they are up for the task other than very vague functions without proof. There is mention of an 'inclusive, transparent, secure solution', yet not elaborated to clarify what this solution might be. The plan to conceive all this is not present in the proposal other than a rudimentary roadmap. To improve this, the proposal should contain that information.

The proposal is very minimal, and the litepaper posted with it only gives a couple of short sentences and keywords, some of which are open to interpretation. Some research of the proposers is possible, however they don't seem to have the skills to realize such a project. Some research showed that they are trying to hire for the project, which is something that should be communicated transparently in the proposal.

A lot of experience is claimed but there is no external links to back this experience (LinkedIn, GitHub, etc...). The budget is not explained at all, there is no cost breakdown. No technical specification. We know their intent but we don't know if they can nor how they plan to do it...
Their website gives a little bit more information: you can find the LinkedIn profile of the company (VentFinance) and the profiles of its founders which do corroborate the claimed experience while this prevent a 1 star rating in this category, the lack of technical details prevents me from going beyond a score of 2. The team needs to provide concrete technical information and a detailed plan so we can see if it actually makes sense on the technical side (reality).

There is simply not enough information present in the proposal to properly asses it. 
The project has a great website containing lots of information, but sadly it is not included in the proposal. Nor is critical information, like a funding breakdown and risk assessment from that website mentioned. It needs some work to make clear to the community what this project is all about. You have the material, just including it would greatly increase the quality of this proposal.

The only audit information described is a roadmap, where it is defined:

-Token sale and Launch of the MVP on the Ethereum blockchain in Q2.
-New Functionality Release and Migration to Cardano in Q3
-Release of Ventup 2.0 and Beta-Release VentSwap in Q4

This roadmap is extremely subjective, as it describes the delivery of a DEX that has no plan in detail, an MVP on another blockchain that is totally against the interests of the Cardano community (what is the purpose of Cardano's treasury in financing the development of a project which will be launched on Ethereum? I don't believe this is positive for Cardano, but it is not clear whether this is included in the budget for this proposal (there was no budget allocation details) or is just an item that is already being developed and will be funded otherwise.

I recommend that the team clarify the point mentioned above and describe a plan according to the Catalyst documentation.
