Cardano would benefit because it would be used as a means of transactions; in this way, both the community and a problem involving metadata would benefit.

It would be useful to know how many people each of the 6 centers could actually help. Also what is the plan for these centers after the initial 3 months? Will this program require more Catalyst funding, or do we risk it collapsing and leaving people stranded?

The requested budget is steep, but the attached documents justify the amount. The budget size is intended to fund 7 hubs, which translates to ~17 956 USD/hub. 
What is missing to place a context around this is how many participants these hubs are designed to accomodate. 
Furthermore there is a very short mention of the infrastructure being needed to support stake pool operations. Which raises the question as to how long it is projected for this project to be support independent.

Biggest issue, which is mentioned, is how to mange costs when saving new passwords. This can happen very regularly. If not backup then user may loose local copy. If backed up everytime a password is updated this could very quickly become more expensive. Is there an ability to batch users updates offchain?
Security very important here. This will become a target. Please provide evidence of security programming exereince.

The 'problem statement' is not well written because it does not really state a problem, but a part of the solution. It would be better to start with "The lack of a […].", it would be easier to understand at first.
The idea of this project is very good. It brings what the Catalyst Project is about – a platform made by the community to the community. It is a very good project. It brings the idea that with better education and organization you can improve the decision making (enhancing individual capacity you make the group better), however this is not clear.
However, I did miss two things: first, I think that would help newcomers, like me, if the team had put some link about the fund4 project; second, I missed with some KPI and to know exactly where you want to reach with this proposal, what do you expect to see as a result and what it would bring to the community or how it would help with the challenge stated.

I fully support this proposal, since it touches a major pain point of the CATALYST community (especially felt by a busy guy like me, who does NOT have the time for searching for scattered pieces of information). I nevertheless strongly suggest to work on the following clarifications along the road:
1) How does this relate to IdeaScale ? Will it be complementary or would it possibly replace IdeaScale in the future ?
2) How can we make sure that we integrate other (similar) proposals into this initiative.

There is clarity in the problem and solution described, but it is not clear how the proposal will address this challenge.

There is information on the budget allocation, but I recommend more details on the allocation of resources for the bounties and the librarian, as the budget of both is relatively high and there is no clear definition of the assignments / possible workload.

The timeline for delivery of the proposal is 3 months, but the milestones defined in Github are not clear. As there are no KPIs it is difficult to audit the proposal and understand the success of the proposal.

The link provided with the up-to-date milestones is very intuitive and easy to visualize the progress.
However, as said before, I wish you had included some KPI and metrics to validate the evolution of the proposal and correlate this evolution with the challenge itself – like correlate the growing numbers of participants with the improvement of the decision making or with the proof of iterations, or with the overall community confidence (maybe with some surveys), etc.

The proposer has reasonable experience in the communications side to enable a tutorial program for CAs.  There is a sole proposer who may cause some risk in development if other priorities or unforeseen events were to happen.  For the scope and size of the project, the budget seems a reasonable amount. and a plan and roadmap are available for the development of the tutorial.  The KPI metrics are largely driven by subsequent actions from the project being concluded and maybe additional development metrics would be nice to have included as well.  The proposer has already helped to develop CA documentation in the past and is committed to the cause.

There is clarity in describing the problem and the solution. The proposal is in line with the challenge.

Various information has been described so that the proposal can be audited. There is a clear, objective roadmap with milestones. There are relevant KPIS. There are details about the proposer and his qualification / experience.

The budget was divided into 4 parts and there is information on how much will be allocated to each part, however, as there is no estimate of how many hours the tutorials will have in total, it is difficult to assess the feasibility of the budget. The budget amount was not defined by hourly load and it would be important to understand what the cost related to the result would be.

Trying to improve the effectiveness and engagement of CAs in the future through video content is a great idea. The proposal details almost every aspect about his planned implementation, however I would have liked to see a clearer vision for the structure of the videos themselves, apart from the fact that they'll be modular. Still, much better than other proposals that focus on the production of video content.

There is a roadmap with some project deliverables included as well as a plan for future changes/scalability included in this proposal.  Some challenges may be in delivering items on time given the sole proposer planning to do the work themselves.    Due to this a clearer milestone or feature delivery schedule would help make it more clear to determine if the project is moving at the right pace.

The images are well-crafted and the  snippet of the story is intriguing, but it does not seem to say how blockchain will be presented to the readers. It speaks about corruption in Africa, through current centralized power structures. And it implies decentralized power and financial structures will somehow counter this. But it does not say what the message will be—what will the youth be told in these media, about blockchain opportunities? It seems this might be remedied if the proposers worked with blockchain experts early on, in the development  of the script, rather than at the end of the production as in in their production schedule(?).

A document was attached with a spreadsheet that details how the financing money would be used between the various stages of the project. In other words, there are no gaps in this regard. I just missed the establishment of a chronology of the practical steps, how would the process of creating this product be done? How many months would it take to make the drawings, to animate them, etc. It would be very beneficial to include a more chronological notion of everything, even to help the community to follow the progress of the process and provide feedback.

The team that proposes to develop the project is an information technology company and already has a sales website, as it was attached, aimed at the real estate market. That is, they already have the necessary basis for the development of the project, but I felt a lack of greater security in the issue of financial transactions in cryptocurrencies, because it was not clear if the team already has experience with this. Both NFT creation and ADA transactions need experienced people to function, and it is just as important a part of the project as the foundation of the website. So I think it would be beneficial to pay more attention to that part of the idea.

The roadmap and milestones are very well described, each step and its related cost are clear. Challenges are very well explained and discussed. The only thing missing are KPIs or key metrics to measure and quantify the success of this proposal. Some suggestions: number of partnerships with campaigns, number of users, volume and total amount of donations, etc.

The author's intentions dialogue a lot with the challenge's objectives, which are, basically, to get new investors for the Catalyst project and increase its visibility. According to the author, newsletters increase loyalty with (old and new) members, the engagement and credibility of the community. I believe that this is due to the fact that the content is better formulated and transmitted in more "formal" ways and with uniform consistency. In this view, the author's ideas respond very well to what was asked for. What seems to me a detail to think about is: how to get the contact, the email of these new people, because they would be interested in receiving content from the Catalyst project on a repetitive basis, without having established an initial interest? If the newsletter is linked to more consolidated media, such as the youtube channel or telegram, I think the idea would work even more efficiently.

The concept of a collectible NFT based game has proven to be successful on other blockchains and shown that they are very good at building communities around the game so this proposal addresses this challenge very well. From a game developer's perspective, I would love to work on a game built on Cardano and these types of projects will certainly also attract more game developers! The proposer states that they aim for battles to take place on the blockchain which is an interesting idea, but they only describe how this would work at a very high level. It would improve the proposal if these various game systems could be described in a bit more detail.

This game/dApp have the potential to bring lots of attention the Cardano. This kind of game can possibly attract lots of players and have a significant impact in the ecosystem. I would like to have seen more information about how the blockchain itself will be used to differentiate it from other off-chain games. It mentions that at first it would be a off-chain game and later on it would be moved to on-chain with more features, and this could be better explained. The website is on but there is not much information there. But in general, the idea is good and well aligned with the challenge objectives.

The team described sound like they have all the necessary skills to successfully implement this proposal; They state that they have previously released games, it would help the proposal if they were to list them. The proposer also seems to have a clear vision of what they consider an MVP. However, I'm also concerned that the budget seems very low for what it is supposed to cover.

While the milestones are set well and comprehensible, auditable success criteria are set, there is no rationale for the budget/ no detailed assessment of the costs. Yet all in all the purpose of the proposal is clear and it is auditable.

The proposer has broken down what they expect to have accomplished in a set amount of time. They have started working on characters for the NFTs (which look great by the way!). It would be helpful to the proposal to state how many of these NFTs they hope to have done for their MVP and since they have already made some, they should have a good idea of the time required for each one. The current roadmap described is a bit confusing as it states that several things are ready, but does not provide them. There is not much information to be gleaned from the twitter feed or the provided website either.

whilst I agree 100% with the challenge, there is one reservation. The amount of funding for the challenge is too small. Monitoring & Evaluation (M&E) efforts for small (low funded) proposals/projects will consume man hours, just as they do for  large projects. This industry has well established hourly rates. Presuming every proposal that is funded at $10-$50k are reasonably complex, the level of effort required by an established Auditing company or agency will consume almost the same amount of funds, We could expect three types of proposals. 1). Individuals/teams of individual active community members. 2). 3rd party Quality Assurance organisations (either management consultants or Quality Assurance organisations). Each would probably establish a different form of auditing and reporting. 3) Well established Monitoring and Evaluation organisations from within the Intl funding agency ecosystem (World Bank, UN, Asian Dev Bank, African Dev Bank, DIFID, GIZ, etc).   See https://www.sopact.com/monitoring-and-evaluation

This proposal is very brief with some concrete (albeit frank) notes about what is to be solved and done technically.  Little information is included about the specifics of who will do and what will they do.  There is a reference to a Metadata team, but that could be spelled out a little more for transparency and visibility.

The proposal does not include a roadmap that could be used for auditing progress. It also does not detail a clearly specified and measurable final goal: as stated, the goal is simply presented as an abstract statement of need.

Very little information about deliveries, roadmap, features, and priorities is included in this proposal.  Very little to help benchmark progress and/or show the way to go through development and a measurement of success.

This proposal would have a great impact on giving the ability to spend ADA funds through fiat means and gives ADA greater utility.  It would impact all ADA holders.  This proposal is more on the MVP side to help prove the concept is possible, this impact won't affect the greater community at the conclusion, but it will drive further development steps to bring fiat-based card spending that is funded by ADA.  Explaining the impact of the MVP will help make the stronger case for spending on this proposal and subsequent future development that would be required.

The proposer has very relevant experience to achieve the proposal's goal. The fact that is it seems that a single person would be responsible for all the development is a down side, but it's acceptable. The proposal mentions that multiple funds would be needed for the full development, but it is not clear what the other further developments are planned. Also, there is a risk of not getting extra fund, and this scenario should be assessed.
More detail needs to be supplied on any regulatory hurdles and how they will be addressed. What country is the proposer intending on doing the MVP in? Is it the UK?

Additional details would be nice, in addition to a roadmap to have an idea of what the deliverables and timeline would be with more details.  The basic timeline provided but not sure if any buffer is considered since it appears to be developed by a sole user.

From skill point of view the team is very strong as well there is a rough time plan attached. It would be useful to address the risks a bit more. In my eyes the biggest challenge is how to convince big studio or production house to join this movement and why they would do so. If this part is not analysed in a detail all the metrics applied for measuring the amount of user base and expansion becomes irrelevant. In overall the requested budget seems right.

The targets set for this development are very optimistic and I am not sure if they are achievable. But in any way, they are pointed out. Some milestones regarding the development of the main platform should be included as well. Risks involving possible IP problems with movie studios should be assessed, and budget should be broken down to make it easier to audit.
The budget is not well detailed and there and there is no timetable which allow us to verify if it's feasible in that time or not.
proposalTitle: Cardano Support for Point of Sale

assessmentNote:
Auditability.... The A word of Catalyst. The CA guidelines specify that an auditable proposal should have a roadmap with milestones and a ... time horizon for achievement.
This proposal does have a roadmap broken down by  Prototype Phase, MVP Phase and Version 2.0. However, no time horizon is provided. The proposed stages imply that a certain flow is implied. But no absolute or relative deadlines have been set and that does hamper auditability. 
We do have a clear description of the targeted problem as well as a clear solution. The lack of a timetable means that I subtract one star, yet the inclusion of a timetable would have improved auditability.
proposalTitle: Cardano Support for Point of Sale

assessmentNote: The proposal addresses in a clear way how the developers would tackle the problem. From scalability point of view it is more or less a one time job and maintenance. The given time plan and goals seems realistic based on the developers experiences. Also, it is beneficial that the whole budget is spent for development activities and it is a transparent breakedown.

The problem/challenge is clearly stated and one that is experienced by us all, undoubtedly. The solution presented is also simple and one that many would gladly rely on; to automate the process and kept distant from any emotional decisions. Such a solution could be deployed not just for ADA for but the entire crypto space.

Draft proposal. The problem and description are reasonable and the idea has potential, but there is no plan, so there is no way to assess the alignment of the proposal with the challenge and its potential for impact. Please, provide more detailes so we can give more feedback.

Potentially an interesting idea but it doesn't go into needed detail to consider it seriously at the moment. Proposal needs more thought and information to be included to understand it better. It's is hard to judge merits of this proposal with the absence of supporting materials.

There is no information about the proposer/team. There is a mention of large connections to the business world but no examples given. There is no plan how the proposal is to be achieved. For 50k there has to be more informations.

The proposal does not elaborate on any background nor experience to provide confidence that this solution can be implemented. It would benefit from the presentation of credentials and/or by stating the team put together and their relevant experience to demonstrate that the DApp can be built within a timeframe and a budget.
The proposer describes himself an entrepreneur with a large network but offers no additional info and links to back it up. The detailed plan, budget etc should have been included.

There is no information provided that would enable us understand on a deeper level what the experience or past relevant work looks like. Things such as Linked in profile, or other credible references would have been really useful.

Unfortunately, there's not enough information provided in this proposal to assess viability nor audibility that it's impossible to give it any measure of effectiveness in addressing the challenge. The $50000 price tag will require more details in order for this proposal to go any further.
Draft proposal. There is no information that makes it possible to assess the auditability of this proposal. I recommend including details and following the Catalyst documentation.

Especially in the case of proposal like this one, there needs to be a very detailed description of the app functions, to help determine the need and utility of it. Suggest re-submission for a future fund, but with a detailed description, a detailed budget, a roadmap, KPIs and so on. It is all mentioned in the self-assessing checklist.

Unfortunately, this proposal does not offer enough information that would allow us to be able to determine the length of this assessment. There is no clear roadmap with milestones and a time horizon for achievement. Neither metrics/KPIs that define the success of the proposal. Including these in the future would make it for an easier proposal to understand.

The expereince of the team appears to be sufficient to build, develop, and implement a project of this scope and size.  There is a roadmap included which already has commitment to this project outside of the proposal (through work in Notion).  The budget seems appropriate for the resources required for the desired features and scope of this project.

The author of the proposal claims to have 5 years of experience with content development for web and mobile, and even attached his profile on linkedin, where you can see several places he worked as a developer. Through these examples, a lot of confidence is established in your ability to develop the project. In addition, the author also considers forming a team with Design professionals, content writers and other developers, that is, he is aware of the complexity and need for plurality that the project team requires. Note: 5.

This proposal highlights a problem that needs to be solved.  There are over 20 comments which show that the community is interested and the problem is real. The community will benefit from the launch of this proposal and will scale as a part of several other components of a community website (which are separate proposals in this fund, but not this campaign).  

The central idea of the proposer outreach campaign and the PC process, in general, is to harness the value from the community and interested people, if funded, this Collaborators list would reduce the barriers to entry for a single collaborator AND well encourage diversity and team building.  This collaborator list will increase the innovative ideas and proposals to our community by increasing the number and quality of proposals and team members.

The proposer is fully committed and the process has started.

The project lays out a feasible roadmap and plans on how to implement the collaborator list.  The project does include success metrics, although they could be a little more fleshed out and made more black and white.  Challenges on how to build a complete list of collaborators should be included (such as social media engagement, etc...)

The idea to have a fund to fast-track small projects has merits. Also, the idea to delegate decision making power could be a way to scale the process. 
However, it is not clear how the side-treasury would actually decide about funding. Are we being asked to effectively trust you to grant the funds? How does the governance of adafund.io itself work? The proposal does not explain this.
Also, it is not clear why the stated problem needs to be solved in the first place. What would we lose if we don't?
The proposers already delivered something in the past. One point deducted because I'm afraid that running a mini-catalyst needs more than just a website.

The description on how the decision making mechanism is compromised and how it differs from Project catalyst and on how the success is audited is only described vaguely, making it difficult to assess how feasible it is.

The proposal provides milestones, indicators, and a timeline that make it easy to audit. It is clear that the proposers have thought through some potential challenges and offer mitigation measures. Voters can easily see the exact elements that are being proposed in a simple and straight forward manner. 

More detail could be provided on how they got to the amount for the small funding pools. What is the likelihood that a project would only require such a minimal amount?

Considering the importance of data rights protection and management (especially if we take a look at the recent issues caused by misuse of big data) this is a good approach to use blockchain to give the consumer back some of their privacy rights and actually pay them if they still consent to sharing their data. A well-reflected proposal that considers many facets of an important issue.

This idea is incredible. Making ordinary people to be in charge of its personal data in an easy way and being compensated for giving permission to use them is incredible.
This is the kind of proposal which brings entrepreneurs from outside the Cardano world which have the will to make the difference in an elegant way in an important project. This proposal has the potential to aggregate value vary fast.

I just think that you could concentrate more power in bringing more brands to the platform in order to bring more people interested in using it.

This is a very ambitious project. If successful it has the potential to bring many non-crypto oriented users to the Cardano ecosystem.  I see good incentives both for businesses using the platform and consumers selling their data. so I think the impact on the challenge goals could be high.

If I understand right the functionality of this app, it first needs to gather the brands to join the platform to, after, do everything they want to do.
In the proposal it is very clear that there are some brands that already see value in this 'new way to approach to customers', and it was very clear that the majority of them, 80%, believe that they're in the right way of doing advertisements and manage the public data.
Therefore, how are you intending to aggregate value to them in order to bring new brands to the platform (since they only see profit)? – I imagine that if you can make an statistic about the improvement of this type of interaction among the brands that are testing the POC and the clients, in the perspective of brands (profitability using this platform, more interested clients, etc), would be a great tool to show them that this new model is better than the old and invasive one.
I would like a more detailed roadmap in order to be easier to identify the milestones (intervals smaller than 3 months, e.g.)

There is a large number of people who are ready to contribute to Wildlife preservation. A dApp based assured impact project is likely to attract volunteer staking and donors. Moreover, the proposal will also provide a staking reward redistributable system which is likely to find more than one use case.

Providing comprehensive documentation can reduce the friction and confusion with onboarding new members. If the site is just one more link in the pile, it can make it difficult for new members to know that it is the correct one to use. Additional steps may be necessary to direct new users early on - like when installing Daedalus or Yoroi.

The problem and description make sense, are clear and within the scope of the challenge. The organization of informations/dates would assist voters, CAs and vCAs in the search for relevant information. Although I believe that the proposal is more in line with the Distributed Decision Making challenge, I also see the relationship with this challenge.

The team seems to have enough experience to put everything in place, and the proposed developments doesn't seem to be very difficult to implement. Budget for implementation makes sense, but some budget for maintenance should also be considered. Team is already committed and is working independently of the funding, which is very good.

This proposal is already in the works through the project team and additional funding will help accelerate and improve the existing work already done.  Project updates are all captured on the site notion.so and the roadmap has some structure to it.  Further defining the roadmap will make the future features clearer and help show priority in the work.  The budget breakdown is reasonable considering the two primary things that the project team has highlighted.  It would be nice to list some stretch goals since this is already in motion and what the additional funding may help get over the line.

The proposal indicates the volume of traffic on the site would be a metric, and given tracking use on the site this can be done. There was also mention of reduced volume of requests in the other channels - which may be harder to evaluate as they may not be currently measured.  In addition, while the budgetary documentation indicated that the funds would be used to pay for AWS hosting; it did not indicate for how long or what the plan would be when those funds ran out.

The problem, the solution and the proposal are aligned with the challenge.

The roadmap has no details, but it is objective, the timeline for the implementation is defined in 3 weeks, within the challenge requirements.

The project is already in development, some updates in the development have been added and can be checked and the team aims to add updates about the development on the website.

There is a budget breakdown, but as I mentioned in the rationale above, there is no clarity if updates to the calendar and information are included in the budget.

There are details about the proposers' experience. Reasonable metrics have been described, but there are no KPIs.

Since this a simple project, I see that the a delivery date is all that's needed to audit the development and the information is there in the text. The success metrics are not that clear and seem to be a little hard to properly measure, like qualitative feedback and relation between people who need support and people looking for support. Number of viewers, as mentioned, might be a better way to track the usage, if people are coming back it's because it's relevant. Budget breakdown is good and well explained.

The problem statement doesn't indicate a problem but an affirmative statement, I recommend the team to modify this point so that the proposal is clearer in its purpose.

The solution described in the proposal is within the scope of the challenge. A decentralized exchange is an extremely useful dapp and one of the most popular today.

The goals are within the expected for the challenge, but no metrics or KPIs have been defined, which makes it difficult to assess the impact of DEX.

The proposal falls squarely within the Metadata Challenge in its emphasis on employing transaction metadata in a privacy-controlled fashion. It leverages an ongoing project by connecting it to Cardano metadata in a proof-of-concept application.

There is a lot of information about what will be done, how it will be done, how much each step will cost and when it will be done. Everything is very well detailed, from the actions, to the parts that make up the project and the audience to be reached. I believe that the proposal is very complete in relation to its applicability, well-directed information and we can have a complete domain of how everything will happen.

Judging by the comments, the proposal seems to be a recognised member of the Catalyst community, but other than that no info about him is provided, no link to previous works, no references. The proposal lacks a detailed budget or an implementation roadmap. The proposer did not complete the steps required by the self assessment checklist. No metrics or a description of what success would look like are provided.

There are almost no milestones and KPIs. The only metric given are commits on github. It is unclear how this metric can be used to measure project progress and solution adoption. The self-assessment checklist also stated that success was specified after 3, 6 and 12 months. There is nothing of this in the proposal. The only information that can be used for this evaluation criterion is the listed development activities.

I rate a 4 in impact because the proposal identifies a specific way to address the challenge question. The proposal identifies the need for boots on the ground and outlines, in detail, a way to accomplish Cardano development within Africa. The proposal in deed identifies that this will add value to Cardano by allowing developers living in Africa to work on projects needed in the local communities. There are no key metrics which is what keeps me from rating the project a 5. I think it is a strong idea, the proposal lacks info required by the rubric.

In terms of feasibility, there is no question that there is already a large dedicated team behind this proposal. Details about the different regional leads are presented in a separate document and they have relevant experience. What could possibly be improved here would be a little more information on how big the individual teams are for the different hubs, but I do trust that they are all well supported from the overarching team. There is also a separate document with a detailed and reasonable looking budget for the different costs related to the individual hubs, covering both the starting one-time costs like equipment and ongoing costs for a time period of 3 months, which does mean that the hubs will need new funding to continue their operation and roadmap, either with another Catalyst proposal or by other means, so some more details about this and about the future sustainability would have made it even better. There are also very relevant local risks with setting up in the different regions, but it does look like the team has identified and taking the major ones into consideration.

WADA has been successfully installing hubs across western Africa since Fund2. Their project community works in close collaboration with other established projects, such as Gimbalabs, which adds to the sincereness and feasibility of the proposal. 
Prioritising cost items in terms of functionality assures a stable form of growth and early operability.

As mentioned in the proposal the project's GitHub can be monitored for progress and the evolution of it can be monitored and audited. Risks are correctly identified and a clear plan of action is presented that could serve as a base for the audits. The proposer seems engaged in the community and responsive to feedback on the proposal.

Catalyst requested budget is 35k$, but we lack information on how this budget will be used and what extra resources are needed to complete the project (Ventup.io claims it received a 100k$ raise for this project). We also lack details on the team composition and experience. Showing previous realization or experiences would help the community to assess the chances of success of the project. Also adding more details on the specific algorithms that will solve the "IDO fairness" issue would add value to the project description.

The timeline breaks down a MVP (not on Cardano) which is not specified, a migration in Q3, and the release of a version 2 in Q4, which is also not specified. How is the budget allocated?

Too much information is missing. This proposal will be difficult to audit.

Milestones of the project development are defined for the coming year, with a prototype to be launched on Ethereum blockchain shortly before migration to Cardano. It's a very weak description of the roadmap. It would help the community to better assess the progress of the project if the proposer could add more information about the features that will be added at the different steps of development, more information on the feature that will make the difference, with an evaluation of the added value of each feature.

The problem and solution statement is reasonable. The proposal has the potential to have a positive impact on Catalyst, but it is not clear that it is within the scope of the distributed decision-making challenge.

The first phase of the proposal made at Fund4, Project Catalyst Landing Page, was inserted in the "Catalyst Value Onboarding" challenge, which I see as reasonable, as there is alignment with the challenge brief of that challenge.

I can also see some relation to the distributed decision-making challenge, but it is less of a direct impact than the Value Onboarding challenge. In any case, there is no description in the proposal of how Landing Page can cause improvement in decision making.

The central place for current and new community members of Project Catalyst is the current IdeaScale platform. It's not the best platform but people are used to it. This proposal seems to duplicate a lot of the current IdeaScale functions and could create even more confusion by scattering resources further. I like that this platform is community driven, but unless it's to replace the IdeaScale platform completely I'm not sure if this would help new community members.

I have a sneaking suspicion that this proposal is an extremely useful and innovative concept but was not fully able to confirm this by the information provided. The information was however, sufficient to suggest that the project is a good candidate for funding. Whether the project is viable will likely be determined by the work undertaken from this point onward. I feel the proposer has the technical nous to suggest further collaboration and peer review will likely lead to success in the future.

The proposer provides a detailed step-by-step plan for the technical implementation with clear milestones and a defined time horizon and uses cases for adoption. The proposal offers a realistic timetable to complete the work. The proposer has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation.

Reading the proposal, I think that you should include the proposers in these videos scope. Looking to the suggestions of video's content, it is very clear that not only the CA would benefit from them, but actually it seems that maybe the proposer would benefit even more. 
One thing that kept my attention is that you helped to create the CA guideline, which is a written 'FAQ' and that gave you several insights and feedback which helped you to think about this proposal. However, have you received lots of messages suggesting that a video series would benefit the community? I am saying this because it seems to me that ask 10% of the challenge funds to change the format of an information is a lot. It would be of a great value if you share some of the feedbacks and the requests – would clarify how many more people would be reached compared with the written format.

It is clear that the proposer has the knowledge to create the content and I imagine that part of the budget asked in the 'creating video' section would be directed to some professionals on the described field (editing, scripting, etc). I the project would benefit from a more detailed budget.
It seems to me that the themes proposed are very general, it would be helpful to any challenge, thus I assume that they will be like a foundation of the series. Therefore I imagine that the updates of the actual funds, challenge and criteria will be launched after. If this is true, I am a bit lost in this roadmap – 1 month to create one video and 2 to create 9 – would be of great interest to have more detail.

This proposal dialogues very well with the objectives of the challenge, as it aims to bring knowledge about cryptocurrencies and blockchain to young Africans, through art, the production of an illustrated story and also an audiovisual animation. In other words, it fits perfectly with what is proposed, and if the objectives of the campaign have been achieved (the authors aim to reach around 1 million Africans with the material), it will certainly be a great driver for the Catalyst community on the continent.

It seems there needs to be an outline provided on how the media will be used to educate on the use of blockchain. And that this may require interaction with blockchain experts and developers from Cardano. There is no doubt that they can produce a book and animation that has high production values and is well crafted. But it is unclear what the message will be about the uses of blockchain for the  youth in Africa. What possibilities will be presented? It is wonderful to mention that the youth are drivers not beneficiaries. So it seems if they are provided more insights into what the possibilities are with blockchain, specifically Cardano blockchain, it will only strengthen or arm the drivers, with insights for creativity and invention. Rather than entice them with wealth creation. This also occurred in the US in education, in the southern states. Where media education was interpreted by those who traditionally had no access financial opportunities. It ended up causing a non-productive and destructive outcome for the students.

Art and NFTs are a natural fit for DApps. An NFT marketplace for graffity is no exception. As the primary question of the challenge is "What applications will provide the most value for end users in 2021", I deduct one star. It feels like there are already a high number of NFT marketplaces out there. Another NFT marketplace would provide limited value to end users. Another star was reduced, because the current propsal is not about an app. It is about the creation of a website to promote the final product and digitalizing art and minting of 50 tokens. This does not provide any special value to the end-user. I deduct another star as there are no steps involved in the proposal to actually implement or even preparte the implementation of the nft marketplace.

So first of all the fees system seems to favor the Marketplace a lot. Then the budgetplan is kina unclear. 2k for graffiti research seems random. Especially because the artist should do the NFT and you just provide the market place.

Then there is no information about the technical stuff and how this marketplace is gonna be built. 

For the next time it would help to add more information to your proposal. The idea seems good but maybe not yet enough thought throu

The main goals are outlined and do seem feasible to a proposer with web store experience. 
Unfortunately I didn't find this proposal during the refinement stage but I think more aspects of the proposal need clarification.  For example, it seems like having a relationship with the artists should be a requirement before creating an NFT, unless you have a not for profit model. But, this fundamentally transforms the nature of illegal graffiti. For me feasibility would be a not for profit model using found, anonymous graffiti works,  with donations to relevant causes (art education for children ,etc) or a for profit model with sanctioned, legal grafitti works and  identified artists. I think more refinement is necessary.

The funds requested seem appropriate for website, promotion, research, and creation of tokens.  It would be relatively easy to audit the success of these clear goals which should be achieved by the end of 2021. However I doubt the success of the project without a more focused approach and further refinement. If the proposers do not receive funding this round, I hope to see their proposal in a future Catalyst fund.

The proposal is a little short which makes it hard to asses. The provided breakdown of the bootcamp helps to see how they plan to do it. But still it would help to provide more information regarding from where they take the information they plan to teach and where exactly the money is going. Also an introduction of the team would benefit instead of just linking the website.

I do think that creating educational content bringing the basics of Cardano's ecosystem is very beneficial for all the community. I really wished that this proposal was in other challenge like "catalyst value onboarding", which I imagine would be more valuable.
Maybe it would be interesting to considerate to simultaneous approach: one promoting ADA to outside world, showing, like you said, real world projects that are being developed and the potential of the ecosystem, and the other one a more elucidating series which provide educational content with short videos – one linking to another to create meaning and purpose. This way I think would be beneficial to the community, which would learn and get more engaged (mainly newcomers), and to the outside people, who would get interested first in the potential and projects being developed and then learn how it all works and could be done.

The proposer has a relevant experience in creating videos and the example provided is very professional. This is good, as a many videos that are being created come from people that have no experience in actual video producing. So here´s a clear advantage in the proposers background and the objectives of the proposal. The team in the background reflect a typical video-crew as far as I understand and would probably guarantee, that the produced videos are very professional as well. 

Since there is not enough information about the intended content for the videos, I cannot really estimate if the team can cover all the topics that would be necessary to put together the Cardano Ecosystem for new members and outsiders. But even with technical and developer content, a documentary film crew might be able to instruct a developer good enough to explain his or her dApp or project without having the same technical knowledge. 

The proposer already showed commitment by producing a teaser video and there´s already a team in the background, that might already have worked before on other projects, so the objective of creating videos will be conducted by a team of professionals. The financial plan is too broad to review at the moment.

The problem statement is subjective, no data has been included to support the problem. It is not as if the industry does not serve digital nomads, there are apps like Airbnb that serve as a mechanism for renting and booking properties efficiently.

It has been described that there will be the possibility of fractional ownership, but What benefit does this proposal seek to bring in relation to the current options? What is the purpose of using a dapp / blockchain? Will fractional purchases be permitted through Cardano's blockchains? These are basic aspects to understand the relevance of the proposal for this challenge.

Although the preparation of a technical specifications document is foreseen as the first phase of the project, it is important to describe at least one rationale of how dapp will work and how it will use the blockchain, without it it is difficult to assess how the proposal addresses the challenge and how it can impact Cardano's blockchain.

Relevant KPIs have been included, which helps the impact assessment.

It is not clear how many people will participate in the proposal. On the Kasaba website it is possible to verify that the Kasaba team has experience in implementing a business plan, but who will actually participate in the proposal? Is there anyone with knowledge in developing smart contracts and knowledge in Plutus? There is no information about who will develop dapp. I recommend that this information be clarified / included.
There is a budget breakdown. What was the reference used for setting the $ 10,000 budget for a DApp developer?

The proposer has limited experience with block chain tech and what issues it can solve. this is apparent by the misapplication in this proposal where the problem identified was not one of trust in exchange. The proposal aims to centralize data and make it more available to political parties which makes them more powerful, the antithesis of public, permission less blockchains. The proposer didn't mention the W3 DID standard which means there is a risk of interoperability. In addition, the lack of blockchain experience means the confidence in the budget is extremely weak, since blockchain dev work is extremely expensive. The project didn't identify how the data would be stored either.

metrics are clear and measurable, but:

what if one person bought all the ada?  

also, what if these client/s are not from Africa at all, just traveled to buy it cheaply (no fees)? There is no mechanism to exclude someone from this service, thus I think there are risks and more complication that has NOT been considered.

The user experience benefits of alternative programming language bindings for the Cardano blockchain is self-evident. Developers can use the tools they are familiar with to write Cardano applications. It is not clear whether the proposal refers to alternative bindings for cardano-node or for cardano-addresses or for cardano-cli or what, which is not reassuring.
Draft proposal. The proposal doesn't describe a problem to be solved. There is no indication of how the proposal is related to the challenge and there is no plan for measuring the impact.

The idea of creating a skeuomorphic wallet for these communities is ingenius and could have high impact on the adoption by potential users. If proven successful, it could easily be applied to regions across the entire world without needing to alter the core system.

The proposal provided very useful information. Yet there are a few things that could have been better. 
The problem statement and solution were initially not very clear. I believe that the cause of this was that there was an effort to cram as much information as possible in there, compromising clarity. 
The funding breakdown was quite limited. It stated that the work would cost ~25k USD and the total request would be 29k USD. To imrpove this, it should be broken down further so the community can form an idea of cost distribution. 
How the app would create revenue is also unclear. Would it take a transaction fee or a one time purchase from the app store? In terms of metrics, it would be useful to set a goal to measure success. (How many users after 3/6/9 months?)

The proposal offers a solution for the training of AI/ML which is based on blockchain. I am aware of the AI training bias and if this can be solved with the Cardano then it is a clear benefit and adresses the challenge. In addition, any AI related development on Cardano should be higly enouraged since it will have rapid growth in the near future (SingularityNET is already onboard).
The measuring metrics are a bit vague, with only estimated total world mcap. It could be beneficial to see how much of this market can be captured, or how many users are estimated.

The experience of the team is impressive and it's great that you run a stake pool. I think this game will be successful. Korean should be added to the list of languages. Young Koreans love this kind of game and are knowledgeable about crypto. I could help with this as I live in Korea.

It's true that these information can be easily found through internet, however have them together in an easy display may cause the amount of people who actually finds them and understand them. Furthermore, more elucidated people allow better decisions to be made.
However, I am missing the metrics and goals to corroborate with the challenge.

By aiming at Cardano's environment impact mitigation, this project could bring value to Cardano and increase adoption by people who care about global warming and are reluctant to blockchain technology and its image of high energy consumption : it does address the challenge. As a side effect, I assume such environment friendly Dapp will help to enlight the true the environment impact of blockchains and thus promoting Cardano over others as it is 99.99999% more energy efficient than Ethereum.

A smart-contract and a Daedalus/Yoroi plugin seem a clear and easy solution to me. An assessment of the risk of not being integrated into these wallets with a good visibility would help the community to assess the chance of success. Also the governance of the Treda fund lacks of details : I think for example to the use a dedicated Treda token/share granted in exchange of the carbon tax that could enable to involve the community in the decision process of the Treda Fund and bring engagement.  Raters can also consider that the proposer does not have programming skills, and no details are provided about  the development team.

Project milestones are lightly described, but not scheduled. The use of funding is not detailed. We can assume that the release of the Treda Smart Contract and one the wallets plugin is a definition of success, but we are missing intermediate milestones. Additional description of intermediate development steps  would help assessing the progress of the project.

I mostly agree. The writing is easy to follow and understand. Only one thing I would like to see is an experimental stage of the system when these 2 games are online, especially my concerns are on the security side of these 'Currency Servers'- from what I understand these kind of servers exist and you are familiar with these concepts, but it is unclear to me if you are fully qualified to create and manage these by yourself. As mentioned, the roadmap is extensive but there is no sandbox period to test the security of the system. I would like to see more documentation on these concepts. Also one more thing is not fully clear to me, this in game currency, how will it be denominated? I think this must be defind clearly before even making an API. And if it is in most likely event pegged to a Fiat currency then this needs more regulative understanding and clearence. In general, my two concerns are for non-blockchain server security and in-game currency implementation (concepts, issuance, governance). I agree that this proposal will be implemented successfully if my concernes are addressed.
proposalTitle: Native Token API for Game Devs

assessmentNote: We are provided with a plan of how the project will work, according to the months. It is also detailed how the financing would be used. However, within this detail, which is really just a division of how much money would go to engineers and to transactions with governments, they could have more information, more explanations. For example, what would the USD 85000 be used for? Part of the salary of professionals, part of the construction of contracts? I was also confused about how these contracts would be hosted. If it's an app, a website...

There are details about the team's experience and qualification. There is an objective timeline. There is no budget breakdown,no KPIs. I recommend that the proposal describes at least an estimate of hours to develop the research.

What I like about this how they introduce a part of their team. The proposer are already in the NFT-DAO which shows that they are already commited to our community. It helps to built trust if a team submits their github which is the case here. The proposal offers a realistic timetable to complete the work and the budget is reasonable. However I'd like to see a more detailed break-down how the funds are calculated. Maybe for the next time you submit a proposal you can try to add this to your proposal.

Given the proposer's experience as a game developer, it seems very likely that they will be able to accomplish what is outlined in the proposal. The budget seems reasonable for a programmer and an artist to get the "base" game completed. It would be helpful to add time estimates as well.  The proposer also identifies several risks and challenges that would need to be addressed such as the cost of transactions, a browser wallet solution similar to metamask, and user identities.

The proposer asks many valid questions and raises concerns and dependencies (e.g. web wallets). The proposal gives a general direction and makes connection to the game development experience, but it is not clear how the lack of particular blockchain experience impacts the success of this proposal. Since an artist will be hired, a detailed breakdown of the budget would warrant a higher score.

The proposal helps to get an understanding of the idea of the project. Unfortunately it misses a clear roadmap, technical details on how the proposer is going to try to achieve his goals and it misses more informations about the proposer. You can always add a linkedin account or link old projects

The proposer provides a very clear scope for the game they are proposing, as well as additional features to explore for possible future additions to the game. Breaking these down into stages would be helpful in determining the feasibility of the project; does the proposer plan to add the additional features in future challenges?

The problem and solution described are clear and relevant to improve Catalyst, but it is not clear what improvements the proposal may bring in the next 2 Funds, as no metrics / KPIs have been described that could indicate the success of the proposal in relation to the challenge objective .

The budget described is reasonable, it involves only the weekly "salary" costs of the two members, there is no mention of additional costs.

In general, the proposal is promising, I believe that the inclusion of more tangible metrics is a key point.

the proposers gained funding in round 3 but have gone over budget.  they have working relationships with Cardano Foundation and Emurgo. They are involved in the blockfrost Cardano API. However it is difficult to tell how much progress they made with the Catalyst 3 funding. The linked github has not been updated in  2 months. I wonder if the 1200 USD requested is sufficient to fund the proposed deliverables.  I suggest the proposers better highlight the progress made in previous rounds to grow the confidence of CAs. This would enhance their chances of winning additional funding.

The fund requests wages for the language Ambassadors and funds for a loan program to help them buy the necessary equipment. For better audibility I recommend the proposer go into more detail about the loan system and how it will function/be auditable.

A good timeline was provided and given KPI's are measured however I thought it would beneficial to include additional measures such as the watch time and the views to engagement ratio. This would allow you to evaluate whether the content being created is actually benefitting individuals in smaller communities. Possible challenges are not considered in enough detail making it hard to evaluate the progress of this proposal.

Although members of the community specifically asked for this in the comments and they have indicated in the self-assessment checklist that they provided a broken down budget, the proposal doesn't include one, and I would highly recommend including one in a future iteration of the project. The requested budget is very small for developing a game on and it's unclear how it would be spent and how it should be audited. The roadmap provided is not detailed enough in the description of the planned steps to be able to properly anticipate the work that needs to be done to accomplish them and to audit the progress.

The team has relevant experience to achieve this proposal and have made verifications of this public on their website. 
The project is likely to succeed considering a broad diversity of features that it has to offer to distinguish itsself from competition. The proposal, website and whitepaper are written in a very clear structure, which brings to mind that the team work in a planned way and have attention to detail.

The feasibility of successfully implementing this project is high. This is not a question of coding, as many applications like this exist. It will be a matter of complying with local laws which is my biggest request to developers to this proposal: provide us in the future more detail of what the AML laws and regulations are in the localities you are seeking to develop in. But I believe the developers should be able to sort through the laws and regulations to ensure the app complies. The other feasibility challenge will be getting users but I do not think that will be difficult so long as the application is built as they outline it and it is aesthetically pleasing.

For this to work it needs the crypto to fiat connections in every country transfers are to happen between. The proposers don't appear to have the experience of connection to achieve this. Evidence of experience or connection in this regard, or even a plan for how they intend to go about it would be required to succeed.
Without a sound plan on how they are going to achieve fiat conversion, this is a nice idea, but unlikely to succeed.

The proposal reads as if the proposers themselves would decide what is a mini-proposal and which ones get funded (and get paid to do this). Perhaps this is not the case, so the proposal would benefit from making it clear how mini-proposals are assessed and who decides on funding e.g. voting by the community ?
It's not clear where these mini-proposals would be posted ? The proposal seems to suggest that this would be on Project Catalyst, but then these need to follow the current timelines and processes, further clarity is required here. 
There is no clear implementation plan presented and the miro board is difficult to read, it's unlikely voters would spend time trying to decipher it. The proposal also doesn't address the risks of people abusing this system e.g. requesting funding for tasks that are part of an already funded Catalyst proposal.
The proposal would benefit from breaking the budget down further, why are we paying each member $900, to write guidelines, for specific training, management of proposals ? Overall $2700 ($900 x 3) to develop a proposal system that is based on the project Catalyst system, seems steep and is likely to deter voters.

The intentions are well placed, but the plan still needs some refinement.  When I first read the heading for your proposal, the first thing that popped up in my head was... Bigger proposals broken down and distributed among smaller groups of teams. Each team tackling a certain problem. I would love to see your proposal steer towards something like that. As you said under the heading - Defining success - 'We hope to design new ways to collaborate together.' If you can find a way to break down big proposals into microtasks, you have succeeded indeed. Maybe you should collaborate with Project Catalyst to assist with the voting and funding of microtasks. Keep up the good work and keep refining this idea.

There is a clear definition of success for the challenge itself and metrics as well, but some guiding metrics for the proposals to be submitted in this challenge should also be included in the text. It might be proposal specific, but there are some general KPIs that could be suggested, like number of users, different kinds of NFTs created, trading volumes, and others.

Thank you for your idea proposal. I enjoyed reading it. To improve its relevance to the Cardano community, please kindly consider the following suggestions:
(1)	The focus of the proposal (or as mentioned the Fund 7 challenge proposal) and objectives can be improved and become more 100% clear. It will have more impact with a stronger punch-line business case and some practical examples. It will help as well to have a SWOT analysis on the top ideas and gain some traction as the objectives, key success factors, and vision.
(2) Some of the links didn't work but overall I do believe the idea is good and should be more developed.

Number, quality and results of particular proposals for use cases are all good objectives to measure. It might be worth thinking about a structure and measurement function by which to engage community members in collating and managing industry contact outreach to grow the community and induct people in different areas so as to engage industry participants with an interest they might not have yet thought about in developing their own proposals.
Again it is not really a proposal itself, the the proposer even stated they don't want the funds, but for them to be given to the metadata team.

Challenge is "What applications will provide the most value for end users in 2021?". By the proposers own admission this project is a long goal. Thus it does not meet the challenge (even though it would be great to pull off).

Looking into the proposer CV, it seems that he can create this product.
I am wondering how much would cost to create the plastic card and the logistics and if you have thought in all logistic nuances – in which country to starts, how the card would be distributed, how many people you need to expand, etc.
I wish you had a more detailed roadmap which would explain or give milestones in which we could verify the dev of working.

The idea is great, it is a good application of blockchain as a way to remove the middleman and to benefit both creators and viewers. This could bring great visibility to Cardano. There are some platforms similar to this, but I see the difference that no middle man at all would exist in this case.
It's a good idea to promote Cardano to wider usage via BTCPay Server which allows e-commerce websites payment.
proposalTitle: Cardano Support for Point of Sale

assessmentNote: The proposer is a former IOHK developers, so that's a plus. On the other hand, the combination of working as a sole developer for the initial phase and the amount requested might not be ideal.
proposalTitle: Cardano Support for Point of Sale

assessmentNote: Experience seems right, also based on the given proposal description I have a confident feeling that they can do the job in the given time frame. Time plan clear as well the team content. Might be the testing topics could get a bit more attention and some risk estimation, what kind of worst case errors could arise with major and minor bugs.

This proposal describes a Limit order on a DEX. So it would be more effective to actually implement this on a dex. 

It can't be said for sure that this is acually a problem that needs to be solved. I think we can trust people to handle their funds.

Like one of the comments mentions, there are already several platforms that offer similar services and this proposal dos not offer any details regarding what would differentiate this dApp from them and why it would benefit the Cardano ecosystem.
Draft proposal. There is no plan and there is no indication of relevant experience for creating a dapp.
The proposal is really short. There is almost nothing to assess. For the next time a more detailed proposal and a clear roadmap would be great.

The team is pretty competent and experienced and collaborating with other people. In addition to this, the plan is very detailed and sets realistic cost calculations and goals. It is higly likely that the project will be implemented successfully
proposalTitle: Devs for Awarenes Event West Africa

assessmentNote: Like the idea and enthusiasm but there are a lot of unknowns that make this plan difficult to assess. I want the author to be rewarded for his vision but feel that the asking budget is too heavy for the proposal at hand. The risks are addressed except for the biggest risk...retaining the staff that are hired.
proposalTitle: Devs for Awarenes Event West Africa

assessmentNote:
The proposal gives the reader a good understanding on how the whole project and implementation would take place.
Even the technical challenges are well explained. You can clearly understand where the challenges and opportunities lie.

The team is very experienced and from various different backgrounds. The plan is extremely detailed and basically presents a complete concept that only needs to be implemented on the cardano blockchain, making it extremely likely that the proposal will succeed. The budget is explained. A small grain of salt is that a senior blockchain dev has not yet been acquired, but considering the paygrade that is planned in the budget for this position, this shouldn't be to much of an issue.

The project appears to be at an advanced state of development, although I haven't done thorough due diligenct. According to comments a Profila smart phone app is about to be released. Their is an extensive team working on the project according to the website. The proposal is very detailed and broken into manageable stages. It is hard to gauge the project's commitment to Cardano, but if they are as far along as they make out, Cardano can only benefit from integration into the project.  I also not that the team has been very responsive to community questions and has an overall professional demeanor.

This is a very good proposal and is one of the things that we must start to value: Nature and wildlife.
Having a place that helps you to donate, having a return (NFT or some part of the pool) is a incredible thing to whom thinks about the future of the planet.
I also think that this idea can aggregate people almost immediately, since who is involved with this kind of things will not lose time.
I do not think that this is feasible because the proposers state at several points throughout the text that they aren't sure how things work or what their plan really is.
Creating a website is not rocket science, so I have high confidence in that part. However, nothing was said about maintenance and keeping it up to date.

The proposers have a plan and budget to do this now, but it is not clear how this will work going forward. new calendar events and resources will continuously be added. how is this going to be managed? If it is maintained going forward it is not useful.

What's missing are the dependencies. This is just one of several proposals totalling $35'200. 
The scope of this one includes just a calendar page and a list of links, which doesn't look overly ambitious. However, there is also the point "Ongoing collaboration with all content creators, community members and developers to integrate any of their current or planned education resources" which seems not to be budgeted

For the funding requested and the roadmap laid out, there is a plan for how the project will be executed.  More information to help understand project development and a roadmap defined will be important to measure progress.
The plan is well presented and it is likely the prospers can deliver on it, though more detail on their experience would be helpful.
This is a well thought out and detailed plan. it addresses a key element of effective decision making, evaluating the success of previous decisions.
Proposer already tried and failed to get this off the ground. Why is now different? No detailed plan provided.

Proposal provides a detailed budget in a spreadsheet, short overviews of each team member, and the link to their project that is already ongoing. The budget is reasonable and there is a realistic time table. The proposal justifies the location for each "hub" they want funding for and finally, they address relevant risks and explain how to plan/adjust for each risk.
The information provided in the Roadmap is sufficient to track and audit the project. Quick question: How many curriculum do you plan to deliver?
I was monitoring this proposal in the last round of funding and can say for certain that details that were missing last time are here now on how this will work and be accomplished. Great job!

The described IDO launchpad and DEX does address the challenge objectives which is to create Dapps adding value to Cardano Blockchain. The brief does explain the lacks in existing services that the project wants to address unfairness, lack of transparency, unengaged community and complexity. However, the description lacks details on how the project will bring a solution to these problems.

The team described experiences in areas and roles related to:

Product management, Cybersecurity Experts, Full Stack Engineers, Blockchain / Cryptocurrency Experts

There is no information available to substantiate these allegations of expertise, so it is not possible to indicate the team's ability to execute the proposal.

There is no solid and structured plan for implementation. There is no budget breakdown.

Considering the fact that the proposal is for the creation of a Launchpad (a project that will essentially evaluate other projects in detail, create ratings, anti-scam features and report this to users) it was to be expected that this proposal itself would be a example of what to expect of due diligence from the proposed Launchpad, but the team failed to conduct due diligence of their own proposal, which is a worrying sign.

I recommend submitting a new proposal based on the Catalyst documentation.
The plan is detailed and the budget is partitioned. There are clear foals, milestones, timelines and deliverables. Success metrics are defined and the amount of work scoped.

The Indian government has a  National Academic Depository, which is to under the University Grants Commission for authentication of academic documents. There is a need for a top-down approach to this complex problem. What has been achieved in Ethiopia is the correct model. It is not a "nonavailability of app" problem. The proposed app is not likely to be used in a general sense in India since there is no clarity on the use of cryptocurrency-backed blockchain projects in India.

The proposal addresses the Challenge's goal of using metadata for tamper-resistant documentation. However, the proposal is silent on how users of the system would verify that the metadata was uploaded by an authorized university—it appears that the process would involve trusting that the Deqree serivce has properly verified the credenials of the submitting official at the university, but that contradicts the "no need for a central authority" requirement in the project description.. The proposal would be stronger if it leveraged established trust frameworks such as the W3C Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) or Atala Prism.

Proposers are 5 undergraduate students. It is not clear they have the technical capabilities to produce the project. The project relies on the universities uploading the data. They have not provided any information on how they intend to convince any universities to come on board.

The reference Github repository is blank and the proposers have not claimed and prior experience in large-scale secure software or blockchain development. The major component of government policy management and legal requirements have not been consider in the road map.

The Roadmap needs more details on the step-by-step action plan, including milestones and KPI'S. 
Will you hire a team to create this platform? How many customers do you plan to onboard by when? When do you plan to release the product?

With the increase in the number of CAs over the funds, one might think that the quality of the evaluations would decrease under the effect of the inclusion of a less specialized audience. Reducing reported reviews and reviews denied by senior CAs is an effective measure of the impact of this project, making its effectiveness clearly measurable.

I think it would be of a great help to add some sort of a communication channel which would allow anyone to really see if the script is being completed, or the videos are being edited or recorded, etc – not have to wait until the video is complete would be great.
The proposal is detailed in terms of the road map for future improvements. The risks associated with the proposed system are also well analyzed, and a pragmatic approach is being undertaken.

Proposal is to provide functionality to a product, in that sense easy to audit. No KPI's given on which to measure success. Please provide KPI's which align with the challenge goal which can be used to measure success.

Motion comic on Cardano can improve the understanding of blockchain among children and can positively impact adoption. However, it is more of a propaganda value. It would be better if a problem of substance is solved to grow Africa in these initial days.

The teaser is compelling and apparently the project has received funding from other sources.  The team has connections to Africa and Blockchain. I think the real challenge here is distribution whether through Social Media or Television Networks. Being produced in Swahili as well as English should help in this respect. It would be good if they could show a stronger connection to media outlets in Africa.

The success of the project is a subjective measure. Even outstanding audiovisual animated movies may not always produce the desired outcome. Therefore it won't be easy to measure the success of the project effectively.

The proposal is full of particularly good intentions, with an ambitious goal. However, besides these intentions we lack the minimum description of the solutions that would address a very widely described problem. We also must consider that climate change and environmental impact is not specific to Africa. I cannot see a wide impact on Africa for this project, because of the lack of details on the solution.

I found it an interesting idea, since the digital art market is growing and I have never seen anything related to graffiti. If people pay for "traditional" digital art, I don't see why the practice with graffiti would not work. The fact of making financial transactions using cryptocurrencies and NFT adds value to the project, which, in my view, reconciles a promising market with the practices of the Catalyst project.
Your website looks professional and gives us an idea of what we can expect from this project. Do you have connections to street artists or urban art galleries?

There referenced webshop is about rental of appartments and houses. This very different to the creation of an application that uses blockchain as it backend. I admit, that there is still the purchase of a good involved in both use-cases but the webshop for the rental business looks like a off the shelf solution. Very limited development know-how is needed to implement such solution. If there is addition know-how available, it is not stated in the proposal.
More information of technical, economic and marketing plan required to asses feasibility.

It would be nice to have a little bit more information regarding how the budget is allocated. The proposer are already committed as the Insitiute already engages in several fields. It is an advantage that there is a whole Institution behind the proposal and not just one person.
The proposer has the ability to produce the video's. No marketing plan has been detailed.

The author doesn't give a lot of details about the length or content. these details will influence the cost of production greatly. Without more exact details about the conent and cost of projection, it will be difficult to know if Catalyst funds are being used efficiently and productively.

The proposal is basically described as an investment and booking platform for real estate. Since this is something that already exists outside blockchain environments, it becomes clear that it is indeed feasible. The proposal however does not give a clear explanation on how it adresses the challenge of benefiting most possible cardano users and also does not explain why this needs to be implemented in a blockchain environment and needs funds in order to do that.

The team does not appear to have much blockchain experience. The current proposal is not for development, but developing the framework, website, branding, and legal consulting. I think the team will need to bring on some additional partners to understand the technical aspects of the Dapp, but meeting their stated goals appears feasible.

I understand that buying crypto in Ethiopia can be difficult, but having a fixed amount of ADA given to a single person, who then sells it on social channels, expecting people to trust him that they will receive their ADA does not seem like a good idea. What if something happens and it fails for whatever reason, unrelated to the actions of the proposer, then the whole Cardano community will be viewed as a scam, since this was a Project Catalyst funded project.

I have been asked about how to buy crypto currency previously.
My advice always is to find out for oneself.

Crypto currency is a risky investment and no one should be led to buy cryptocurrency without understanding what it is all about for themselves. Many people often learn the hard way.

Encouraging people to buy any cryptocurrency even if one has a high opinion about it is wrong. 
The proposal will create unhealthy expectations and an unsustainable market that will have a negative consequence for the reputation of Cardano.
