Moreover where the legality is unclear and in a country like Ethiopia where authorities can make up rules on the fly it would be wrong to assume the absence of a regulation as a loophole to be exploited. It doesn't work that way.

Moreover the challenge is about creating awareness about the technology and what the cardano can do for the community. Not about cryptocurrency. 
In Africa where cryptocurrency is viewed as a means to subvert the rules, it would be wrong for the community to get on the wrong side of the government.

The plan needs more detail on what you are actually going to do. Also why not set up an actual exchange rather than just relying on a lot of trust to get trades done. There seems a high risk that buyers lose their money in a scam that has credibility by being supported by Project Catalyst
This would be a great addition to the ecosystem. Simple safe cold storage options are valuable.

This is the beginning of a potentially good proposal, the need for quality step-by-step guides about everything Cardano is indeed a good idea. Yet what subjects wold be covered? How long would the videos be? Would they have a voice-over? All this questions and many more should be covered in a detailed plan.

The proposal does not directly address the challenge of attracting new proposers to Catalyst. A similar proposal with video guides to the Catalysts proposal process would better meet the challenge, if it could demonstrate that such resources do not exist already.

The experience of the proposer is not given in sufficient detail to build confidence. The project seems very ambitious, I think it would be more successful if 2 or 3 languages were focused on in the initial funding stage.  Not all languages will have an equal impact. There is also no detailed plan for marketing to promote adoption, and the timeframe seem short for the amount of local expertise required.  A smaller initial proposal would build confidence and encourage additional funding in future rounds.

Impact - 4
This proposal strives to a address a critical need that must be addressed - how can the Cardano community actively promote and invest in societal diversity and equity in Africa, as well as other regions with little representation in current SPOs.  Addressing this need will help the Cardano community address the two objectives listed in the campaign brief: 
(1) Cardano is considered the best public block-chain operating in Africa; and 
(2) Cardano projects in Africa are not isolated but networked and growing.  
Cardano cannot be considered the best public block-chain operating in Africa if it lacks a critical mass of SPOs based in Africa; and supporting a critical mass of SPOs in Africa will provide an important network to support and grow Cardano projects throughout Africa.

The proposal's solutions offer a sound, general roadmap for addressing the problem identified. It would bring together a steering group of relevant, knowledgeable stakeholders; it would strive to understand and quantify current diversity; it would develop a new SPO evaluation, ranking system, and prototype tool to enable stake delegation that benefits representational and decentralization goals; and it would collaborate with staking information services. These are all excellent elements to include.

But my main concern is the proposal's description of what success looks like.  The proposal currently lists three descriptions:
1) Continuous measurement and reporting on Global and African level societal decentralisation,
2) Transparent, principled, objective based SPO recommendations, and
3) Increase African and Societal level decentralisation through adoption by staking information services (has dependencies).
As written right now, these descriptions of success are laudable, but also lack measureable criteria that can be used to measure the project's progress and success.  For example, what is the anticipated time necessary to execute the different solutions?  Is there a specific, measurable outcome that is desired as part of the SPO recommendations? A transparent, principled, and objective process is essential to any recommendation, but what is the desired outcome? (e.g. x number of people informed? y number of SPO's evaluated, etc). What is a reasonable increase in decentralisation, and in what timeframe? Additional SMART criteria (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic, & Time-related), could go a long way in offering concrete ways to evaluate the project's success.

The technical information is somewhat sparse and it is unclear where traditional technology (why MongoDB?) ends and Cardano starts. Further clarification where you foresee the need for freelance developer(s) would have been helpful, too.
I'm very excited about this kind of game that uses NFTs. Your ideas and story sound great. What does the M stand for MRPG?
This proposal addresses Cardano Fund 5: DApps & Integrations Challenge. The project proposal is solid and can impact many people seeking to play game that are built on the Blockchain.
The stake pool and in-game marketplace should help long-term funding for this game How will you overcome multi-accounts and bots? PRISM might be an option.
The proposer is clearly making strides in the organization and outreach, but the success of the project will depend on community acceptance.

The proposal is very well planned and the proposers are experienced in managing projects, which is also reflected in the plan. Some work and research already has been done, which shows the commitment . Assuming they can onboard a developer, which should be well possible with the proposed budget, it is very likely that the plan will be implemented successfully

Both the proposed MVP and the final product seems to be feasible due to the team's experience and engagement. Also, all the relevant information about the proposers in linked there which is very good. The plan in clear, structured and each step is well described. Budget breakdown in the proposal is very good, and the details in the linked file are very well described. Proposal seems to be completely feasible based all the information provided.

The team appear to have the necessary skills to bring this project to fruition and the links provided helped to further this appearance. The plan is well presented and achievable. Budget is straightforward and not excessive and this gives confidence that the proposal if funded is likely to move forward. The team have done well to highlight the risks and the community questions are answered appropriately.

Overall a really sound proposal that has aced the concept of marrying blockchain technology to a use case that the community will value. The potential of this proposal is high and it resonates well with Cardano values. I feel this proposal will be well received by the community and makes for an excellent example of the type of projects that will provide value adding to the community.
What previously successful projects of yours can you highlight?
Due to missing metrics, milestones it is hard to judge the audibility.
How will success be measured? Have you thought of running a charitable stake pool?

19.35k is not a small amount but the funding is broken down in great detail in the attached document. While difficult to audit in exact terms, it should be easy to see if the project has momentum by the end of phase 1.  I would have suggested that the proposal only request funds for phase 1 to have more chances of success. If results were positive it should be easy to acquire more funding in future rounds. If you do not get the vote this time, I suggest you take that approach in future Catalyst funds.

The description of the problem and solution is clear and the proposal is in line with the challenge

Several deliverables have been described, dates for their delivery have been defined, but the absence of KPIs makes it more difficult to audit the proposal. There are details on the budget allocation.
Considering the fact that the budget is considering the management of the platforms for two years, I think it is important that the roadmap contemplates this term as well, since the deliverables described have a later date for implementation in 12 months.
proposalTitle: Open Ideas and Data For Cooperation

assessmentNote:
There's a budget breakdown, but it still leaves some open questions for example in these two items: "Review and Identification Tasks $1000"
"Swarm Sessions and Training $2500", what would the funds be used for, to pay someone for x hours of work ?
You also requesting funds to pay licenses for 3 platforms for 2 years, since this proposal emphasis on a trial and feedback-loop based iterations would it not be wiser to commit to smaller time-frame ? 
There is no clear roadmap of expected timelines presented, just "Our objective is to have a smoothly working alternative dataflow and data reporting setup as soon as possible."
proposalTitle: Open Ideas and Data For Cooperation

assessmentNote: there is a good proposed metric how to check if it works - but the aim is very low  - only 3 new proposals, as far as I understood.
It would be good to have information on how many outreach events this proposal is targeting and how many people there are at each. It is however a relatively small funding request.

Havin an easy-to-use API with great documentation, videos, & example games that allow Game Developers to create their own in game currency would be a great enrichment for the Cardano ecosystem. I deduct 1 star because of the criteria in challenge: "What are the the tools that we need to prioritize first" Having the ability to create and trade in-game currencies is not a "basic functionality".
proposalTitle: Native Token API for Game Devs

assessmentNote: The project seems to be very well thought out and meticulously planned. The proposer's previous experience as a game developer, educator and API specialist is confidence inspiring that this project will be successfully implemented. My only concern is that the roadmap and expected implementation seems a bit overly optimistic for a one-man endeavour, I would have liked to see plans to bring on a least one extra developer, part time or on a volunteer basis.
proposalTitle: Native Token API for Game Devs

assessmentNote: The proposer's honesty and ability to self evaluate the time and effort needed to successfully execute the proposal is a very positive sign that implies a level of thoroughness that will definitely make the auditing process easier. The roadmap is extremely clear and the community members doing the auditing have an exact picture of what to expect and when.
proposalTitle: Native Token API for Game Devs

assessmentNote:
The Roadmap is good but needs more details on the step-by-step action plan, including milestones and KPI'S. 
When do you plan to meet those governments? How many by when? When do you plan to release the product?

The proposal has a noble aim; however bulk of the fund is being assigned for tasks seemingly unrelated. Currently, MASAI pool has a stake of 1K ADA and to make the pool sustainable there is a requirement to attract a large number of small delegators. The proposal aim to initiate a advertisement campaign in Kenya to do this. However the idea of marketplace is not very clear.

The proposer is operating a stake pool and has experience in DevOps. He claims no experience in marketing and product promotion being a teacher. It will be a major challenge for the proposer to achieve this with the requested fund.

The proposal details how the financial amount would be used. Also, we can know, in a detailed way, how the project would be going on, as the months go by. In this way, I think there is only a lack of a sense of what the objectives are to be achieved with each action step, but other than that, everything is well situated.

The progress of the project is subjective. There is no clarity on the marketplace and what is meant by ADA Float. The use of Atala for access to the website is also vague. There are limited measurable progress points in the proposal.

Looking at this from 30000ft it ticks all the right boxes, What might be useful is to expand on any basic research you/other groups have done to date  and which strand you are potentially looking to explore further. Even if this is at a very high level it will help contextualise the interoperability problem for the voters (most of whom will not read beyond the headline)

There is clarity in the description of the problem and the solution. The proposal is within the scope of the challenge. One of the big problems with NFTs is that the scarcity of it only exists within the blockchain in which it was created, studying ways to move these NFTs through different blockchains in a safe way is important for the NFT ecosystem to develop. The creation of a viable model of portability of these NFTs could provide new options and tools for developers to expand related applications.

The absence of tangible metrics makes it difficult to assess the impact of this challenge.

Think of it as DNS for Cardano addresses. Its easy to underestimate what a game changer this could be. Someday human readable addresses will be the norm. The project aims to help developers integrate this functionality into their Dapps, and will also provide a new role for stake pool operators.

The proposer has 20+ years experience in the gaming industry which helps a lot. But there is no mention of experience in the blockchain area. Then such a game uses a lot of time to develop and the proposer is working alone, maybe searching for a team would help.

A more detailed plan and budget is missing unfortunately.

The proposer provides no auditable goals on which to audit the success of the project. If funding was received, how many NFT artworks would be commissioned? How rich of a game world can we expect for the 12,000 dollar funding? How will gameplay provide revenue to the developer to make the project sustainable?
No information around the team behind this. No detailed technical experience required, more of a marketing and entrepreneurship required.
The only thing missing is some methods to quantify the actual gain (#) of people who are joining the community because of the Slush partnership.

I can see the benefit of an open source Yoroi metadata backend, but I wish the proposers had made a stronger effort to describe the use case  or included the rational in their previous proposal.  More rational as to why this would be better than a native Yoroi solution would also be appreciated.

This is a good use case for the immutability of the blockchain. I would add that just have the ability to store predictions immutably when they are made to later go back access their accuracy would be very useful

The proposal team is well qualified, and the description of the plan and deliverables describe a viable and achievable approach. Accomplishing the goals (five deliverables) in a single calendar month seems overly ambitious, but none of the goals are particularly risky. The proposal is also not specific about the language/platform on which the tool/framework will be implemented--that makes it more difficult to assess the software-development risks.
This is an interesting proposal. It is not clear this proposal meets the objectives of this fund. It is not focused on the developer ecosystem.

The proposer is very enthusiastic and responsive, but I think the plan is a little too ambitious. One or two languages only  could be tried in a test run, and more funding requested in subsequent Catalyst rounds. This would result in a project easier to manage and more likely to produce high-quality, relevant content.

The team is already developing ERGO DEX (on ERGO's blockchain) and has expertise in different areas relevant to the proposal as research and development, software engineering and experience in functional programming languages (Scala and Haskell), but there is no information about experience with the Plutus language or if the team is participating in the Plutus Pioneer Program.

The plan is reasonable, detailed, includes a clear and objective roadmap. There are details on budget allocation.

A recommendation that may seem unnecessary, but I think it is important to change the name of DEX. If a DEX adopts the name of the blockchain itself, it ends up causing confusion, even more when there is an interest that the project be ported to Cardano. It doesn't make any sense to have an "ETHEREUM DEX" running on Cardano's blockchain for example (To be clear, this is a recommendation to the team and I'm not using it to set the score, just to give feedback)

Because of the professionalism of the proposer and the proposal, I feel implementation will be successful if fully funded.  The team has a core of 6 people with diverse experience.  The ALDEA website is professional looking.  They are backed a DAO with stakepools and are obviously integrated into the Cardano community, which helps me feel confident in the proposals success
Requires detailed plan, and the ability to implement it.

This proposal is not a DeFi protocol, it's an API marketplace, this belongs in a dApp or developer ecosystem challenge not in a DeFi focused challenge. its also not at all how this makes Cardano DeFi protocols more competitive, when you look at the protocols that scale Etheruem DeFi sector, 0 of them are API marketplaces, instead they focus on derivatives, swaps, lending, insurance and automated trading strategies. 

Developers also only need 2 Cardano API's and Blockfrost to build a dApp

What is a CNFT? Anyway, this project looks great. I can't wait to play this kind of game with NFTs. How will the game prevent multi-accounts and bots getting an advantage? These are two thing that can kill a game.

A popular game could in principle drive adoption of Cardano to a wider audience, however this project doesn't present the elements of what would make it unique, both as an interactive experience or as a blockchain technology. Apart form mentioning that certain elements of the game would be tokenised no mention of how these mechanics would work.
I would suggest rewriting the proposal with a focus on what would make the project unique and popular and thus drive adoption to Cardano.

The proposal fully addresses the challenge: a viral RGP browser game, if properly realized, can attract a lot of new users and open the Cardano ecosystem to the "entertainment" sector. The reference sector for games is undoubtedly relevant and above all aimed at a general public.
The use of CNTFs within the game is an important factor in terms of adoption and generated transactions.
If the game begins to be used it is inevitable that a volume will be created for the exchange of CNTFs in addition to what happens in the game.
The idea of ​​developing the entire battle mechanism directly in-chain gives even more value to what has already been indicated.
Information on a marketing plan would be good.

With regards to IFOs, will the projects be screened by your team? IDOs similar to those on Uniswap can be permissionless, but it would be good to also have offerings where there is more trust because the projects have been vetted. You could talk more about security of funds.

Sounds like a great project. Curation is definitely something the NFT space needs. I like how art organisations and the artist will get paid through smart contracts when pieces are sold on the secondary market. I wonder how we can bring more traditional artists to the NFT space. Very few of my favourite artists have released NFTs. I also like how you broaden the scope to paintings, music and photography. Could universities art departments be included? And what about private art owners? Could they make NFTs of the original artworks that they own?

Very detailed proposal. Maybe needs to be condensed a little, as it's quite a long read. The market opportunity section doesn't read very well. One of your links to the questionnaire didn't work as there's an asterisk placed at the end which needs deleting.

I give this proposal a 5 for impact because the application idea aims to bring a high level of value to users in this calendar year. They are developing an IOS application to help migrants send funds home to family members in a user friendly manner (mitigating the confusion around sending cryptos in the current space). This proposal seeks to use crypto to explicitly make the world a better place. My only concern about meeting the goal of the challenge regards profitability. As the proposal states, transaction fees will be "almost zero" so I wonder how app creators will create a profit. But I still give it a 5 even considering that question.

The proposers seem to have a lot of experience with the structure of the Discord, however not with programming (at least it is not mentioned under relevant experience). A realistic time budget is presented.

Since this project is very simple, it would be easy to audit and confirm that it has been performed according to the plan, specially because it would be an open source development. Also, KPI is clearly stated and it is sufficient to evaluate the proposal impact. Obs.: This assessment is very similar to the one in Bot to Assign Channels, because the proposal text is almost the same as well.

The plan is simple to implement but the methodology for selecting projects for funding is not clear. Catalyst follows a very rigorous peer review process. Without this step, it is not possible to assess the success of the initiative.

The proposal doesn't provide the experience of the team members. It doesn't explain how the "product operation gets done effectively". It doesn't explain how the micro-proposals would be reviewed, and what ensures that the first mini proposal are operating within 3 months, nor why it actually takes 3 months if mini-proposals are targeting a $1k budget.

The proposal is well aligned with Cardano's mission to become a central technology in the future, although I am not sure if such a solution is completely feasible. In the near future, most country will have regulations regarding transactions and it will not be as easy as it is today to send money abroad without paying the usual taxes. Although, I believe such a solution could still have lower taxes than the current methods.
The success criteria and suggested metrics are rather broad and could be refined further, although, they are sufficient to measure progress.

Part of this issue here is that success is driven by the world outside the community. To be accepted as the best solution for NFT's, we need more than just technical NFT solutions. It requires a concerted marketing solution. VHS didn't beat BetaMax by being technically superior. Interoperability with other NFT solution will be key.

The metrics proposed don't actually measure the stated goal. We need to measure to market share gains in NFT's on Cardano vs other platforms, probably by both numbers of NFT's and value. Perhaps also looking at market share across industries, geographies etc. This is much bigger than collectible art in the long term.

This appears to be a proposal to promote stake pool diversification, rather than a challenge for example that could be more useful broadened to be "how best to improve Cardano's decentralisation" I don't believe it is controversial or needing of multiple proposals to encourage diversification these are more issues that can be addressed through network parameter modification.

Suggested KPIs are easy to manipulate since it is not difficult to claim various geographical locations or obtaining an extra team member to claim a different country. Giving new SPOs $2000 dollars has varying buying power around the world and will not provide a level playing field. Furthermore, the biggest investment for an SPO is their stake, which at the current valuation of ADA will run in the tens of thousands USD in order to have a slightly attractive and competing stake pool. It is unclear where these funds will be aquired.
Need more metrics to assess proposals rather than success or otherwise of the challenge itself

I agree that AI is a massively important area for technological development, and that it is brilliant news that Singularity have chosen Cardano to partner  with. In particular the way in which governance can be suitably and democratically organised to make AI ethical is I think a vital and unique function that Cardano can bring to the process. It is great that this challenge suggests we should be thinking about how we as a community can help with it. I wonder though whether the best approach would be to work with Singularity off line rather than through Catalyst for the time being until the Singularity roadmap is better understood and the community can be more targeted in its interaction, particularly on the ethics and governance side of AI development.

The challenge is to define and implement a process for improving and benchmarking auditable in the Catalyst proposal. With the large community, it is quite feasible to come up with a unique methodology.

The proposal does identify all the pertinent metric and value points that would indicate whether a project is running well and as planned. These could well form the basis of what the 'audit team' could measure. Instead of proposals under this challenge, we could instead as a community vote on expert, learned and experienced community members who could form part of the audit team to assist IOG in this laborious task. This removes 'Auditability'  from being being a challenge but we could instead on-board voter-selected panelists, and I suggest, consisting of very experienced VCAs (e.g. the proposer of this proposal), funded by the treasury.
The number of funded proposals from this project could also be used as a metric.

Criteria may need to be revised once an implementation team is assembled. Perhaps it may be best to first measure use volume outside of cardano based on real examples of NFTs.  Real-Estate ownership immediately comes to mind as a real-world example where there is huge need for ownership verification.

Metrics and KPIs are stated, some number would improve even more this information. The roadmap is simple, but clear and effective. The risk of not being funded again, if the first fund is received, was not assessed to inform what would be the plan if such a thing happens.
If this works, would be great for the customer. A platform which can unite every streaming platform and cheaper than average.
Due to the roadmap it is quit easy to audit the system when the team issues prograssing reports on a regular base.
I give a 1 for impact because, while it is an interesting idea, the proposal does not indicate a timeline so I cannot know whether the proposal will bring value to Cardano users in 2021.
proposalTitle: Cardano Support for Point of Sale

assessmentNote: How big is the BTCpay market? Is 85,000 too much to enable this functionality? It is a large portion of the fund.
proposalTitle: Cardano Support for Point of Sale

assessmentNote: I would like to add the option not only transfer ADA into a stablecoin, but to any other pair a user can choose on the setting. And be able to do it on a limit sale or at a stop loss
This proposal address of the many needs in cryptocurrency space that's seldom overlook, especially as regulation is tightened around the industry.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: I felt sure this proposal was within the Grow Africa Grow Cardano section only to discover after reading it that it was Dev ecosystem. That's ok but I could not help but think the former was more appropriate. So in essence this immediate proposal   is to hire and train 3-4 developers to work on the much bigger Cardano proposal to come later.
proposalTitle: Devs for Awarenes Event West Africa

assessmentNote: The team seems to be highly qualified and the plan is well laid out. Since they are already working on it I see no problem with it being implemented successfully.
This proposal is creating a different opportunity for monetizing user data, where users are in control of their own data as well as benefiting from it, unlike the current/traditional system.

This is a well thought out and described project. It is a strong candidate to receive funding under this proposal. It should be noted the proposers have submitted another proposal for 19200 funding under the metadata challenge

The proposer presented a clear budget and roadmap. The only thing that might aggregate the project is specifically say how much the ambassador will need, for example. It's hard for me to depend on a person in a dapp to give me critical information, since the proposal says nothing about contracts and payments.
The breakdown of the requested funds (see pdf), the listed metrics, open-sourcing the contract, and the communication with the proposer warrant the highest auditability score.
simplification of calendar and resources would be useful, though it may not directly affect the fund goal.

This project takes an existing centralised application and applies to in a decentralised way on the Cardano blockchain. This would drive a large number of users to interact repeated with the blockchain.

This is a well thought out and described project. It is a strong candidate to receive funding under this proposal. The proposer has also submitted another proposal for 42400 under the DApps and integrations challenge.
Another proposal to add functionality that is missing in IdeaScale. The alleged gap is really there.
The proposal could use more detail on how it is going to solve the issues raised, ideally in an automated fashion.
More detail required to asses feasibility. Currently it is an idea, not a feasible proposal.
What platform is this being created through. How in the incentivization scheme going to work.

There is no roadmap but it is not a proplem as the proposal is different to others meaning it is more experminental. The first goal is to work with other projects to identify the areas of greatest need.
The proposer is operating spectrum pool and has demonstrated expertise in the related field.
This proposal effects many west african countries with various approaches and indeed seems money well spent in order to have a big diversified effect
This proposal meet Fund 5 Grow Africa, Grow Cardano Challenge. If implemented well this proposal will bring a lot of new people to use the Cardano platform.
The Proposers have the experience required to deliver this project. A relatively detailed cost breakout of the plan by location is provided.
It is likely for this proposal to be implemented because it includes a straightforward plan which will serve the Cardano Community build momentum and growth in Africa.

The proposal mostly makes its purpose clear and how it is going to be implemented. It would have been interesting however to have more examples of what the miro page will contain in order to have a clearer vision of what the community would get out of the funds.

For such a simple project, it would be very simple to audit, which is to check that Miro board is ready after 3 months. I personally believe this would be ready in even less time. There is no risk or challenge associated.
Whilst these improvements will enhance the process, they seem marginal.
The proposal address the current challenge being faced by the proposers.
Who's better equipped than Ideascale to implement changes to Ideascale?
The plan is simple and well detailed and the team should have no problem implementing it.
The team which is running the current site will be able to make this modification.
DEXes are center pieces of a blockchain-based economy.
This is a complete dApp challenge proposal to build a multi-feature DEX on Cardano
The Dapp integrates the Cardano ecosystem with other protocols.
they did, they also have a far out timeline for completion.
In my opinion,  information given is a enough to assess the success of of the project.
It is not clear how this project will reach proposers
Proposal is for the development of a trading dApp with automated strategies mirroring top traders
Team behind the proposal has extensive market making experience and a complete project plan.

Whilst this would be great to have, there are ways to achieve it using other intermediaries which already handle the FIAT side such as centralised exchanges, payments providers (VISA/Mastercard/paypal) and other cryptocurrencies. If people can directly earn ADA and can spend it on real world goods and services, the need to convert to fiat diminishes.

A challenge that promotes the integration of ADA with FIAT is something that is in line with Cardano's mission, but a reference timeline for the challenge has not been defined, which increases subjectivity.


One of the requirements of the checklist is that the challenge does not include the endorsement of a specific proposal and the proposer is referencing his proposal:

"I have a solution, which will be given in Fund 7 (I'm not saying this in attempt to corner the challenge. I'm telling you this so you know it's 100% feasible.)
This Proposal Solves the "Philippines Problem".
* Proposal received over 200 Kudos in previous funding round.
Once the transition between $ ADA and FIAT and back is easier and cheaper for consumers than going from one FIAT to another (ex: USD to YEN), $ ADA will become a world currency by default…
The funding request amount is due to not only cost of development but also the creation of liquidity pools. "
There is no detailed project plan included in this proposal or attachments

Not clear this is feasible for the community. DID requires use cases. This means finding large organisations (public or private), to take on DID's on blockchains (such as the Ethiopian education system deal). These types of deals are more generally achieved through centralised marketing than a decentralised approach. However maybe across the community we have the connections.
The Success Metrics and Criteria can effectively address the challenge.
Use cases for NFTs are abundant, the  community should not have any problems of bringing up ideas and proposals to sell cardano NFTs to the world.
Use cases can definitely be crowd sourced by the community.
The success criteria and metrics are ok. I can wait to see the proposals to take off.
Yes, more stake pools = more decentralisation and lead to more tps in the future

I think the proposer needs to think more widely on how this could be achieved. Simple ideas like changing the SPO rankings, or changing the SPO block selection algorithms to favour geographic diversity can push this to happen by changing the economic incentives. We don't need to specifically fund the physical setup of nodes in countries.
Measurement seems straight forward enough; number of pools in country after 12 months
No clear metrics for success, other than "sell and NFT for a lot".
It does, and it is evolving, through Catalyst.
Awesome idea. Reliability needs to be incentivised to be achieved.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: This is definitely within scope of what the community can achieve.
proposalTitle: Disaster: When all is at stake

assessmentNote: The proposer states: This funding challenge isn't devised to promote: (a) diversity training, (b) hiring tests, (c) performance ratings and/or (d) quotas. But nothing from the proposal itself reads any different than the initiatives he mentions, neither in motivation, nor scope.
This seems too big a goal for the cardano community.
We can and should step up to this challenge.
The community could definitely achieve this if funding was provided.

The interoperability of blockchains is a very hard to cope with topic, as only a portion of the catalyst community are developers and even a smaller fraction of those will have the technical knowledge to understand multiple blockchain mechanisms in order to execute projects tackling interoperability problems. However something the catalyst community could cope with is indeed beeing in contact with other blockchain communities and elaborate cooperations on common goals that could then be pitched to the actual devs.

This is really a matter for IOHK and Cardano Foundation leaders at this point rather than the community, supportive as the community is of a rational, informing and friendly approach to partners, competitors and the public.

I am conflicted in my assessment of this proposal because firstly, I do see the need for better auditing processes not only when there will be hundreds of on-going funded projects but also now with the projects we have already funded. I am uncertain of the level of auditing currently being performed and whether IOHK publishes their data and findings, but I trust that it is being done correctly. Secondly, whilst I agree with the most of the details presented here on how and what to look for in validating quality of projects, keeping to standards & ROI, I find it hard to accept that this is better served & performed decentrally as opposed to a more central/appointed/annointed committee or company or a group of people who can maintain the sets of standards to measure. We as Cardano would do ourselves a disservice knowing our blockchain is peer-reviewed and rigorously wrung through academics and experts to then have to rely on a decentralised approach to validate the projects that are tacked on to Cardano and funded by Catalyst, by relatively unknown parties. At least now with IOG being in charge of auditing, there is comfort knowing its being done to a certain standard and one we can trust.

I think this a a process matter unlikely to garner great innovative feedback from the majority of Catalyst participants, however the issue raised will be of interest to proponents and to the governance process.

Accountability agents are already identified as a part of the Cardano (Voltaire) roadmap. Success of this challenge will be determined by the number of proposals, the funding levels requested and the final reporting that is generated.
Good metrics within the terms of the proposal themselves. Could be improved by adding community feedback on the success or otherwise of the application of Treasury funding.
I am sure the community could pull this off if they desired.
Eventually, however we need to work on governance first.
If neccessary, experts or skills and structures will have to be put in place.
Great idea to get more people involved and building for Cardano.
This could be a very useful use case driving Cardano.
The community has the requisite knowledge and when engage the best experts.
This type of challenge is within the communities ability to deliver.
The criteria and metrics proposed are spot on and effective for its purpose.
It is easy to count the NFT-connected proposals.

I give an impact score of 1 for several reasons. The challenge is to bring value to users in 2021 but it does not seem feasible for this card to launch in 2021, as the proposer states - it is no easy task to become a card issuer. It also isn't clear why Cardano funded prepaid debit cards are important. Almost no metrics or scaling addressed in the proposal.

I see this idea as feasible and aligned with the Challenge's goals. Although, I don't see any great advantage of such a system. Since the ADA would be converted into FIAT to pop-up the debit card, the only difference between doing this via this Dapp and using an usual debit card is that it would be done in a single step. I believe it should be considered some way to keep the balance in ADA in the wallet, and also to find aspects to differentiate from other cards, for e.g. cashback. It would be good to check what other solutions already exist. The non-custodial aspect of this current solution already is a good differential.

BTCPay does describe itself as a self-hosted, open-source cryptocurrency payment processor. Furthermore, it states that it is secure, private, censorship-resistant and free. I like that. I've personally been searching for an open-source no-free, self-hosted, no-intermediary cryptocurrency payment processor and having one that integrates ADA would be excellent for the ecosystem, in my view. I know that it is not an easy thing to find - and having ADA included would be a boon. I think that the proposer has identified a clear case of an integration that merits attention and that will benefit the Cardano ecosystem. The proposed project to add Cardano support to BTCPay Server is something that would collectively advance the use of ADA & help to promote adoption. Effectively, I think the proposed project hits the nail on the head in terms of - increasing both utility & adoption of Cardano. I think that - if executed succesfully - the proposal would add value and more options to the Cardano ecosystem and its users and stakeholders.
proposalTitle: Cardano Support for Point of Sale

assessmentNote:
The developers are providing links to their LinkedIn profiles as proof of their claimed 20+ years of combined professional experience in iOS development.

Their track records there leave little doubt concerning their capabilities about their Swift development skills. More information on their experience in cryptography is needed though ; as one of the first rule for devs dealing with cryptography is "don't create your own crypto library". This lack of experience or mention of it could be compensated with a planned audit of their code but there is no mention of such an audit (mandatory when dealing with cryptography of this magnitude).

We also really regret that they don't go into any detail on how the API their library will provide will actually work: to what backend will it connect to?
The goal of such SDKs is to provide a solid bridge for developer to the Cardano blockchain but we don't know how their bridge will look like, how long it will be or where it will land. This lack of information makes it difficult to properly assess its feasibility or future strength, although there are several ways to achieve this, some are more decentralized than others and directly impact the longevity of such a project.

There is also no mention of long term support. The project focus on a very short 8 weeks development plan with very little details on what features the SDK will actually provide so even if it is successfully implemented we don't really know what to expect... The experience of the developer implies that they must have thought about this, we can only give them the benefit of the doubt but the lack of information is unfortunately too important to give this proposal more than 2 stars in feasibility. 

They've built their proposal to explain the non-developers why it is useful but they forgot that the Community Advisors spending time reviewing proposals in the dev eco system are often other engineers who need real details about how things will actually work in order to assess if their project is viable. As it is, the proven experience of the developers is the only positive aspect concerning the feasibility of this proposal but this alone is not enough...

A very good solution to a problem we'll all grapple with in years to come. Despite the fact this is very US-centric (and I myself am outside of the jurisdiction), this first step may well open up later developments that can solve similar tax regulation challenges in many other countries. That the proposal mentions 'international' accommodation at a later phase paves the way for further development. Crypto taxes are becoming more sophisticated (Aust included) and where 3 years ago there were no mentions of stake taxes, now it's a recognised aspect of the reporting obligation. I can foresee my own headaches in manually calculating my crypto taxes for 2020-2021 and if this solution can ease the activity somewhat, then it's a very good solution indeed.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: The proposer does have the appropriate SME level expertise to oversee the development of the project.  Additional information specific to the developer requirements would make this proposal more complete.  The proposer also appears to have a development team performing similar work on the Tezos blockchain.  Looking at the proposed scope as written, the funding amount for a developer to perform the work could be reevaluated and/or address the features likely to be created in this proposal
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote:
The proposer does have first-hand knowledge of the tax system and is a US tax attorney licensed in the state of Florida, with a masters degree in taxation law. However, experience with taxation is key - although the software development side is also critical for the proposals success. 
I like that he developed a Tezos web-based tool - and it speaks favorably of his abilities. 
The proposer states that this project will require hiring no more than 2 professional freelance software developers. At least 90% of any secured funds will go towards this portion of the project. What is not clear is has the proposer identified the exact competencies of the software developers that he needs and whether he will be able to oversee their work properly and ensure smooth delivery. 
As the project is being proposed by a single proposer, without a developer team in place - or clearly identified (at least in terms of competencies), it remains to be seen whether the proposer can really deliver on the expected first stage results: "a private and stable price oracle and REST-API database bridge that is suitable for traditional tax finance reporting purposes". This is somewhat of a weakeness as the proposal would have benefited from listing the relevant skills and experience of other team members required to implement the proposal. 
Although the proposer gives a Q1 2022 deadline for finishing the project there is no detailed timetable for the specific stages that would allow an auditor to measure progress, which may be an important ommission. 
While the proposal states that at least 90% of the secured funds will go towards 2 professional freelance software developers, it is not clear how this calculation has been made and where will the remaining 10% of funds end up. 
The three stages of the proposal ($15,000, $12,000 and $8,000) do not seem to have further cost breakdown so it is difficult to judge how well they are prepared and how realistic they are, especially as the software developers are not part of the team yet. So, are these estimates too high, are they too low, are they just right? How much coding services will be required, how many hours of work, how much will an hour of freelance coding cost? Further details may make this proposal very firm and very tight. In case it is not voted for in Fund 5, it would be good if the proposer were to resubmit it with the additional information - a clearer timetable and better identified team/tasks and costs would make it very very good.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: Academically and by background, the proposer has presented bona fides pertinent to the solution. Grappling with tax law is the hardest component of this project. The proposal indicates familiarity with what is required in able to produce a working solution. Translating these requirements to codeable elements is the main challenge. That said, there is enough background presented here to see the project through. What would be helpful is a breakdown of the milestones by resources and by cost in order to get a sense that the plan is executable and achievable in the timeframe mentioned. As mentioned in the Comments section, 35k is a significant amount to allocate to this very important solution, given the total funds for F5 is limited. It could be an option to break this down into a multi-fund proposal with each fund addressing each of the phases.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: This proposal does have a roadmap that consists of three key stages and a general time horizon for achievement, with a working product expected in Q1 2022. The three individual phases do not have deadlines for completion, which could mean that the proposer either forgot to include them or has not developed a clear timetable for each stage. The proposer did include metrics for measuring the end result ("a report of the comprehensive tax picture for the user that includes the determination of income from staking ADA, any gain or loss from selling ADA, income from receiving payments in ADA for any other reason, and the potential tax liability form sales or exchanges of ADA that was received, but not purchased"). There is a clear understandable description of the problem and a solution is offered, however the proposal could provide more information about the technical challenges. The proposer is currently acting solo - without a team/group of software developers. The experience of the software team members is key for developing a good private and stable price oracle and REST-API database bridge - but it is impossible to assess that developer experience currently in this proposal, as this will come later when the "2 professional freelance software developers" (no details about required skills and experience) come on board. Taking into account that is a technical, software proposal for a DApp/Integration, the  lack of verifiable experience of the to-be-identified developers is  a minus in terms of assessing its feasibility. We don't know anything about the two key people who will develop the software component of this project. This is the key first stage that is also the most expensive, so if it does not deliver, the project will be in jeopardy.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: Project required more details on the technical implementation required, and how this impacts timeline and milestones. This is especially important since the proposer is not a technical expert but intends to hire this talent.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: The proposal has a relatively detailed road map. However, there is a lack of information on the requirement of budget and rationale for a ambitious time plan. The proposal also claims that "The platform will be deployed once that smart contracts are available on Cardano and we have completed all the development and testing". The statement that development and testing have been completed is conflicting with the requirement of money and the quantum of fund projected.

The proposal lacks a budget breakdown in order to better understand how the money will be spent, and also some KPIs to measure the community engagement with the game. Besides that, there is a good roadmap with some already accomplished goals (which could have more information in the proposal as well) for the first phase of the game, which is really nice. It would be good to see some mapped risks as well. But the auditability of the proposal is overall good.

The proposer provided a good breakdown of how the funds would be allocated, but currently there's no research done to establish the baseline for KPI metrics for each phase/months such as # restaurants/ consumers / drivers signed, as well as expected revenue

Although a label registry for on-chain financial data is relevant to the Metadata Challenge, the proposal does not effectively detail the specific approach and solution for achieving that. Rather, it states requirements and assumes that third-party capabilities would be available to support the solution of the stated problem.

Proposer has not covered any of the regulatory hurdles that may be involved in setting this up. Are there money laundering of KYC issues that would need to be covered before VISA would allow this? These are probably much bigger than the technical issues and should be addressed.

I give a 2 for impact because it is a fantastic idea but I think the timeline for implementation is fantasy at best. The proposal says that by later this year 10 studios will be on board to host their content on the application but there are no business development people on the team. There is no evidence that there are connections to studios who would host their content on this application. So the challenge of getting this done in 2021 is just not going to be met. However, they could likely get their platform up and running it just won't have premium content at a level comparable to netflix. I think this app could add a lot of value to cardano users.

I give a 2 for auditability since their main metric for success is number of users. I think the code, marketing, and other metrics need to be included to be audited but the proposal includes very little to go off of.

Unfortunately, the information provided is very scarce as we don't really know what to expect: This proposal can be summed up in a single very short sentence: "A Swift SDK that will provide an API for developers to deal with Wallets, Address, Keys and Transactions leveraging the use of the available hardware secure chip". That is nearly all the information we are provided once you remove the "Why it's useful part". So we don't know to which extent they plan to support each of these four aspects nor if they've properly assessed the challenges and risks associated.
Since they have experience in unit tested code well then why not provide a list of the unit tests their library plans to pass in each category?

This proposal effectively addresses the goal of developing a DApp that provides values through its integration with the Cardano ecosystem.  The end-user of the DApp would benefit through the simplification of the tax process required.  The only slight concern would be with future regulation changes and the ability of the application to picot and/or develop features to address said changes.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote:
This proposal does identify a really important integration for blockchain technologies - creating a "link" to facilitate reporting of transactions to the legacy tax systems that exist in real life. The focus of the proposal is to develop a web based tax solution for on chain and staking reward activity. I personally see it as a well-worth integration for a blockchain system that aims to become the "global financial operating system" - as the taxation aspects need to be facilitated to end users. 
The proposed tax compliance tool is a a US tax attorney licensed in the state of Florida, with an LL.M Masters in the laws of taxation, which indicates a good understanding of the matter at hand. 
Greater transparency and certainty about taxes for US (and other stakeholders) is certainly of value for the Cardano ecosystem. The three project phases seem to be well conceived in general terms and there is already a seemingly working backtobasics site providing a similar service for the Tezos blockchain. 
I like the fact that the proposer has thought of long-term sustainability of the project via the sale of access to a private and stable price oracle and REST-API database bridge to third party users.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: The proposer has the tax knowledge (LinkedIn profile to verify would be good). He does not have the technical expertise. Without a detailed technical plan it is impossible to know it the requested funds will be adequate to hire the required people to complete the technical side of the project.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: This proposal lays out a high-level assessment of what needs to be done and what it aims to accomplish.  The ambiguity of taxation across the US and the World may make this proposal need to clearly define what success looks like.  If the DApp doesn't aim to address specific tax regulations and only focus on developing a tax basis and capital gains output, then the scope of this project may be scaled down.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: The proposal is presented well enough that it will effectively address the challenge. Familiarity with US tax law (and potential modification to accomodate other jurisdictions) is a confidence booster. The proposal lists each of the phases required, however, it may benefit from a professional blockchain/IT developer to assess each step through the development process to validate some assumptions in terms of resources and costing. This should provide granularity in terms of milestones and the work required. It may be prudent for the proposer to engage  developers early on and lock commitments to be part of the team to enhance this proposal into a ready-to-start project
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote:
Although creating a web platform is not the hardest thing, what came to my attention is that only one participant gave its linkedin reference. We do not have relevant reference of the information of the other two which are already participating.
Another point is that the aim of this project is to 'merge with […] other relevant projects as possible […]" in order to be collaborative, but it does not explain how it wants to achieve it.
This proposal does not address how much money it'll need to start running and nor how much it would cost to maintenance and which part (how much or percentage) would stay in the pool.
I think it's important to have more clarity in the explanation of how it would be feasible – important to describe how much money it would cost to start, how it would generate funds to maintain the platform, how much would be necessary to stay in the pool, in accordance with the number of users, to incentive them to help the platform and how it would be delivered to them.

Obviously there is a need to swap the native tokens on cardano. Developing a decentralized exchange on cardano is a fantastic idea. However as this is one of the most known applications for smart contracts there is going to be other proposal DEXes that try to achieve the same.  It is hard to see from this proposal how exactly YaYswap stands out. I think expaining in detail how your edge against competitors will benefit cardano could really help the value proposition!

This proposal is aligned with the challenge objective, is presented with a very well structure project with clear targets and appropriate timelines. The proposal takes in consideration the next steps after the first contact through the marketing campaign, the concept behind the landing page I consider appropriate. The entire catalyst community and ultimately the Cardano community will benefit from the successful implementation of this proposal. The result of the implementation of this proposal can give us key information that allows us to make decisions as a community to improve the on boarding experience of new entrepreneurs. To improve this proposal I would suggest the inclusion of content that promotes or reinforces "Catalyst" as a brand. That the new members understand that this is not just a funding opportunity, but rather a new way to add value to the world.

I think one of the reasons why there are not more activity on Catalyst is that very few people know about it. The platform and decentralized nature is actually amazing, but more people need to hear about it. I think a lot of people ended up here kind of randomly. An ad campaign targetting entrepreneurs, both blockchain savvy and those with ideas that would benefit from blockchain (like I was when I found Catalyst) would be very useful for attracting more people.

Not enough detail has been provided relative to the $140,000 USD requested. 

As a yardstick, for individuals applying for a job or a grant (elsewhere) paying that much, they have to demonstrate that they are trustworthy, have the expertise to deliver such a project, jump through some hoops, and can produce plans and milestones for the project. 

While Catalyst doesn't mandate such things yet, I can not affirm that this proposal will be implemented successfully without a similar level of vetting.

The author of the proposal claims to be a veteran of the security technology he intends to implement (Plutus smart), in addition to having experience with Cryto and development technology. He attaches his linkedin profile to prove his achievements, which always transmits security in the past information. I just missed the intention of forming a team, because hardly a project can happen entirely under the responsibility of one person. As far as I can imagine, at least it would be interesting to include a UX / UI designer to make the application more ergonomic for the public. Therefore, I believe that the author does have competence, but he also needs other people to carry out a more solid project.

The scope of this proposal is developing a prototype for the paper wallets authentification system, given the fact that the proposal states that he's a Plutus Pioneer and the timeframes given, no major obstacles in developing this prototype should occur. The only slight reservations I have about the project is the fact that it's completely reliant on the existence of smart contracts and the timeframes given for the project don't take any possible delays with the deployment of that into account. I would have liked to see a clear identification of this risk and others that the team might face in the implementation of the project.

The author provides a plan of goals to be achieved according to the months and a division of the financial amount that has been requested. It also clarifies what your intentions are in case the plan works, how to expand the project. Apparently, an investment would no longer be necessary, since the application would be ready, it would only be distributed among more stores. Thus, the details of the practical part of the plan are well understood. Just one observation would be that, as I said earlier, I believe that other people would also be needed to carry out the project, the money would need to be reorganized between the parties, including the salaries of the new team members. Other than that, everything seems to me well resolved.

Using Cardano to generate thrust is a good principle in general and applying this goal to charity donations makes sense. The definition of the problem is supported by a thorough study from give.org. Charities using this app could bring new users to Cardano and bring visibility through a real-world application. The proposer evaluates the existing targeted market at several hundred billion USD. It is also claimed that new users could involve in a donation process thanks to the thrust added by this app.

This proposal provides an interesting use case for metadata which is also protected by encryption. What isn't clear is how this idea will advance the use of cardano's metadata, and why this needs to be on chain. For instance, I can store encrypted files and transfer them already without needing to use cardano.

This proposal does pose to solve an interesting future issue concerning the next phase of financial infrastructure being built in the Cardano Ecosystem.  Details are provided, but a further statement to show the impact of why if not completed would help to drive the impactfulness of the project.

The proposal doesn't provide any concrete measurable details that would show progress. It also doesn't provide goals for the proposal.  The proposal mentions giving the funds to another entity that isn't identified.
There isn't sufficient information to audit this proposal, because there is no road map or implementation plan. In addition, how will the protocol be standardized without bugs, securely?

I believe that the team has relevant experience to make this happen, although it seems that there are no blockchain devs already engaged with the project. Also, I see the lack of commercial experience, specially in the area of video content and IP In general, as a possible down sides. I believe that the targets for 2021 and 2022 are very optimistic. It doesn't mean it won't happen, I just think it will take longer than what is stated in the proposal.
Probably adding a more detailed roadmap with in order to give more information and points to the public verify the steps being accomplished.

No detailed plan or technical experience. What oracle are you using for price assessment? How is the exchange conducted? What stablecoin and where is it held? What about tax implications? It may be more tax effective to hedge with a derivatives product and not exit into a stable coin. Would you line up transactions with staking windows?

The proposer has background in US tax system, but he would need help in developing smart contracts especially in Cardano ecosystem. There's less information on how long each phase of the deliverable would take as well as whether the project will be open sourced or not.
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: KPI measurement is not clearly stated in the proposal for each milestones especially related to the expected users/ecosystem
proposalTitle: Back to Basis - Tax compliance tool

assessmentNote: Team claims the experience to deliver. I do question though given their experience why the timeline is so long. Can you not expedite it, which would also help hit the fund goal.

I would have liked to see a little more details on how the selection process would work, but other than that I haven't found anything lacking, perhaps an estimated start date but I'm guessing it could start as soon funds are received.
Catalyst could indeed benefit from a dashboard page. One star less because the proposal does not elaborate how and by whom such a website will be maintained and what the ongoing costs are.

I believe the idea is very good, we really need a centralized website to gather most of the information around Catalyst. As mentioned in the proposal, there is already a website going on, and it would be good to partner up with them instead of doing something from scratch. I see that there are other developments going in the some website and it would be good to have it done like that. I was just a bit worried about the maintenance, since budget only mentions the setup, but I believe this will be included in a future proposal.

This project does have a significant impact on the catalyst community to create a calendar as well as learning resources that are stored on the catalyst.  This will be able to help grow awareness and centralize information needed to learn and understand Catalyst better than the current form of mixed social media items (Discord, Telegram, Catalyst Site, etc...).  Centralizing the resources in a single place will be helpful.  Further defining what those resources are and whether they are existing in another place or will be newly created.

This one of the first dex's to launch on Cardano and the proposal is complete however the timeline to implement is way too far out. Alonzo goes live in 3-4 months and this challenge is for solutions that will go live in the next 6 months.

This project will bring additional options to expand Defi into the Cardano ecosystem and will be impactful for those looking to leverage Defi options.  Scalability and future plans are questionable since the funding of the project will begin with donations as well as private fundraising outside of Catalyst.

While a DEX sure is a useful thing, this proposal is not the most professional of proposals in this category. It mentions a lot of blockchain-y keywords, while a proper explanation about functions and implementation is not provided. Some of the promised functions seem unrealistic.

The principle of having people use the blockchain without even being aware of it is key to driving adoption of Cardano to an ever increasing percentage of the general population. Password managers are certainly an application that more and more of us use on a daily basis, taking advantage of blockchain infrastructure to improve the technology and potentially expose the strengths of decentralisation and Cardano in the process is bound to have a large impact.

There are no clear milestones or KPI's defined so it will be difficult to audit the progress and impact of this proposal. Some suggestions on metric to use as KPI could be , the increase in website visits compared to IdeaScale, number of new users contributing to the development of cardanocataly.st, bounty rewards awarded.

Should the goal on number of submissions (15) not be a little more aggressive? More details on who will be targeted by the marketing campaign would be useful. For instance how are you targeting people who are likely to be proposers?

while the team is talented with an array of languages, none of them are block chain and there is a concern whether they will be able to deliver. In addition, there is no discussion on how to provide provable authority for the original issuance of the degree on chain, revocation, privacy, and administration. this could be achieved with the use of Digital ID. The problem is one of the better defined ones on Catalyst, however the solution is lacking.

The proposal starts strong but mixes use-cases and it is unclear how the integration will actually look like. The mentioning of arbitration in the future further confuses the reader who actually knows what arbitration is and how decisions are rendered.
Nonetheless, the proposal has potential to drive adoption if the standard makes sense to people who would build the actual DApps on top of this standard.

This proposal id's a current problem. The exponential growth in number of proposals adds a strain on CA's, most of them which are also new to the system. The proposal would benefit of some real figures e.g. current proposals per registered CA, number of flagged assessment in previous rounds.
Well written and updated guidelines already solve this problem but having video complements would certainly help and likely prove a better medium for some people, and have a positive impact on the progress of Catalyst.

The proposar has published a fully functional product with the same concept. The proposal is for improving the feature including security audit and encryption support. Therefore with the proven track record it is highly likely that the proposal will be implemented successfully.

The problem statement does not present a problem but a solution, I recommend changing the statement to facilitate the understanding of the proposal.

The proposal proposes the creation of a DEX in the AMM model, which is within the scope of the challenge. The defined goals indicate delivery of the mainnet public release within the period of 6 months, therefore within the expected for the challenge.

This proposal identifies a problem that it can address and does address the challenge question "how do we seed and grow Cardano in Africa?" However, the bootcamp outline is vague in nature and the details of implementation are lacking. It is a great idea, there simply isn't a clear plan laid out that makes me assess at a 3, 4, or 5 level. Generally, I would consider this concept scalable, but again no details to prove if it is.
This proposal is a asking for a lot of money without providing any information on the number of students it would educate, or where those students would be from, how they would be chosen etc.

There are no details on how many people will participate in the proposal and details on the qualifications and experiences related to the technical requirements to develop the blockchain integration.

There are details on the budget allocation. Relevant KPIs have been described. There is a well-defined timeline, but the deliverables described in the timeline are not clear indicators of development. When will a functional version of the dApp be delivered?

I recommend including more information to measure the success of the proposal.

the allocation of the 16.5K in funding for the first round is not detailed, but clear and realistic goals are laid out for this phase.  While not particularly easy to audit, we can expect a website explaining the nature of the project. I expect the most relevant and auditable data will be presented in future catalysts rounds where we will hopefully see a detailed technical roadmap resulting from the research done in this phase.

While the idea and solution have merit so some extent I don't feel I have enough information to rate this proposal higher at this stage. legal aspects and security aspects will require further thought. What will happen with the Ethiopian Birr collected? I could not easily see this in the proposal.

This dApp is a very good idea and a very good use case for blockchain, and can potentially bring a lot of good advertisement to Cardano itself. The benefits, as well as challenges an everything in between is mapped. Also, it is one of the best written proposals I've seen so far. Well structured, clear, video, audio, slides, short and long versions, and all the information is there. This could be used as a model in a future 'proposer course'. Flawless!

As said in previous comment, the problem is well defined and it is a direct application of blockchain. The different aspects of the project are well documented, targeted market, opportunities, marketing strategy. Risks have been listed and mitigated. It makes me feel it is a very well thought out project. The two proposers have skills in project management and computer science. One of them is following the Plutus pioneer program which shows a determination for developing skills on Cardano. A partnership with an identified charity for the initial launch would have made me give the 5 stars.

The difference in this part of the proposal is that it is made by an African, and we intend, with this challenge, to increase the number of sites involved in Catalyst projects. According to what has been said, the author is a teacher, administrator and SPO operator. In other words, he has experience with the activity intended here, an experience that can be viewed better through the link that was attached. It is a site that speaks the newest SPO in question, has a means of contact and so on. Despite this, a more definite notion about the other team members could have been included in the proposal as well, because I believe that the SPO is not fully taught by the author, individually. It would then be interesting to know who the other people involved are, their areas of expertise and so on.

The proposal does an excellent job of listing 9 individuals involved and their relevant experience. Also, the proposer answers 5 guiding questions with enough clarity to demonstrate they are committed to discovering a viable model through research. It is a positive sign that over 320 people have joined the proposers NFT-DOA Discord group and they are contributing already to this vision. The GitHub repositories are active (https://github.com/NFT-DAO). All of these factors give me confidence that some level of plan will be formulated from the research phase and this would be a good investment of Catalyst funds ($8,200).

The description of the problem and solution is objective and clear. The proposal is within the scope of the challenge. The use of human readable addressess facilitates the integration of users and developers and allows developers to substitute Cardano addresses without rewriting / publishing their code. The established goals indicate the potential for positive impact. I recommend including KPIs so that the potential for impact is more measurable and objective.

There are details on the qualification and experience of the members who will participate in the proposal and the information described indicates the aptitude to implement the proposal successfully.

There is a very well structured and detailed plan. Although there is information that the resources will be used for contract development, marketing and operational estimates for a six-month launch cycle, there are no details on the allocation of resources, which makes it difficult to assess the feasibility of using the resources. I recommend that the allocation of resources be detailed.

The proposer identified their experience but without any details. The existing Cardano transaction fees may make popularity traction more difficult based on the proposals design. The proposal identified that it could not be played until another proposal is built.

The proposal is very interesting and summarized, because it intends to take various contents from the Catalyst community to various people in Africa, through the generation of translations in languages ​​spoken by the natives of the continent (with at least 1 million people who speak the language). In this way, an idea can benefit both Africa and our community, as it will reach potential new members, and in addition, these people may generate wealth for both themselves and the community. In other words, the project will bring potential returns in the future, not being limited to a single action.

A project with a structure this big is bound to become a very broad and large task. 
It was unclear to me where these langbassadors would come from. What pool are you recruiting from and how are you planning to reach them? 
I'd like to add that the proposed project is massive and might be more feasible to achieve if executed in smaller steps. As the African continent holds a large number of different languages, consider focussing on a few major languages (e.g. French) to start with instead of going after all of them simultaneously. Then apply and expand that structure to other languages. That would ensure an early income and create a more robust system. 
In the attached documents, the proposer includes an incubator program. I am unsure how this fits in a news agency and it seems like this could serve as a second side project after the first one has successfully launched. 
Finally there is the requested budget which could be set much lower if the project starts out on a smaller scale to then scale up.

According to the self-description the team should be able to design a small indiegame and they have already started the process, which is a nice advantage and indication of dedication. Since no proper credentials of the team or the games they claim to have produced are provided however, only three stars. This rating will change if the requested information is provided in the comments.
Seems like a simple game. What is the hook to get people to play it? How will it be marketed? What platforms will it be played on?

Having a different funding model that supports smaller chunks of work could help developers e.g. developers you want to create an MVP as prof of concept for a Catalyst proposal, or smaller pieces of work that need to be done as part of funded proposals. To fit the challenge (Developer Ecosystem) this mini-proposals would need to be "restricted" to development works, like solving small technical problems or contributing with code writing. The mini-proposals examples provided in the proposal do not fir this category so the proposal would benefit from specifying what classifies as mini-proposal within the context of this challenge

There are a lot of proposals on Catalyst that lacks the necessary team behind the proposal.  Microtasks can be the solution to those proposals and also encourage co-creation and collaboration. Completing microtasks will take less time, thus quicker funding and increasing developer adoption.

With the community hubs being set up around the African continent and other parts of the world, it is difficult to give this challenge setting a priority. LCCs that will be funded in Fund4 will give us a good understanding of their effectiveness and progress.
